PREFACE
         This code of the City of Ponca City, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 6359, passed May 27, 2025. Ordinances
of the City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code
to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code
has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio

publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE 6247
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND DESIGNATING THE CITY CODE OF PONCA CITY, 2017 (THE
"2017 CODE"); PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN PRIOR ORDINANCES; PROVIDING
THAT CERTAIN PRIOR ORDINANCES SHALL REMAIN IN FORCE; ACCEPTING THE PUBLISHER'S
AFFIDAVIT; DIRECTING THE CITY CLERK TO TAKE CERTAIN ACTIONS; PROVIDING A
SUMMARY OF CONTENTS OF THE 2017 CODE AS REQUIRED BY 11 O.S. 2001, §§14-108(C)
AND 14-107(A); PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE.
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF PONCA CITY,
OKLAHOMA:
Section 1.   A doption and designation.
The ordinances and codes of a general and continuing character affecting the
public at-large of the City of Ponca City ("City"), having been compiled and
codified by the authority of the Ponca City Board of Commissioners pursuant to
the terms of a certain agreement entered into by and between the City and
Sterling Codifiers, Inc. of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho ("Sterling Codifiers"), are
hereby approved, adopted and ordained to be the code of ordinances of the City
upon the subjects therein set out and said ordinances shall be in full force
and effect from and after the date hereinafter specified. The code of
ordinances, consisting of Titles 1 - 12, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and
enacted as the "City Code of Ponca City, 2017," (the "2017 Code"), which Code
shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the City adopted on or
before September 1, 2017, through Ordinance No. 5977 to the extent provided in
Section 3 hereof.
Section 2.   Title 1 chapter 1 section 1 of the Ponca City Code shall be
amended to read
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the Board of Commissioners, this city code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Ponca
City. This city code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the CITY CODE OF
PONCA CITY (2017), and is hereby published by authority of the board of
commissioners of the city of Ponca City, Oklahoma, and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-4 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this city code by title in any legal documents.
Section 3.   Repeal of prior ordinances.
All prior codified City ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on
or before September 1, 2017, and not included in the 2017 Code or recognized
and continued in force by reference therein and except as are preserved by
Section 4, are hereby repealed; and, in addition, all prior un-codified City
ordinances or parts of ordinances of a general and permanent nature and enacted
prior to September 1, 2017, that conflict with the provisions of the 2017 Code
are hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict.
Section 4.   Exclusions to repeal of prior ordinances.
That the repeal provided for in Section 3 hereof shall not affect any of the
following:
   (a)   Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture
incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective
date of such Code.
   (b)   Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of
money for the City, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City or any
evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by
the City.
   (c)   Administrative ordinances or resolutions of the Commission not in
conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of such Code.
   (d)   Any right or franchise granted by any ordinances of the City.
   (e)   Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating,
opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the
City.
   (f)   Any appropriation ordinances.
   (g)   Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes.
   (h)   The zoning ordinance or any amendment thereto.
   (i)   Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the City.
   (j)   Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes
therefor.
   (k)   Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the
City.
   (l)   Any ordinance extending or contracting the boundaries of the City.
   (m)   Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification, or compensation
of any City officers or employees, not inconsistent herewith.
   (n)   Any ordinance declaring certain property to be a public nuisance and
authorizing procedures for the demolition of same.
   (o)   Any ordinance or resolution prescribing specific parking restrictions,
no parking zones, specific speed zones, parking meter zones, and specific stop
or yield intersections, or other specific traffic regulations.
   (p)   Any ordinance setting or establishing fees for licenses, permits,
utility services or any other services issued or performed by the City.
Section 5.   Repealer to not revive certain ordinances.
The repeal provided for in Section 3 hereof shall not be construed to revive
any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance
which is repealed by this ordinance.
Section 6.   Acceptance of the publisher's affidavit, City Clerk's certificate,
and entry of certain findings in official minutes of the Board of
Commissioners.
The City Clerk has certified to the Board of Commissioners that he has received
a publisher's affidavit from Sterling Codifiers, Inc., which is attached as
Exhibit "B" and incorporated and made a part hereof, and it is the finding of
the Board of Commissioners that the copies of the City Code of Ponca City,
2017, received from Sterling Codifiers, Inc., are true and correct copies of
the manuscript for said Code as authorized and said finding shall be entered in
the official minutes of the Board of Commissioners. The City Clerk's
certification is attached hereto as Exhibit "C."
Section 7.   Directions to City Clerk.
The City Clerk, upon publication of the 2017 Code by Sterling Codifiers, Inc.,
is hereby directed to take all actions necessary to comply with the provisions
of the Ponca City Charter and Article XIV of Title 11 of the Oklahoma Statutes
concerning the codification of the ordinances of the City.
Section 8.   Summary of contents of 2017 Code.
As required by 11 O.S. 2011, § 14-108(C) and 14-107(A), the contents of the
2017 Code are hereby summarized as follows: [See Exhibit A, "Summary of
Contents of 2017 Code," attached to this Ordinance as adopted by the Ponca City
Board of Commissioners and on file in the Office of the Ponca City Clerk].
Section 9.   Effective date.
The provisions of Sections 1 through 7, inclusive, of this Ordinance shall take
effect on the 1st day of November 2017.
ORDAINED and PASSED by the Board of Commissioners of Ponca City, Oklahoma this
9th day of October, 2017.
SIGNED by the Mayor of the City of Ponca City on the 9th day of October, 2017.

CHARTER 1
 
Notes
  Editor's note:  The Charter of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma, was prepared
  and proposed by a board of freeholders composed of two members from each of
1 the five wards, chosen at the election held on the first day of April 1919,
  under and pursuant to the provisions of Article XVIII of the constitution of
  the State of Oklahoma.
ARTICLE I. INCORPORATION AND TERRITORY
Section 1. Incorporation.
All inhabitants of the City of Ponca City, Kay County, Oklahoma as the
boundaries and limits of the City are herein established, or may hereafter be
established, shall be a body politic and incorporated under and to be known by
the name and style of "The City of Ponca City," with such powers, rights,
privileges, duties and immunities as are herein and by the Constitution and
laws of the State of Oklahoma specifically or impliedly provided, fixed, given,
granted and invested, and such other and further powers, rights, privileges,
duties and immunities as are incident to and necessarily accompany those
specifically provided, fixed, given, granted and invested.
Section 2. Boundaries.
All limits to and boundaries of the City of Ponca City are hereby established
co-extensive with and coincident to the limits and boundaries as they exist at
the time of the adoption of the Charter.
Section 3. Additions.
Any territory adjoining the present or future boundaries of the City of Ponca
City may from time to time, in any shape or size desired, be admitted to and
become a part of said City as by law now or hereafter provided, or on
application made or written consent given to the City by the owner or owners of
the said land, or on the application made or written consent given by a
majority of the legal voters residing upon the land proposed to be admitted. In
all such cases the territory so added shall be described by metes and bounds in
the ordinance admitting, assenting to the admission or of accepting the land
proposed to be admitted; and thereupon the inhabitants of the territory so
admitted shall acquire and thereafter, equally with the inhabitants of the
original municipal territory, hold all of the powers, rights, privileges,
duties and immunities specifically or impliedly provided, fixed, given,
granted, and invested by the Constitution and laws of the State of Oklahoma and
by this Charter and all ordinances of the City of Ponca City.
Section 4. Platting.
Should any property lying within the City limits as established by this
Charter, hereafter be platted into lots and blocks, such platting shall so
conform to the adjoining platted land that the streets, alleys, avenues and
public ways shall coincide, and the proposed plat before the same is filed for
record, shall be submitted to and approved by the City Engineer. The City shall
never be required to pay any sum for any street, alley, avenue or public way,
but when any such plat is filed all of the streets, alleys, avenues and public
ways shown thereon shall immediately become the property of the City for use as
public highways, and may be cared for and used as such.
ARTICLE II. POWERS OF THE CITY
Section 5. General powers.
The City of Ponca City shall have perpetual succession; may use a common seal;
may sue and be sued; may implead and be impleaded in all courts and places; may
contract and be contracted with; may take, hold, use, acquire and receive
property, real and personal, for the use, benefit and in trust for the
inhabitants thereof and when such property or any of it is no longer useful or
beneficial, may sell the same and convey the title thereto, may perform and
render all public services; may condemn and acquire by condemnation, property
for public use when the same shall be necessary for such; provided, that in
each and every instance adequate compensation shall be made to the person or
persons whose property is so taken or injured, and provided further, that the
manner and procedure of such condemnation, taking and compensation shall be
according to that specified by the laws of the State of Oklahoma for such at
the time thereof.
Section 6. General welfare.
The City of Ponca City shall have power to enact and enforce all ordinances for
the protection of the life, health and property of the inhabitants; to prevent
and summarily abate and remove nuisances, both public and private; to provide
and preserve and enforce good government; and to do and provide for the doing
of all things which may be proper and necessary for the promotion of the
general welfare of the inhabitants.
Section 7. Reservation of powers.
The enumeration of general and particular powers herein shall never be held or
construed to be a circumscription of or limitation upon any powers whenever or
wherever elsewhere provided, fixed, given, granted, invested or implied, it
being the intention by the proposition and adoption of the Charter to reserve
and confer upon the inhabitants of the City of Ponca City the entire right,
full powers and unrestricted privileges of self-government; such right, power
and privilege, however, to be held and exercised conformably with and not
violative of the Constitution and laws of the State of Oklahoma.
Section 8. Additional powers.
The City of Ponca City shall have power to make all proper regulations
concerning keepers of inns, hotels, taverns, rooming houses and other public
places, draymen, horse drivers, jitney drivers, hack drivers, automobile
drivers, omnibus drivers, and to fix maximum rates for the transportation of
goods and persons within the City to prevent extortion, to preserve order, and
to avoid confusion.
Section 9. Gambling.
To suppress gambling houses, games of chance and lotteries, and to punish
persons found guilty of gambling, selling pools, and conducting or having to do
with lotteries.
Section 10. Bread and milk.
To provide for the regulation of and to regulate bakeries and to prescribe and
fix the weight, quantity and price of bread sold within the City; to provide
for the inspection of and to inspect any and all milk sold or offered for sale
within the City and to fix a maximum retail price therefor; to condemn, destroy
and prohibit the sale of any and all bread or milk found unfit for human
consumption; and to fix and collect the fees for such regulation and
inspection.
Section 11. Animals and fowl at large.
To restrain, regulate and prohibit the running at large of horses, mules,
cattle, sheep, swine, goats, and other animals, and chickens, geese, ducks,
turkeys, pigeons, and other fowl and authorize and provide for the impounding
and restraining of the same, and to order their sale, or destruction when they
cannot be sold, and to provide for the imposition and infliction of penalties
upon the owners thereof for the violation of any ordinances imposing such
restraint, regulation or prohibition.
Section 12. Dogs.
To provide for the taxation of and to tax dogs and to regulate, restrain and
prohibit their running at large, and to impose penalties upon the owners
thereof for the violation of any ordinance imposing such taxation, regulation,
restraint, or prohibition.
Section 13. Firecrackers and roller skates.
To regulate, restrain and prohibit the rolling of hoops, flying of kites,
firing firecrackers and pyrotechnics and the use of velocipedes, roller skates,
bicycles, slingshots and any and every other thing the use of which tends to
annoy persons or frighten horses.
Section 14. Whistles and other noises.
To regulate, restrain and prohibit the ringing of bells, blowing of horns,
bugles and whistles, and the crying of sales, ballyhooing of shows, and any and
all other noises or disturbances which tend to annoy persons or cause them to
congregate upon the streets.
Section 15. Mendicants.
To restrain and prohibit mendicants, beggars and other persons of infirm and
maimed bodies or suffering from diseases of any kind, from soliciting alms,
help or assistance within the City, and to prescribe a penalty for the
violation of any ordinance imposing such restraint or prohibition.
Section 16. (Disapproved by the Governor.)
Section 17. Driving animals through streets.
To regulate and prohibit the driving of cattle, horses, mules and other animals
through the streets, alleys, avenues and public ways within the City.
Section 18. Profanity and disturbance of the peace.
To prevent all trespasses and breaches of the peace, assaults, batteries,
fighting, quarreling, profanity, boisterousness, insults, and other disorderly
conduct, and to punish all persons thus offending.
Section 19. Abandoned right of way.
To require all steam or street railway companies owning or having control of
tracks within the City, which tracks may be abandoned, to remove such tracks at
their own expense and to repair and restore at their own expense the street or
way upon which such abandoned track or tracks are located, so that the part so
occupied by the said company shall be in the same condition as the other part
of said street or way.
Section 20. Horse racing.
To suppress, prevent and prohibit horse racing and dangerous riding or driving
within the City.
Section 21. Cruelty to animals.
To prevent and prohibit the cruel treatment of animals and provide punishment
for and punish those guilty of such cruelty.
Section 22. Hitching horses.
To compel persons to fasten their horses or other animals within the City,
whether such animals are attached to vehicles, standing in the streets, or
otherwise.
Section 23. Undesirables.
To restrain and punish vagrants, vagabonds, vice-venders, pimps, prostitutes
and panderers.
Section 24. Drugs.
To regulate, prohibit and control the keeping, sale and use of cocaine, opium,
morphine, and other drugs, and the salts, compounds and derivatives thereof,
and prescriptions therefor.
Section 25. Disease and danger.
To authorize or direct the destruction of clothing, bedding, furniture, places,
things and buildings infected with the germs of any communicable disease, and
authorize or direct the destruction of any building, part thereof, or other
object, after the same shall have become a nuisance and dangerous to the health
or safety or lives of the inhabitants of the City.
Section 26. Quarantine.
To make and enforce regulations to prevent the introduction of communicable
diseases into the City and to make and enforce provisions for quarantine within
the City and at any place or places without the City and within five miles of
the limits thereof.
Section 27. Theaters and dance halls.
To permit, forbid and regulate theaters, dance halls and dances therein and
other places of amusement.
Section 28. Dram shops.
To prohibit dram shops, saloons, and other places where intoxicating liquors
are sold, to declare such places nuisances and to abate them.
Section 29. Bawdy houses.
To prohibit and abolish bawdy houses and to punish the keepers and inmates
thereof; to prevent and suppress the keepers of houses of assignation and
common resort, and punish the keepers and frequenters thereof; and to declare
any building or place used as a bawdy house, house of assignation or place of
common resort, a nuisance and, upon proof that the owner thereof knew that the
same was being used as such house or place, to confiscate the same.
Section 30. (Disapproved by the Governor.)
Section 31. Prize fights.
To prohibit and prevent prize fights, cockfights and dogfights; to regulate
boxing matches and sparring exhibitions and to provide for and inflict
punishment upon any and all persons guilty of violating such prohibition and
regulation.
Section 32. Firearms.
To regulate and prohibit the carrying of firearms and other weapons and to
provide and inflict punishment therefor as is now or may be hereafter provided
by the laws of the State of Oklahoma for a violation of such regulation or
prohibition.
Section 33. Vagabonds and recalcitrants.
To provide workhouses and work places for City convicts who are unable or who
refuse to pay any fine or costs assessed against them or who have been
sentenced to imprisonment in the City prison; and provide for the working of
and to work such convicts upon the streets, alleys, public ways and public
grounds.
Section 34. Prison.
To provide and maintain a prison for the incarceration and retention of persons
arrested and waiting trial, and persons who have been convicted of offenses,
and to make and enforce any and all regulations concerning the care and keeping
of such persons, and the said prison.
Section 35. Nuisance.
To define what shall be determined nuisances within the City and within one
mile outside of the City limits; to abate such nuisances either summarily or by
process; and to provide punishment for and inflict punishment upon the makers
or keepers thereof.
Section 36. Vehicles.
To regulate the use of automobiles, motor cars, motorcycles and other power-
driven vehicles, the speed and lighting thereof, the licensing of the same, and
permits to persons for the driving and use thereof, and to prohibit the use of
power-driven vehicles except by the holders of such permits; subject however to
the right of the state exclusively to tax same.
Section 37. Steam boilers.
To control the location and regulate the use of steam boilers and steam
engines, prescribe the qualifications of persons as keepers or engineers
thereof, to issue permits therefor to persons found to have such
qualifications, and to provide and enforce such rules and regulations for the
keeping, running and use of boilers and engines as shall be deemed proper for
the protection of life, health and safety of persons and the safeguarding of
property.
Section 38. Construction.
To inspect buildings in course of construction and the condition of all
buildings already constructed, prescribe and enforce regulations relative
thereto, and fix and collect fees for such inspection.
Section 39. Poles.
To regulate the length, height and strength of all telephone, telegraph,
electric light and other poles, to prohibit the location, and enforce the
removal thereof.
Section 40. Reformatory.
To provide for the establishment of and to establish, maintain and regulate a
house or place of correction and reformation for youthful criminals and
delinquents.
Section 41. (Disapproved by the Governor.)
Section 42. Wires.
To regulate the location and prohibit the placing of telephone, telegraph,
electricity-conducting, and other wires, and to require at any time that such
wires be removed, changed or that they be placed underground.
Section 43. Keeping animals.
To provide for the regulation of and to regulate and prohibit the keeping of
cows, swine, goats, sheep, dogs, and all other animals, and chickens, geese,
ducks, turkeys, pigeons, and all other fowl, within the City limits or any
specified parts thereof.
Section 44. Vitalizing provision.
To enact such substantive and remedial ordinances, adopt such resolutions,
establish such rules, and provide such measures as shall be necessary for or
convenient in giving execution and effect to the Charter and to each and every
part, portion and provision thereof.
ARTICLE III. OFFICERS
Section 45. Qualifications.
Every person elected to, or named to fill an unexpired term of an elective
office of the City of Ponca City must be a qualified elector of the City of
Ponca City at the time he is inducted into office. Every appointed officer must
be a qualified elector, or become a qualified elector of the City of Ponca City
at the time of his induction into office or as soon thereafter as is permitted
under the laws of the State of Oklahoma to so become such elector. Every such
elective or appointive officer must, before entering upon the discharge of his
duties, take the official oath prescribed by the constitution of the state of
Oklahoma and such additional oath or oaths as the board of commissioners may
from time to time prescribe. Should any such officer cease to be or fail to
qualify as an elector of the city of Ponca City, as aforesaid, or to possess
any other qualifications elsewhere prescribed or required of him, such fact
shall operate as a vacation of his office, and he shall not thereafter perform
any of the duties incident thereto, except that should any such officer move
from one precinct to another precinct within the city of Ponca City this fact
shall not disqualify said officer. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 46. Officer Defined.
The term "officer" shall apply only to those in elective offices and to the
following appointive offices: city manager, city treasurer, city clerk, city
judge (or his substitute), city attorney, chief of police, chief of fire
department, superintendent of water and light department, and such of their
assistants or other heads of departments and their assistants as the board of
commissioners may, from time to time, by proper ordinance, cause to be so
classified. The term "officer" as herein used, shall not include policemen,
other than the chief, and shall not include employees or agents other than
those above provided. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 47. Official Bonds.
Each and every officer and employee, before he enter(s) upon the discharge of
the duties of his office, shall make a good and sufficient bond, condition[ed]
upon the faithful and efficient performance of his official duties, such bond
to run in favor of the city of Ponca City and to be approved by the board of
commissioners. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 48. Graft.
No officer, employee, agent or servant of the city of Ponca City shall ever
take, accept or receive, either directly or indirectly any fee, money,
emolument, gift, compensation, reward, gratuity, or anything of value or
otherwise, except the official salary, for or because of the performance or
non-performance of any of the duties of his office or any action or failure to
act in regard or incident thereto. Any officer, employee, agent or servant who
shall violate either the letter or spirit of this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction therefor shall be fined in a sum of not less
than one hundred or more than one thousand dollars, and imprisoned in the
county jail for a period of not less than thirty days or more than one year,
and the fact of such violation shall operate as a vacation of his office and he
shall not thereafter perform any of the duties incident thereto. (Approved 3-
17-1920)
Section 49. Board Of Commissioners.
All powers conferred on or reserved to the city of Ponca City and/or the
inhabitants thereof shall, unless otherwise provided in the charter, be
exercised by five commissioners, to be known as and designated by the term
"board of commissioners", each and all of whom shall be elected by the
qualified electors of the city of Ponca City at large and one of whom shall be
known as mayor, as provided herein. The mayor and other members of the board of
commissioners shall be conservators of the peace and shall at all times and
places and under all circumstances and in every event, protect, defend and
maintain each and all of the rights, privileges and immunities of the city and
inhabitants thereof. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 50. Board Created.
There is hereby created a board of commissioners to consist of five electors of
the city, one of them shall be elected as mayor, all shall hold office for a
term of three years or until their successors are elected and qualified, except
that the commissioners and mayor serving at the time this section becomes
effective shall serve their unexpired terms. The terms of office of all
commissioners will expire as follows: The mayor on March 1, 2007; commission
positions 1 and 3 on March 1, 2005; and commission positions 2 and 4 on March
1, 2006. On the second Tuesday in February of 2007, and each three years
thereafter there shall be elected a mayor; and on the second Tuesday in
February, 2005, and each three years thereafter there shall be elected
commissioners to positions 1 and 3; and on the second Tuesday in February,
2006, and each three years thereafter, there shall be elected commissioners to
positions 2 and 4. The mayor and all commissioners shall qualify and assume the
duties of their respective offices on March 1 after their election, or within a
reasonable time in the event a run-off election is necessary. In any year when
a presidential preferential primary is held in February, then the elections
above referenced shall be held on the same day as the presidential preferential
primary. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 51. Powers Of Board And Division Of Duties.
All the powers of the city except such as are by law vested in the board of
education and except as otherwise provided by charter or by the constitution of
the state, are hereby vested in the board of commissioners; and, except as
otherwise prescribed by the charter or by the constitution of the state, the
board of commissioners may by ordinance or resolution, prescribe the manner in
which any power of the city shall be exercised. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 52. Mayor.
The mayor shall cause the enforcement of all laws and ordinances of the city
and the resolutions and orders of the board of commissioners; and he shall
perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the board of commissioners
not inconsistent herewith. He shall preside at all meetings of the board of
commissioners when present, and shall sign all ordinances, contracts and other
instruments on behalf of the city and shall have the power to administer oaths.
All legal papers provided by the laws of the state to be served on the mayor of
a municipality shall be served on the mayor, or upon the acting mayor if the
latter is functioning under the provisions of section 60, or, if neither the
mayor nor the acting mayor is available within the city for service, upon some
other commissioner present and available. The proof of service upon one other
than the mayor shall state the grounds which made such service appropriate and
necessary. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 53. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 54. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 55. Mayor, Additional Duties.
The mayor shall perform the following duties and have the following powers: He
shall preside at all meetings of the board of commissioners when present, sign
all contracts and other instruments requiring the assent of the city, and have
power to administer oaths. All legal papers now provided by the laws of the
state to be served on the mayor of a municipality shall be served on the mayor,
and in his absence on the acting mayor, and in the absence of both, on another
commissioner. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 56. Assumption Of Duties, Time Required Of Commissioners.
Each commissioner shall devote so much of his/her time as may be necessary for
the efficient transaction of the business and affairs of the city as provided
by the charter. Whenever any person elected to the office of mayor or
councilman neglects, refuses, or fails to qualify within ten days of the
beginning of the term for which (s)he has been chosen, or whenever the mayor or
a councilman neglects, refuses, or fails, except in case of sickness, to attend
the meetings of the council for seven consecutive regular meetings without
first having the consent of the council, which consent must be entered upon its
records, or removes from the city, is convicted of or pleads "no contest" to a
felony or becomes mentally incompetent as defined by statute, the council shall
declare that a vacancy exists in such office and shall proceed to call an
election to fill such vacancy at which election a person shall be elected to
serve out any unexpired term in such office. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved
at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 57. Employees To Make Reports.
The board of commissioners of the city of Ponca City may request a report in
writing at any time from any officer or employee of the city, whereupon such
officer or employee shall forthwith make such report. (as amended January 14,
1974)
Section 58. (as amended January 14, 1974)
Section 59. Bonds Of Commissioners.
The mayor and each other member of the board of commissioners shall, before he
enters upon the discharge of the duties of his office, execute in favor of the
city of Ponca City a good and sufficient bond in the sum of five thousand
dollars conditioned upon the faithful performance of all the duties of his
office, such bonds to be approved by the county judge of Kay County, Oklahoma,
and thereafter filed with the city clerk of the city; and any elector may bring
an action at any time in the proper court for the purpose of exacting or
enforcing the penalty of such bond; provided that should such action fail from
any cause the elector so bringing the same shall immediately pay to the officer
giving such bond all of the expenses incurred by such officer in defending such
action; and provided further, that with the petition filed in said action there
shall be tendered to and filed with the court clerk of Kay County and subject
to his approval a bond in the sum of five hundred dollars the condition of
which shall be the payment when due of the restitution money above provided to
be paid. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 60. Vice Mayor.
At such time as the mayor or commissioners elected in the spring elections
assume their positions, the board of commissioners shall elect by majority
ballot one of their number as vice mayor, and the commissioner so elected shall
be invested with all of the powers and be charged with performance of all of
the duties of the mayor at all times, places and events whenever the mayor from
any cause or by any reason is unable to act. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved
at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 61. Vacancy In Office Of Mayor Or Commissioner.
Should a vacancy occur in the office of mayor or any of the commissioners, the
board of commissioners shall immediately call an election for filling the
vacant position. Provided, that should such vacancy occur within ninety days of
the next general election, no election to fill the vacancy shall be held but
the position shall be filled by the results of the general election. (Res.
5441, 12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 62. Powers Of Board Of Commissioners.
The board of commissioners shall have control and supervision over all
departments of the city except as herein otherwise provided, and to that end
shall have power to make and enforce such rules and regulations as they may see
fit and proper for and concerning the organization, management and operation of
all the departments of the city and whatever agencies may be created for the
administration of its affairs. Except as otherwise provided in this charter,
they shall have power to create such offices as they deem necessary for a
prudent and successful administration of the affairs of the city, and to fix,
allow, and pay salaries of the persons appointed thereto, and may delegate the
administrative and executive duties, rights and functions to one person who
shall be known as city manager, provided that the term of any office so created
by them shall never exceed the period of one year, and they shall have power to
abolish at any time any such office and terminate the official duties and
relations of the person occupying the same. The mayor shall propose and submit
to the board of commissioners nominations for all offices created by said
board, and such nominations shall be subject to confirmation by a majority vote
of the board. In the event any such nomination by the mayor shall fail of
confirmation by the board, nominations for such positions may be made by any
member of the board of commissioners, subject to confirmation by the board. In
the event no nomination is confirmed, the board, by majority action shall make
a temporary appointment of an officer pro tempore to discharge the duties of
said positions until a nominee of the mayor or commission member is confirmed.
(as amended January 14, 1974; July 9, 1991)
Section 63. Meetings Of Board Of Commissioners.
The board of commissioners shall meet in regular session at the city hall, or
such other place as shall have been designated by ordinance, at least once
every two weeks, to give consideration to and take action upon all business
which may lawfully come before them. A majority of said board shall constitute
a quorum for the transaction of such business, but no action of said board
shall be effective unless upon the affirmative vote of a majority of such board
and no ordinance shall be passed or become effective until the same shall have
regularly received the affirmative votes of at least three members of the board
cast in open session. Special meetings may be called at any time by the mayor
or by any four members of the board, to consider such matters only as shall be
specified in the call for said special meeting, but no special meeting shall be
held until after twenty four hours' notice thereof in writing shall have been
given to or waived in writing by at least four members of the board. (as
amended January 14, 1974)
Section 64. Report Of Mayor.
The mayor shall from time to time make such recommendations as he shall deem to
be for the welfare of the city, and on the first Monday in June of each year or
so soon thereafter as practicable, submit to the board a record of the receipts
of the city for the year then last past and an estimate of the needs and
expenses of the city for the year next ensuing.
The head of each department of the city government shall make a written report
to the mayor not later than the last day of April in each year, showing the
operations of such department for the preceding year. These reports shall be a
part of the mayor's report to the board of commissioners. The mayor shall also
make such recommendations to the board of commissioners concerning the increase
or decrease of departmental estimates as in his judgment may best serve the
interests of the city. He shall also submit an estimate for a special
contingent fund for the current year. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 65. Appropriations.
The board of commissioners shall on the second Monday in June, or as soon
thereafter as practicable, appropriate such sums of money, respectively, for
each of the various departments of the city government as they deem necessary
for the maintenance and operation thereof during the ensuing year. In addition
to the department appropriations herein provided for, the board shall also make
appropriation for contingent purposes as may be deemed necessary. The
appropriation herein provided for shall be based upon estimates submitted by
the mayor in his report, provided the same shall have been submitted to the
board as herein required.
In making up the allowance for any year the board of commissioners shall first
make provision for the payment of the interest and for the creation, setting
aside and preservation of a sinking fund upon all of the outstanding
indebtedness of the city and shall then make appropriations as the remaining
revenues of the city may justify, to be appropriated among the respective
departments or appropriated for such other public uses as the board of
commissioners may deem proper; provided however, that in no case shall the
entire appropriations so made, including interest and sinking fund on the
bonding debt, and appropriations for all other public uses and purposes, ever
exceed the estimated available resources for the fiscal year, which estimate
shall be based upon the probable revenue of the city derived from ad valorem
taxes upon the basis of the total valuation of property for taxation for the
preceding year, and of such other contingent revenue of the city as shall
probably accrue. It shall be deemed malfeasance for the board of commissioners
to make any appropriations the sum total of which shall exceed the estimated
available or probable revenues for any fiscal year.
Unless otherwise provided by the charter and by ordinance passed hereunder, all
property in the city liable to taxation shall be assessed in accordance with
the provisions of general laws of the state so far as the same apply.
The board of commissioners shall have the management and control of the
finances of the city except as otherwise herein provided. They shall have the
power to appropriate money for the payment of debts and expenses; to provide by
ordinance special funds for special purposes under the provisions of the
charter and to make the same disbursable only for such purposes; to provide by
resolution for the payment of any existing and outstanding indebtedness as
appropriated and for the payment of any bonds that may from time to time be
issued, and shall for such purposes have the power to levy, assess and provide
for the collection of special taxes.
The board of commissioners shall have the power to fund or refund by ordinance
the whole or any part of the existing debts of the city, or any further debt,
by acquiring and cancelling the evidence thereof and to issue other bonds in
lieu thereof, either registered or coupon, bearing interest at a rate not
greater than the original indebtedness, and to this end may apply the sinking
fund belonging to any series of bonds so refunded, and may pay and retire any
bond by using the sinking fund thereof. (as amended April 6, 1993)
Section 66. (Disapproved by the governor.)
Section 67. Rules Of The Board - Judge Of Qualifications.
The board of commissioners shall provide such rules and regulations for its
government and order of business as the members may deem proper. Except for
issues of election and voter irregularities and recount of votes for elections
conducted by the county election board and for which jurisdiction to review
shall reside with the district court and the election board, the board shall be
the judge of the qualifications and election of its members, including the
mayor, and shall have authority to correct the results which may have been
theretofore announced, if there be a contest of the right to any office voted
upon at the next preceding election and written notice of such contest has been
given it by an opposing candidate within ten days after such election shall
have been held. The mayor, municipal judges or the city clerk shall have
authority to administer all oaths proper in the conduct of the municipal
affairs and government of the city. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved at
referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 68. Vacancies In Office.
Should a vacancy occur in any office, place or position, except in the office
of mayor, the same shall be filled as provided in section 62 of the charter.
The person appointed to fill any vacancy as provided in this section shall
perform the duties of said office during the unexpired term thereof. (as
amended January 14, 1974)
Section 69. Offices Of City Manager, City Attorney, City Clerk And City
Treasurer.
The offices of city manager, city attorney, city clerk and city treasurer are
hereby created. The city manager, city attorney, city clerk, city treasurer and
such other offices as shall from time to time be created by the board shall be
appointed the first meeting in September annually according to the procedure
provided in section 62 of the charter of the city of Ponca City, such officers
to serve for a term of one year and until their successors are appointed and
qualified. (Ord. 4927, § 1, 1-30-1978, approved at referendum 4-4-1978)
Section 70. City Attorney, Duties.
The city attorney shall represent and care for the interests of the city in all
litigation and controversies to which the city may be a party; approve or
reject as to form all proposed ordinances before they shall be adopted; draft
all proposed ordinances granting franchises; inspect and report his opinion
upon all papers, instruments, documents and contracts in which the city may be
interested; give legal advice and assistance to any and every officer of the
city, when called upon so to do, with respect to any legal question involving
any official duty or other matter of interest or moment to the city; and
perform any and all other duties which may from time to time be assigned to him
by the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall have authority
to appoint and remunerate such assistants to the city attorney as may be deemed
necessary. If it shall be brought to the attention of the city attorney that
any person, firm or corporation exercising a franchise or privilege from the
city has been guilty of any violation of the terms or conditions thereof, or
has failed to comply in any material respect with the provisions thereof, it
shall be his duty to make a complete report of the matter to the board of
commissioners. If the board shall determine that such report is well founded it
shall become the immediate duty of the city attorney to take such action as may
be necessary and proper with respect thereto, and if there shall have been a
flagrant violation of the terms or conditions of the franchise or privilege,
the city attorney shall institute a suit in the proper court for the purpose of
obtaining a judgment of forfeiture of the said franchise or privilege.
Section 71. City Clerk, duties.
The City Clerk shall have the custody of all the ordinances, books and records
of the City. It shall be his duty to examine in detail all bills, accounts and
claims against the City, and endorse upon each his approval thereof; he shall
be the chief accountant of the City and keep or supervise the keeping of all
its books, accounts and transactions; he shall keep a detailed record of all
receipts and disbursements of money, and at least once in each month shall
examine the books of account of all the officers of the City charged with the
receipt or disbursement of money and report to the Board of Commissioners the
nature of his findings and conclusions. He shall ascertain and report to the
Board of Commissioners whether any expenditure made or proposed to be made by
the City is excessive either in price of the thing purchased or proposed to be
purchased, the computation of the charge therefor, or the regularity of the
appropriation for its purchase. He shall make a monthly report to the Board of
his official conduct.
Before the City Clerk shall enter upon the discharge of the duties of his
office he shall give a good and sufficient bond in the sum of Two Thousand Five
Hundred Dollars conditioned upon the faithful discharge of all the duties of
his office, such bond to be made in favor of the City. The Board of
Commissioners shall have power to require of the City Clerk at any time during
his term of office a bond in excess of the amount herein provided, should the
interests and proper protection of the monies of the City and the trust funds
coming into his hands justify the same in the discretion of said Board. The
City Clerk shall act as clerk to the Board of Commissioners, shall be present
at all their meetings, and do and perform all of the duties in relation thereto
as may be prescribed by the Board.
Section 72. City Treasurer, duties.
The City Treasurer shall receive, care for, safely keep and properly pay out of
all funds of the City, except such trust funds as may be by law confided to the
other officers of the City. He shall make and file with the Board of
Commissioners a monthly account and report setting forth all the transactions
of his office. Before he enter(s) upon the discharge of the duties of his
office he shall give a good and sufficient bond in favor of the City in the sum
of not less than Five Thousand Dollars and in such greater sum or sums as the
Board of Commissioners may from time to time require, conditioned upon the
faithful discharge and performance of all the duties of his office.
Section 73. Municipal Court and Judge.
A Municipal Court is hereby established for the City of Ponca City and there is
hereby created the office of Municipal Judge.
The Board of Commissioners shall appoint a Municipal Judge at the same time and
for the same term as provided in the Charter for City Clerk, City Attorney and
City Treasurer, who shall have exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine all
complaints of offenses against the ordinances of the City and who shall keep a
docket in which he shall enter every cause commenced before him. In all cases
prosecuted in the Municipal Court, all procedure(s), including appeals, shall
be the same as that provided by the laws of the State of Oklahoma for trials in
and appeals from municipal courts.
In all offenses charged before the Municipal Court the accused shall be
entitled to release on an appearance bond until trial, in such an amount as may
be fixed and subject to the approval by the Municipal Judge, and all
forfeitures of bonds, including appeal and appearance bonds shall be enforced
by appropriate actions to be instituted by the City Attorney. All monies
collected in such proceedings shall be paid into the City Treasury.
In all actions in the Municipal Court there shall be taxed as costs against the
accused, and collected from him as in the cases of fines, such sum or sums upon
pleas of guilty or upon convictions after trial as may now or may hereafter be
provided by ordinances, and all sums collected shall be paid into the City
Treasury.
The Board of Commissioners is hereby vested with power to remit fines and to
grant pardons in all cases arising out of conviction in the Municipal Court.
Section 74. Police.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to establish and maintain a City
Police Department, including a Chief of Police, and to appoint such policemen
as it shall deem necessary.
Section 75. Qualifications of policemen.
No person shall be eligible to appointment, or be appointed or serve as a
policeman or officer of police to the City of Ponca City who shall have been
convicted of any offense, the punishment for which may be confinement in the
State Penitentiary; nor shall any person be appointed who is not shown to be of
good character, or who cannot read and write the English language, or who does
not possess ordinary physical strength and courage. All policemen and firemen
of the City of Ponca City shall hold their position during good behavior and
shall not be removed from the same except for such cause as renders them unfit
to remain in the service of the City, and after written notice, giving the
grounds for such discharge or removal and an opportunity to be heard on such
charges or reasons.
Section 76. Salaries of officers.
The Board of Commissioners shall fix the salaries of all other officers and
employees, agents and servants of the City. The salaries of the Chief of
Police, other policemen and officers of police, and of the Municipal Judge
shall be their sole and only compensation and the compensation of such officers
shall never be contingent upon arrests made, or upon the number thereof, or
upon convictions had. The compensation of all officers of the City shall be
definitely fixed at the beginning of their terms, and such compensation shall
not be increased or diminished during such term. The members of the Board of
Commissioners shall serve without compensation or pay, and they shall not have
power to provide any pay or compensation for themselves.
Section 77. Mayor chief executive officer.
The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the City, with all the
rights, powers and duties appertaining therein. He shall be entitled to vote
upon all questions, ordinances, rules, regulations and matters that may be
submitted to or acted upon by said Board. (as amended January 14, 1974)
ARTICLE IV. FRANCHISES
Section 78. Franchises required for use of public highway for certain purpose.
No street, alley or public highway in the City of Ponca City shall ever be used
by any person, firm or corporation for the construction or operation of a
street railway, telegraph line, telephone system or any other business of a
public or quasi-public nature, without obtaining authority therefor under a
franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of the Charter. It shall be
the duty of the Board of Commissioners and the City Attorney to bring suit
against any person, firm or corporation violating the terms hereof for the
purpose of ejecting the offender from the occupancy of such property, and to
recover damages for the illegal use thereof.
Section 79. Control and use of streets inalienable, exceptions.
The ownership, right of control and use of the streets, highways, alleys,
parks, public places and all other real property of the City are hereby
declared to be inalienable to said City except by a franchise or easement
therefor, granted as hereinafter provided; and no franchise or easement
involving the right to use the same, either along, across, over or under, shall
ever be valid, unless expressly granted and exercised in compliance with the
terms hereof and of the act granting the same. No act of omission of the City,
its Board of Commissioners, officers or agents shall be construed to confer or
extend by estoppel or indirection any right, franchise or easement not
expressly granted.
Section 80. Franchises may be conferred.
The City shall have power, subject to the terms and provisions hereof, to
confer upon any person or corporation the franchise or right to use the
property of the City, as defined in the preceding section, for the purpose of
furnishing to the public any general public service, including light, power,
telephone or telegraph service, refrigeration, steam, or the carriage of
passengers or freight within the City, or for any other purpose whereby a
general service is to be furnished to the public for compensation or hire to be
paid to the franchise holder, whereby a right to in part appropriate the
streets, highways or other property of the City, is necessary or proper;
provided that no franchise shall be granted by said City to any person, firm or
corporation to own, control or operate waterworks or electric light and power
plants therein while the City shall own and operate such plants of its own.
Section 81. Exclusive franchises prohibited.
No exclusive franchise or privilege shall ever be granted nor a franchise nor a
privilege to commence at any time after six months subsequent to the passage of
the ordinance granting the same, and no franchise shall be directly or
indirectly extended beyond the term originally fixed by the ordinance granting
the same; nor shall any franchise be granted to any person or persons or
corporation authorizing such persons, firm or corporation, their associates,
assigns or successors to acquire the physical property, rights or franchises of
another person or corporation to whom or to which a franchise has already been
granted by the City whereby the rights and properties held and used under such
franchise are assigned to another person, firm or corporation which holds a
franchise extending beyond the time of the expiration of the franchise of the
person, firm or corporation selling such physical properties, rights or
franchises.
Section 82. People Shall Authorize Franchises.
The city shall have the power to grant any franchise or right granted in the
preceding section, provided, that the city shall not grant, extend, or renew
any franchise except with the approval of a majority of the qualified voters as
provided in section 83, and no franchise shall be granted, extended or renewed
for a longer period than twenty-five years. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 83. Franchise Petition And Election.
Whenever a petition signed by a number of qualified voters of the city, equal
to twenty-five per centum of the total number of votes cast at the next
preceding general municipal election, demanding that a franchise be granted,
extended or renewed, shall be filed with the city clerk, the board of
commissioners shall call a special election thereon as soon as possible
consistent with the provisions of this charter for holding special elections,
at which the question shall be submitted of whether or not such franchise shall
be granted, extended or renewed. If at such election the majority of the voters
voting thereon shall vote for the granting, extending or renewing of such
franchise the same shall be granted by the board of commissioners at their next
succeeding regular meeting. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-
2005)
Section 84. Percentage Of Receipts To Be Paid To City.
All persons or corporations to whom or to which franchises may hereafter be
granted, or their assigns and successors, shall as compensation for the right
or privilege enjoyed pay to the city a percentage of the gross receipts of the
business pursued by the holders of the franchise, as approved by the City
Commission. The amount of said bonus or compensation shall be fixed by
ordinance granting the franchise and shall be payable on the second day of
January of each year, for the preceding year. Said bonus or compensation shall
be exclusive of and in addition to all lawful ad valorem taxes upon the value
of the franchise or other property of the holder thereof, and lawful occupation
taxes imposed upon the occupation or calling of the holder of such franchise.
The board of commissioners may, however, in their discretion in the ordinance
granting any franchise, provide that no bonus shall be paid for the first five
years thereof. (Approved 3-17-1920, as amended by special election held 7-10-
2007)
Section 85. Board To Have Access To Books Of Franchise Holder.
In order to ascertain the true amount of such gross receipts and to determine
the amount of such bonus or compensation and for any other purpose relating to
the business or affairs of the city the board of commissioners shall have power
to examine or cause to be examined the books, papers, and records of franchise
holders, to take testimony and compel the attendance of witnesses under oath
and under such rules and regulations as said board of commissioners may adopt,
and should any franchise holder refuse inspection of its books, papers or
records or the production of the same when lawfully required so to do by the
board, or should any officer, agent or employee of said franchise holder refuse
to give testimony before said board, the board of commissioners shall have
power by ordinance to declare the franchise or privilege enjoyed by such
corporation or person so in default annulled and terminated. (Approved 3-17-
1920)
Section 86. People May Waive Bonus.
If the franchise, the granting of which is demanded by the petition filed as
provided in section 83 of the charter, contains a provision that no bonus shall
be paid by the franchise holder to the city for the privilege thereof, or a
provision fixing the amount of the bonus to be paid, such provision in the
franchise if the franchise be granted shall supersede section 83 of the
charter, and no bonus or the amount of bonus fixed in the franchise, as the
case may be, shall be paid to the city thereunder. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 87. (Disapproved by the governor.)
Section 88. Right To Purchase Franchise Properties.
No franchise shall hereafter be granted except upon condition that the city
shall have the right at any time after fifteen years from the granting thereof,
to purchase the physical properties of the franchise holder and to terminate
its franchise and all privileges enjoyed by it thereunder; provided, the
majority of the qualified voters of the city voting thereon shall vote to do
so. Upon the petition of twenty-five per centum of the qualified voters to the
board of commissioners the matter of the acquisition of such property shall be
submitted at an election to be determined by a vote of a majority of the
qualified voters voting thereon; which election shall be held at the next
succeeding election in the city taking into consideration the requirements of
this charter for the calling and holding of special elections; and provided,
that the owner of such physical property shall be compensated for the value
thereof, considering solely the physical assets, such value to be determined by
the report of the majority of three arbitrators, one to be selected by the
board of commissioners, one by the owner of the physical property to be valued
and the third by the arbitrators so selected. But if the owner of such physical
property shall refuse for thirty days to select an arbitrator, then the value
of such property shall be fixed by the board of commissioners. (Res. 5441, 12-
28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 89. (Disapproved by the governor.)
Section 90. Steam railways.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to authorize steam railways
operating their lines through and from the City of Ponca City to other towns
and cities to lay their tracks and establish their switches on and over the
streets and other property to the City or such parts thereof as the Board of
Commissioners may see fit, subject to the terms of the Charter and to such
conditions as may be imposed by the Board of Commissioners.
ARTICLE V. ORDINANCES
Section 91. Subjects.
The Board of Commissioners are hereby vested with the power and charged with
the duty of adopting all laws, ordinances and resolutions upon every subject,
object and matter within the authority of the government instituted by the
Charter.
Section 92. Mayor to approve or veto.
Every ordinance, law or resolution of the Board of Commissioners shall, before
it takes effect, be presented to the Mayor for his approval and signature or
disapproval. If he approves it he shall sign it; if he disapproves it he shall
specify in writing his objection thereto and within three days return the same
to the Board of Commissioners or to the City Clerk, with such disapproval. If
he does not return it within three days it shall be in force and effect
according to its terms, as if he had approved it.
Section 93. Veto.
A veto by the Mayor shall suspend the action of the Board of Commissioners for
three days, after which time the Board may by majority vote pass any
resolution, law or ordinance over the veto of the Mayor but in all such cases
the Mayor shall not be deprived of his right to vote as a member of the Board
of Commissioners. In case the Mayor's veto shall be sustained the matter shall
not again come before the Board of Commissioners within three months. In
ordinances or resolutions making appropriations the Mayor may veto any or every
item therein, but such veto shall not extend to any item or items not vetoed,
and those which he disapproves shall not become effective unless and until
passed over his veto in the manner above specified.
Section 94. Enrolling and publishing.
Every ordinance which becomes a law of the City shall be enrolled by the City
Clerk or such other officer or person as may be selected by the Board of
Commissioners, within the next succeeding five days, Sunday excepted, or as
soon thereafter as practicable. It shall then be compared carefully with the
ordinance and all amendments thereto, if any, by the City Attorney and at least
one member of the Board of Commissioners. When no errors exist, the officers
comparing shall endorse on the margin "Correctly enrolled," and give the date
thereof and subscribe their names thereto. Every ordinance shall be published
in a newspaper of general circulation and printed and published in the City,
and the affidavit of the printer or publisher, or any other competent proof,
that such publication was made shall be presumptive evidence in all courts and
places of the legal publication and promulgation of such ordinance; provided
that amendments and corrections made in digesting and revising ordinances for
publication in book form need not be so published. All ordinances shall become
effective upon their publication.
A compilation of all ordinances of the City when printed and published in book
form bearing on the title page thereof the recital "Published by the Board of
Commissioners of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma", shall be prima facie
evidence of their authenticity and shall be admitted and received as such in
all courts and places without further proof.
Section 95. Style.
The style of all ordinances shall be "Be It Ordained by the Board of
Commissioners of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma", but such ordination clause
may be omitted when the ordinances are published in book form or are revised
and digested under the order of the Board.
The style of all ordinances, resolutions and measures initiated shall be "Be It
Ordained by the People of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma".
Section 96. Printing.
The Board of Commissioners shall have the power to cause the ordinances of the
City to be printed in code form and to have the same rearranged and digested as
often as to the Board may seem proper.
Section 97. Present ordinances.
All ordinances, resolutions, rules, measures and regulations now in force in
the City of Ponca City, and not in conflict herewith, shall remain in force
under the Charter until altered, amended or repealed.
Section 98. Recording.
All ordinances and resolutions upon their final passage shall be authenticated
by the presiding officer of the Board and the City Clerk, and thereafter
recorded in books kept for that purpose.
Section 99. Initiative and referendum.
All the rights, power(s), privilege(s) and authority with reference to
ordinances, resolutions, and legislation, given by the Charter to the Board of
Commissioners are subject and subordinate to the rights, powers, privileges and
authority of the people secured by and reserved to them in the initiative and
referendum provisions now or hereafter in force in the Constitution and
statutes of the State of Oklahoma.
ARTICLE VI. IMPROVEMENTS
Section 100. Street includes avenue.
The word "Street", as used in this Article includes "Avenue" within its
meaning.
Section 101. Street improvement, made how.
When the Board of Commissioners shall deem it necessary to grade, pave,
macadamize, gutter, curb, drain or otherwise improve any street, alley, public
place, park or ground, or any part thereof, within the limits of the City, for
which a special tax is to be levied, as herein provided, said Board shall by
resolution declare such work or improvement necessary to be done, which
resolution shall be adopted by a majority vote of the Board, and except as
hereinafter provided the passage of such resolution shall be conclusive of the
public necessity therefor and the benefit thereof, and no notice of such action
by the Board shall be requisite to its validity. Such resolution shall in
general terms set forth the nature and extent of the improvement or
improvements to be made, the section or sections of any public street, alley,
place, park or ground to be improved, the material or materials with which the
improvements are to be constructed and the method or methods under which the
cost of such improvements is to be paid. Such resolution may specify that such
improvement may, at the election of the Board, be constructed from different
material and may specify different or alternative methods of making such
improvements and providing for the payment of the costs thereof. Upon the
passage of such resolution it shall be the duty of the City Engineer forthwith
to prepare specifications for such improvements, which specifications shall
embrace the different materials or alternative plans or methods under which
such improvements or parts thereof are to be constructed, if such different
material or alternative methods or plans of construction or payment are
specified, and the character of bond or bonds required of the successful bidder
for the construction of such improvements and the maintenance thereof, as
herein provided. When such specifications have been prepared they shall be
submitted to the Board of Commissioners for its approval. The Board shall have
power to require of the contractor or contractors to whom the work may be let,
a bond for the faithful performance of the contract and the maintenance of the
work in good condition, for a term not less than five years from the completion
and acceptance thereof, and for the maintenance thereof by the contractor. The
bonds required by the Board to be executed by the contractor shall be executed
by such contractor to whom the work may be let together with one corporate
surety acceptable to said Board, which shall be a surety company authorized to
do business in the State of Oklahoma.
It is provided, however, that when any such resolution shall provide for the
improvement of any street or part thereof by paving or macadamizing, the owners
of more than one-half in area of the property liable to assessment for the
payment of the cost of such improvement may protest against the making of the
improvement; provided that no protest may be made against the making of such
improvement when the distance to be improved is not more than three blocks of
whatever size and four intersecting streets and there is at the limits of the
section to be improved paving or macadamizing already constructed or under
contract for construction or for the construction of which jurisdiction has
been secured by the City, on or across the street to be improved. Upon the
passage of a resolution providing for any improvement against the making of
which such property owners may protest, the City Clerk shall notify such owners
by publication of a notice one time in a weekly newspaper or five times in a
daily newspaper published and of general circulation in the City, notifying
them of the passage of the resolution, of the streets or part thereof to be
improved and that they may file their written protest against the making of
such improvement in the office of the City Clerk within ten days after the last
publication of such notice. The Board of Commissioners may by ordinance
establish and enforce such rules relating to the signing and filing of
protests, as may be by it deemed proper. Any number of streets or parts thereof
may be included in one resolution, but such protest shall be made separately as
to each street or part thereof. The filing of a valid and sufficient protest,
within the proper time, signed by the owners of more than one-half in area of
the property subject to assessment for payment of the cost and expense of such
improvement, shall deprive the Board of Commissioners of power under such
resolution to make such improvement. If no sufficient protest be filed, the
Board of Commissioners shall by resolution declare such fact and shall proceed
thereafter as in cases where no notice is required. The finding of the Board as
to the sufficiency of any such protest shall be conclusive and binding for all
purposes and against all persons, and it shall have power to have hearings
thereon and compel the attendance of witnesses under oath to determine the
sufficiency thereof.
Whenever a petition, signed by the owners of more than one-half in area of the
property subject to assessment for the payment of the cost of any such
improvement, is filed with the City Clerk paying for the improvement of any
street, alley, public place or ground as herein provided, it shall be the duty
of the Board of Commissioners to cause the improvement to be contracted for and
constructed as herein provided in the case of improvement authorized by
resolution.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to cause sidewalks, curbs and
gutters to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired under and by virtue of the
terms of this Section and Article and of the various subdivisions thereof,
either separately or together with other improvements; provided, that the cost
of construction, reconstruction or repairing sidewalks shall be borne entirely
by the owners of the property abutting upon said sidewalks; and provided
further, that the right of the Board to order the construction, reconstruction
or repairing of such sidewalks, curbs and gutters shall be exclusive of and in
addition to the powers in the Charter conferred upon the Board of Commissioners
otherwise to order such improvements.
Section 102. Power to change grade.
The Board of Commissioners is hereby empowered to establish and change the
grade of all streets, alleys or other public places in the City or part or
section thereof, whenever in their judgment the public convenience may require
such change of grade; provided that no material change of the permanent,
established grade shall be made without due compensation to the owners of
abutting property, having permanent improvements erected therein with reference
to the previous legally established grade, and the Board of Commissioners shall
prescribe by ordinance the method of ascertaining the compensation due to any
such property owner whose property is affected by such material change of
street grade, and the City shall pay to such owner such compensation so
ascertained.
Section 103. Payment for improvements.
The cost and expense, including the contract price, of grading, paving,
macadamizing, curbing, guttering, draining and otherwise improving any street,
alley, public place, park or ground, or part thereof, shall be paid by the
owners of the property abutting upon the property, street, alley or other
public place or portion thereof ordered to be improved; provided that when any
railroad or street railroad or railroad switch of any kind lies on and across
any such street, alley or other public ground ordered to be improved, the
owners of such railroad and railroad switches shall pay the entire cost of so
improving the entire right of way of such owners across such street, alley or
other public ground and in any event they shall pay the cost and expense of
such improvement between the rails and for two feet on each outside thereof;
and when any such railroad or switch lies in and parallel with any street,
alley or other public ground the owners thereof shall pay the entire cost of
making such improvement between all rails, tracks and series of tracks and for
two feet outside of the outside rails of the track and series of tracks. The
pro rata cost of such improvement payable under the terms hereof by any
railroad or street railroad or the owner thereof, together with all costs of
collecting the same shall be a special tax against and secured by a lien upon
the roadbed, ties, rails, fixtures, rights and franchises of such railroad or
street railroad and the owners thereof, and wherever a contract shall be let
for any such improvement, the Board of Commissioners shall levy a special tax
upon the roadbed, ties, rails, fixtures, rights and franchises of such railroad
or street railroad for the pro rata share due from such road, for the
improvement as above provided for, and the City and abutting property owners
shall be relieved of the part of the costs to be paid by such road. Said tax
shall be levied at or after the time such contract is let or executed and shall
become due and delinquent as the ordinance levying the same may specify, and
shall be a lien from the time of levying, and the proceeds thereof shall be
used for the payment on the costs of such improvement. If said taxes be not
paid as provided by ordinance, then collection shall be enforced, after
certification of the assessments to the County Clerk, as the collection of
other assessments and taxes under the laws of the State of Oklahoma. The lien
provided for shall be a first and prior lien paramount to all encumbrances,
except taxes, upon the roadbed, ties, rails, fixtures, rights and franchises of
the person, firm or corporation owning the railroad or street railroad
aforesaid. When any street, alley or other public way or ground is ordered
paved, graded, curbed or guttered, drained or otherwise improved as herein
provided, any person having right of way or operating a railroad intersecting
or crossing such street, alley, public way or ground so ordered improved, shall
bear the entire expense of grading, paving, curbing and guttering and laying
sidewalks over and across their tracks and right of way for the full width of
such right of way.
Section 104. Contract for improvements.
When specifications have been adopted by the Board for contemplated
improvements, provided for by the Charter, it shall be the duty of the City
Clerk or such other officer as shall be designated by the Board of
Commissioners to at once advertise for sealed bids for the construction of such
improvements, in accordance with the specifications adopted therefor. Such
advertisement shall be inserted in a daily paper of general circulation in the
City of Ponca City and shall state the time within which bids may be received
as prescribed by the Board, which shall be not less than ten days nor more than
fifteen days from the insertion of said advertisement. Bids shall be filed with
the City Clerk or such other officer as the Board of Commissioners shall
designate and shall be opened and read in public meeting of the Board of
Commissioners. The Board shall have the right to accept such bids as it shall
deem most advantageous to the City and the owners of the property abutting on
the public street or alley named to be improved, or may reject any and all
bids; and where the improvement is ordered on different specifications, and for
the construction of work or part thereof with different materials, and under
different plans or methods of construction, or payment for such improvements,
the Board shall have full power after opening bids to select such methods,
plans and materials for making such improvements or any part thereof, as it may
deem best and let the work to such bidder and upon such bid as it may select
subject to the terms hereof. No bid shall be amended, revised or changed after
being filed. All bids shall be accompanied by a certified check for five per
cent of the amount of such bid as a forfeit, in case of failure of the bidder
or bidders, if successful in securing the work bid, to enter into a contract
and bond as required by the Charter, for the performance of such work. When
bids for such improvements have been accepted by the Board the City shall enter
into a contract with the contractor or contractors, to whom the work has been
let for the performance thereof, which contract shall be executed in the name
of the City by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk or such other officer
as may be designated by the Board, with the corporate seal. The contractor or
contractors to whom such work has been let, shall execute such bond or bonds as
may be requested by the Board and as herein provided. Said bond or bonds to be
approved by the Board if satisfactory.
It is provided, however, that when the City has acquired jurisdiction to make
any improvement in this Article provided for, and all the required proceedings
up to but not including the advertising for bids have been perfected and
completed the Board of Commissioners may, if in their judgment the same be
advantageous to the City and the property owners affected, let a contract for
the construction of such improvements without advertising for bids. Such
contract may be let to any contractor at such a price as the Board of
Commissioners in their discretion may deem proper, but not exceeding the last
contract price for a like improvement; but no such contract shall be let in
this manner except within three months next succeeding the date of the next
preceding contract let for a like improvement nor shall such contract be let
except when the methods or plans of construction and the manner of payment for
the next preceding improvement are identical with the methods or plans of
construction and the manner of payment for the next preceding improvement of
like character. Further proceedings in such cases shall be taken as provided in
cases where contracts are let upon advertisement for bids.
Section 105. Assessment of cost.
After excluding the cost of making any improvements between and two feet on
each side of the track and rails of railroad or street railroads, and the
entire cost of any improvements crossing the right-of-way of any railroad,
which costs are to be assessed against and wholly paid by the owners of such
railroads, as herein provided, and subject to the terms hereof, the City of
