Ponca City acting by its Board of Commissioners shall have power to assess the
whole costs of construction, reconstruction and repairing any sidewalks,
curbing, guttering and paving any street or alley or making any other
improvements ordered under the terms hereof, against the property abutting upon
the street, alley, public ground or part or section thereof upon which such
improvements are to be constructed, and shall have the power to fix a lien
against such property and in apportioning the costs of such improvement against
abutting property owners, each quarter block shall be charged with its due
proportion of paving, both the front and side streets on such block, and the
alley or alleys therein, together with the area formed by street intersection
and alley crossing which cost shall be apportioned among the lots or
subdivisions of such quarter blocks, according to the benefit to be assessed to
each lot or parcel. If any portion of the abutting property shall not be
platted into lots or blocks, the Board of Commissioners shall include such
ground in proper quarter block districts for the purpose of appraisement and
assessment as herein provided. Provided, that in no event shall such costs be
assessed against such owners or their property, or liability therefor finally
determined, until after hearing herein provided for and after the adjustment of
equities between such owners; provided further, that the costs assessed against
any property shall be in proportion as the front of the property of each owner
is to the whole frontage of property in such quarter block so ordered to be
improved. Provided, that if the application of this rate would, in the opinion
of the Board, in particular cases, be unjust or unequal, it shall be the duty
of the Board to assess and apportion said costs in such proportion as it may
deem just and equitable, having in view the special benefits in enhanced value
to be received by each owner of such property, and the equities of such owners
and the adjustment of such apportionment, so as to produce a substantial
equality of benefits received by, and burdens imposed upon each owner. The
Board shall also have power to provide that the proportion of the said costs
which may be assessed against the said owners and their property shall bear
interest at a definite rate not to exceed thirteen per cent per annum, when the
payment thereof is deferred, and shall have the power to include in any
assessment which may be made against such owners and their property reasonable
costs of collection, where such costs are incurred, and a reasonable attorney's
fee where attorney's fees are incurred. (Res. 3909, §2, 6-1-1982, approved at
referendum 7-13-1982)
Section 106. Hearing on assessment.
The contract or contracts for such improvements and the bond or bonds having
been executed and approved by the Board, it shall be the duty of the City
Engineer to at once prepare a written statement describing the property, by
block or lot number, or otherwise, abutting upon the section or sections of the
street, public ground, or alleys named to be improved, so describing the
property as to identify the same; and such statement shall also contain an
estimate of the total costs of such improvement and the proportion and amount
of such costs to be assessed against abutting property. Such statement shall be
submitted to the Board which will examine the same and correct any errors which
may appear therein; but no error, omission or mistake in such statement shall
in any manner invalidate any assessment made or liens or claims fixed
thereunder. When such statement has been examined and approved by the Board and
it has determined to assess the costs of such improvements against such
property, it shall so declare by resolution, directing notices thereof to be
given unto the owners by publication for five consecutive dates in a daily
newspaper published and of general circulation in the City of Ponca City, and
also to mail to such owners a copy of such notice by registered letter
deposited in the post office in the City of Ponca City directed to the address
of such owner, if known, or if such address be not known then to the agent or
attorney of such person, if known, provided that the registered letter
aforesaid shall be deposited in such post office in the City of Ponca City
within ten days prior to the date set for the hearing hereinafter provided for,
and provided further, that the method herein prescribed for service of notice
by registered letter shall be merely cumulative of the service of notice by
publication above mentioned; and provided, that in all cases where personal
service by registered letter shall not be obtained said service by publication
shall nevertheless be deemed valid and binding. The certificate of the City
Clerk or such other officer as shall be designated by the Board to the effect
that the address of such owner or owners or their agent or attorney is unknown
to him, and personal service cannot be had upon them, shall be deemed
conclusive of such fact. The notice aforesaid shall state the time of the
hearing hereinafter provided for, the general character of the improvements
determined upon by the Board, the street or part thereof to be improved and the
proportionate part and amount per front foot of the total cost of the proposed
improvement, which it is contemplated shall be assessed against the property
abutting upon the street, alley or public ground to be improved. On the date
stated in the notice aforesaid or any time thereafter before any special
assessment is actually levied, any person, firm or corporation interested in
any property which is claimed to be subject to assessment for the purpose of
paying the cost of any improvement, in whole or in part, shall be entitled to a
full and fair hearing before said Board as to all matters affecting such
property, or the benefit thereto of such improvements or any claim of liability
or objection to the making of such improvements or any claim of invalidity or
irregularity in any of the proceedings in reference to making such improvements
or any other objection thereto. Such person, firm or corporation shall file
their objection in writing and thereafter the Board of Commissioners shall hear
and determine the same, and full opportunity shall be given to the persons,
firms or corporations filing such objections to produce evidence, subpoena
witnesses and to appear in person or by attorney and a full and fair hearing
thereof shall be given by the said Board which hearing may be adjourned from
time to time, without further notice and the Board of Commissioners shall have
full power to inquire into and determine the facts necessary to the
adjudication of objections and the ascertainment of special benefits to such
owners by means of such improvements, and shall make such order in each case as
may be just and proper. Any objections to the regularity of proceedings with
reference to the making of such improvements as herein provided or to the
validity of any assessment against such property or the owners thereof, shall
be deemed waived, unless presented at the time and in the manner herein
specified. The time as set for such hearing shall be not less than ten days
from the time of the first publication of such notice. When the hearing above
mentioned has been concluded the Board shall by ordinance assess the property
abutting upon the public street or alley or part thereof ordered to be
improved, such proportionate part of the costs of said improvement as by such
Board may have been adjudged against such property. Said ordinance shall fix a
lien upon such property for the respective amounts to be assessed and shall
state the time and manner of payment of said assessment.
Section 107. Pipes in streets.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to enact all ordinances and to
establish all rules and regulations that may be necessary to require owners of
all property subject to assessment to pay the cost of such improvement, to
cause to be put in and constructed all water, gas, or sewer pipe connections to
connect with any existing water, gas or sewer pipe in and underneath the
streets, alleys and other public places, or ground or part thereof where such
improvements are to be made, and all costs and expense for making such
connections not paid for by property owners shall be taxed against such
property, and shall be included in and made a part of the general assessment to
cover the cost of such improvement. They shall have power to establish all
rules and regulations necessary to cause all existing water, gas and other
mains to be lowered to conform to the improvement grade in the street to be
improved and to provide a lien against the same for the cost of such lowering
if not performed by the owners thereof.
Section 108. One side of street may be improved.
Subject to the provisions hereof the Board may, when deemed just and proper,
order improvements to be made on only one side of the public street or alley or
section or portion thereof, and may assess the cost of, or a portion thereof,
against the property and the owner of property abutting on such side of such
street or alley or section or portion thereof.
Section 109. Errors corrected.
When any error or mistake shall occur in any proceedings, provided for in the
Charter, it shall be the duty of the Board to correct the same, and whenever it
shall have been finally determined in any suit that any assessment against any
property or its owner or lien against such property fixed or attempted to be
fixed under the terms hereof is, for any reason, invalid, unlawful, or not
enforceable, then it shall be the duty of the Board to at once proceed to
reassess against such property such proportion of the cost of making such
improvements as shall be proper, lawful and just and fix a lien against such
property; and such Board shall have power, and it shall be its duty, by
ordinance or resolution, to adopt such rules and regulations, and to make such
orders as shall, in compliance with the law, provide for correcting such
mistakes and making a valid reassessment against such property and fixing a
valid lien thereon; said Board shall have power and it shall be its duty to
adopt such rules and regulations for a hearing to the owners of such property
before such reassessment which may be necessary or proper, in order to legally
bind such owners and their property by such reassessment; and shall have power
to adopt all other rules and regulations which may be requisite to a valid
reassessment of such property. Subject to the provisions of this Charter the
cost of any such improvement or improvements, after deducting the proportion of
such costs as may be assessed against any railroad or street railroad, and the
proportion of said costs which have been finally assessed against property
abutting upon the street or alley or section or portion against property
abutting upon the street or alley or section or portion thereof, ordered to be
improved, shall be borne and paid by the City.
Section 110. Payment of assessments.
When any of the public improvements provided for in this Article are ordered to
be made, the cost or part thereof, which may be assessed against abutting
property and against railroads and street railroads, as herein provided, and
such cost so apportioned and assessed against the abutting property as provided
for by this Charter, and the lien as established and fixed by the Board of
Commissioners in favor of the contractor as herein provided for, such abutting
property shall be held liable for the payment of such costs so assessed against
it, and the City shall not be responsible or liable for any part of such costs
as assessed and taxed against such abutting property and shall not be liable
for any part or portion of the costs of any street improvements, except when
the City through the Board shall have obligated itself to pay a part of such
costs. The time and manner of payment of such assessments, the manner of
payment of the contractor by the issuance of bonds, and all other matters and
things relating to the payment of the contract price of such improvement, the
payment and collection of assessments and installments thereof, and the
certification and collection of delinquent assessments shall be as provided by
the laws of the State of Oklahoma for cities without charters, or the Board of
Commissioners may by general ordinance prescribe other and different methods of
payment, collection and certification of assessments and installments, and may
prescribe other and different methods of issuing bonds for the payment of the
cost thereof or may provide for the issuance of tax certificates or warrants
evidencing the lien on and against the property liable to assessment to be
issued in such manner and form and with such terms and provisions, not
inconsistent with the Charter as may be deemed proper.
Section 111. City may pay part of cost.
The City shall have power to borrow money on its credit, and the Board may by
ordinance authorize the issuance by the City of its negotiable coupon bonds for
the purpose of paying the City's part of any such permanent street improvements
as embraced in the terms of this Article. Such bonds to be within the limit of
indebtedness prescribed by the Constitution and the Charter. Such bonds shall
bear interest at the rate of not more than six per cent per annum, payable in
semi-annual installments, and the principal thereof shall be payable in not
more than twenty years from their date. Such bonds shall be authorized and
executed in accordance with the terms of the Charter with reference to the
issuance of other bonds; provided, that no such bonds shall be issued unless
the question of such issue shall first be submitted to a vote of the qualified
tax payers, and the same shall be approved at such election in accordance with
the provisions of the Constitution and of the Charter, and the Board of
Commissioners shall provide in any resolution or ordinance authorizing such
bond issue for the levying of an annual tax sufficient to meet the accrued
interest and provide a sinking fund for the payment and retirement of such
bonds, and the bonds provided for in this Article shall be sold by the City for
not less than par. Such bonds shall not be sold by the City until registered
and approved in accordance with the requirements for other bond issues by the
City.
Section 112. General provisions.
All contracts heretofore entered into by the City of Ponca City or which may
hereafter be entered into by the City and before the provisions of the Charter
become effective, and all ordinances made in relation to such contracts, and
all improvements shall be carried forward and completed and paid for in
accordance with such laws and ordinances, and all costs of such improvements
shall be assessed by the Board of Commissioners against the abutting property
owner and other persons, firms or corporations made liable for the payment of
such costs under and in accordance with the provisions of the laws and
ordinances then in force. The Board of Commissioners created and authorized by
the Charter are hereby authorized and directed, and it is hereby made their
duty to do and perform or cause to be done or performed, all things which, by
such existing laws and ordinances of the City, the City Council of the City and
the officers thereof, acting thereunder are now authorized or permitted to do,
in order to carry into effect the terms of such contract and to assess the
costs of improvements against such property, and to provide for the collection
of such assessment and to provide for the issuance of assignable certificates
or bonds therefor, and to do and perform any other act or thing which may be
necessary under the said existing laws and ordinances of said City, to give
effect to said contracts and to provide for the enforcement thereof. The fact
that more than one parcel or lot of land, the property of the owner or jointly
owned by two or more persons, firms or corporations having been assessed
together in one assessment shall not invalidate the same or the lien thereof.
The costs of any such improvements assessed against any property, together with
all costs and reasonable expenses in collecting the same, including reasonable
attorney's fees when incurred shall be secured by a lien upon such property
superior to all other liens, claims or title, except City, county and state
taxes and such lien may be enforced for the nonpayment of taxes by the County
Treasurer as in the case of other taxes and the Board may by resolution or
ordinance make such rules and regulations not inconsistent with the Charter, as
it may deem necessary, to provide for the speedy collection of such assessments
for improvements. Any error or omission in selling property or designating the
names of owners or other errors or omissions may be corrected at any time by
the Board or at the suit of any interested party. In any suit brought under the
provision of this Section it shall be proper to join as defendants two or more
property owners who are interested in any single improvement or any single
contract for such improvement.
Section 113. Limitation of action.
At any time within ten days after the hearing in Section 106 of this Article
provided for has been concluded, any person or persons, corporation or
corporations, having an interest in any real estate which may be subject to
assessment under the Charter, or otherwise having any financial interest in
such improvement or improvements, or in the manner in which the cost thereof is
to be paid, who may desire to contest on any ground the validity of any
proceeding that may have been had with reference to the making of such
improvements, or the validity in whole or part, of any assessment lien fixed by
said proceedings may institute suit for that purpose in any court of competent
jurisdiction. Any person, or persons, corporation or corporations, who shall
fail to institute such suit within a period of ten days, or who shall fail to
diligently prosecute such suit in good faith to final judgment, shall be
forever barred from making any such contest or contests, and this estoppel
shall bind their heirs, successors, administrators and assigns. The City of
Ponca City, or the person or persons to whom the contract has been awarded
shall be made defendant in such suit, and any other proper parties may be
joined therein. There shall be attached to plaintiff's petition an affidavit of
the truth of the matter therein alleged, except such matters as are alleged on
information and belief, and that such suit is brought in good faith and not to
injure or delay the City or contractor or any owner of real estate abutting on
the improvement. Unless the provisions of this Section are complied with by
plaintiff or plaintiffs such suit shall be dismissed on motion of any
defendant, and in that event plaintiff or plaintiffs shall be barred and
estopped to the same extent as if no suit had been brought. In any case where a
suit is brought as provided for in this Section then the performance of the
work may be suspended at the election of either the City or the contractors
until such suit shall be finally determined in the court of original
jurisdiction or any appellate court to which the same may be taken by appeal or
writ of error; provided that any appeal or writ of error shall be perfected
within thirty days from the adjournment of the term of court of original
jurisdiction at which final judgment was rendered in such suit; and provided,
that no appeal or writ of error to review the judgment of such court may
thereafter be taken or sued out by either party.
Section 114. Sidewalks.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power in their discretion by resolution
passed by majority vote to order the construction, reconstruction or repairing
of sidewalks as herein provided along or upon any street, public place, alley
or square, or part or section thereof, within the City or in front of any
property abutting upon the same. No notice of the passage of such resolution
shall be necessary except as herein provided. Such resolution shall in general
terms describe the sidewalk to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired,
material of which it is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, the
street, alley, square or place or section or part of section thereof along
which said sidewalk is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired. Upon the
passage of such resolution it shall be the duty of the City Engineer forthwith
to prepare and present to the Board plans for the said sidewalk or repairs for
the same, detailing the nature of the construction, reconstruction or repair
thereof, and the material or materials of which the same are to be constructed,
reconstructed or repaired. If satisfactory the Board shall approve the said
plans, and the same shall remain on file in the office of the City Engineer.
Upon the approval of the said plans the City Engineer shall at once prepare and
file with the Board a statement containing a brief description of the property
abutting upon the street, avenue, alley, public place or square, or part or
section thereof where sidewalks are ordered constructed, reconstructed or
repaired, which description may be by lot or block numbers or any other
description which shall be sufficient to identify the same, together with an
estimate of the cost of such sidewalk, or repair of same in front of each lot
or tract. Upon the filing of such statement it shall be the duty of the City
Clerk, or such other officer as shall be designated by the Board to publish in
a daily paper of general circulation printed within the City of Ponca City, a
notice to the owner or owners generally of the property along which the
sidewalk or sidewalks are to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, and
stating the street, avenue, alley, public place or square or section, or
sections or parts thereof, along which the same are ordered to be constructed,
reconstructed or repaired, and that the plans and specifications for such work
have been adopted by the Board and are on file in the office of the City
Engineer, and notifying the owners of property abutting upon such proposed
sidewalk or sidewalks, to construct, reconstruct or repair the same in
accordance with such resolution, plans and specifications, within thirty days
after the publication of such notice. The Board shall have power to adopt rules
and regulations providing for the giving of such notice to the owner or owners
of such property in a way or ways other than by the publication thereof as
above prescribed, or may provide for the giving of additional notices, but such
additional notice shall be cumulative to the published notice, and the service
of such notice by publication shall be sufficient without any other, further or
additional notice. The owners of property abutting upon the street, avenue,
alley, place or square, or part, parts or section thereof, along which the
sidewalks are ordered to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired shall within
thirty days from the giving of the notice to them, construct, reconstruct or
repair the said sidewalks in accordance with the said resolution, plans and
specifications, at their own cost and expense, and should they fail to do so,
it shall thereupon be the duty of the Board to provide for and to construct,
reconstruct or repair the same, either by the City purchasing the materials and
employing the labor necessary or by letting the said work by contract under
such rules and conditions as may be adopted or provided by the Board, and with
or without competitive bidding therefor. Whenever the City shall have
constructed, reconstructed or repaired, any sidewalk, or caused the same to be
done by contract, the Board shall assess the whole costs and expenses thereof
against the property abutting upon the street, avenue, public place or square
along or upon which the said sidewalks shall have been so constructed,
reconstructed or repaired. Such assessment shall be apportioned and levied
against each lot or tract separately, and shall constitute a separate liability
against each lot or tract and shall be collected and the payment thereof
enforced as provided in the Charter for the collection of special taxes and
assessments. No assessment for the cost of such sidewalks shall be made against
any property until the Board shall have so declared by resolution, and notice
thereof shall have been given the property owners as provided in the Charter.
If such notice be given by publication thereof, such publication shall be made
in a newspaper of general circulation and printed in the City of Ponca City,
for three consecutive days, and also by mailing a copy thereof to the owner or
owners of the property liable to assessment, by registered letter addressed to
the last known address of such owner or owners or their agent, agents or
attorneys; provided, that such registered letters shall be deposited in the
post office in the City of Ponca City not less than five days prior to the
hearing hereinafter provided to be had, such notice by mail shall be merely
cumulative to the publication notice given, and in all cases, instances and
events the publication of the notice in such newspaper shall be sufficient for
all purposes. The notice aforesaid shall state the time and place of the
hearing hereinafter provided to be had, the general character of the sidewalk
ordered to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, the street, avenue,
alley, public place or square, or parts or sections thereof along which the
said improvement is proposed and that the cost and expense of the said
improvement will be assessed against the property abutting thereon. The time of
the said hearing shall be not less than one week from the date of the first
publication of the said notice. On the date specified in the notices aforesaid,
and at any time before an assessment is actually levied, any person or
corporation owning or interested in any property liable to assessment or sought
to be assessed, may present to the Board or any member thereof, objection in
writing to the proposed assessment being levied, and such assessment shall not
be levied until after the Board shall have held and given a full and fair
hearing upon such objection. At such hearing the person or corporation making
the said objection shall have the right to produce evidence, subpoena
witnesses, and appear in person and by attorney. The said hearing may be
adjourned from time to time without notice, and when the Board shall have been
sufficiently advised in the matter they shall make such order relative thereto
as shall be proper. Any and all objections as to the regularity of the
proceedings or any part thereof with reference to such improvements shall be
deemed waived unless presented at the time and in the manner herein specified.
If the order of the Board made at the conclusion of the hearing shall overrule
the objections filed, the Board shall thereupon by ordinance assess the costs
and expenses of such improvement against each lot or tract of the abutting
property, apportioning to each its proper part thereof. The ordinance levying
such assessment shall create a lien upon the property assessed and shall
specify the time at which the same shall be paid, which time shall not be
longer than sixty days from the date of the passage of the said ordinance. Such
assessment shall bear interest from the date of its levy and until paid, at a
rate not to exceed eight per cent per annum. The lien so created upon and
against such property shall be evidenced by assignable tax certificates or
warrants issued in such manner and form and containing such provisions not
inconsistent with the Charter as the Board shall provide, such certificates or
warrants to be delivered to and received by the contractor, if such work be
done by contract, in full payment for the said work, the City retaining a
sufficient number and amount thereof to reimburse it for the costs and expenses
other than the contract price; or, if the City shall have paid or incurred the
cost and expense of such improvement, such certificates or warrants shall be
issued to and become the property of the City.
Section 115. Repairing and resurfacing.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to cause paving, macadamizing,
curbing and guttering to be repaired or resurfaced under and by virtue of the
terms of the Charter, and such repairing or resurfacing may be done or provided
to be done either separately or together with other improvements; provided that
the passage of the resolution by the Board declaring the said work necessary to
be done shall be conclusive of the public necessity therefor and of the benefit
thereof, and no notice of such action by the Board shall be requisite to its
validity.
Section 116. Railways on improved streets.
Should any railroad or street railway company propose to lay a track or tracks
in or upon any street, avenue or part or portion of any street or avenue which
shall have been improved, it shall become liable for such part or portion of
the cost of such improvement as the Board of Commissioners may direct, or as is
fixed by the Charter.
Section 117. Specifications required for certain contracts.
All contracts for the purpose of making any public improvements or constructing
any public buildings or making repairs to the same shall be made in compliance
with the Oklahoma Public Competitive Bidding Act of 1974 (61 O.S. §101 et seq.,
1974), any amendments thereto or any successor acts. (as amended April 3, 1990)
Section 118. (Disapproved by the Governor.)
ARTICLE VII. RECALL OF ELECTED OFFICERS
Section 119. Elected officers may be recalled.
The holder of any elective office may be removed at any time by the voters of
the City of Ponca City. The procedure to effect such removal shall be as
follows: A petition demanding the election of a successor of the person sought
to be removed, containing a general statement of the grounds for which the
removal is sought and signed by a number of the qualified voters of the City
equal to or greater than thirty-five per centum of the total vote cast for the
office of Mayor on the official ballot at the last preceding general municipal
election, shall be filed with the City Clerk who shall within ten days after
such filing examine and ascertain if the said petition be in due form and
signed by the requisite number of qualified voters and attach to said petition
his certificate showing the result and conclusion of his examination. If by the
City Clerk's certificate the petition is found to be defective as to form it
may be amended or reformed in any particular except as to signatures within ten
days from the date of said certificate. If such petition be amended or reformed
the City Clerk shall within ten days after such amendment or reformation
examine the same as amended or reformed and make his certificate relative
thereto, and if such second certificate shall show the petition to be
insufficient it shall be returned to the person filing the same, and the
proceeding theretofore had shall not be deemed or held prejudicial to the
filing of a new petition or further petitions for the same purpose or relief.
If the second or any subsequent petitions, or if the petition filed in the
first instance be sufficient, the City Clerk shall immediately submit the same
to the Board of Commissioners after his examination and approval thereof. The
action or failure to act on the part of the City Clerk shall be final except
that such may be made the subject of proper judicial inquiry and mandate.
Section 120. Recall Election To Be Called And Held.
Upon the submission of a recall petition to the city clerk, the board of
commissioners shall call a special election thereon and the same shall be
conducted, held and the result thereof declared in all respects as are other
city elections. The candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast at
such election shall be declared elected to such office, and shall, immediately
upon his qualification therefor, enter upon the discharge of the duties
thereof. In the event no one candidate at said election shall receive the
highest number of votes cast, a run off election shall be held consistent with
the calling and holding of municipal elections wherein the two candidates
receiving more votes than any others shall be the only candidates whose names
will appear on the ballot for the run off election. The candidate receiving the
majority of the votes cast at said run off election shall be declared elected.
The officer elected at such special election shall hold the said office during
the unexpired term thereof. The person sought to be removed may be a candidate
in the recall election. In such election if some candidate other than the
person sought to be removed is elected, the incumbent shall thereupon be deemed
removed from office upon the qualification of his successor, and should the
person so elected fail to qualify within ten days after being notified of his
election the office shall be deemed vacant. If the incumbent be a candidate at
such election and shall be elected to such office he shall continue therein
without again qualifying. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-
2005)
Section 121. Reserved. (Res. 5441, 12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
ARTICLE VIII. ELECTIONS
Section 122. Candidates For Office And Election.
(a) The general election laws of the state of Oklahoma shall apply to the
conduct of all elections in the city of Ponca City, unless otherwise provided
by city charter. Municipal elections shall be conducted by the Kay County
election board unless the board of commissioners directs that city personnel
shall conduct the election.
(b) Notice Of Municipal Elections.
   1. The city shall give public notice of a general municipal election or a
special election by publishing the resolution. The resolution shall contain the
facts described in section 13-102 of title 26 of the Oklahoma Statutes or any
subsequent state statute specifying the resolution's contents.
   2. The resolution shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation
in Ponca City at least ten (10) days before the beginning of the filing period
for a general municipal election or a special election wherein a vacancy in
office is to be filled, or at least ten (10) days before the date of a special
election held for other than filling a vacancy in office.
(c) Municipal Election For Offices.
   1. A general election for members of the board of commissioners of Ponca
City shall be conducted on the second Tuesday in February of each year, except
in any year when a presidential preferential primary is held in February, then
the election shall be held on the same day as the presidential preferential
primary.
   2. A special election for members of the board of commissioners of Ponca
City shall be conducted when necessary to fill vacancies in the office of a
commissioner or mayor.
   3. If no candidate in a general or special election receives more than fifty
percent (50%) of the votes cast for all candidates for the office sought in the
election, a run-off election between the two candidates with the highest number
of votes shall be conducted. For general elections, the run-off shall be
conducted on the first Tuesday in April of that year or as soon thereafter as
permitted by state law for elections conducted by the county election board.
For special elections, the run-off shall be conducted as soon as possible
taking into consideration the limited dates on which the county election board
is permitted to conduct elections.
   4. A candidate for office, whether in a general or special election,
receiving more than fifty percent (50%) of the votes cast for all candidates
for the office sought shall, subject to satisfying all other qualifications of
the office, be entitled to be issued a certificate of election in due and
proper form, in the same manner and subject to the same exceptions and caveats
as for county officers. Candidates elected to office shall serve for the term
to which they are elected and until their successor is elected and qualified or
appointed and qualified, and for so long during their term as they continue to
satisfy the qualifications of such an office holder.
(d) Unopposed Candidates In Elections. Any candidate who is unopposed for an
office in a general or special municipal election shall be deemed elected and
certified; and his/her name shall not appear on the election ballot. If there
is only one candidate for each of the offices which are to be filled at the
election, and no questions are to be voted upon at the election, the general or
special municipal election shall not be held.
(e) Manner Of Becoming A Candidate - Declaration Of Candidacy - Filing For
Office. To be eligible to become a candidate in the general election or a
special election in which an office is being filled, a person must for at least
six (6) months prior to filing a declaration of candidacy: (1) maintain their
primary residence within the jurisdictional limits of the city of Ponca City
and (2) be a registered voter at an address within the municipality. To become
a candidate in a general or special election, a declaration of candidacy must
be filed with the Kay County election board during the filing period
established for that election by the board of commissioners.
(f) Special Election Ballot - Preparation And Arrangement. The ballot for a
special election shall be prepared by the city attorney and shall set forth the
proposition or propositions to be voted upon, and if more than one proposition
is submitted, they shall be arranged so that each proposition may be voted upon
separately.
(g) In the event city officials are directed to conduct said election, the
duties required to be performed by the county election board shall be performed
by the city clerk and the duties required to be performed by the county board
of commissioners shall be performed by the board of commissioners of the city
of Ponca City, and the duties required to be performed by the sheriff shall be
performed by the chief of police, and other city officials are hereby required
to perform the various duties provided by state election law prescribed by
county officers, in whose stead they act, subject to the same penalties and
provisions prescribed by said election laws as to such officers. (Res. 5441,
12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 123. Reserved 1
.

  section 123, General laws to govern; section 125, Election precincts to be
  divided; and section 126, Qualifications and duties of election officials.
Section 124. (Disapproved by the governor.)
Sections 125, 126. Reserved 1

1 election held April 5, 1994, and by the governor on July 1, 1994 repealed
  section 123, General laws to govern; section 125, Election precincts to be

Section 127. General And Special Elections Defined.
General elections are those elections conducted early and regularly each year
to fill recurring positions on the board of commissioners becoming vacant by
reason of expiration of terms of office. All other elections, whether to fill
vacancies in the board of commissioners, or vote on special issues or
questions, whenever they may be conducted, are special elections. (Res. 5441,
12-28-2004, approved at referendum 3-1-2005)
Section 128. (Disapproved by the governor.)
ARTICLE IX. HEALTH AND SANITATION
Section 129. Sewers.
The board of commissioners shall have power by ordinance: To provide for,
construct and maintain a general sewer and drainage system to be divided into
public and private sewers and drains and to be constructed, maintained and
regulated in such manner and out of such material as the board of commissioners
may prescribe. Sewers may be established as the board of commissioners may
direct, and there may be extensions or branches of sewers constructed or
entirely new throughout as may be deemed expedient. They may, if necessary,
levy a tax on all taxable properties in the entire city to pay for the
construction and repairs of such public sewers, which shall be called a
"special sewer tax", and shall be used solely for such purpose. No public sewer
shall be run diagonally through private property when it is practicable,
without injury to said sewer, to construct it parallel with one of the exterior
lines of such property. No public sewer shall be constructed through private
property when it is practicable to construct it along or through a street or
public highway. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 130. License Butchers.
To regulate and license butchers and prevent their slaughtering animals in the
city limits, and revoke licenses for malconduct in trade, and regulate, license
and restrain the sale of fresh meat, fruit and vegetables, and the slaughter of
animals, and to license and regulate or prohibit slaughterhouses within the
city limits. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 131. Prevent Nuisances.
To compel the owner or occupant of any grocery, soap tallow or chandler
establishment, or blacksmith shop, tannery, stable, slaughterhouse, or other
building, or sewer, privy, hide house, or other unwholesome or nauseous place
or house, to cleanse, remove, fill up, repair or abate the same, as may be
necessary for the health, comfort and convenience of the inhabitants. (Approved
3-17-1920)
Section 132. Regulate And Inspect Food.
To regulate the inspection and slaughter of animals and the sale of fresh meats
within the city, and the inspection and sale of flour, meal, fish, salt and
other provisions, and all other articles of food and drink whatsoever, to be
consumed within the city, and to appoint inspectors, weighers and gaugers, and
prescribe their duties and powers, and to regulate their fees, and to provide
for the inspection and weighing of hay and coal, ice, and the measurement of
coal, gas, and other fuel to be sold in the city. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 133. Noisome Smells.
To regulate, restrain, locate, abate or prohibit gas reservoirs and tanks, glue
factories, bone boilers, hide houses or establishments for burning hides, soap
factories, places for rendering lard tallow, offal and other substances that
can be rendered and all establishments where any nauseating, dangerous,
offensive or unwholesome business may be carried on. (Approved 3-17-1920)
Section 134. Scavenger And Scavenge.
The city of Ponca City shall have the right and power by ordinance to provide
that the tenant or owner of any property shall pay to the city reasonable
charges for the removal of night soil or other refuse matter from the closets
of the premises thereof, or for the removal of slops, offal, excrement, filth,
waste substances and other refuse matter, and to prohibit anyone except someone
in the employ of the city, or by the city authorized to do so, from removing or
carrying away the contents of any privy, vault or water closet, or any
receptacle, or any slops, offal, excrement, filth, waste substances or other
refuse matter and the city shall have the right to have inspected the premises
of all persons at any time in the interest of the public health; and for the
purpose of making such inspection, the officers and agents of the city, duly
authorized to do so, shall have a right to enter the premises of any person at
any hour during the daytime to make such inspection. Whenever notice is given
by any officer or employee of the city inspecting any premises to the effect
that said premises need cleaning, the said night soil, slops, offal, excrement,
filth, waste substances and other refuse matter shall be removed and the owner
or tenant of such premises shall pay the City the price prescribed therefor,
and failure so to do shall subject said person to the penalties to be
prescribed by ordinance, and said persons shall be fined, upon conviction in
Municipal Court, in any sum not less than One Dollar or more than One Hundred
Dollars.
Section 135. Five mile jurisdiction.
The City of Ponca City shall have jurisdiction over all places within five
miles of the corporate limits of the City for the enforcement of all health,
quarantine or waterworks ordinances and regulations thereof.
Section 136. Board of Health.
The Board of Commissioners are hereby authorized and required to create a Board
of Health for the City, whose duties and jurisdiction shall be determined and
prescribed by said Board of Commissioners, said Board of Health to consist of
not more than three reputable physicians of the City of Ponca City, to be
appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the Board of Commissioners.
Section 137. Unsanitary place a nuisance.
Any building, private sewer, drain, toilet, pipe, or any other place or thing
within the City of Ponca City, found in an unsanitary condition, is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and the same shall be immediately abated by the owner
thereof, and if such owner fail or refuse to abate the same any police or other
officer of the City, or any person injured or annoyed thereby, may summarily
abate the same either by removal or by repairing; and if the same be repaired
the property upon which the same shall be or be found shall be liable for all
costs and expenses incurred in repairing or abating the same.
Section 138. Refuse to be cared for.
The City of Ponca City shall also have power to require any person or
corporations owning or operating manufacturing enterprises within or without
the City which shall discharge refuse matter into the Arkansas River or its
tributaries, to make other provisions for such refuse matter or so purify the
same that the public health will be fully protected.
Section 139. Fill up drains.
To require the owners of private sinks and privies to fill up, cleanse, drain,
alter, relay, repair, fix and improve the same as they may be ordered by
resolution or ordinance, and impose penalties upon persons failing to do the
same. If there be no person in the City upon whom such order can be served, or
if no such person can be found therein, the City may have such work done, and
the costs of the same shall be a lien on the property and taxed against it, and
collected in such manner as the Board of Commissioners may provide.
Section 140. Carcasses not to be buried in City.
To prevent any person from bringing, depositing or burying within the City
limits the carcasses of any dead animals or other unwholesome substances, or
matter, or filth of any kind, and to require prompt removal of the same, and
impose all necessary penalties for the enforcement of such powers.
Section 141. Inspect dairies.
To provide for the inspection of dairies and products therefrom, inside and
outside of the City limits, doing business within the City and to charge and
collect license fees for inspection; to establish and maintain a standard of
sanitary conditions governing dairies inside and outside the City, doing
business in the City; and to inspect and establish and maintain a standard of
quality of all dairy products sold in the City, and to provide for penalties
for the violation thereof.
ARTICLE X. PUBLIC SAFETY
Section 142. Fire Department and prevention of fires.
The City of Ponca City shall have power:
(a) To provide means for the protection against and the extinguishment of
fires, and shall provide for the regulation, maintenance and support of a Fire
Department, and for the purpose of guarding against the calamity of fire, may
prescribe fire limits, and may regulate and prohibit the erection, building,
placing or repairing of wooden buildings within such fire limits in said City
as shall be designated and prescribed as fire limits, and may also within said
limits prohibit the moving or putting up of any wooden buildings from one place
to another therein, and may direct and prescribe that all buildings within the
limits so designated in the ordinances as fire limits shall be made or
constructed of fireproof material, the kind, character, extent and quality of
which buildings and materials may, by ordinance, be prescribed and fixed, and
may prohibit the repairing of wooden buildings in such limits when the same
shall have been damaged to the extent of thirty-three and one-third percent of
the value thereof, and may prescribe the manner of ascertaining such damage and
may declare all wooden buildings in the fire limits which they deem dangerous
to contiguous buildings, or which may cause or promote fires, to be nuisances,
and may require and cause the same to be removed in such manner as may be
prescribed, at the expense of the owner, and may further prescribe limits
within which only a fireproof roofing may be used, and may impose a penalty for
violation of such rules and regulations. The City shall have the right by
ordinance to regulate, prescribe and govern the storage of lumber, sash, doors,
blinds, nitroglycerine, dynamite, powder and any and all commodities of an
inflammable, combustible or explosive nature and any and all kinds of goods,
wares and merchandise, and prescribe limits within which such materials may be
carried, and fix penalties for violation of the rules and ordinances governing
the same.
(b) To procure fire engines, hooks, ladders, buckets and other apparatus, and
organize fire engine, hook and ladder and bucket companies, and prescribe rules
of duty for the government thereof, with such penalties as they may deem
proper, and make all necessary appropriation therefor.
(c) To regulate or prevent the carrying on of manufactories and other works
dangerous in causing fires, and to regulate the location of sheds and other
buildings dangerous on account of fires.
(d) To prevent the deposit of ashes in unsafe places and cause the removal from
one's premises of all trash, old papers, straw, goods, boxes, barrels and
anything else dangerous on account of fire and filth, slop and animal or
vegetable matter and everything else offensive and dangerous to health and
comfort and to cause all buildings and enclosures in a dangerous state to be
put in safe condition.
(e) To regulate the size, number and construction of doors and stairways to
theaters, tenement houses, hotels, boardinghouses, apartment houses, audience
rooms, public halls, schoolhouses and buildings used for the gathering of large
numbers of people, whether now built or hereafter to be built, so that there
may be convenient, safe and speedy exit in case of fires.
(f) To require the construction of suitable fire escapes on or in hotels,
lodging houses, factories and school and other buildings whether now or
hereafter built.
(g) To compel the owners or occupants of houses or other buildings to have
suitable scuttles in their roofs and stairs and ladders leading to the same.
(h) To authorize one or more officers, agents or employees of the City to enter
in and upon all buildings and premises to examine and discover whether the same
are dangerous on account of fire, or in any unclean state, and cause all
defects to be remedied, and filth and trash to be removed, and generally the
Board of Commissioners shall have power to establish such regulations for the
prevention and extinguishment of fires as it may deem expedient.
(i) To fix by ordinance the salaries of all firemen and other persons connected
with the Fire Department.
(j) To provide for the payment of and to pay pensions to men who have served
not less than ten years continuously in the employ of the City as firemen.
Section 143. To regulate trains and tracks.
The City of Ponca City shall have power by ordinance or otherwise to regulate
the speed of engines, locomotives and street cars within the limits; to require
all steam and electric railway companies to keep the streets over which they
run properly drained and to light the same whenever deemed necessary, and to
require that all railroad tracks, switches and turnouts conform to the grade of
the streets so as to interfere as little as possible with the ordinary travel
in the use of said streets.
Section 144. Poles and wires.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to cause telegraph, telephone and
electric light companies to change the location of their poles, and to cause
all erected poles to be taken down and removed, and the wires run underground,
if it be decided by the Board that the public interest and safety should be
conserved thereby.
Section 145. Repairing and maintaining streets.
Any person, firm or corporation required by contract, franchise or otherwise to
construct, reconstruct or repair any street improvement, or to keep any portion
of any street, alley or part thereof or the pavement thereon in repair or to
maintain the same in safe condition for public travel, who shall be served with
a written notice signed by any owner or owners of property abutting such street
or alley or such portion thereof, such notice to be served by delivering in
person or by mailing same by registered mail at the post office address of his
residence, and who shall fail to refuse to perform his duty according to the
terms of such franchise, contract or other obligation, within ninety days after
the date of service of such notice, shall forfeit to the City the sum of fifty
dollars for each day after the expiration of said ninety days until such
street, alley or portion thereof such person, firm or corporation is bound to
repair or maintain, is repaired and put in good condition for public travel as
required by the terms of such contract, franchise or other obligation, until
the terms thereof are complied with, such sum or sums to be recoverable at the
suit of the City or of any owner of property abutting on said street or alley
or portion thereof, to the use of the City, in any court of competent
jurisdiction. The penalty herein provided shall be in addition to and
cumulative of any other penalty, condition or requirement contained in such
franchise, contract or other obligation. In any suit brought under this Section
any judgment therein recovered may be a lien upon any sum held by or deposited
with the City, or in trust, to guarantee or secure the performance of the
condition of any franchise, contract or obligation.
Section 146. Obstructions in streets.
The City shall have power to prohibit and prevent all encroachments into and
upon the sidewalks, streets, alleys and other property of the City, and may
provide for the removal of all obstructions from the sidewalks, curbstones,
gutters and crosswalks at the expense of the owners or occupants of the grounds
fronting thereon, or at the expense of the person placing the same there; the
City shall also regulate the planting and protecting of and shall have complete
control over shade trees in streets and the cultivation and uniform trimming
thereof and the building of bulk heads, cellar and basement ways, stairways,
railposts, awning posts, and all other structures projecting upon or over and
adjoining, and all excavation through and under the sidewalks or along the
streets of the City.
Section 147. Condemnation of buildings.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to condemn all dangerous buildings,
fences, sheds, awnings or structures of every kind, and to require the owners,
or occupants to remove the same, and may punish by fine and imprisonment or
either any person failing to do so. They may remove the same at the expense of
the City on account of the owner of the property and assess the expense
thereof, including condemnation proceedings if any, as a special tax against
the land, and the same may be collected as other special taxes provided for in
the Charter, or by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction.
Section 148. Penalty for obstructing streets.
It shall be unlawful for any person to encumber or obstruct any street, highway
or grounds of the City with any posts, boxes, lumber, fences or with anything
else, and he may be punished as may be provided by ordinance.
Section 149. Minors on the streets.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to prohibit minors from going on
the public streets and in the public places in the City of Ponca City between
the hours of nine o'clock p.m. and four o'clock a.m. without the consent of
their parents or guardian.
Section 150. Traffic regulations.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to enact and enforce ordinances
regulating the speed, driving, handling and parking of automobiles and other
vehicles on the streets of the City.
Section 151. Oil houses, elevators, building permits.
In addition to all powers granted elsewhere in the Charter, the City of Ponca
City shall have power to regulate and prohibit the storage of oil, oil houses
and yards in any portion of the City, to provide for inspection of such houses
and yards, and to prescribe the material of which such houses shall be
constructed; to regulate and provide for inspection of passenger and freight
elevators in buildings; to prohibit and regulate the construction and erection
of livery stables and blacksmith shops in the resident portion of the City; to
authorize the inspection of all buildings and structures during the erection,
require them to be erected in accordance with regulations prescribed, and to
prohibit their erection without having first had a building permit issued.
ARTICLE XI. REVENUE AND FINANCE
Section 152. Taxation.
The City of Ponca City shall have power and is hereby authorized annually to
levy and collect taxes for general revenue purposes, not exceeding ten mills on
the dollar of the assessed value on all real, personal and mixed property in
the City, not exempt from taxation by the Constitution and laws of the State;
provided the City of Ponca City, by a majority of the qualified property tax-
paying voters of said City, voting at an election to be held for that purpose,
shall be allowed to become indebted in a larger amount than that specified in
Section 26, Article 10, of the Constitution of the State of Oklahoma and in a
larger amount than that specified in this Section of the Charter for the
purpose of purchasing or constructing public buildings or public utilities, or
for repairing the same, to be owned exclusively by the City; provided, that the
City, in incurring any such indebtedness requiring the assent of the voters
aforesaid, shall have the power to provide for and before or at the time of
incurring the same, shall provide for the collection of an annual tax in
addition to all other taxes provided for by the Charter, sufficient to pay the
interest on such indebtedness as it falls due and also to constitute and
maintain a sinking fund for the payment of the principal thereof within twenty-
five (25) years from the date of contracting same, and all bonds heretofore
issued or to be issued by the City, in pursuance of the requisite vote
heretofore taken, as above provided, of the property tax-paying voters of the
City, shall for the purpose, and in compliance with the terms of this Section
stated, be deemed and held to have been duly and legally authorized and issued.
Section 153. Poll tax.
The City shall have power to levy and collect a poll tax on all electors of the
City under sixty years of age, not exceeding two dollars per capita, per annum.
The said poll tax shall be levied and collected by the persons or officers
specified, and in the manner and at the time hereinafter provided by ordinance
of the City, and a penalty for nonpayment of such tax when may be prescribed by
ordinance duly enacted by the City.
Section 154. Itinerants and brokers.
To license and regulate any itinerant or transient vendor of clothing or
wearing apparel or article of bedding or merchandise of any description
whatever, ticket brokers, or scalpers, or dealers in railway tickets, dealers
in bankrupt or fire stock, or damaged goods of any kind, secondhand dealers,
pawnbrokers, junk shops and dealers in junk, and all other business or
occupations whatever, which in the opinion of the Board of Commissioners shall
be properly subject to police regulation, and to require the person or persons
or corporation pursuing any business or occupation mentioned in this Section,
to give any and all bonds in such amounts and with such conditions as the Board
of Commissioners may prescribe. No license shall be assignable, except by the
permission of the Board of Commissioners.
Section 155. Occupation.
The City shall have power to levy and collect a license tax on auctioneers,
contractors, druggists, hawkers, peddlers, bankers, brokers, pawnbrokers,
merchants of all kinds, grocers, confectioners, restaurants, butchers, taverns,
public boardinghouses, billiard tables, bowling alleys and other amusement
devices, drays, hacks, carriages, omnibuses, carts, wagons and other vehicles
used in the City for pay, hay, scales, lumber dealers, furniture dealers,
saddle or harness dealers, stationers, jewelers, livery stable keepers, real
estate agents, express companies or agencies, shows, theaters, and all kinds of
exhibitions for pay; provided, however, that all scientific and literary
lectures and entertainments shall be exempt from taxation, and also all
concerts and musical or other entertainments given exclusively by citizens of
the City.
Section 156. License revoked.
In all cases where, by any of the provisions of the Charter, or by ordinance in
pursuance thereof, a person is required to obtain a license for any calling,
occupation, business or vocation, and has, on complaint before the Municipal
Court, been adjudged guilty of violating any rule, regulation or ordinance of
the City in relation thereto, said Court, in addition to the punishment imposed
therefor, may suspend or revoke the license so granted.
Section 157. Lien.
A lien is hereby created on all property, personal and real, in favor of the
City, for all taxes, ad valorem, occupation or otherwise. Said lien shall exist
from the time of assessment or levy until the taxes are paid. Such lien shall
be prior to all other claims, and no gift, sale, assignment or transfer of any
kind, or judicial writ of any kind, can ever defeat such lien, but the
Commissioners can pursue such property, and whenever found, seize and sell
enough thereof to satisfy such taxes.
Section 158. Attachment for tax.
If anyone against whom a personal tax is assessed, and which is due and unpaid,
whether the same be delinquent or not, shall have removed out of the City, or
shall be about to remove out of the City, or shall have removed or about to
remove his personal property out of the City, it shall be the duty of the
Commissioner of Finance to proceed at once and collect such taxes by seizure
and sale of any personal property of such person to be found in the City of
Ponca City or anywhere in the State of Oklahoma.
Section 159. Collection of tax.
The Board of Commissioners shall have full power to provide by ordinance for
the prompt collection of taxes assessed, authorized, levied or imposed under
the Charter, and are hereby authorized and to that end may and shall have full
power and authority to sell or cause to be sold all kinds of property, real and
personal, and may and shall make such rules and regulations and ordain and pass
all ordinances deemed necessary to the levying, laying, imposing, assessing and
collecting of any taxes provided or authorized in the Charter. Unless otherwise
provided by ordinance and the Charter, all property in such City liable to
taxation shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of the general
laws of the State, insofar as applicable.
Section 160. Exempt certain property.
The Board of Commissioners are hereby empowered and authorized to exempt from
municipal taxation for a period not exceeding five years, manufacturing
establishments and public utilities, as an inducement to their location in the
City.
ARTICLE XII. PUBLIC PROPERTY
Section 161. City may own utilities.
The City of Ponca City shall have power:
(a) City may engage in public service. To buy or construct, own, maintain,
extend and operate a system or systems of waterworks, gas or electric lighting
plants, telephones, street cars and sewers, or any other public service or
enterprise that may be approved by a majority of the qualified voters of the
City, voting therefor, at any regular election for City Officers, or at a
special election called for that purpose in accordance with the provisions of
the Charter; and may demand and receive compensation for such service furnished
for private purposes, and shall have power to condemn the property of any
person, firm, or corporation for the purpose of operating and maintaining any
such utility, and for distributing such service throughout the City or any
portion thereof, but in such condemnation proceedings no allowance shall be
made for the value of any franchise and only the actual physical assets shall
be purchased by the City.
(b) City may acquire, own and sell property. To acquire or own within or
without the City limits either by purchase, donation, bequest or otherwise, all
property it may need for any municipal purposes whatever; and all necessary
rights of way thereto, and shall also have the power to sell and dispose of the
same, except as otherwise provided in the Charter.
(c) City may improve property. To provide all needful buildings for the use of
the City; to provide for enclosing, improving, ornamenting and regulating all
public grounds belonging to the City; to provide hospitals and regulate and
maintain the same, and to permit or prohibit private hospitals; and to
establish an active system of inspection and regulation over all such premises.
(d) City may purchase or condemn property. To purchase or condemn and hold for
the City, within, or outside the City limits within five miles therefrom, all
necessary lands for hospital purposes and waterworks and erect, establish and
regulate the hospitals, workhouses and poorhouses, and provide for the
government and support of the same, and make regulations to secure the general
health of the City, and to prevent and remove nuisances, and to make provisions
for furnishing the City with water; and water rates shall be fixed annually by
the Commissioners at their first meeting in June; provided, the condemnation of
such property outside of the City limits shall be regulated in all respects as
provided by law for the condemnation of property for railroad purposes and
provided, further, that the police jurisdiction of the City shall extend over
such land and property to the same extent as over public cemeteries.
Section 162. Adoption of Charter does not change rights of City.
All real estate owned in fee simple, or held by lease, sufferance, easement or
otherwise, all public buildings, school buildings, schoolhouses, fire engine
stations, public squares, parks, streets, alleys, and all property of whatever
kind, character and description which has been granted, donated, purchased or
otherwise acquired by the City of Ponca City, through any means or agency, and
all causes of action, choses in action, rights or privileges of every kind and
character, and all property of whatsoever character or description which may
have been held, and is now held, controlled or used by the said City of Ponca
City for public uses or in trust for the public, shall vest in, and remain in
and inure to the said Corporation, the City of Ponca City, under the Charter
and all suits and pending actions to which the City of Ponca City heretofore
was, or now is, a party, plaintiff or defendant, shall in no wise be affected
or terminated by the provisions of this Charter, but shall continue unabated.
ARTICLE XIII. LABOR
Section 163. City may employ labor.
The City of Ponca City shall have power to do by day labor, under municipal
direction, any work which may become advisable or necessary to be done.
Section 164. Eight hours a legal day.
In all work done by or for the City, either by day work or by contract, eight
hours shall constitute a day's work and no employee of the City on work for the
City, or employee of any contractor or subcontractor of such work shall be
required to work longer than eight hours in any one calendar day; provided,
that this Section shall not apply to the fire or police department or to
employees engaged in clerical work for the City and, provided further that this
Section shall not be construed to apply to any contract entered into by the
City prior to the passing of this Act; provided that in case of emergency, an
employee may be required to work longer than eight hours, but when required so
to work longer than eight hours, such employee shall be paid for such overtime
at the rate of one and one-half times the rate such employee is paid for his
labor during the eight hours.
Section 165. No lien on City property.
No lien of any kind can ever exist against the public halls, parks or public
works of the City. All sub-contractors, material men, mechanics and laborers
upon any public works of the City, are hereby required to notify the City of
all claims they may have on account of such work against the City, and when
such notice has been given the City shall retain an amount from any funds due
the contractors sufficient to satisfy all claims; provided, that such notice
may be given at any time after such indebtedness becomes due and before final
settlement; and, provided further, that no contractor or sub-contractor shall
issue any time checks on or on account of any public works of said City.
Section 166. Convicts.
The Board of Commissioners shall have the power to prohibit the working of
State convicts within corporate limits of the City.
ARTICLE XIV. MISCELLANEOUS
Section 167. City may summon witnesses.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power to summon and compel the attendance
of witnesses, and the production of books and papers before them whenever it
may be necessary for the more effective discharge of their duties. All process
shall be signed by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk and be served by
the Chief of Police or any police officer of the City.
Section 168. Sections not interdependent.
In the event any part, article, section or subdivision of this Act shall be
held to be unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, such holding shall not
be construed to invalidate or impair the remainder of this Act, but the same
shall continue in full force and effect notwithstanding such holding.
Section 169. Optional remedies.
Whenever any power, authority or right is conferred herein upon the City of
Ponca City or upon the Board of Commissioners, and provisions are incorporated
herein or elsewhere for the exercise thereof in different ways, such provisions
shall be held and construed to be cumulative and in such cases the
Commissioners shall be empowered to use their discretion with respect to which
of such provisions shall be exercised.
Section 170. Style of process.
All writs, subpoenas, or other process issuing out of the City court, shall run
in the name of the City of Ponca City, and may be executed and served by the
Chief of Police or his deputies, or policemen of said City anywhere in Kay
County, Oklahoma.
Section 171. Contracts.
All bonds, contracts, or other instruments requiring the assent of the City
shall be signed by the Mayor or the Acting Mayor, and attested by the City
Clerk.
Section 172. No bond required of City.
It shall not be necessary in any action, suit or proceeding in which the City
is a party, for any bond, undertaking or security to be executed in behalf of
the City, but all such action, suits, appeals, or proceedings shall be
conducted in the same manner as if such bond, undertaking or security had been
given, and said City shall be liable as if such obligation had been duly given
and executed.
Section 173. City not to be attached or garnished.
The property, real and personal, belonging to said City shall not be liable to
be sold or appropriated under any writ of execution or cost bill, nor shall the
funds belonging to said City, in the hands of any person, be liable to
garnishment on account of any debt it may owe or funds it may have on hand due
any person, nor shall the City or any of its officers or agents be required to
answer to any writ or garnishment of any account whatsoever, nor shall said
City be liable to the assignee of any wages of any officer, agent or employee
of said City, whether earned or unearned, upon any claims or account,
whatsoever, and as to the City any such assignment shall be absolutely void.
Section 174. All contractors to give bond.
The Board of Commissioners shall require good and sufficient bonds of all
contractors, with at least two good and sufficient sureties, who shall be
residents of the State of Oklahoma. No nonresident of the State shall ever be
received as surety on any bond payable to the City except such guarantee
companies as may be satisfactory to the Board of Commissioners. And in all
cases at least one of the sureties must be a resident of Kay County, Oklahoma.
When bondsmen are not residents of Kay County such proof of their solvency may
be required as the Board of Commissioners may deem necessary.
Section 175. Fund not to be diverted.
All appropriations made or set apart for the payment of any interest or sinking
fund, or both, shall under no circumstances ever be diverted to any other
purpose.
Section 176. When State law to govern.
All questions arising in administering said City government, and not provided
for in this Act, shall be governed by the State law in such cases made and
provided.
Section 177. Charter a public Act.
This Act shall be deemed a public act, and judicial notice shall be taken
thereof in all courts and places, without the same having been pleaded or read
in evidence.
Section 178. Fiscal year.
The fiscal year shall begin at twelve o'clock noon, on the first day of July of
each year.
Section 179. Amendments to Charter.
The people of the City of Ponca City hereby reserve to themselves the right to
propose amendments to this Charter as provided by the Constitution and Laws of
the State of Oklahoma.
Section 180. Charter may be repealed.
The Charter may be repealed and the City of Ponca City thereupon and thereafter
subject to the general laws of the State of Oklahoma the same as though no
Charter had ever been adopted, at an election called and held for that purpose
pursuant to a petition for the holding of such an election. Such petition, when
filed with the City Clerk, must have signed thereto the names of a number of
electors of the City not greater than one-fourth (1/4) of the total number of
votes cast at the regular municipal election next preceding, and shall not be
presented to the City Commissioners until after there shall have called at the
City Clerk's office and signed the same such additional number of electors as
shall make the total number of signatures thereto equal to or greater than
forty (40) percent of the total vote cast at the regular election next
preceding for the City officer who received the highest number of votes at such
election. Upon the presentation of such petition to the City Commissioners they
shall within ten days call a special election to be held within twenty days
after such call, at which the question of repeal shall be voted upon by the
general electors of the City. If a majority of the electors voting at said
election shall vote in favor of the repeal, the Charter shall stand repealed.
If the Charter be repealed the Mayor and other officers, except the two
Commissioners, shall continue in office and administer the affairs of the City
under the Constitution and Laws of the State of Oklahoma until their successors
are elected and qualified. The offices of the two Commissioners shall, by the
result of said election, be abolished. At the said election called and held for
the purpose of voting upon the question of repealing the Charter, there shall
be held, as a part thereof, an election of officers provided by the laws of the
State of Oklahoma for Cities of the First Class, and if the Charter be repealed
and such officers elected they shall immediately thereafter qualify for and
assume the duties of the offices to which they shall have been elected. The
officers so elected shall hold their respective offices until the next general
election as provided by law for Cities of the First Class.
We, the undersigned members of the Board of Freeholders elected at the regular
election held in and for the City of Ponca City on the First day of April,
1919, for the purpose of preparing and proposing a Charter for the City of
Ponca City, to be submitted to the voters of said City at an election to be
called and held for such purpose, do hereby certify that the within and
foregoing is the original Charter so prepared and proposed by us.
In Witness Whereof, we have hereunto set our hands and signed and certified the
said Charter in duplicate this Twenty-eighth day of June, 1919.
