TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Numbering System
1-1-3: Acceptance
1-1-4: Amendments
1-1-5: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the Board of Commissioners, this Code is hereby declared
to be and shall hereafter constitute the official City Code of Ponca City. This
Code shall be known and cited as the CITY CODE OF PONCA CITY (2017), and is
hereby published by authority of the Board of Commissioners of the City of
Ponca City, Oklahoma, and shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent
legislation of the City as provided in section
1-1-4 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this Code by title in any legal documents. (Ord. 6247, 10-9-2017, eff. 11-1-
2017)
1-1-2: NUMBERING SYSTEM:
   A.   Numbering System Explained: For the purposes of internal references in
this Code and citation by its users, each section of the legislation included
in this Code has been assigned a number that indicates the title in which the
legislation is included, the chapter or article as the case may be in which it
is found and the location of the section within that chapter or article, as
follows:
 
Example: 5-1A-2
First number ( 5-1A-2) Title of Code
Second number (5-1A-2) Chapter of title
Letter (5-1A-2)        Article of chapter
Third number (5-1A-2)  Section of chapter and/or article
 
   B.   Referencing Code Provisions: References or citations made in a form
other than the foregoing will not defeat the intent of a user in citing this
Code when that intent is otherwise clear. This Code is to be construed
liberally to carry out its intent and purpose. (2003 Code)
1-1-3: ACCEPTANCE:
This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
State as the ordinances of the City of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2003 Code)
1-1-4: AMENDMENTS:
   A.   Effect: Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed
in such form as to indicate the intention of the Board of Commissioners to make
the same a part hereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that
reference to the "city code of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma", shall be
understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. (1980 Code §
2-35; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Manner: All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code
which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in
accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion
herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any
part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded
from this Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the
subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of
repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such
time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted
as a new Code of ordinances by the Board of Commissioners. (1980 Code § 2-36)
   C.   Language: Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be
made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this
Code in substantially the following language: "That section           of the
city code of Ponca City, Oklahoma, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...".
The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (1980 Code § 2-37;
amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   New material:
      1.   In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the code is to
be added, the following language may be used: "That the city code of Ponca
City, Oklahoma, is hereby amended by adding a section (or chapter, article or
other designation as the case may be), to be numbered          , which reads as
follows: ...". The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.
      2.   In lieu of subsection D1 of this section, when the board of
commissioners desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature
embracing a subject not previously existing in the code, which the board of
commissioners desires to incorporate into the code, a provision in
substantially the following language may be made part of such ordinance: "It is
the intention of the board of commissioners, and it is hereby ordained, that
the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the city code
of Ponca City, Oklahoma, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered
to accomplish such intention". (1980 Code § 2-38; amd. 2003 Code)
   E.   Repeal: All sections, chapters, articles or other provisions of this
code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number,
chapter, article number, or other number, as the case may be. (1980 Code § 2-
39)
   F.   Subject To General Penalty: In case of the amendment by the board of
commissioners of any section of this code for which a penalty is not provided,
the general penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such
amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the
aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same
chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate
to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed
therein. (1980 Code § 2-40)
   G.   Supplementation Of Code:
      1.   By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this code shall be
prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of
commissioners. A supplement to the code shall include all substantive permanent
and general parts of ordinances passed by the board of commissioners or adopted
by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and
all changes made thereby in the code. The pages of a supplement shall be so
identified that they will fit properly into the code and will, where necessary,
replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new
pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the code will be
current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in
the supplement.
      2.   In preparing a supplement to this code, all portions of the code
which have been repealed shall be excluded from the code by the omission
thereof from reprinted pages.
      3.   When preparing a supplement to this code, the codifier (meaning the
person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make
formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included
in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a
unified code. For example, the codifier may:
         a.   Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subsections;
         b.   Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections
and other subsections of the code printed in the supplement, and make changes
in such catchlines, headings and titles;
         c.   Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subsections to
be inserted in the code and, where necessary to accommodate new material,
change existing section or other subsection numbers;
         d.   Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to
"this chapter", or "this article", as the case may be, or to "sections       to
     " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the code which
embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the code);
and
         e.   Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the
original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the code; but, in no case
shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance
material included in the supplement or already embodied in the code. (1980 Code
§ 2-41; amd. 2003 Code)
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or
deletions, any part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or
portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any manner whatsoever
which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby; provided,
that supplementation of this code by authorized persons shall be permitted.
(1980 Code § 1-9)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Effect Of Repeals
1-2-4: Court Proceedings
1-2-5: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this city
code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this city code or are
by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation
ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances. (2003 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this city code or by virtue of the
preceding section, excepting as the city code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this city code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (2003 Code)
1-2-3: EFFECT OF REPEALS:
The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at
the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall
not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect,
nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of such repeal, of
an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed.
(1980 Code § 1-13)
1-2-4: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as
to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done,
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or
claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any
such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this city code. (2003 Code)
1-2-5: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this code are
severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this
code shall be declared invalid, unenforceable or unconstitutional by the valid
judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity,
unenforceability or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining
phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this code. (1980 Code §
1-12)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Rules Of Construction, Definitions
1-3-2: Incorporation By Reference
1-3-3: Parenthetical Information
1-3-4: Catchlines Of Sections
1-3-5: Reference To Code, Conflicts
1-3-6: Police Power Extended To City Property
1-3-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION, DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this code and of all ordinances of this city, the
following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed, unless such
construction or definition would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of
the board of commissioners, would be repugnant to the context of the provisions
or the context clearly requires otherwise.
All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common
and approved usage of language; but technical words and phrases and such others
as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be
construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning.
(1980 Code § 1-2)
The rules of construction and definitions set forth in this section shall not
be applied to any section of this code or city ordinance which shall contain
any express provision excluding such construction or definition, or when the
subject matter or context of such provisions or ordinances may be repugnant
thereto. (1980 Code § 1-3)
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS: The governing body of the city.
CITY: The city of Ponca City in the county of Kay in the state of Oklahoma.
CODE: This city code of Ponca City as designated and cited in section
1-1-1 of this title.
COMPENSATION: For the purpose of section 76 of the city charter, "compensation"
shall mean monetary remuneration, but shall not include reasonable
reimbursement of expenses and costs related to such public service.
COUNTY: The county of Kay in the state of Oklahoma.
DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY: Whenever a provision appears in this code requiring an
officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be
construed to authorize such officer to designate, delegate and authorize
subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless
the terms of the provision or section expressly designate otherwise.
EASEMENT: A right, liberty, privilege or advantage without profit which the
owner of one parcel of land may have in the land of another. A right in the
owner of one parcel of land, by reason of such ownership, to use the land of
another for a special purpose not inconsistent with a general property right in
the owner.
GENDER: A word importing either the masculine or feminine gender only shall
extend and be applied to the other gender and to persons.
IN THE CITY: The words "in the city" or "in this city" mean and include any
territory within the corporate limits of this city and the police jurisdiction
thereof, and any other territory over which regulatory power has been conferred
on the city by general or special act, except as otherwise specified.
JOINT AUTHORITY: Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more
officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise specifically
declared.
LAW: Any statute, ordinance or regulation promulgated by the United States, the
state, the county, the city or any agency thereof, as well as the rules and
regulations of other bodies politic that may be appropriate.
MONTH: A calendar month.
NUMBER: Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural, and
any word importing the plural number shall include the singular.
OATH: The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases
in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such
cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm"
and "affirmed".
OFFICER: Any person designated as such by section 46 of the city charter, but
such person shall not be considered an officer for purposes of state law. For
purposes of state law, an "officer" is any person who is elected to an office
in the municipal government or is appointed to fill an unexpired term of an
elected officer, and the city clerk and the city treasurer, or as may be
amended hereafter by state law.
OFFICIAL TIME STANDARD: Whenever certain hours are named in this code they
shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in
the city.
OFFICIALS, EMPLOYEES, BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AGENCIES: Whenever reference is made
to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the city by
title only, i.e., "mayor", "clerk", "manager", "chief of police", etc., they
shall be deemed to refer to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or
other agencies of this city.
OR, AND: "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the context of
the provision requires it.
OWNER: When applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the
entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Shall include and be applied to a firm, partnership, association,
corporation, organization, club, society, group acting as a unit, or body
politic and corporate, as well as to an individual.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes money, goods, chattels, evidences of debt, things
in action, and any other species of property, except real property.
PRECEDING, FOLLOWING: The "next before" and the "next after", respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real, personal and mixed property.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any public way, park, cemetery, school yard or open space
adjacent thereto; any public lake or stream; and any place or business open to
the use of the public in general, open to public view or to which the public
has access.
PUBLIC WAY: Any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other
public thoroughfare.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
REASONABLE TIME: In all cases where any section of this code or city ordinance
shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or reasonable notice to
be given, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only
as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such duty, or compliance with
such notice.
RESIDENCE: The place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to
which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person
eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps
shall be deemed to be his residence.
ROADWAY: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for
vehicular traffic.
SHALL, MAY: The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is discretionary.
SIDEWALK: Any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of
the roadway and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
SIGNATURE, SUBSCRIPTION: Includes a mark when the person cannot write, when his
name is written near such mark and is witnessed by a person who writes his own
name as witness.
STATE; THIS STATE: The state of Oklahoma.
STREET: Includes public streets, avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys,
lanes, viaducts, bridges, public ways and approaches thereto and other public
thoroughfares in the city devoted to public use.
TENANT, OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall mean any person who
occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
TENSE: Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well
as the past or present.
WRITING, WRITTEN: Includes typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of
representing words and letters.
YEAR: A calendar year. (1980 Code § 1-2; amd. 2003 Code)
1-3-2: INCORPORATION BY REFERENCE:
All standard codes, rules, regulations, and other subject matter herein or
hereafter properly incorporated by reference, together with subsequent
amendments thereto, pursuant to state law, and future documents incorporated by
reference shall be kept and preserved in the office of the city clerk. (1980
Code § 1-4)
1-3-3: PARENTHETICAL INFORMATION:
The matter in parentheses at the ends of sections in this code is for
information only and is not a part of this code. Citations to the 1980 code of
the city (1980 Code §        ) and to later ordinances indicate only the source
of such section, and the text may or may not be changed by this code. (1980
Code § 1-5; amd. 2003 Code)
1-3-4: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS:
The catchlines of sections of this code are intended as mere catchwords to
indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be
titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly
so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline,
is amended or reenacted. (1980 Code § 1-6; amd. 2003 Code)
1-3-5: REFERENCE TO CODE, CONFLICTS:
In addition to the rules of construction and definitions specified in this
chapter, the following rules shall be observed in the construction of this
code:
   A.   All references to titles, chapters, articles or sections are to the
titles, chapters, articles and sections of this code unless otherwise
specified. (1980 Code § 1-7; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   If the provisions of different chapters of this code conflict with or
contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all
matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of such chapter.
   C.   If conflicting provisions be found in different sections of the same
chapter, the provisions of the section which is last in numerical order shall
prevail unless such construction would be inconsistent with the meaning of such
chapter. (1980 Code § 1-7)
1-3-6: POLICE POWER EXTENDED TO CITY PROPERTY:
The police power of the city is hereby extended to include all lands or
property owned or leased by the city or any agency of the city and the general
ordinances of the city shall be applicable on such property. (1980 Code § 1-8)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Penalty Not Exclusive
1-4-3: Application Of Provisions
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty Imposed: Whenever in this code or in any ordinance of the City
an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a
misdemeanor, or whenever in this code or ordinance of said city the doing of
any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful,
and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such
provision or the failure to perform any such act shall be punished by a fine
not exceeding the maximum amount of money or imprisonment authorized by
Oklahoma Statutes for municipal courts not of record. No penalty shall be
imposed by the court, including fine and costs, which is greater than that
established by the statutes of the state for the same offense.
   B.   State Authorized Assessments: Court costs, subpoena costs, plus the
fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses along with all applicable state
assessments shall be assessed in an amount not to exceed those authorized by
state statute for municipal criminal courts not of record. The payment of all
such assessments shall be in addition to, and not in substitution for, any and
all fines and penalties otherwise provided for by law. The City shall retain
such portion of state assessments as by law permitted.
   C.   Authorization to Issue Citations: The City Manager, through his/her
agents, is hereby authorized to issue a citation for violation of this Code.
Any agent of the City who meets the minimum requirements set forth in 11 O.S.,
22-111.1, shall be authorized to prepare and issue a citation. Citations may be
issued in person or by Certificate of Mailing. (Ord. 6033, 1-9-2006; amd. Ord.
6305. 5-9-2022)
1-4-2: PENALTY NOT EXCLUSIVE:
   A.   License Or Permit Revocation: The imposition of a penalty under the
provisions of this code shall not prevent the revocation or suspension of any
license, franchise or permit issued or granted under the provisions of this
code.
   B.   Nuisance Abatement: In the event any violation of this code is
designated as a nuisance under the provisions of this code, such nuisance may
be summarily abated by the city in addition to the imposition of a fine. (1980
Code § 1-11)
1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this city code the same as though it were a part
of each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this city code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but
not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that an order to abate a nuisance or the revocation of a
license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar
any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this city code
and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach,
the provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2003 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this city code designating the duties of any officer or
employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for
any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intention of the board of commissioners to impose such fine or penalty on such
officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section
creating the duty. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 5
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 1
SECTION:
1-5-1: Meetings
 
Notes
1 1. See also city charter sections 49, 50, 51, 62 and 63.
1-5-1: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the board of commissioners will
be held at five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M. on the second and fourth Monday of
each month and at two o'clock (2:00) P.M. on the first and third Monday of each
month in the commissioners room of the city hall or at such other locations as
specified in the public notice of said meeting or as to which the commission
may, from time to time, adjourn and reconvene.
   B.   Special Or Emergency Meetings: Special or emergency meetings may be
held at any time and place in the city upon call by the mayor or any four (4)
members of the board of commissioners.
   C.   Conformance With Statute: All meetings, whether regular, special or
emergency, shall conform to requirements of the Oklahoma public meetings act 1
. (1980 Code § 2-16; amd. 2003 Code)
 
Notes
1 2. 25 OS § 301 et seq.
CHAPTER 6
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Officers And Personnel
1-6-2: City Manager
1-6-3: Finance Director
1-6-4: Compliance With Fair Labor Standards Act
1-6-1: OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL:
   A.   Officers Enumerated: The following positions are officers and are
nominated and confirmed annually and serve at the pleasure (at will) of the
board of commissioners for the good of the service:
      City manager
      Finance director/city clerk/city treasurer
      Police chief
      City attorney
      Municipal judge
      Fire chief
      General manager of Ponca City Energy
      Alternate municipal judge (Ord. 6225, 10-24-2016)
   B.   Other Employees And Personnel: Employment of all other employees and
personnel shall be the responsibility of the city manager. Such employees and
personnel shall serve at the pleasure (at will) of the city manager for the
good of the service.
   C.   Appointive Officers: The employment of all appointive officers and
employees is at will, and such officers and employees shall serve at the
pleasure of their appointive authority. No appointive officer or employee shall
have any right to employment, contractual or otherwise, or any property or
liberty interest in their continued employment. (1980 Code § 2-54; amd. 2003
Code)
1-6-2: CITY MANAGER:
   A.   Office Created: The office of city manager is hereby created. (1980
Code § 2-60)
   B.   Powers, Duties: The powers and duties of the city manager shall consist
of the following:
      1.   The power and duty to assist the board of commissioners in the
making of policies, through preliminary planning, recommendation, technical
assistance, reporting and providing information.
      2.   The power and duty to plan how the policies adopted by the board of
commissioners, or the people, may best be administered and executed, and to
organize the administrative personnel and the physical facilities of the city
to carry out such policies.
      3.   The power and duty to direct, control, supervise and coordinate all
administrative agencies, departments, officers and employees of the city,
including the officers listed in subsection 1-6-1A of this chapter.
      4.   The power and duty to see that proper records (financial and other)
are kept, and to keep the board of commissioners informed by making reports and
otherwise.
      5.   To see that the laws, ordinances and other policies of the city are
properly administered and executed.
      6.   To prepare a budget annually and submit it to the board of
commissioners, be responsible for the administration of the budget after it
goes into effect, and recommend to the board any changes in the budget which he
deems desirable.
      7.   To submit to the board of commissioners a report as of the end of
the fiscal year of the finances and administrative activities of the city for
the preceding year.
      8.   To keep the board advised of the financial condition and future
needs of the city, and make such recommendations as may seem to him desirable.
      9.   To appoint, promote, demote, suspend and terminate all employees and
personnel whose appointment is reserved to the city manager and whose positions
are not listed in subsection 1-6-1A of this chapter.
      10.   To perform such additional powers as are necessarily implied to
carry out his duties and responsibilities.
      11.   To perform such other duties as the board of commissioners may
prescribe. (1980 Code § 2-61; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Acting City Manager: In case of the temporary absence, disability or
suspension of the city manager, the board of commissioners may appoint an
acting city manager to serve until such absence, disability or suspension
ceases. The board may remove an acting city manager at any time. When there is
an assistant city manager, he shall be acting city manager in such cases until
the board provides otherwise. (1980 Code § 2-63)
   D.   Vacancies: In case of a vacancy in office, the same shall be filled
under the provisions of sections 62 and 68 of the city charter. (1980 Code § 2-
65)
1-6-3: FINANCE DIRECTOR:
   A.   Serve As Clerk And Treasurer: The chief financial officer of the city
shall be known as the finance director. The finance director will, among other
things, serve as the city clerk and city treasurer. (2003 Code)
   B.   Bond: The finance director shall give a good and sufficient bond in the
sum of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00), conditioned upon the
faithful discharge of all the duties of his office, such bond to be made in
favor of the city. (1980 Code § 2-74; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Duties As Clerk: The city clerk shall have the custody of all
ordinances, books and records of the city; he shall attest all documents signed
by the mayor and affix the seal of the city thereto where required; the city
clerk shall act as clerk of the board of commissioners and shall be present at
all of its meetings; he shall keep the records of paving districts and other
special assessments; he shall collect, receive, and deposit all monies due the
city daily; and shall do and perform all the duties in relation thereto as city
clerk as may be prescribed by the board of commissioners, the state statutes,
the provisions of this code and city ordinances. The city clerk, when
designated, shall supervise the city elections. (1980 Code § 2-73; amd. 2003
Code)
1-6-4: COMPLIANCE WITH FAIR LABOR STANDARDS ACT:
For purposes of interpretation of section 164 of the city charter, said charter
section shall be interpreted to be consistent with the federal fair labor
standards act, providing for executive and administrative exemptions, adopting
the definitions of "work week" and "overtime compensation". In the event of any
inconsistency or variance in the language or in an interpretation between said
section of the city charter and the fair labor standards act, the fair labor
standards act shall prevail. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 7
ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Precincts And Voting Locations
1-7-2: Conduct Of Elections
1-7-1: PRECINCTS AND VOTING LOCATIONS:
In the event the city clerk is directed to conduct a special election, the city
clerk shall be responsible for designating precincts and voting locations.
(1980 Code § 12-1; amd. 2003 Code)
1-7-2: CONDUCT OF ELECTIONS:
City elections shall be conducted pursuant to regulations and requirements of
state law, and shall be in compliance with section 122 of the city charter.
(2003 Code)
CHAPTER 8
MUNICIPAL CRIMINAL COURT 1
SECTION:
1-8-1: Definitions
1-8-2: Jurisdiction
1-8-3: Principal Officer Of Court
1-8-4: Prosecuting Officer
1-8-5: Assistant City Attorney
1-8-6: Court Clerk
1-8-7: Municipal Judge
1-8-8: Rules And General Procedure
1-8-9: Jury Trials
 
Notes
1 1. See section 73 of the city charter.
1-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
COURT: The municipal criminal court of this city.
JUDGE: The judge of the municipal criminal court, including any acting judge or
alternate judge thereof as provided for by the statutes of this state,
provisions of this code, and this chapter.
THIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT: The district court judicial district of the state
wherein the government of this municipality is situated. (1980 Code § 11-16)
1-8-2: JURISDICTION:
The court shall exercise original jurisdiction to hear and determine all
prosecutions wherein a violation of any provision of this code or ordinance of
this city is charged, including any such prosecutions transferred to the court
in accordance with applicable law. (1980 Code § 17)
1-8-3: PRINCIPAL OFFICER OF COURT:
The chief of police shall be the principal officer of the court. (1980 Code §
11-18)
1-8-4: PROSECUTING OFFICER:
The city attorney, or his duly designated assistant, shall be the prosecuting
officer of the court. He shall prosecute all alleged violations of the
provisions of this code and ordinances of the city. He shall be authorized, in
his discretion, to prosecute and resist appeals, proceedings in error and
review from this court to any other courts of the state, and to represent this
city in all proceedings arising out of matters in this court. (1980 Code § 11-
19)
1-8-5: ASSISTANT CITY ATTORNEY:
There is hereby created the office of assistant city attorney. The board of
commissioners shall appoint an assistant city attorney to serve for a term of
one year to be appointed at the first regular meeting of September along with
city officers. He shall be appointed in the same manner as provided for in the
charter of the city for city clerk, city attorney and city treasurer. (1980
Code § 11-20; amd. 2003 Code)
1-8-6: COURT CLERK:
   A.   Designated; Duties: That person designated by the city manager, shall
be the clerk of the court. He shall assist the judge in recording the
proceedings of the court and in preparing writs, processes and other papers. He
shall administer oaths required in proceedings in the dockets of the court. He
shall perform such other clerical duties relating to the proceedings of the
court as the judge shall direct. He shall receive and receipt for forfeitures,
fees, deposits and sums of monies payable to the court. He shall daily pay to
the finance director all monies so received by him, except such special
deposits or fees as shall be received to be disbursed by him for special
purposes. All monies paid to the finance director shall be placed in the
general fund of the city, or in such other fund as the board of commissioners
may direct, and it shall be used in the operation of the city government, or as
otherwise provided, in accordance with budgetary arrangements governing the
fund in which it is placed. (1980 Code § 11-21; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Bond: The clerk of the court shall give bond, in the form provided by
11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-111, in the sum of two thousand dollars
($2,000.00). When executed, said bond shall be submitted to the board of
commissioners for approval. When approved, it shall be filed with the city
clerk and retained in the city archives. (1980 Code § 11-22; amd. 2003 Code)
1-8-7: MUNICIPAL JUDGE:
   A.   Qualifications: There shall be two (2) judges of the court; namely a
municipal judge and an alternate municipal judge. A judge must be duly licensed
to practice law in the state. A judge may engage in the practice of law in
other courts, but he/she shall not accept employment inconsistent with his/her
duties as judge, or arising out of facts which give rise to or are connected
with cases within the jurisdiction of the court, pending therein or which might
become the subject of proceedings therein.
   B.   Term: The official term of each judge shall be one year, expiring as
other appointments made pursuant to section 62 of the charter.
   C.   Alternate Municipal Judge: The alternate municipal judge shall sit as
acting judge of the court in any matter if the municipal judge is:
      1.   Absent from the court,
      2.   Unable to act as judge,
      3.   Disqualified from acting as judge in the case.
   D.   Acting Judge: If, at any time, there is no municipal judge or alternate
municipal judge, duly appointed and qualified, available to sit as judge, the
mayor shall appoint some person, possessing the qualifications required by this
section for the judge, who shall preside, as acting judge, over the court in
the disposition of pending matters until such time as the municipal judge or
alternate municipal judge shall be available.
   E.   Filling Vacancy: Upon the occurrence of a vacancy in the office of any
judge, such vacancy shall be filled pursuant to the procedure provided in
section 62 of the charter. (Ord. 6016, 5-23-2005)
   F.   Retired Judges: Any person who has been a judge of the municipal court
and who has ceased to hold that position under honorable circumstances is
hereby determined to be a "retired judge" and shall be entitled to all the
rights and privileges of such a position as may be conferred by state law and
these ordinances. (Ord. 6015, 4-11-2005)
1-8-8: RULES AND GENERAL PROCEDURE:
   A.   Application Of District Court Rules: In all trials, as to matters not
covered in this chapter, or by the statutes relating to municipal criminal
courts, or by rules duly promulgated by the supreme court of Oklahoma, the
procedure applicable in trials of misdemeanors in the district courts shall
apply to the extent that they can be made effective. (1980 Code § 11-52)
   B.   Rules Authorized: The judges may prescribe rules, consistent with the
laws of the state, the provisions of this code, and with the ordinances of this
city, for the proper conduct of the business of the court. (1980 Code § 11-53)
   C.   Enforcement Of Rules, Orders: Obedience to the orders, rules and
judgments made by the judge or by the court may be enforced by the judge, who
may fine or imprison for contempt committed as to him while holding court, or
committed against process issued by him, in the same manner and to the same
extent as the district courts of this state. (1980 Code § 11-54)
   D.   Change Of Venue Denied; Disqualification Of Judge: In prosecutions
before the court no change of venue shall be allowed; but the judge before whom
the case is pending may certify his disqualification or he may be disqualified
from sitting under the terms, conditions and procedure provided by law for
courts of record. If a judge is disqualified, the matter shall be heard by the
alternate or acting judge, appointed as provided in this chapter. (1980 Code §
11-55; amd. 2003 Code)
   E.   Direction Of Writs, Process: All writs or process of the court shall be
directed, in his official title, to the chief of police. (1980 Code § 11-56)
   F.   Style Of Prosecutions: All prosecutions for violations of the
provisions of this code and ordinances of this city shall be styled "The City
of Ponca City v. (naming defendant or defendants)". (1980 Code § 11-57)
   G.   Initiation Of Complaints: Except as provided hereinafter, prosecutions
in the court shall be initiated by the filing of a written complaint,
subscribed and verified by the person making complaint, and setting forth
concisely the offense charged. (1980 Code § 11-58)
   H.   Issuance, Service Of Summons:
      1.   Upon the filing of a complaint charging violation of a provision of
this code or a city ordinance, the judge, unless he determines to issue a
warrant of arrest, or unless the defendant previously has been issued a
citation or has been arrested and has given bond for appearance, shall issue a
summons, naming the person charged, specifying his address or place of
residence, if known, stating the offense with which he is charged and giving
him notice to answer the charge in the court on a day certain, containing a
provision for the official return of the summons, and including such other
pertinent information as may be necessary.
      2.   The summons shall be served by delivering a copy to the defendant
personally. If he fails to appear and to answer the summons within the
prescribed period, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest. (1980 Code § 11-
59)
   I.   Issuance, Execution Of Arrest Warrant: Except as otherwise provided in
the provisions of this code or city ordinances, upon the filing of a complaint
approved by endorsement by the city attorney or by the judge, there shall be
issued a warrant of arrest, in substantially the following form:
The City of Ponca City to the Chief of Police of the City of Ponca City,
Oklahoma. Complaint upon oath having this day been made by (naming complainant)
that the offense of (naming the offense in particular but general terms) has
been committed and accusing (name of defendant) thereof, you are commanded
therefore forthwith to arrest the above named (name of defendant) and bring
(insert him, her or them, as appropriate) before me, at (naming the place).
Witness my hand this        day of           , 20     .
                                                          
       Judge of the Municipal Criminal Court
       of the City of Ponca City
(1980 Code § 11-60)
   J.   Bail For Appearance: Upon arrest, or upon appearance without arrest in
response to citation or summons, or at any other time before trial, before or
after arraignment, the defendant shall be eligible to be released upon giving
bail for his appearance in an amount and upon conditions fixed by the judge,
who shall prescribe appropriate rules of court for the receipt of bail. In case
of arrests made at night or under other conditions of emergency or when the
judge is not available, the rules shall authorize the chief of police, or his
designated representative, to accept a temporary cash bond, not less than ten
dollars ($10.00) nor more than the maximum monetary penalty provided for such
offense charged. (1980 Code § 11-61)
   K.   Arraignment: Upon making his appearance before the court, the defendant
shall be arraigned. The judge, or the city attorney, shall read the complaint
to the defendant, inform him of his legal rights, including the right of trial
by jury, if available, and of the consequences of conviction, and ask him
whether he pleads guilty or not guilty. If the defendant pleads guilty, the
court may proceed to judgment and sentence or may continue the matter for
subsequent disposition. If the plea is not guilty, and the case is not for jury
trial, the court may proceed to try the case, or may set it for hearing at a
later date. (1980 Code § 11-62)
   L.   Postponement: Before trial commences, either party, upon good cause
shown, may obtain a reasonable postponement thereof. (1980 Code § 11-63)
   M.   Personal Appearance: The defendant must be present in person at the
trial. (1980 Code § 11-64)
   N.   Procedure On Guilty Plea: If the defendant pleads guilty or is
convicted after trial, the court shall defer sentencing or render judgment
thereon, fixing the penalty within the limits prescribed by the applicable
provision of this code or city ordinance and imposing sentence accordingly.
(1980 Code § 11-65; amd. 2003 Code)
   O.   Witness Fees:
      1.   Witnesses in any proceeding in the court, other than police officers
or peace officers, shall be entitled to such fees per day, plus an amount for
each mile actually and necessarily traveled in going to and returning from the
place of attendance if their residence is outside the limits of the city, as
provided by 28 Oklahoma Statutes section 81. However, no witness shall receive
fees or mileage in more than one case for the same period of time or the same
travel. (1980 Code § 11-66; amd. 2003 Code)
      2.   A defendant seeking to subpoena witnesses must deposit with the
clerk a sum sufficient to cover fees and mileage for one day of attendance for
each witness to be summoned, but such deposit shall not be required from an
indigent defendant who files an affidavit setting out:
         a.   The names of no more than three (3) witnesses;
         b.   That the defendant, by reason of his poverty, is unable to
provide the fees and mileage allowed by law;
         c.   That the testimony of said witnesses is material; and
         d.   That their attendance at the trial is necessary for his proper
defense.
The fees of such witnesses shall be paid by the city. (1980 Code § 11-66)
   P.   Entry Of Judgment: At the close of trial, judgment must be rendered
immediately by the judge who shall cause it to be entered in his docket. (1980
Code § 11-67)
   Q.   Discharge Upon Acquittal: If judgment is of acquittal, and the
defendant is not to be detained for any other legal cause, he must be
discharged at once. (1980 Code § 11-68)
   R.   Suspension Or Deferment Of Sentence: After conviction and sentence, the
judge may defer or suspend sentence, in accordance with the provisions of, and
subject to the conditions and procedures imposed by, sections 27-123 and 27-124
of title 11, Oklahoma Statutes, as amended.
   S.   Court Costs: If judgment of conviction is entered, the judge shall tax
the costs to the defendant in such sum up to the maximum permissible by state
statute plus any additional fees required by statute, all of which the
defendant shall pay, in addition to any fine that may be imposed.
   T.   Execution Of Imprisonment: If, after conviction, judgment of
imprisonment is entered, a copy thereof, certified by the clerk, shall be
delivered to the chief of police, the sheriff of the county, or other
appropriate police officer. Such copy shall be sufficient warrant for execution
of the sentence. (1980 Code § 11-71; amd. 2003 Code)
1-8-9: JURY TRIALS:
   A.   In all prosecutions in the municipal court for any offense for which
the municipality, with the concurrence of the court, seeks imposition of a fine
of more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) excluding court costs, or
imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment, a jury trial shall be had
unless waived by the defendant and the municipality. In prosecutions for all
other offenses, or in cases wherein a jury trial is waived by the defendant and
the municipality, trial shall be to the court. At arraignment, the defendant
shall be asked whether he demands or waives trial by jury and this election
shall be recorded in the minutes of the arraignment and entered on the docket
of the court respecting proceedings in the case. The City Attorney or Assistant
City Attorney may announce at the time of the arraignment or at any time at
least two weeks prior to trial, that the maximum fine in the case shall be five
hundred dollars ($500.00) or less and that no jail time will be imposed; such
announcement shall then be binding on the court.
   B.   List Of Jurors:
      1.   Drawing Of Names: Whenever a calendar has been made up for the trial
of cases by jury, the judge shall request, in writing, the presiding judge of
the district court for this judicial district to cause the names of a stated
number of jurors, deemed sufficient to dispose of the cases on the calendar, to
be drawn from the jury wheel in accordance with the governing statutes of the
state, and to be certified by the clerk of the district court to the judge of
the municipal criminal court. The request shall be made in time for the list to
be certified and the jurors to be summoned legally before the trial of the
calendar begins.
      2.   Time Limit; Additional Drawing: If it is anticipated that the
completion of the calendar will require more than two (2) weeks, the request
for jurors shall specify the number required for each two (2) week period, as
provided by law for the drawing of jurors for the district court. Additional
drawing of other names also may be requested by the judge, when necessary, in
accordance with the law for such additional drawings in the district court.
      3.   Compliance With State Law: If, in the future, provisions of the law
respecting the drawing of jury lists for the district court are changed, the
judge shall take such steps, in requesting jury lists for the court, as are
necessary to comply with the state law. (1980 Code § 11-82)
   C.   Juror's Summons:
      1.   Form: Upon receipt of the jury list, the clerk of the court shall
cause a summons substantially in the following form to be issued and served
upon each person on the list:
State of Oklahoma )
         ) ss
   County of Kay )
To (name of juror) Greeting: You hereby are summoned to appear in the Municipal
Criminal Court for the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma, to be held at (specify the
address, room number, etc.) on the        day of         , 20    , at the hour
of (specify hour) to serve as a juror in said court, and to continue in such
service until discharged by the court.
Hereof fail not, under penalty of law.
Issued under the authority of said court, this        day of          , 20    .
                                                          
      Seal of Court   Clerk of the Municipal Criminal Court
         of the City of Ponca City, Oklahoma
(1980 Code § 11-83)
      2.   Service: Service of juror's summons shall be made as the judge may
prescribe by rule or direct by order, either in person upon the juror by the
chief of police or by any member of the police force of this city, or by the
clerk of the court, through certified mail, directed to the juror at his
address as given in the jury list, with request for a personally signed return
receipt. In any proceeding wherein service of summons by mail is in issue,
evidence of the due mailing of the summons by the clerk or a member of his
staff and the presentation of an official postal return receipt purportedly
signed by the addressee shall be prima facie evidence that the summons was duly
received by the addressee and, therefore, that he was properly served
therewith. (1980 Code § 11-84)
   D.   Composition Of Jury: A jury in the court shall consist of six (6)
jurors, good and lawful men or women, residents of the city possessing the
qualifications of jurors in district court. (1980 Code §11-85)
   E.   Duty Of Jurors: After the jurors are sworn, they must sit together and
hear the proofs and oral arguments of the parties, which must be delivered in
public and in the presence of the defendant. (1980 Code § 11-86)
   F.   Votes Required For Verdict: A verdict of the jury may be rendered by
the vote of five (5) jurors. (1980 Code § 11-87)
   G.   Duties Of Judge: In all actions tried before a jury, the judge shall
determine all questions of law, including questions as to the introduction of
evidence, arising during the trial. He also shall instruct the jury as to the
law. (1980 Code § 11-88)
   H.   Nature Of Verdict: The verdict of the jury, in all cases, must be
general. When the jury has arrived at its verdict, it must deliver the verdict
publicly to the court. The judge must enter the verdict in the docket or cause
it to be so entered. (1980 Code § 11-89)
   I.   Discharge Restricted: The jury must not be discharged after the cause
is submitted to it until a verdict is rendered, unless the judge, for good
cause, discharges it sooner; in which event, the court may proceed again to
trial and so on until a verdict is rendered. (1980 Code § 11-90)
   J.   Fees: Jurors shall receive for their services such sum as provided by
statute for municipal courts not of record, or in the absence of such statute,
then as provided for jurors in criminal trials in the district courts. Jurors
shall be paid out of the general funds of the city. (1980 Code § 11-91; amd.
2003 Code; amd. Ord. 6267, 5-28-2019)

CHAPTER 3
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT/PUBLIC SAFETY DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2-3-1: Department Established
2-3-2: Office Of Director Created
2-3-3: Qualifications
2-3-4: Duties And Responsibilities
2-3-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of emergency management/public safety
in the municipal government of the city. (1980 Code § 2-123)
2-3-2: OFFICE OF DIRECTOR CREATED:
The office of director of emergency management/public safety is hereby created.
(1980 Code § 2-124)
2-3-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The director of emergency management/public safety shall, prior to his
appointment to such office, have comprehensive knowledge of emergency
management, disaster preparedness, public safety communications, and safety and
training methods. He shall have demonstrated ability to foster and maintain
cooperative relationships with other department heads, city officials, federal
and state agencies, and the general public. Such officer should demonstrate
resourcefulness, sound judgment in emergencies, demonstrated integrity, tact,
and be in good physical condition. He shall also have a good knowledge of the
geography of the city. (1980 Code § 2-125; amd. 2003 Code)
2-3-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Generally: The director of emergency management/public safety shall:
      1.   Perform the administrative duties in directing the activities and
personnel for emergency management, and such other areas as may be assigned.
(1980 Code § 2-127; amd. 2003 Code)
      2.   Be responsible for meeting with the public, both individually and
collectively, concerning emergency management, public safety communications.
      3.   Be responsible to see that all reports are prepared as may be
required by the city manager, city commission and state and federal agencies
regarding emergency management.
      4.   Attend state, regional and national emergency management information
agency meetings and seminars as may be required by the city manager.
      5.   Have such other duties as may be assigned. (1980 Code § 2-126)
   B.   Coordination Of Activities: The director shall evaluate and coordinate
all the safety activities of all departments of the city, and where he finds
deficiencies he shall make recommendations to the heads of the departments for
the correction of all unsafe procedures. (1980 Code § 2-127)
   C.   Rules And Regulations: The director of emergency management/public
safety shall make all rules and regulations for the operation of the department
as may be necessary subject to the approval of the board of commissioners.
(1980 Code § 2-128)

shall be established a plumbing, mechanical, electrical 1 , and building
inspector. Each inspector shall enforce the ordinances, codes and laws relating
to plumbing, mechanical, electrical, buildings and property maintenance, and
shall otherwise perform other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance. The
phrase "building official", and "code official", when referred to in the
ordinances and laws of the city, shall be deemed to mean one or more of the
code inspectors. (2003 Code)

SECTION:

2-7-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a police department in the municipal government of
the city. (1980 Code § 28-16)
2-7-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Department Head: The head of the police department shall be an officer
entitled the chief of police. (1980 Code § 28-17)
   B.   Powers, Duties: The chief of police shall have such powers and duties
as may be prescribed by law, the city charter, this code and city ordinance.
(1980 Code § 28-18)
2-7-3: RESERVE POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   Appointment: Reserve police officers may be appointed by the chief of
police. Reserve police officers shall have the powers, duties and functions as
set forth in 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 34-101B and this code. Reserve police
officers shall serve on a part time basis and shall perform duties only while
on authorized duty. (2003 Code)
   B.   Minimum Requirements: Reserve officers appointed must meet minimum
requirements as established by 70 Oklahoma Statutes section 3311. (1980 Code §
28-32)
   C.   Hours Of Duty Limited: The duty of reserve municipal police officers is
limited to not more than one hundred ten (110) hours per calendar month. (1980
Code § 28-33; amd. 2003 Code)
2-7-4: DISPOSITION OF PERSONAL PROPERTY, MONEY OR LEGAL TENDER:
The chief of police is authorized to dispose of personal property, money or
legal tender which has come into his possession in accordance with 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 34-104, or as such provision is hereafter amended. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 8
FIRE DEPARTMENT 1
SECTION:
2-8-1: Department Established
2-8-2: Chief Of Fire Department
2-8-3: Ambulance Service
2-8-4: Sole Provider Ambulance System
 
Notes
1 1. See section 142 of the city charter.
2-8-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a fire department in the municipal government of
the city. (1980 Code § 14-16)
2-8-2: CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Department Head: The head of the fire department shall be an officer
entitled fire chief or chief of the fire department. (1980 Code § 14-17)
   B.   Powers; Duties: The fire chief shall have such powers and duties as may
be prescribed by law, the city charter, the provisions of this code and the
ordinances of the city. (1980 Code § 14-18)
2-8-3: AMBULANCE SERVICE:
   A.   Service Created: There is hereby created an emergency medical services
program within the fire department, to include ambulance service. (1980 Code §
14-29)
   B.   Scope Of Service: EMS/ambulance service shall be furnished throughout
the city and its general vicinity as determined by the fire chief through
standard operating procedures for the fire department. (1980 Code § 14-30)
   C.   Rates: (Rep. by Ord. 6023, 6-27-2005)
   D.   Administration Generally: The ambulance service is placed under the
fire chief or such other persons as may be designated by him for administrative
control. (1980 Code § 14-32)
   E.   General Operation: The operation of the ambulance service shall be
performed by the members of the fire department in such manner as shall be
ordered by the fire chief or by representatives designated by him. (1980 Code §
14-33)
   F.   Inspection Of Equipment: The fire chief, or some member of said
department authorized by him, shall once in each month examine the condition of
ambulances and all ambulance equipment and make a report on the condition of
the same to the mayor. (1980 Code § 14-34)
   G.   Records: The fire chief shall keep a complete record in his office of
all runs made by the city ambulances, the names of the patients, the point
where the patient was received and the place to which the patient was
delivered. (1980 Code § 14-35)
2-8-4: SOLE PROVIDER AMBULANCE SYSTEM:
   A.   The emergency medical service operated by the city of Ponca City, or
its assignee, shall be the sole provider for all of the ground vehicle
ambulance service, both emergency and nonemergency, within the corporate city
limits and shall hold the city's exclusive ambulance license, as authorized by
state statute.
   B.   All ambulance calls originating within the corporate city limits of the
city must utilize the emergency medical service of the city of Ponca City or
its assignee.
   C.   All ambulance services operating outside of the corporate city limits
of the city must first obtain authorization from the emergency medical service
dispatch prior to operating within the city of Ponca City. (Ord. 6023, 6-27-
2005)

TITLE 3
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING AGENCIES
ARTICLE A. PLANNING COMMISSION
SECTION:
3-1A-1: Commission Created; Appointment
3-1A-2: Composition
3-1A-3: Terms
3-1A-4: Officers
3-1A-5: Compensation
3-1A-6: Quorum, Voting
3-1A-7: Rules And Regulations
3-1A-8: Duties, Powers And Functions
3-1A-9: Personnel
3-1A-10: Planning Commission Act As Zoning Commission
3-1A-11: Traffic Evaluation And Planning
3-1A-1: COMMISSION CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created in and for the city a planning commission. The mayor
shall appoint the members of the city planning commission subject to approval
and confirmation by the board of city commissioners. (1980 Code §§ 26-21, 26-
23)
3-1A-2: COMPOSITION:
The city planning commission shall consist of nine (9) citizens of the city as
hereinafter provided. The members of the commission shall be nominated and
appointed solely with reference to their fitness and without reference to party
affiliation, and shall represent, insofar as possible, different professions
and occupations existing in the city. (1980 Code § 26-22)
3-1A-3: TERMS:
The members of the city planning commission shall hold office for a term of
three (3) years, and until their successors are appointed and qualified;
provided, however, that they shall be appointed in such a manner that the terms
of three (3) members shall expire each year. (1980 Code § 26-24; amd. 2003
Code)
3-1A-4: OFFICERS:
The members of the city planning commission shall meet within two (2) weeks
after their appointment and confirmation and organize by electing from their
members a chairman and vice chairman. (1980 Code § 26-26; amd. 2003 Code)
3-1A-5: COMPENSATION:
The members of the city planning commission shall serve as such without
compensation. (1980 Code § 26-29)
3-1A-6: QUORUM, VOTING:
   A.   Quorum: Five (5) members of the city planning commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business and an affirmative majority
vote of the quorum shall be required to approve any item of business. (1980
Code § 26-25; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Constraints On Voting: A planning commission member shall not vote on
any question or matter being considered by the planning commission in which he
or she shall have a direct personal or financial interest. (1980 Code § 26-28)
3-1A-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The members of the city planning commission shall adopt from time to time
bylaws, rules and regulations, and amendments thereto, as may be necessary to
effectuate the purposes of this article. (1980 Code § 26-28)
3-1A-8: DUTIES, POWERS AND FUNCTIONS:
   A.   Preparation Of Plans: It shall be the duty of the city planning
commission to prepare, from time to time, a master plan for the city. (1980
Code § 26-30; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Consideration, Investigation And Report:
      1.   The planning commission may consider and investigate any subject
matter tending to the development and betterment of the city, and make
recommendations as it may deem advisable concerning the adoption thereof to any
department of the municipal government, and for any purpose make, or cause to
be made, surveys, maps or plans. Before final action shall be taken by the
board of city commissioners, or any department of the city government, on the
location and design of any public building, statue, memorial, park, parkway,
boulevard, street and alley, playgrounds, public grounds, bridge, or the change
in location of any street or alley, or the grade thereof, such question shall
be submitted to the city planning commission for investigation and report.
      2.   All plans, plats or replats of land laid out in lots or plats, and
streets, alleys or other portions of the same intended to be dedicated to
public or private use within the corporate limits of the city, shall first be
submitted to the city planning commission for its approval or rejection. (1980
Code § 26-32)
3-1A-9: PERSONNEL:
The city planning commission shall have the power and authority to employ
engineers, attorneys, clerks and a secretary, or other help deemed necessary,
subject to the approval of the board of city commissioners. The salary and
compensation of such employees shall be fixed by the board of city
commissioners, and shall be paid out of the city treasury as other officers and
employees, and the necessary expenses incurred by said commission shall be paid
out of the city treasury as other legal expense of the city government. (1980
Code § 26-31)
3-1A-10: PLANNING COMMISSION ACT AS ZONING COMMISSION:
   A.   The city planning commission is hereby appointed the zoning commission
of the city; and the city planning commission shall have the powers of a zoning
commission as provided by state law. Whether exercising the powers of a
planning commission or the powers of a zoning commission, it shall be legally
one board known as the city planning commission.
   B.   Exercising the powers of a zoning commission, the city planning
commission shall recommend the boundaries of the various zones and appropriate
zoning regulations to be enforced therein. It shall have all the powers
expressly conferred upon it by state law and city charter or ordinance, and
those powers necessarily implied thereby. (1980 Code § 26-34; amd. 2003 Code)
3-1A-11: TRAFFIC EVALUATION AND PLANNING:
The planning commission shall have the authority to coordinate official traffic
activities of the several departments of the city, to supervise the preparation
and publication of traffic reports, to receive complaints having to do with
traffic matters, and to recommend to the board of commissioners and to the city
traffic engineer, the chief of the traffic division, and other city officials,
ways and means of improving traffic conditions and administration and
enforcement of traffic regulations. The approval of all or any part of said
recommendations of the planning commission relative to the placement of traffic
control devices for which said commission's recommendation is provided in this
chapter by the board of commissioners shall have the same force and effect of
law as if a separate ordinance were passed for each of said recommendations.
(Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
ARTICLE B. BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT
SECTION:
3-1B-1: Board Created
3-1B-1: BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created in and for the city a board of adjustment. See section
11-17-8 of this code for provisions regarding the zoning board of appeals.
(1980 Code § 26-46; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 2
PERSONNEL BOARD
SECTION:
3-2-1: Board Established; Composition
3-2-2: Qualifications
3-2-3: Terms Of Office
3-2-4: Organization And Officials
3-2-5: Advisor To Board
3-2-6: Vacancies; Removals
3-2-7: Compensation
3-2-8: Duties
3-2-9: Hearing Procedure; Scope Of Disciplinary Action
3-2-10: Investigations
3-2-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby created a personnel board consisting of three (3) members
appointed by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 2-241)
3-2-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
Members of the board shall be persons in sympathy with the application of merit
principles to public employment. No member of the board shall be employed by or
be an elected or appointed official of the city, or be a member of any local,
state or national committee of a political party or an official or member of a
committee in any partisan political club or organization. Nor shall any member
hold or be a candidate for an elective office. (1980 Code § 2-242)
3-2-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
The members of the board shall serve for terms of three (3) years, provided
that in the appointment of the first board that the board of commissioners
shall appoint one member for a term of one year, one for a term of two (2)
years, and one for a term of three (3) years. (1980 Code § 2-243)
3-2-4: ORGANIZATION AND OFFICIALS:
Immediately after their appointment, and on the first meeting of each year
thereafter, the personnel board shall meet and organize by electing from their
number a president and secretary. The board shall establish its own rules of
procedure and establish its own meeting times. (1980 Code § 2-244)
3-2-5: ADVISOR TO BOARD:
The city manager shall serve as the city's advisor to the personnel board.
(1980 Code § 2-245)
3-2-6: VACANCIES; REMOVALS:
   A.   Vacancies: Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of
term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original
appointments are made. (1980 Code § 2-246)
   B.   Removal From Office: Members appointed to the board may, after public
hearing, be removed by the board of commissioners for inefficiency, neglect of
duty or malfeasance in office. (1980 Code § 2-247)
3-2-7: COMPENSATION:
Members of the personnel board shall serve without compensation but shall be
reimbursed for any expenses approved by the board of commissioners and incurred
in the performance of their assigned duties. (1980 Code § 2-248)
3-2-8: DUTIES:
In addition to the duties set forth elsewhere in this chapter, the personnel
board shall:
   A.   Advise the city manager and the board of commissioners on matters of
personnel policy and problems of personnel administration.
   B.   Represent the interest in the improvement of personnel administration
in the city's service.
   C.   Make any inquiry which it may consider desirable concerning personnel
administration in the city's service.
   D.   Make recommendations to the city manager or the board of commissioners
with respect thereto.
   E.   Hear appeals, receive evidence and determine facts, and affirm, modify
or reverse the administrative action appealed from and direct the proper action
to be taken. (1980 Code § 2-249)
3-2-9: HEARING PROCEDURE; SCOPE OF DISCIPLINARY ACTION:
   A.   Employee Request For Hearing: If an employee files a request with the
personnel board for a hearing as provided for in the city's personnel policy
and procedure manual, the personnel board shall schedule a hearing at the
earliest possible time, but in no case later than three (3) weeks from the date
of receipt of the request. At the discretion of the employee the hearing may be
private or open to the public.
   B.   Informal Procedure: In conducting the hearing, the procedure shall be
informal and it shall be assumed that the action complained of was taken in
good faith unless proved otherwise.
   C.   Action Favoring Employee: If the personnel board finds the action
appealed from was improper, the employee shall be reinstated to his/her former
position without loss of pay or the personnel board may impose a lesser form of
disciplinary action, but in no case shall disciplinary action be increased.
(1980 Code § 2-250)
3-2-10: INVESTIGATIONS:
During the course of any investigation or hearing, the personnel board may
request any employee of the city to attend to give witness. Any employee
refusing to do so may be subject to disciplinary action as provided in the
city's personnel policy and procedure manual. (1980 Code § 2-251)
CHAPTER 3
AIRPORT DIVISION; ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
3-3-1: Airport Division
3-3-2: Airport Advisory Board
3-3-1: AIRPORT DIVISION:
   A.   Division Established: There is hereby established an airport division
in the municipal government of the city. (1980 Code § 4-16)
   B.   Airport Manager:
      1.   Division Head: The head of the airport division shall be entitled
the airport manager. (1980 Code § 4-17)
      2.   Powers, Duties: The airport manager shall have the supervision and
control of the city airport, and shall serve as staff liaison to the airport
advisory committee. Such person shall have such other powers and duties as may
be prescribed by this code or city ordinance. (1980 Code § 4-18)
3-3-2: AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD:
   A.   Board Established: There is hereby established in and for the city a
board which shall be known as the airport advisory board. (1980 Code § 4-33)
   B.   Composition: The airport advisory board shall be composed of five (5)
regular members. (1980 Code § 4-34)
   C.   Appointment: The members of the airport advisory board shall be
appointed in the manner provided by section 62 of the city charter. (1980 Code
§ 4-35)
   D.   Terms: There shall be five (5) regular members of the airport advisory
board, and they shall serve for terms of three (3) years each. Each shall serve
until their successor is duly appointed and qualified. (1980 Code § 4-36)
   E.   Ex Officio Member: The mayor shall be an ex officio member of the
airport advisory board. (1980 Code § 4-37)
   F.   Compensation For Expenses: The members of the airport advisory board
shall serve as such without pay or other remuneration except such expenses as
shall actually be expended and allowances as may be approved by the board of
commissioners. (1980 Code § 4-38)
   G.   Organization: The airport advisory board shall organize itself and
shall hold open meetings and keep records and minutes of its meetings as
provided by law. (1980 Code § 4-39)
   H.   Meetings: The airport advisory board shall meet on call as often as may
be required. (1980 Code § 4-40)
   I.   Duties: It shall be the duty of the airport advisory board to advise
and recommend to the board of commissioners the planning, development,
construction, enlargement, improvement, maintenance, equipment, operation,
regulation, protection and policing of the municipal airport and such
additional land adjacent to the airport as is subject to the jurisdiction of
the federal aviation association. (1980 Code § 4-41)
CHAPTER 4
E.W. MARLAND ESTATE COMMISSION
SECTION:
3-4-1: Commission Created; Appointment
3-4-2: Derivation Of Authority; Existence
3-4-3: Terms
3-4-4: Termination
3-4-5: Compensation
3-4-6: Ex Officio Members
3-4-7: General Purpose; Organization
3-4-8: Director Of Estate
3-4-9: Fiscal Officer
3-4-10: Derivation, Use Of Income
3-4-11: Status Of Personnel
3-4-1: COMMISSION CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
   A.   Creation: There is hereby created under the general authority and
supervision of the board of commissioners a special commission, which shall be
known as the E.W. Marland Estate commission, herein referred to as the
commission. (1980 Code § 2-175)
   B.   Composition: The commission shall consist of eleven (11) persons,
including a chairman, all of whom shall not be less than eighteen (18) years of
age. (Ord. 6111, 11-23-2009)
   C.   Appointments: Nomination and confirmation of membership on the
commission shall be made on the second Monday of May each year and shall be in
compliance with section 62 of the city charter. (1980 Code § 2-179)
3-4-2: DERIVATION OF AUTHORITY; EXISTENCE:
The commission created under the provisions of this chapter shall derive its
authority from the board of commissioners. It shall continue in existence
perpetually or until dissolved by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 2-
176)
3-4-3: TERMS:
   A.   Terms Specified: Members shall be appointed to three (3) year terms,
staggered so that approximately one-third (1/3) of the members' terms expire
each year. (Ord. 6111, 11-23-2009)
   B.   Number Of Terms; Filling A Vacancy: No member of the commission shall
succeed himself for more than one additional term. Initial terms which fill a
vacancy shall not be included as a term.
   C.   Vacancies: Vacancies occurring in the membership of the Marland Estate
commission shall be filled pursuant to section 62 of the city charter for the
balance of the unexpired term. (1980 Code § 2-180)
3-4-4: TERMINATION:
Failure to attend three (3) consecutive meetings by any member of the
commission shall result in a termination of membership for such member upon
recommendation of the city manager unless the board of commissioners shall
waive such absences for good cause shown. (1980 Code § 2-181)
3-4-5: COMPENSATION:
No compensation shall be paid for services rendered as a member of the E.W.
Marland Estate commission. Expenses incurred in direct service to said
commission, if approved by the city manager, may be submitted as a claim for
consideration by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 2-182)
3-4-6: EX OFFICIO MEMBERS:
The city manager shall be an ex officio member of the commission, along with
the director of the E.W. Marland Estate who shall serve as a resource to the
commission and provide appropriate staff services. (1980 Code § 2-183)
3-4-7: GENERAL PURPOSE; ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Submit Advice And Recommendations: The general purpose of "the
commission" shall be advisory in nature and as a recommending body to the board
of commissioners. The commission shall recommend policies, regulations, rules,
space allocation, uses and user fees, an annual budget and a plan for long
range development, which shall be reviewed and updated regularly. These
recommendations shall be consistent with the provisions of dedicatory
resolution 3204, relating to the E.W. Marland estate, wherein the E.W. Marland
estate has been perpetually dedicated to "... cultural, educational,
historical, recreational and similarly related purposes". It shall advise the
board of commissioners through the city manager; submit written reports as
required and minutes of its meetings and perform other functions required by
the board of commissioners.
   B.   Officers: The members of the Marland estate commission shall, in May of
each year, elect the following officers: chairperson, vice chairperson and such
other offices as it may deem necessary. In the event the commission is unable
to successfully fill either of these offices by means of election, the mayor
may be asked to fill the office(s) by appointment. The officers shall be
elected for a one year term. Further excepting, that no officer shall serve
more than two (2) successive terms in the same office. The commission may
create an annual program of work to achieve the long range plan and may
structure itself through committees and task forces to accomplish the program
of work. The commission shall prepare and submit to the board of commissioners
an annual report reflecting progress of and direction for the outlined program
of work.
