6-2A-5: PERFORMANCE OF WORK BY CITY:
   A.   In the event that any condition declared to be a nuisance under this
chapter is not remedied within ten (10) days after notice, the city may abate
the nuisance, or cause the same to be abated through a contractor.
   B.   In the event the city abates the nuisance, the appropriate city
official shall keep a due and proper account of the cost of abating the
nuisance and shall, if the abatement be performed by city personnel, certify
the account to the city clerk, who, in turn, shall certify the account to the
city commission, and the city commission shall ascertain the cost of the
abatement. Whether abated by the city or through a contractor employed by the
city, the costs of abating the nuisance shall be assessed as a special tax
against the lot or parcel of land in connection with which the nuisance exists,
is growing or against the lot or parcel of land adjacent to which the
vegetation or other landscaping exists. If work to abate the nuisance is to be
performed through a contractor, the procedure provided in section
6-1-8 of this title shall be followed.
   C.   The cost of abatement shall be certified by the city clerk to the
county assessor to be placed upon the tax rolls for collection as other
assessments in similar cases made and provided. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
6-2A-6: NOTICE; HOW GIVEN:
   A.   Written Notice: At least ten (10) days' written notice shall be given
to the owner and, if different than the owner, the resident of the property by
mail at the address shown by the current year's tax rolls in the county
treasurer's office before any remedial action may be taken by city. Such notice
may further be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law.
   B.   Contents Of Notice: The notice to abate the nuisance issued under the
provisions of this chapter, shall contain:
      1.   An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing through the
municipal court clerk within ten (10) days.
      2.   The location of the nuisance, a description of what constitutes the
nuisance and a statement of the acts necessary to abate the nuisance.
      3.   A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no
request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate
such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person and further that
the costs of abatement will become a lien against the property where the
nuisance exists.
      4.   An order that it be abated or removed within ten (10) days, unless a
longer time period is established by the code enforcement officer because of
the extent of the nuisance or difficulty in removing it would compel a
reasonable person to believe the same could not be accomplished by a normal
person, exercising due diligence, within ten (10) days. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
6-2A-7: APPEAL OF DETERMINATION BY CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
   A.   Development Services Director Designated As Administrative Hearing
Officer: Any appeal of determinations made by a code enforcement officer under
this chapter shall be made to the development services director, or in his
absence the building inspector, who, for purposes of this chapter, is hereby
designated as the administrative hearing officer. (Ord. 6102, 7-13-2009)
   B.   Requesting A Hearing: Any person who believes themselves aggrieved by a
determination of a code enforcement officer under this chapter, may appeal such
determination by requesting a hearing of the matter before the administrative
hearing officer and payment of a filing fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00).
Such hearing shall be de novo, with the burden of proof upon the city to
establish its burden by clear and convincing evidence. In the event the
appellant is successful, the court, in its discretion, may order the filing fee
refunded the appellant. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004; amd. Ord. 6102, 7-13-2009)
   C.   Right To Appeal To Commission: The property owner or occupant shall
have the right of appeal to the board of commissioners from any order or
determination of the administrative hearing officer. Such appeal shall be taken
by filing written notice of appeal with the city clerk within five (5) days
after the administrative order is rendered. Once again the burden shall be upon
the city to establish its burden by clear and convincing evidence.
   D.   Risk Of Serious Injury: In the event a condition exists which creates
an imminent risk of serious injury to persons or property such that notice to
the owner or occupant and the time limitations imposed thereby are an
unacceptable risk, the city may immediately cause the condition to be abated.
In such instance the city shall keep a forced account of its efforts, shall
document the condition abated, shall notify the owner or occupant of the
abatement and inform them that they have thirty (30) days to pay the cost
thereof or may appeal the imposition of costs by requesting a hearing within
ten (10) days of the date of the notice. Such request shall be made to the
municipal court clerk who, upon payment of a filing fee of thirty five dollars
($35.00) by the appellant, shall docket the same for hearing before the
administrative hearing officer. If, upon hearing, the administrative hearing
officer shall determine either: 1) that the condition, although being in
violation of this chapter, was not an imminent threat, or 2) that the condition
did not violate any provision of this chapter, then the costs of abatement
shall not be charged to the owner or occupant and the filing fee shall be
refunded. If the administrative hearing officer shall determine that the
summary abatement was proper, or no appeal is timely taken after receipt of
notice of the abatement by the city, the owner or occupant shall have the
opportunity to pay the abatement costs and if the same are not paid within
thirty (30) days, the department performing the abatement shall certify the
account to the city commission, and the city commission shall ascertain the
cost of the abatement. Such amount shall then be forwarded to the county
consistent with the procedure provided by state law to be placed upon the
property as a lien. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
6-2A-8: FAILURE TO ABATE; OFFENSE:
Any owner or occupant of such lot or parcel of land who shall fail, refuse or
neglect to trim or remove any tree, shrubs, plants, fences, or landscaping as
required by this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense, and each and
every day that said owner shall fail, refuse or neglect to abate the nuisance
shall be a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
6-2A-9: PRIVATE TREES OVERHANGING PRIVATE PROPERTY:
The owners of any tree on private property overhanging any other abutting
private property shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken
or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of persons or property
on abutting private property. If limbs from a tree or bush on private property
overhang or extend onto other private property in such a manner as to touch,
including intermittent touching, buildings, trees or bushes or other structures
or improvements, or interfere with the passage thereon or the reasonable
enjoyment thereof, it shall be the duty of the owner of the property on which
the tree or bush is located to keep said tree or bush trimmed so as to avoid
said touching, obstruction of passage or so that the enjoyment of the abutting
property is not interfered with. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE, REFUSE AND TRASH
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Functions Of Solid Waste Division
6-3-3: City Removal Authority; Contract
6-3-4: Unauthorized Collectors
6-3-5: Rental Agents Provide Refuse Service
6-3-6: Occupant And Owner Request Refuse Service
6-3-7: Garbage Container Requirements And Restrictions
6-3-8: Collection Of Garbage And Refuse
6-3-9: Residential And Business Collection Schedule
6-3-10: Rates And Charges
6-3-11: Transporting Garbage
6-3-12: Noncollectible Waste
6-3-13: Refuse Disposal At City Landfill
6-3-14: Littering; Burying
6-3-15: Depositing And Scattering
6-3-16: Collection Of Ashes
6-3-17: Cleanliness
6-3-18: Protection From Rats; Container Base
6-3-19: Littering Prohibited
6-3-20: Duty Of Owners Abutting Alley
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
ASHES: Shall include all ashes of wood, coal and coke and the residue resulting
from the combustion of any material or substance, soot, cinders, slug or
charcoal.
BRUSH: Shall include trees, tree branches, shrubbery, trimmings from trees and
shrubbery, grass, leaves or any other plant material related to yard
maintenance.
BUSINESS, COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT OR INSTITUTION: Shall include any building
or structure or premises not defined herein as a "residence".
CITY: The city of Ponca City.
COLLECTION ROUTE: Shall include "refuse route" and mean a prescribed line of
travel by crews and equipment engaged and used at regular stated intervals in
the collection, transportation and delivering of refuse for disposal.
CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: Shall be deemed to include excess materials that have been
discarded or unused as a result of the construction, repair or demolition of
any building, structure, or project and shall include, but not be limited to,
lumber, shingles, insulation, sheetrock, paper, plastic, concrete and concrete
tailings, the accumulation of which may create a nuisance or be deleterious to
public health or offensive to sight.
GARBAGE: Shall be deemed to include animal, fruit and vegetable waste materials
resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of foods in
kitchens, stores, markets, hotels, restaurants and other places where food is
stored, cooked or consumed.
NONCOLLECTIBLE WASTE: Shall include poisons, acids, caustics, explosives, body
wastes, automobile frames, large bulky objects such as stoves, refrigerators,
hot water heaters, furniture, trees, and materials that may cause damage to
collection equipment or personal injury to collectors, dirt, rocks, or other
debris resulting from construction, reconstruction or repairs of premises,
grass clippings, animal excreta, dead animals, or any article or substance
soiled by human or animal excreta that has not been wrapped and tightly sealed
in moistureproof paper prior to placement for collection, and refuse which has
been combined or mixed with any of the above mentioned objects or items.
OCCUPANT OF PREMISES: The occupant of any premises within the city of Ponca
City.
OWNER: The owner of all premises where more than one family resides on a lot or
parcel of land, or adjoining lots or parcels of land belonging to the same
person, unless the premises occupied by each family, including the yards, are
clearly defined and under the exclusive control of the occupant.
PICK UP POINT: Any premises regularly serviced by the department of public
works, solid waste division.
PREMISES: Land, buildings, or other structures or parts thereof, upon or in
which refuse is stored or accumulated.
REFUSE: Putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, including garbage, rubbish
and trash.
RENTAL AGENT: The agent, contractor or employee in charge of the renting or
maintenance of any premises occupied by more than one family.
RESIDENCE: Any building or structure used solely as a family domicile including
single- and multi-family dwelling units, apartments, rooming houses, boarding
houses, and trailer courts, but shall not include hotels, tourist courts,
motels, motor courts, motor hotels or apartment hotels.
RUBBISH: A normal accumulation by resident families or commercial
establishments of worthless, offensive matter, the accumulation of which may
create a nuisance or be deleterious to public health or offensive to sight or
smell but shall not include items or objects defined herein as noncollectible
wastes.
SPECIAL HANDLING WASTE: A waste that is integrated in the municipal solid waste
area of the landfill which requires extra attention. Examples are as follows:
documents which must be covered immediately, sludge which must be dried by
mixing with dirt, and nuisance materials such as carbon black.
TRASH: Nonputrescible solid wastes, including excessive accumulations of
household rubbish, but shall not include waste matter that is not in a proper
container as provided herein.
UNDUE ACCUMULATION: The accumulation of garbage, rubbish or trash in amounts
exceeding the capacity of the waste receptacle at the pick up point or at the
point of disposal. (1980 Code § 16-1; amd. Ord. 6109, 11-9-2009)
6-3-2: FUNCTIONS OF SOLID WASTE DIVISION:
The solid waste department shall assist in maintaining good general sanitation
and health conditions in the city by collecting, transporting and delivering
for disposal, and disposing in a safe and sanitary manner all garbage, rubbish
and trash collected within the city. (1980 Code § 16-31; amd. 2003 Code)
6-3-3: CITY REMOVAL AUTHORITY; CONTRACT:
The board of commissioners is hereby exclusively authorized and empowered to
provide by contract or otherwise for the collection, removal and disposal of
trash, garbage or refuse within the corporate limits thereof, and no person,
firm, or corporation shall engage in the removal or disposal of trash, garbage
or refuse within the city, either from their own premises or premises of
another, unless specifically authorized to do so by contract or other written
authority of said board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 16-30)
6-3-4: UNAUTHORIZED COLLECTORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation other than trash or
garbage collectors of the city, duly authorized by the board of commissioners,
their agents, servants or employees, to remove any trash or garbage from any
trash or garbage container in the city. (1980 Code § 16-27)
6-3-5: RENTAL AGENTS PROVIDE REFUSE SERVICE:
No rental agent shall rent any portion of any premises within the city and
occupied by more than one family or person, or permit occupancy of any portion
of the premises, unless the owner has provided refuse services and otherwise
complied with the provisions of this chapter. (1980 Code § 16-28)
6-3-6: OCCUPANT AND OWNER REQUEST REFUSE SERVICE:
   A.   Notify Clerk's Office: Every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any premises within the city shall notify the utility billing
office of the beginning of such occupancy and request refuse pick up service.
Failure of any owner, rental agent or occupant of such premises to make such a
request shall not prevent, nor in any way impair or impede the city clerk's
office from: (1980 Code § 16-29; amd. 2003 Code)
      1.   Adding the address of the premises to the proper refuse collection
route records;
      2.   Providing such service;
      3.   Enforcing by appropriate action the regulatory measures prescribed
in this chapter and causing the fee or charge thereof to be paid.
   B.   Occupancy, Evidence Of Garbage Accumulation: Any place, abode or
residence, or any place of business occupied and/or in operation shall be prima
facie evidence that garbage, rubbish and/or trash is being produced and
accumulated on the premises. (1980 Code § 16-29)
6-3-7: GARBAGE CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Business Establishments:
      1.   Containers Furnished By City: The owners and/or operator of such
business, commercial establishment or institution in the city, being served by
the city solid waste department shall be furnished adequate refuse containers
at or near the rear of such establishment by the city. Charges for such
containers and collection service shall be provided herein.
      2.   Restrictions On Garbage Pick Up: Solid waste department personnel
shall not be permitted to enter businesses, commercial establishments, or
institutions to make collections, nor shall collection be made of any refuse
not placed in a closed container provided by the city. The city shall not
collect, except by special pick up as provided herein, any items listed in
subsection 6-3-8C1 of this chapter. Special pick up shall be as provided in
subsection 6-3-8C2 of this chapter.
      3.   Wet Garbage: Businesses, commercial establishments and institutions
depositing wet garbage in containers provided by the city for collection shall
wrap such garbage in moistureproof paper or plastic bags prior to depositing in
said container. (1980 Code § 16-32; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Enclosed Receptacles: No person shall deposit any wastepaper, cans, or
other rubbish for collection on any street or public or private property within
the city without placing same in an enclosed receptacle or container. (1980
Code § 16-33)
   C.   City Owned Containers: City owned two (2) cubic yard containers may be
used upon the recommendation of the solid waste department. (1980 Code § 16-34;
amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   Refuse Can Specifications; Use; Placement; Removal:
      1.   Use: The owners, occupants or rental agents of residential dwellings
shall provide a sufficient number of refuse containers or receptacles for the
storage and disposal of garbage, rubbish and trash. As such, receptacles shall
be kept clean and in good repair. The lids or covers of containers or
receptacles shall be kept securely in place at all times that the container or
receptacle contains refuse so that flies and other insects will not have access
to the contents thereof.
      2.   Specifications: Refuse containers shall be of substantial galvanized
metal or plastic construction, and provided with handles of sufficient strength
to lift such container and the contents therein, and a tight fitting, flytight
cover with handle. Containers shall be not less than twenty (20) nor more than
thirty five (35) gallons and shall weigh not more than seventy five (75) pounds
when filled. All receptacles shall be watertight. Disposable plastic bags may
be used in lieu of refuse containers provided herein. However, where disposable
plastic bags are used, the bag must be securely tied and weight of contents
shall not exceed the manufacturer's weight specifications, nor shall they be
torn or contain objects not recommended by the manufacturer or that may create
a hazardous condition for collection personnel. (1980 Code § 16-35)
      3.   Nonconforming Containers:
         a.   Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this
chapter or that may have ragged or sharp edges, or any other defect liable to
hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof, shall be promptly
replaced by an approved container upon receipt of notice to that effect from
the solid waste superintendent. If the container is not replaced within ten
(10) days after receipt of notice, it shall be disposed of by the solid waste
department as waste. (1980 Code § 16-35; amd. 2003 Code)
         b.   Oil drums, grease drums, and similar metal containers, paper
grocery bags, broken wooden boxes and crates, broken or wet cardboard boxes are
not acceptable as refuse containers and will not be picked up or emptied. (1980
Code § 16-35)
      4.   Placement Of Refuse Containers:
         a.   Inside Premises: Solid waste department personnel shall not be
permitted to enter houses, gates, fenced portions of the premises, enclosed
porches, garages or similar enclosures to make collections.
         b.   Sunken Containers: Solid waste department personnel shall not be
permitted to remove refuse containers or refuse from underground, sunken or
recessed refuse container storage vaults or similar storage areas to make
collection. (1980 Code § 16-35; amd. 2003 Code)
         c.   Placement In Streets: All refuse containers shall be set out,
properly bundled or in proper containers as provided herein, at the front curb
line in plain view or in the event there is no front curb line, in plain view
at the edge of the nearest public street fronting the dwelling unit.
         d.   Placement In Alleys: If there is an alley in the rear of the
premises which offers all weather accessibility to refuse collection vehicles,
the refuse containers shall be placed in the alley front in which such dwelling
is located, but outside of any fences or enclosed areas, except as hereinafter
provided. The city manager or his appointed representative shall have the
authority to notify customers presently being serviced from alleys to relocate
their containers to conform with provisions of this chapter pertaining to
collection from the street if it is determined by the city manager that the
alley does not conform to all of the following conditions:
            (1)   The alley shall be a through alley so the refuse trucks are
not required to back into or back out of same in order to collect refuse; and
            (2)   The alley shall not be less than fifteen feet (15') wide; and
            (3)   If the alley is "L" or "T" shaped, the turns shall be wide
enough to be safe for the refuse collection trucks to turn without damage to
them or to adjacent improvements or private property; and
            (4)   The surface of the alley is of a material which, in the
opinion of the city manager, will permit the convenient and reasonably safe
operation of refuse trucks at all seasons of the year.
      5.   Removal Of Refuse Containers: Refuse containers placed for
collection as provided herein shall be removed by the owner or occupant from
the place of their placement for pick up within twenty four (24) hours from the
time said container is actually collected. (1980 Code § 16-35)
      6.   Carryout Service: When residents are served by carryout service,
refuse containers must be placed at the side of the house, provided that such
location does not place the container in a fenced or enclosed portion of the
premises and that such location is not more than seventy five feet (75') from
the alley or street which the refuse collection truck utilizes to serve such
dwelling unit. Carryout service will only be provided for the collection of
garbage, rubbish or trash when properly containerized. It shall not include
brush and leaf collection which must be placed at the curb line or alley front
when properly bundled. (1980 Code § 16-35; amd. 2003 Code)
   E.   Unauthorized Use, Meddling With Containers:
      1.   No person shall dispose of ashes, brush, garbage, noncollectable
waste, refuse, rubbish or trash (hereinafter collectively "trash") upon public
or private property except as specifically provided for in this chapter.
      2.   No person, without being or having the permission of the owner,
tenant or occupant of the premises served by any trash receptacle, shall damage
or otherwise meddle or interfere with the use of any trash receptacle.
      3.   No person shall deposit trash in a receptacle or container for
collection thereof, whether said receptacle be privately owned or furnished by
the city, without being or having the permission of the owner, tenant or
occupant of the premises served by said container. Provided, containers placed
in public places such as parks, ballfields and along sidewalks may be used by
the public for trash generated on those premises, but may not be used for
disposal of off site generated trash.
      4.   Persons shall be responsible for the proper disposal of their trash.
It shall be prima facie evidence of unlawful disposal of trash if documents
normally associated with the generation of trash bearing the name of the
charged party, such as envelopes, prescription bottles, bills, mail and junk
mail, are found in unauthorized containers.
      5.   Violations of this subsection E are determined to be offenses and
punishable within the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court. (Ord. 6035,
2-13-2006)
6-3-8: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
   A.   Authorized Collectors: It shall be unlawful for any person other than
authorized collectors as provided herein or owners of garbage, rubbish or trash
to collect, bundle or interfere in any manner with refuse containers,
receptacles or bulk refuse placed at the curb line or alley front or other
public places in the city.
   B.   Pick Up Of Garbage:
      1.   Refuse collected by the city, whether under contract with a licensed
operator or through its own city department, shall include "garbage",
"rubbish", "trash", "refuse", "brush" as defined in section
6-3-1 of this chapter. In addition, newspapers, if tied in bundles; cardboard
boxes, if collapsed and tied; and rags, leather and rubber goods, wastepaper,
if bundled, will be collected, provided that such materials may be loaded into
a packer type truck.
      2.   Brush, in order to be picked up, shall be bundled in bundles of not
more than thirty six inches (36") in diameter, and not be more than four feet
(4') in length. Individual limbs shall not exceed two inches (2") in diameter.
Leaves will be picked up only if bagged properly.
   C.   Special Pick Up:
      1.   Waste Described: The city shall not collect, except by special pick
up as provided herein, the following:
         a.   "Noncollectible waste" as defined in section
6-3-1 of this chapter.
         b.   "Undue accumulations" of refuse as defined in section
6-3-1 of this chapter.
         c.   Any refuse that is not placed in a proper container.
         d.   Any type of refuse not capable of being loaded into a packer type
truck.
         e.   Cuttings from shrubbery, leaves, grass, bedding straw and such
articles as would consume an unreasonable amount of space in the packer type
trucks or consume an unreasonable amount of loading time for a collection
route. (1980 Code § 16-36)
      2.   Special Arrangement: Residents desiring special pick up of
noncollectible refuse, brush or refuse listed in subsection C1 of this section
may make special arrangements for such pick up through the solid waste
department. Charges for such pick up shall be as provided herein. (1980 Code §
16-36; amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   Maximum Amount Of Refuse: A maximum of one hundred five (105) gallons
of refuse will be picked up per resident per pick up day. (1980 Code § 16-37)
6-3-9: RESIDENTIAL AND BUSINESS COLLECTION SCHEDULE:
   A.   Residential: All properly containerized refuse will be collected twice
weekly. Collection days shall be as designated by the city manager.
   B.   Business, Commercial Establishments And Institutions: Collection shall
be furnished daily according to the individual needs of the business,
commercial establishment or institution being serviced. (1980 Code § 16-38)
   C.   Times To Place Refuse For Pick Up: Refuse shall be placed at the curb
site or alley front as provided herein not later than six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
on the day of the designated schedule of pick up. No owner or occupant shall
permit trash, garbage or other refuse in or out of containers to stand along
the roadside waiting for collection or for any other reason for a continuous
period in excess of twenty four (24) hours. (1980 Code § 16-39; amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   Holiday Collection Schedule: The solid waste department shall observe
all days designated as public holidays to be observed by all personnel employed
in the city's service. Persons whose refuse collection day falls on a public
holiday will be serviced on their next regularly scheduled collection day.
(1980 Code § 16-40; amd. 2003 Code)
6-3-10: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Regular Collection: For the purpose of deferring the expenses of
collection, removal, and disposal of trash, garbage and refuse as provided
herein, the Board of Commissioners, through its proper officer, is authorized
and directed to collect from the owners and occupants of any premises within
the city limits a charge payable each month. Such charges are hereby
specifically provided for and fixed in the following schedule of rates and
shall be effective from the first billing cycle in July 2025:
      1.   Single-Family Residences: For each single-family residence,
including house trailers or mobile homes, the charge will be $24.02 per month;
except for those in which the head of the household is sixty-five (65) years of
age or older, in which event the charge will be $23.07 per month.
      2.   Carryout Service: For each residential unit, of any type, requiring
carryout service, a charge of $11.98 per month, in addition to the regular
monthly charge.
      3.   Special Pick Up: Any special pick up for undue accumulation, non-
collectible waste or other special pick-ups which are not normally placed in
the container and picked up during regular pick up days, shall be subject to a
minimum charge of $46.17.
      4.   Grass Clippings: A special pick up charge for grass clippings is
$9.25 minimum or $0.91 per bag, whichever is greater.
      5.   Privately Owned Containers: For each business establishment for
which a service is provided without a City-owned container, a charge of $40.60
per month for solid waste service.
      6.   City Provided Containers:
         a.   Businesses: Monthly charges for businesses, commercial
establishments and institutions for which the City provides the containers
shall be as follows:
 
           1/WK    2/WK    3/WK     4/WK     5/WK
2 yard      $83.11  $153.78 $213.37  $269.69  $329.27
3 yard      $105.32 $185.67 $262.31  $338.50  $412.83
4 yard      $128.39 $224.44 $318.17  $407.31  $497.35
