         b.   Outside City Limits Fuel Surcharge: Additionally, a fuel
surcharge is imposed on container accounts that are located outside the city
limits. The surcharges are:
            (1)   Two (2) to five (5) miles outside city limits, add $14.66 per
pull in addition to base container rate;
            (2)   Over five (5) to ten (10) miles outside city limits, add
$38.27 per pull in addition to base container rate;
            (3)   Over ten (10) to fifteen (15) miles outside city limits, add
$62.17 per pull in addition to base container rate;
            (4)   Over fifteen (15) to twenty (20) miles outside city limits,
add $86.10 per pull in addition to base container rate
      7.   Outside City Limits: The charge for trash and garbage collection
outside the city limits shall be the same amount set for citizens who reside
inside the city limits.
      8.   Compactor Type Containers: A charge of $10.61 per cubic yard, plus
$1.25 per ton for the state solid waste landfill fee, plus $211.50 per lift, is
hereby established for pick up, hauling and landfill fees for those persons,
firms or corporations utilizing compactor type containers. Those persons, firms
or corporations utilizing front unloading compactors will be charged an
additional $78.14 per pull for the additional handling of containers.
      9.   Landfill Use: All users of the Municipal Landfill shall pay the
applicable rates set forth below and no federal, state, county, municipality,
Indian tribe or nonprofit agency shall be exempt from such charge. Rates shall
be established for vehicles delivering refuse to the City Landfill; the rates
based on the weight of the refuse disposed are as follows:
 
All vehicles: $21.11 minimum
$54.71  per ton for compacted/uncompacted refuse
$143.92 per ton for special handling waste
$154.55 per cubic yard for other industrial waste
$1.25   per ton state solid waste landfill fee
$9.62   per tire disposed of at the landfill
Double rates will be imposed on any vehicle entering the landfill with an open
load (uncovered or unsecured).
 
      10.   Open Top Roll-Off Containers: The following rates are established
for usage of a City-owned open top roll-off container:
 
$6.94   per cubic yard capacity Plus
$1.25   per ton state solid waste landfill fee Plus
$211.50 per pull of the container
 
   A minimum of two (2) pulls per month is required or a $215.24 per month
container rental will apply.
      11.   Monthly Charge, Compactors: The monthly charge for City-owned,
self-contained compactors shall be $554.16.
      12.   Cardboard Collection: The charge for the collection of cardboard in
specially marked City-owned containers shall be 75% of the rate of the same
size of container as set forth in this section.
      13.   Special Containers: If the specially marked containers are not
properly utilized, the establishment shall be charged full rate for the size of
the container as described herein.
   B.   Rates For Special Events: For the purpose of deferring the expenses of
collection, and removal and disposal of trash, garbage and refuse as provided
herein, the Board of Commissioners, through its proper officer, is authorized
and directed to collect from the owners or responsible agencies of any special
functions within the city limits a charge payable per City-owned container
utilized or requested. Such charges are hereby specifically provided for and
fixed in the following schedule of rates and shall be effective from the first
billing cycle in July 2024:
      1.   City-Owned Containers: Charges for City-owned containers at special
events or special functions for which the City provided the service or
container shall be as follows:
 
Cubic Yards Per Pick Up Or Service
2           $27.71
3           $33.26
4           $36.97
6           $46.17
 
      2.   Setup Fee: A setup fee of $36.24 is established per City-owned
container for the transportation to and from the event.
(Ord. 6254, 5-14-2018; amd. Ord. 6295, 5-24-2021; Ord. 6308, 5-23-2022; Ord.
6323, 5-22-2023; Ord. 6342, 5-28-2024; Ord. 6357, 5-27-2025)
6-3-11: TRANSPORTING GARBAGE:
   A.   Nuisance Condition Prohibited: The transportation of all trash, garbage
or other refuse through streets, alleys, or thoroughfares within the City
limits shall be conducted in such manner as to create no nuisance and shall
comply with all ordinances of the City.
   B.   Vehicle Design: Collection vehicles for garbage shall have completely
enclosed watertight bodies. All collection vehicles shall be so designed that
the wheel and axle loads, when fully loaded, shall not exceed the schedule of
weights allowed by the laws of the state. (1980 Code § 16-42)
6-3-12: NONCOLLECTIBLE WASTE:
Noncollectible waste shall not be placed with refuse for collecting, but shall
be disposed of correctly and properly by the person or persons owning,
occupying, renting or leasing the premises wherein such material is
accumulated. (1980 Code § 16-43)
6-3-13: REFUSE DISPOSAL AT CITY LANDFILL:
   A.   Residential Trash: Residential trash, garbage or other refuse may be
disposed of personally by the producer of same at the city sanitary landfill
site or transfer point provided by the city. The producer of such trash,
garbage or refuse shall be responsible for the collection and transportation of
such materials to the disposal site in a lawful manner and to dispose of such
material in a lawful manner.
   B.   All Refuse: All collected trash, garbage or other refuse originating in
the city, whether collected by the city under contract with a licensed
contractor, through its own city department, or collected by persons on their
own premises and disposed of by said persons, if disposed of within the city
and by said contractor or persons, shall be disposed of in a lawful manner.
Persons collecting and transporting trash, garbage or other refuse on a
commercial basis, who dispose of said trash, garbage or other refuse at a
landfill site or transfer point owned or maintained by the city, shall pay the
city fees prescribed by the board of commissioners, by resolution, for disposal
of said trash, garbage or other refuse.
   C.   Refuse Generated Outside State: Any waste generated from outside of the
state and presented for disposal at sanitary landfills operated by the city
must first be approved for disposal by the board of commissioners before its
acceptance by the landfill. (1980 Code § 16-44)
6-3-14: LITTERING; BURYING:
No person shall throw, discard or bury any trash, garbage, construction debris
or other refuse upon any premises, public or private, in any manner that may
menace the public health or cause a nuisance of offensive odors or sight. Any
violation of this section shall be an offense punishable within the
jurisdictional limits of the municipal court. (Ord. 6109, 11-9-2009)
6-3-15: DEPOSITING AND SCATTERING:
No person shall deposit, scatter or allow to be scattered, any trash, garbage,
construction debris or any refuse upon any premises, public or private, in any
manner that may menace the public health or cause a nuisance of offensive odors
or sight. Any violation of this section shall be an offense punishable within
the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court. (Ord. 6109, 11-9-2009)
6-3-16: COLLECTION OF ASHES:
Ashes shall not be placed in the same receptacle with any other refuse or trash
but shall be placed in separate containers for collection. Ashes shall be
soaked with water where necessary to extinguish all live embers prior to
placement for collection. No hot ashes shall be collected. (1980 Code § 16-23)
6-3-17: CLEANLINESS:
It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any building, residential or
commercial establishment having trash, garbage, or other refuse to provide for
and have proper storage containers as provided for herein of sufficient size
and number to handle the accumulation of trash, garbage or refuse on the
premises during the interval between private and public collections. In the
case of collections not taken care of by the city, there shall be no undue
accumulation of materials, and the buildings and premises shall be kept in a
clean and orderly condition. (1980 Code § 16-25)
6-3-18: PROTECTION FROM RATS; CONTAINER BASE:
Every business, commercial establishment, or institution shall be required to
protect its trash and garbage containers from the infestation by rats. If the
alley surface is not suitable for the container provided by the city, then the
owner or occupant of the premises shall be required to construct a flat base
for trash and garbage containers provided by the city, made of concrete four
inches (4") thick or its equivalent. (1980 Code § 16-26)
6-3-19: LITTERING PROHIBITED:
   A.   Generally: It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast or
deposit upon any street, alley, sidewalk or any yard or premises, public or
private, any filth of any kind, or cans, paper, trash, paper containers,
rubbish, bottles or any other form of litter or waste matter. (1980 Code § 16-
2)
   B.   Duty Of Business Owners, Occupants:
      1.   Generally: The owner or occupant of any store or other place of
business situated within the city shall exercise reasonable diligence at all
times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins,
cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials thrown or left on
the premises by its customers, and to take reasonable measures to prevent the
same from drifting or blowing onto adjoining premises.
      2.   Receptacles: Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be
placed on the premises accessible to the customers of such business where the
above referred to articles of waste may be disposed of.
      3.   Signs: Each and every business establishment shall place upon its
premises in conspicuous places in close proximity to the receptacles above
referred to, signs which shall, in essence, convey to its customers a request
that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material. (1980 Code §
16-3)
   C.   Duty Of Customer: It shall be unlawful for any customer going upon the
premises of another to in any manner dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper,
paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials
except in receptacles provided for such purposes. (1980 Code § 16-4)
   D.   Operators Of Curb Service Establishments: Every person, firm or
corporation operating so called curb service, sandwich or drink businesses at
which the customers are served in their automobiles shall, at the close of each
day's business, clean and sweep up and remove from the grounds thereof and the
streets, alleys, sidewalks and parking on and adjacent to such premises all the
trash and refuse, including paper cups, and paper napkins, fountain straws and
other rubbish which has therein accumulated. (1980 Code § 16-5)
6-3-20: DUTY OF OWNERS ABUTTING ALLEY:
   A.   Litter In Alley: It is the duty of owners, occupants and tenants
(collectively for this section "owner") of property abutting an alley to keep
and maintain the alley abutting their property, from the centerline of the
alley to the property line of the owner, clean and free of uncontainerized
trash, rubbish and debris.
   B.   Vegetation Growing In Alley: No owner shall permit vegetation to grow
between the centerline of an alley abutting the owner's property to the
property line of the owner's property so as to interfere with the safe passage
of vehicles thereon or with lawful uses of the alley.
   C.   Duties Of Solid Waste Division: It is determined that the duties of the
solid waste division, as part of the operation of the solid waste utility,
shall include the responsibility of monitoring the cleanliness and safe passage
of alleys. In the event an owner fails to maintain their portion of an alley
clean and free of uncontainerized trash, rubbish and debris as per the
requirements of subsection A of this section, or has failed to maintain
vegetation in the alley so as to not interfere with the safe passage of
vehicles or other lawful uses of alleys as per the requirements of subsection B
of this section, it shall be the responsibility of the solid waste division to
so inform the owner by prominently placarding the property in such a manner as
to put the owner on notice of the deficiency and the owner's duty to remedy the
problem. If the owner fails to remedy the problem within ten (10) days thereof,
the solid waste division shall be responsible for cleaning the property and
collecting the costs thereof from the owner at a published rate to be
established by the solid waste division.
   D.   Violation: Any violation of a provision of this section shall be an
offense punishable within the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court.
(Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
CHAPTER 4
ABANDONED, INOPERATIVE AND JUNKED VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Certain Vehicles Prohibited
6-4-3: Nuisance Declared
6-4-4: Notice Of Violation; Hearing
6-4-5: Removal By City
6-4-6: Reclamation By Owner
6-4-7: Penalty
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings given herein:
DISMANTLED, JUNKED, ABANDONED, UNSERVICEABLE, WRECKED, PARTIALLY DISMANTLED OR
INOPERABLE VEHICLES: Shall be deemed to include the major parts thereof,
including bodies, engines, transmissions, frames and rear ends.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any real property in the city which is not public property.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any property owned or controlled in the city limits of the
city of Ponca City, Kay County, state of Oklahoma, or the United States
government, and shall include all streets and highways.
VEHICLE: Any automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, wagon,
bus, motor scooter, go cart, golf cart, or self- propelled farm or construction
equipment. (1980 Code § 21-50)
6-4-2: CERTAIN VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
No person shall deposit, store, keep or permit to be deposited, stored or kept
in the open upon public or private property, a dismantled, junked, abandoned,
unserviceable, wrecked, partially dismantled, inoperable, junked or abandoned
vehicle or any vehicle legally or physically incapable of being operated on the
public streets, for a period exceeding forty eight (48) hours, unless such
vehicle, or the parts thereof, is completely enclosed within a building or
stored in connection with a business lawfully established pursuant to the
zoning ordinances of the city, or is stored on property lawfully designated
under the zoning ordinances of the city as a place for such vehicles to be
stored. (1980 Code § 21-51)
6-4-3: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The accumulation, storage or keeping of one or more vehicles or parts thereof
as described in section
6-4-2 of this chapter shall constitute a nuisance detrimental to the health,
safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. It shall be the duty of the
owner of such vehicle or the parts thereof or the owner of the private property
or the lessee or other person in possession or control of the property upon
which such vehicle is located to remove the vehicle from such property or have
the vehicle housed in a building where it will not be visible from the street
or from other private property. The removal or enclosure shall be made within
five (5) days after notice has been given to the owner of the vehicle or the
owner, lessee or person in control of the property upon which such vehicle is
located that the vehicle or vehicles have been determined to be a nuisance by
the code enforcement official. The time may be extended by the enforcement
official in the case of an obvious hardship. (1980 Code § 21-52)
6-4-4: NOTICE OF VIOLATION; HEARING:
   A.   Delivery Or Posting Of Notice: The code enforcement official or his
designee shall notify the owner of the vehicle, or the owner of the private
property or the lessee or other person in possession or control of the property
upon which such vehicle is located of such abandoned, junked, unserviceable,
inoperable or dismantled vehicle, by personal delivery of such notice or the
posting of such notice on the front door of the property upon which such
vehicle is located and the vehicle that the code enforcement official has
determined to be a nuisance pursuant to section
6-4-3 of this chapter.
   B.   Hearing And Appeal: The owner of the vehicle or the owner or possessor
of the property may request a hearing to appeal the code enforcement official's
determination by making application for appeal, in person, with the municipal
court clerk within five (5) days of the posting or delivery of the notice,
whichever is sooner. Such appeal will be heard before a judge of the municipal
court as scheduled by the municipal court clerk. Such appeal hearing shall be
de novo with the burden upon the city to establish by clear and convincing
evidence that the vehicle is in fact properly designated a nuisance and that
its location or maintenance is prohibited by this chapter. (1980 Code § 21-53)
6-4-5: REMOVAL BY CITY:
Upon failure of the owner of the vehicle or the owner, lessee or person in
control of the property upon which the vehicle is located to request an appeal
hearing, or to remove the vehicle or to place it in an enclosed building within
five (5) days after notice has been given as set forth above, or to appear at
an appeal hearing which they may have scheduled, the code enforcement official
shall promptly cause the vehicle to be removed. (1980 Code § 21-54)
6-4-6: RECLAMATION BY OWNER:
The owner of any vehicle so removed may regain possession thereof by making
application to the code enforcement official within thirty (30) days after its
removal and upon payment to the city all reasonable costs of removal and
storage which shall have accrued to such vehicle. If the vehicle is not
reclaimed within thirty (30) days, it may be sold or disposed of without
further notice and, after payment of towing and storage costs, all funds
remaining shall become the property of the city to defray the remaining costs
of abatement. (1980 Code § 21-55)
6-4-7: PENALTY:
Any person in violation of section
6-4-2 or
6-4-3 of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each and every violation and each day of such violation
shall be a separate offense. (1980 Code § 21-56; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 5
SMOKING AND FIRE PREVENTION
SECTION:
6-5-1: Smoking Prohibited
6-5-2: Open Burning
6-5-3: Fireworks
6-5-1: SMOKING PROHIBITED:
   A.   Smoking Within Any Indoor Public Places/School Spaces Prohibited: It is
unlawful to smoke tobacco, clove, herbal, alternative smoking products or vapor
producing products:
      1.   Within any indoor place, used by or open to the public, except as
may be permitted by Oklahoma Statutes;
      2.   On public transportation;
      3.   In any indoor workplace (except where specifically allowed by law)
and in school buildings and on school property where prohibited by the
institution owning the property. It is also unlawful to smoke such products
within twenty five feet (25') of the entrances to such public or open to the
public facilities.
   B.   Exceptions: The restrictions provided in this section shall not apply
to stand alone bars, stand alone taverns and cigar bars as defined by Oklahoma
Statutes or in vapor shops which sell exclusively vapor products.
   C.   Designated Outdoor Spaces:
      1.   The park and recreation department shall determine where "No
Smoking" signs should be installed, and install the same, to prohibit smoking
within fifty feet (50') of public outdoor venues owned by the city where groups
of people assemble and where smoking should not be permitted in consideration
of the following criteria:
         a.   Protection of the health of other users of the facility by
avoiding secondhand smoke or vapors of unknown substances;
         b.   To discourage smoking and vapor products near areas where youth
are likely to congregate;
         c.   Where there are city improvements present which could be damaged
by fire or lighted tobacco products;
         d.   Where there is the potential for accumulation of smoking debris
such as to constitute unsightly litter and to prevent the toxic residue of
tobacco products accumulating and leaching into the ground.
   D.   Penalty: Violation of this section shall be an offense punishable in
the municipal court by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 6185, 3-10-2014)
6-5-2: OPEN BURNING:
No person shall set fire to or burn grass, trash or any other debris or rubbish
inside the city other than in incinerators approved by the fire marshal or in
an outside open location approved by the fire marshal. The fire marshal is
authorized to adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary for safe
burning in incinerators and of outside debris, rubbish and trash. Domestically
generated trash and garbage shall not be subject to burning, but shall be
landfilled. Any appeal from such a determination of the fire marshal under this
section shall be to the city commission. Any violation of this section shall be
an offense punishable within the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court.
(Ord. 6080, 5-12-2008)
6-5-3: FIREWORKS:
   A.   Definition: "Fireworks display" shall mean an outdoor fireworks display
of aerial shells or ground display pieces.
   B.   Use Restrictions; Display Allowed: It shall be unlawful for any person
to possess, store, to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail or use or
explode any fireworks. Exception: The use of fireworks for display is allowed
as set forth in the fireworks permit process.
   C.   Display Permit Required; Application: Fireworks permits are required to
conduct a fireworks display. Permit application shall be made not less than
fifteen (15) days prior to the scheduled date of the display. The permit
application shall include a diagram of the grounds on which the display is to
be held showing the point at which the fireworks are to be discharged; the
location of buildings, highways and other lines of communication; the lines
behind which the audience will be restrained; and the location of nearby trees,
telegraph or telephone lines and other overhead obstructions. At the time of
permit application, the fire chief shall be consulted regarding requirements
for standby fire apparatus. Fireworks display permits are required to be in the
possession of the operator at the time of the display and are not transferable
to any other person or location.
   D.   Supervision: Fireworks display operations shall be under the direct
supervision of a pyrotechnic operator. The pyrotechnic operator shall be
responsible for all aspects of a display related to pyrotechnics.
   E.   Bond Or Insurance: The permittee shall furnish a bond or certificate of
insurance in the amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for the payment of damages which could be caused either to a
person or persons or to property by reason of the permitted display and arising
from acts of the permittee, agents, employees or subcontractors.
   F.   Special Effects Permit: A permit is required to use pyrotechnic special
effects material. A permit for use shall be granted only to a pyrotechnic
operator.
   G.   Permit Fee: Permit fee shall be in such amount as established by
resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time.
   H.   Penalty: Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 6
EMERGENCY ACTION EXPENSES RECOVERY
SECTION:
6-6-1: Definitions
6-6-2: Purpose
6-6-3: Liability
6-6-4: Recovery Of Expense
6-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the terms herein are defined as follows:
EMERGENCY ACTION: All of the concerted activities conducted in order to prevent
or mitigate injury to human health or the environment from a release or
threatened release of any material into or upon the environment.
GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES: Shall include the city, emergency management department,
the city utility authority, the city development authority, the city public
works authority, any entity responding under a mutual aid agreement with the
city or any entity responding at the request of and on behalf of the city.
PERSON: Shall include any individual, corporation, association, partnership,
firm, trustee or legal representative.
RECOVERABLE EXPENSES: In general, are those expenses that are reasonable,
necessary and allocable to the emergency action. Recoverable expenses should
not include normal expenditures that are incurred in the course of providing
what are traditionally local services and responsibilities, such as routine
firefighting within the city limits. Expenses allowable for recovery may
include, but are not limited to:
   A.   Disposable materials and supplies acquired, consumed and expended
specifically for the purpose of the emergency action.
   B.   Compensation of employees for the time and efforts devoted specifically
to the emergency action that is not otherwise provided for in the governmental
entity's operating budget.
   C.   Rental or leasing of equipment used specifically for the emergency
action (e.g., protective equipment or clothing, scientific, technical or
specialized equipment).
   D.   Replacement cost for equipment owned by the governmental entity that is
contaminated beyond reuse or repair if the governmental entity can demonstrate
that the equipment was a total loss and that the loss occurred during the
emergency action (e.g., self-contained breathing apparatus irretrievably
contaminated during the response, protective clothing that cannot be
decontaminated, etc.).
   E.   Decontamination of equipment contaminated during the response.
   F.   Special technical services specifically required for the response
(e.g., cost associated with the time and efforts of technical experts or
specialists not otherwise provided for by the governmental entity).
   G.   Other special services specifically required for the emergency action.
   H.   Laboratory cost for the purposes of analyzing samples taken during the
emergency action.
   I.   Any costs of cleanup, storage and/or disposal of the released material.
   J.   Costs associated with the services, supplies and equipment procured for
a specific evacuation.
   K.   Medical expenses incurred as a result of response activities.
   L.   Medical expenses that may be incurred as a result of the emergency
action, including efforts to recover expenses pursuant to this chapter.
RELEASE: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying,
discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing into or upon
the environment. (1980 Code § 14-41; amd. 2003 Code)
6-6-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter provides a means for the governmental entities to recover through
billing procedures or through civil suit the recoverable expenses they incur in
taking an emergency action. (1980 Code § 14-42)
6-6-3: LIABILITY:
Any and all persons responsible for a release or threatened release which
results in an emergency action shall be liable to the governmental entities for
the recoverable expenses resulting from the emergency action. (1980 Code § 14-
43)
6-6-4: RECOVERY OF EXPENSE:
The staffs of the governmental entities involved in the emergency action shall
keep a detailed record of its recoverable expenses resulting from the emergency
action, and said staff shall certify that these expenses were incurred, before
billing is sent out. (1980 Code § 14-44)
CHAPTER 7
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
SECTION:
6-7-1: Definitions
6-7-2: Emergency Authority Of Mayor
6-7-3: General Operation
6-7-4: Emergency Powers
6-7-5: Enemy Caused Emergency
6-7-6: Natural Emergency
6-7-7: Expenditures Restricted
6-7-8: Liability
6-7-9: Gifts, Donations
6-7-10: Compensation; Expenses
6-7-11: Powers And Duties, Generally
6-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: The preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency
functions other than functions for which primary responsibility is assigned
elsewhere by federal, state or local law or ordinance, to protect the public
peace, health and safety, and to preserve lives and property, in the city
during any emergency resulting from enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile
action, or from any flood, drought, fire, hurricane, earthquake, tornado, storm
or other catastrophe in or near the city and involving imminent or actual peril
to life and property in the city. These functions include administration,
organization, planning, recruiting, training, education, information, welfare
service, relief service, police service, warden service, fire service, rescue
service, medical service, health service, transportation service,
communications service, streets and sewers service, utilities service, general
engineering service, plant protection service, supply service, mutual aid,
mobile support, evacuation, and all other functions necessary or incidental to
the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions.
ENEMY CAUSED EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by actual or impending
attack, sabotage or other hostile action, anywhere within the United States,
and involving imminent peril to lives and property in the city. Such emergency
shall be deemed to exist only when the mayor shall so declare by public
proclamation. Such emergency shall be deemed to continue to exist until the
mayor shall declare its termination by public proclamation, or until the
governing body shall declare its termination by resolution.
NATURAL EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by any actual or impending
flood, drought, fire, hurricane, earthquake, tornado, storm or other
catastrophe in or near the city and involving imminent peril to lives and
property in the city. Such emergency shall be deemed to exist and to be
terminated under the same conditions as prescribed for any "enemy caused
emergency". (1980 Code § 10-1; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-2: EMERGENCY AUTHORITY OF MAYOR:
   A.   The emergency management authority of the city is vested in the mayor,
who shall have the power to delegate the authority to other individuals,
committees or organizations. Such powers to be exercised by the vice mayor in
the absence of the mayor.
Should exigencies warrant, the city manager may proclaim the existence of a
state of emergency which edict shall remain in force until such time as the
mayor or city commission shall either ratify or repeal the same.
   B.   The Mayor, during the existence of a state of emergency, by
proclamation, may, in the area affected by public disorder, disaster, or riot
at the time of the proclamation is issued:
      1.   Prohibit any person being on the public streets, or in the public
parks or at any other public place during the hours declared by the Mayor to be
a period of curfew;
      2.   Prohibit a designated number of persons from assembling or gathering
on the public streets, parks or other areas either public or private;
      3.   Prohibit the transporting, possessing or using of gasoline,
kerosene, or combustible, flammable, or explosive liquids or materials in a
glass or uncapped container of any kind except in connection with the normal
operation of motor vehicles, normal home use or legitimate commercial use;
(Ord. 6030, 10-24-2005)
      4.   (Rep. by Ord. 6044, 7-24-2006)
      5.   Prohibit the sale, purchase or dispensing of alcoholic beverages;
(Ord. 6259, 6-11-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
      6.   Prohibit the sale, purchase or dispensing of other commodities or
goods, as (s)he reasonably believes should be prohibited to help preserve and
maintain life, health, property or the public peace;
      7.   Prohibit the use of certain streets, highways or public ways by the
public;
      8.   Prohibit such other activities as (s)he reasonably believes should
be prohibited to help preserve and maintain life, health, property or the
public peace;
      9.   Waive competitive bidding and other statutory provisions in the
conduct of government which would be time consuming to the detriment of the
health, welfare and safety of persons and/or property;
      10.   Requisition public and privately held resources for transportation,
fuel and its transportation, public shelter and quarantine, foodstuffs, and
medical supplies and equipment;
      11.   Declare quarantine;
      12.   Restrict the passage of people and goods into and out of the City
or within its interior;
      13.   Mandate the cancellation of events wherein a significant number of
persons may be anticipated to gather.
   C.   Pursuant to the Oklahoma Emergency Management Act of 2003 and
specifically section 683.11(F) the Mayor and the Board of Commissioners are
authorized to exercise emergency powers without regard to time consuming
procedures and formalities prescribed by law (excepting mandatory
constitutional requirements) pertaining to the performance of public work,
entering into contracts, incurring obligations, the employment of temporary
workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and materials, and
the appropriation and expenditure of public funds.
   D.   The Mayor may impose the emergency powers herein contemplated for such
times, upon such conditions, with such exceptions and in such areas as (s)he
from time to time deems necessary, subject to the Board of Commissioners' power
to terminate. (Ord. 6030, 10-24-2005)
6-7-3: GENERAL OPERATION:
The Emergency Management Director shall have general direction and control of
the Department of Emergency Management and shall be responsible for carrying
out the provisions of this chapter. In so doing, all reasonable efforts shall
be made to cooperate, insofar as permitted by other appropriate legislation,
with the Federal government, State government, and its subdivisions, with other
states and their subdivisions, and with private agencies, in all matters
pertaining to emergency management in the City. (1980 Code § 10-5; amd. 2003
Code)
6-7-4: EMERGENCY POWERS:
Prior to an emergency within the City, the Emergency Management Director shall
have the following powers:
   A.   To make, amend and rescind the necessary orders, rules and regulations
to carry out the provisions of this chapter within the limits of the authority
conferred upon him herein, with due consideration to be given to the plans and
powers of the Federal government, the State government, and other public and
private agencies and organizations empowered to act in either enemy caused
emergencies or natural emergencies, or both.
   B.   To prepare comprehensive plans for the emergency management of the city
in both enemy caused and natural emergencies, such plans and programs to be
integrated and coordinated with the plans and programs of the federal
government, of the state government, and of other public and private agencies
and organizations empowered to act in either enemy caused or natural
emergencies, or both.
   C.   To establish, within the limits of funds available, a public warning
system composed of sirens, horns, or other acceptable warning devices.
   D.   To establish and carry out recruitment and training programs as may be
necessary to develop an adequate, qualified emergency management volunteer
corps.
   E.   To conduct drills, exercises and similar programs as may be necessary
to develop a well trained, alert, fully prepared emergency management
department.
   F.   To make such studies and surveys of the industries, resources and
facilities of the city as it deems necessary to ascertain its capabilities for
emergency management, and plan for the most efficient emergency use therefor.
   G.   On behalf of the city, to enter into mutual aid arrangements with
surrounding communities, both in the states of Oklahoma and of Kansas, subject
to the approval of the city commission.
   H.   To delegate any administrative authority vested in it under this
chapter, and to provide for the subdelegation of any such authority.
   I.   To take any other action proper and lawful under its authority to
prepare for either an enemy caused or a natural emergency. (1980 Code § 10-6;
amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-5: ENEMY CAUSED EMERGENCY:
In the event of any actual enemy caused emergency, as proclaimed by the mayor,
the emergency management director, with the approval of the mayor, may exercise
during such emergency, the power to enforce all rules and regulations relating
to emergency management, and acting under the authority of statutes, when
enacted, or under the authority of the mayor as an agent of the state governor,
may take control of all means of transportation and communications, all stocks
of fuel, food, clothing, medicine and supplies, and all facilities including
buildings and plants, and exercise all powers necessary to secure the safety
and protection of the civilian population. In exercising such powers, he shall
be guided by regulations and orders issued by the federal government and the
state governor relating to emergency management and shall take no action
contrary to orders which may be issued by the governor under similar emergency
powers. (1980 Code § 10-7; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-6: NATURAL EMERGENCY:
In the event of any natural emergency as proclaimed by the mayor, the emergency
management director shall coordinate in every way proper the activities of the
emergency management department. It is specifically charged in such emergency
with the collection, evaluation, and dissemination of information to all
agencies, both public and private, participating in the city's emergency
management department or cooperating in any such emergency. It shall, as
emergency management authority, have the power to recommend appropriate action,
but it shall not otherwise have control over the participating agencies. It
shall also recommend to the mayor the allocation of any funds received from the
federal or state government or from any other source to alleviate distress and
aid in restoring normal conditions. (1980 Code § 10-8; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-7: EXPENDITURES RESTRICTED:
Expenditures for supplies, equipment and other necessary items for the city's
emergency management program shall be made only on the authority of the city
manager. (1980 Code § 10-9; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-8: LIABILITY:
Neither the city nor any officer or member of the emergency management
department provided for in this chapter shall be liable for personal injury or
property damage sustained by any person appointed or acting as a volunteer
emergency management worker or member of any agency engaged in emergency
management activity prior to or during either an enemy caused or a natural
emergency. Nor shall the city or any such officer or member be liable for the
death or injury of any persons, or damage to property, resulting from such
emergency management activity prior to or during either an enemy caused or a
natural emergency. (1980 Code § 10-10; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-9: GIFTS, DONATIONS:
Whenever the federal government or the state, or any person shall offer to the
city any services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift,
grant or loan, for purposes of emergency management, the mayor may accept such
offer and may authorize the emergency management department to receive same
subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the
agency making the offer. (1980 Code § 10-11; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-10: COMPENSATION; EXPENSES:
The emergency management director shall serve with or without compensation at
the discretion of the board of commissioners and may be reimbursed for actual
expenses in the conduct of his duties by submitting sworn claims for such
expenses and having said claims approved in the regular order of business.
(1980 Code § 10-42; amd. 2003 Code)
6-7-11: POWERS AND DUTIES, GENERALLY:
The director of emergency management shall be the executive head of the
department of emergency management and shall be responsible to the mayor and
city manager for carrying out the emergency management program of the city. He
shall coordinate the activities of all organizations for emergency management
within the city, and shall maintain liaison with, and cooperate with emergency
management agencies and organizations of other governmental units both within
and without the state and of the federal government, and shall have such
additional authority, duties, and responsibilities as may be authorized under
this chapter, or amendments hereto. (1980 Code § 10-43; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 8
ABANDONED BUILDINGS
SECTION:
6-8-1: Definitions
6-8-2: Statutory Authority
6-8-3: Declaration Of Public Nuisance And Abatement Procedures
6-8-4: Petition For Removal
6-8-5: Administrative Officer
6-8-6: Right Of Appeal
6-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
 
                    Any building located within the municipality that is not
ABANDONED BUILDING: currently occupied and has been declared unsecured or
                    dilapidated pursuant to Section 22-112 or 22-112.1 of Title
                    11 of the Oklahoma Statutes and remains in such condition.
OWNER:              The owner of record as shown by the most current tax rolls
                    of the county treasurer. (Ord. 6331, 7-24-2023)
 
6-8-2: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
Buildings within the municipal limits may be declared abandoned and abated as
such with the provisions of 11 O.S. § 22-121.4. (Ord. 6331, 7-24-2023)
6-8-3: DECLARATION OF PUBLIC NUISANCE AND ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
The municipal governing body may abate the public nuisance caused by an
abandoned building within the municipal limits in accordance with the following
procedures:
   A.   At least ten (10) days’ notice that an abandoned building is to be
abated pursuant to the procedures for abatement set forth in this section shall
be given to the owner of the property before the governing body holds a
hearing. A copy of the notice shall be sent by mail to the property owner at
the address shown by the current year’s tax rolls in the office of the county
treasurer. Written notice shall also be sent by mail to any mortgage holder as
shown by the records in the office of the county clerk to the last-known
address of the mortgage holder. At the time of mailing of notice to any
property owner or mortgage holder, the municipality shall obtain a receipt of
mailing from the postal service, the receipt of which shall indicate the date
of mailing and the name and address of the mailee. However, if neither the
property owner nor mortgage holder can be located, notice may be given by
posting a copy of the notice on the property and by publication as defined in
Section 1-102 of Title 11 of the Oklahoma Statutes. Such notice shall be
published once not less than ten (10) days prior to any hearing or action by
the municipality pursuant to the provisions of this section;
   B.   A hearing shall be held by the governing body to determine if the
property is an abandoned building as defined by this section;
   C.   Pursuant to a determination that the building is an abandoned building,
the governing body may order the agents of the municipality to pursue abatement
of the public nuisance caused by the building and shall order the city clerk to
place the building on an abandoned building list to be maintained by the clerk.
At any time after such determination and order, the agents of the municipality
may cause the public nuisance to be abated as authorized in this section, and
such abatement may continue until such time as the building is removed from the
abandoned building list in accordance with the procedures set forth in
6-8-4;
   D.   Abatement of an abandoned building by the municipality may include any
or all of the following:
      1.   Any lawful city regulatory or city police and fire protection action
in relation to the abandoned building or the owner of such building necessary
or appropriate for the protection of inhabitants in and visitors to the
municipality. Upon receipt of any necessary warrant to authorize such action,
the agents of the municipality are granted the right of entry onto the property
for the performance of any such action as a governmental function of the
municipality,
      2.   The quarterly assessment against the property on which the abandoned
building is located and against the owner of the abandoned building of the
actual costs of any municipal regulatory action taken in relation to the
abandoned building or the owner of such building as authorized above,
      3.   The assessment against the property on which the abandoned building
is located and against the owner of the abandoned building of the actual costs
of any municipal police or fire protection action taken in relation to the
abandoned building or the owner of such building as authorized above, and
      4.   An assessment for any other actual expenses incurred by the
municipality in relation to the abandoned building, including, but not limited
to, the costs of notices, mailings and publications.
   E.   After the determination that a building is an abandoned building, and
before commencement of any of the abatement actions authorized by paragraphs C
and D, the city clerk shall file a notice of lien with the county clerk
describing the property, the findings of the governing body at the hearing, and
stating that the municipality claims a lien on the property for all abatement
costs and that such costs shall also constitute the personal obligation of the
property owner from and after the date of filing of the notice;
   F.   From and after the determination that a building is an abandoned
building, and continuing until such time as the building is removed from the
abandoned building list in accordance with the procedures set forth in
paragraph G, the city clerk shall determine the actual quarterly abatement
costs for the abatement procedures authorized by this section. After such
determination, the city clerk shall mail a statement of the actual quarterly
abatement costs for the abatement procedures authorized by this section to the
property owner and demand the payment of such costs by the owner. In addition,
a copy of the statement shall be mailed to any mortgage holder at the address
provided for in paragraph A. At the time of mailing of the statement of costs
to any property owner or mortgage holder, the city clerk shall obtain a receipt
of mailing from the postal service, the receipt of which shall indicate the
date of mailing and the name and address of the mailee; and
   G.   When full payment is made to the city clerk for actual abatement costs
incurred and billed in accordance with paragraph F of this subsection, the city
clerk shall send the property owner and any mortgage holder by mail a receipt
for such payment; but if payment attributable to the actual quarterly costs of
such abatement is not made within six (6) months from the date of the mailing
of the statement to the owner of such property, a lien in the actual amount of
the abatement shall be filed against the abandoned building. Until finally
paid, the costs and the interest thereon shall be the personal obligation of
the property owner from and after the date the notice of lien was filed with
the county clerk. In addition, the costs and the interest thereon shall be a
lien against the property from the date the notice of lien was filed with the
county clerk. The lien shall be coequal with the lien of ad valorem taxes and
all other taxes and special assessments and shall be prior and superior to all
other titles and liens against the property. The lien shall continue until the
cost is fully paid. A mineral interest, if severed from the surface interest
and not owned by the surface owner, shall not be subject to any lien created
pursuant to this section. Upon receiving full payment, the city clerk shall
forward to the county clerk a notice of discharge of the lien. (Ord. 6331, 7-
24-2023)
6-8-4: PETITION FOR REMOVAL:
Any owner or mortgage holder of any building determined by the governing body
of the municipality to be an abandoned building pursuant to this section may
petition the governing body in writing at any time after such determination for
removal of such building from the abandoned building list maintained by the
city clerk. Any such petition shall be filed with the city clerk. Within thirty
(30) days after such petition is filed with the city clerk, the governing body
shall hold a hearing to determine if the building is no longer an abandoned
building. Upon such a determination, the governing body shall order the
building removed from the abandoned building list. The city clerk shall comply
with such order by removing the building from the abandoned building list;
provided, the real property on which the abandoned building is located and the
owner of such building shall remain liable for payment of any and all abatement
costs incurred by the municipality prior to the determination and order by the
governing body that the building should be removed from the abandoned building
list. Upon full payment of any costs certified against the property, the city
clerk shall file a release of the notice of the lien in the county clerk’s
office within ten (10) days after receiving such payment. (Ord. 6331, 7-24-
2023)
6-8-5: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER:
The governing body hereby designates the Development Services Director or his
designee to carry out any or all of the duties of the governing body under this
chapter. (Ord. 6331, 7-24-2023)
6-8-6: RIGHT OF APPEAL:
The property owner shall have the right to appeal to the governing body from
any order of the administrative. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written
notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the
administrative order is delivered or mailed to the owner at the address shown
in the county treasurer records.
(Ord. 6331, 7-24-2023)
CHAPTER 9
NOISE CONTROL
SECTION:
6-9-1: Purpose And Intent
6-9-2: Definitions
6-9-3: Prohibited Noises - General Standard
6-9-4: Prohibited Noises - Specific Examples
6-9-5: Exemptions
6-9-6: Enforcement And Remedies
6-9-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
Ponca city is an urbanized community with different land uses located in close
proximity to one another. This pattern of land use development makes it
inevitable that everyday noise will be audible to one (1) degree or another.
The city encourages all persons to be good citizens of their neighborhood, and
to be considerate to those who live nearby. Persons who work or reside in the
city should be knowledgeable of, and abide by, applicable laws and city
ordinances. The purpose of this chapter is to strike a balance between normal,
everyday noises that are unavoidable within the city environment and those
noises that are so excessive and annoying to persons of ordinary sensitivity
they should be curtailed in order to protect the comfort and tranquility of all
persons.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
6-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, phrases and terms as used in this chapter shall have the
meanings indicated as follows:
CONSTRUCTION: Shall mean any of the following:
   A.   The operation of any tool, machine or equipment including, vehicles,
and any associated work, including, but not limited to, demolition, grading,
excavating, or construction;
   B.   Performing any construction, maintenance or repair on buildings,
structures or utilities or any work preparing a site for construction or
repair;
   C.   Any painting using motorized equipment or any painting that is part of
the construction activity;
   D.   The loading or unloading of construction equipment, materials, or
supplies from vehicles at or near the site of the construction activity;
   E.   The staging or idling, at or near the site of construction activity, of
any construction vehicle or any vehicles bringing construction equipment,
materials or supplies to the site of the construction;
EMERGENCY WORK: Any work performed for the purpose of preventing or alleviating
property damage threatened or caused by an emergency or work by private or
public utilities when restoring utility services.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: Any police officer or animal control officer or code
enforcement officer employed by the City of Ponca City.
INTERIOR CONSTRUCTION: Construction activities taking place entirely within a
structure that is enclosed on all sides with the windows and doors installed
and closed.
OFF ROAD MOTOR VEHICLE: Any self-propelled motor vehicle having two or more
wheels which is intended for, or capable of, use off of public or private
roadways. This shall include, but is not limited to, motorcycles, dirt bikes,
ATV's, and go carts.
RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD: Those portions of the city that are zoned for and
developed as residential dwelling units, regardless of density or residential
zoning classification.
RESPONSIBLE PERSON: The owner of property or the person in control of such
property or the person who is responsible for creating or allowing any sound or
noise to exist.
SOUND: Shall include, but not be limited to, amplified music or voices or
vibrations from amplified music or voices.
SUNRISE: The moment or instant in the morning under meteorological conditions
with standard refraction of the sun's rays, when the upper edge of the sun's
disc is coincident with an ideal horizon, as determined by the official US
timekeeper, the US Naval Observatory.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
6-9-3: PROHIBITED NOISES - GENERAL STANDARD:
Unless otherwise permitted in this chapter, no person shall make, permit to be
made or cause any noises, sounds or vibrations anywhere within the city that
are so loud, prolonged and harsh as to be annoying to reasonable persons of
ordinary sensitivity and to cause or contribute to the unreasonable discomfort
or disturbance of any persons within the vicinity. Causing or permitting noises
to occur is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and in violation of this
chapter. When considering whether a noise, sound or vibration is unreasonable
within the meaning of this section, the enforcement officer shall take in
consideration the following factors;
   A.   The volume and intensity of the noise, particularly as it is
experienced within a residence or place of business;
   B.   Whether the noise is prolonged and continuous;
   C.   How the noise contrasts with the ambient noise level;
   D.   The proximity of the noise source to residential and commercial uses;
   E.   The time of day; and
   F.   Any other relevant circumstances or conditions.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
6-9-4: PROHIBITED NOISES - SPECIFIC EXAMPLES:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, the following acts and
the causing or permitting thereof within a residential neighborhood, are
declared to be a public nuisance and in violation of this chapter:
   A.   Amplified Sound, Radios, and Musical Instruments: The using, operating
or permitting to be played, used or operated between the hours of ten o’clock
(10:00 p.m.) and sunrise of any radio, musical instrument, stereo, television
set, or instrument or device similar to those specifically mentioned for the
production or reproduction of sound in volume sufficiently loud as to be
plainly audible at a distance of fifty feet or more therefrom its origin.
   B.   Engines, Motors and Mechanical Devices. The sustained, continuous or
repeated operation or use between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and
sunrise of any motor or engine or the repair, modification, reconstruction,
testing or operation of any automobile, motorcycle, ATV, machine, contrivance,
or mechanical device that is being plainly audible at a distance of fifty feet
(50') or more therefrom its origin. Racing the engine of any motor vehicle
shall be prohibited at any time at any location.
   C.   Loading And Unloading Waste and/or Materials. Loading, unloading,
opening, closing or other handling of boxes, containers, building materials, or
similar objects between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and sunrise,
excluding normal handling of solid waste, and recycling containers by a public
or franchised collector.
   D.   Construction Activities. Construction activity between the hours of ten
o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and sunrise. Interior construction is permissible. To
minimize the disturbance to the surrounding community, the motors and engines
for construction related vehicles and equipment shall not be left idling and
shall be turned off when not in use.
   E.   Non-Emergency Signaling Devices. Sounding or permitting the sounding of
any electronically amplified signal from any bell, chime, siren, whistle or
similar device, intended for non-emergency purposes, from any place, for more
than ten consecutive seconds in any hourly period. Houses of religious worship
shall be exempt from the operation of this provision.
   F.    Noises By Animals. No person shall permit any animal that is kept or
maintained upon any premises owned, occupied or controlled by such person to
permit such animal to emit any noise, sound, or cry which interferes with the
comfortable enjoyment of life and property by any individual.
   G.   Lawn Maintenance Equipment. The use or operation of any powered lawn
maintenance equipment between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and sunrise
or allowing the use of such equipment to blow leaves, dirt and other debris off
sidewalks, driveways, lawns and other surfaces.
   H.   Commercial Establishments Adjacent to Residential Neighborhoods.
Notwithstanding any provision of this code to the contrary, continuous,
repeated or sustained noise from the premises of any commercial establishment
which is adjacent to one or more residential dwelling units, including any
outdoor area under the control of the establishment, between the hours of ten
o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and sunrise that is plainly audible from the residential
dwelling unit's property line.
   I.    Loud Parties Or Gatherings. Generating any noise from a party, event
or other gathering of people on private property (whether from a home, a
commercial business or any other location in the city) that is determined by an
enforcement officer to constitute a threat to public peace, health and safety
or a violation of this code or state law due to the magnitude of the crowd, the
volume of noise, the level of disturbance to the surrounding neighborhood,
unruly behavior, excessive traffic or destruction of property generated by the
party or gathering.
   J.   Tree Removal Or Trimming Services. The trimming or removing of trees or
vegetation by the property owner or a commercial service using any electrical
or gas-powered machine between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00 p.m.) and
sunrise.
   K.   Operating Off-Road Motor Vehicles On Private Property. Operating an
off-road motor vehicle on private property located within one thousand (1,000)
feet of a residence not owned by the operator of the motor vehicle at any hour
of the day or night.
   L.   Operating Off-Road Motor Vehicles On Public Or Private Streets.
Operating an off-road motor vehicle on any public or private street at any hour
of the day or night, unless said motor vehicle is legally licensed and tagged
to operate on public streets.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
6-9-5: EXEMPTIONS:
The following activities shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter:
   A.   Civil Emergency. The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting
persons to the existence of an emergency or the emission of sound in the
performance of emergency work. For the purposes of this section, "emergency"
means a condition that constitutes an immediate threat to public safety, health
and welfare or to property.
   B.   Warning Devices. Warning devices necessary for the protection of public
safety as for example, police, fire and ambulance sirens and train horns.
   C.   Construction Activities, Commercial Tree Removal or Trimming Services -
Special Circumstances. The provisions of section 6-10-4 do not apply to any
person who performs construction, repair, earthmoving work, excavation or
commercial tree trimming and removal services if:
      1.   The work to be done is necessary to protect or promote public safety
or welfare or is otherwise in the public interest; or
      2.   Hardship caused by unreasonable delay due to weather would result
from the interruption of work thereof during the hours specified in section 6-
10-4. The person doing such construction, repair, excavation, or commercial
tree trimming and removal shall obtain a revocable permit from the building
official prior to and before the commencement of any such work.
   D.   Outdoor Activities. Permitted activities conducted on public parks and
playgrounds, licensed and approved child day care facilities, and public or
private school grounds, including but not limited to school athletic and school
entertainment events.
   E.   Outdoor Gatherings, Performances, Shows and Sporting Events. Provided
such events are conducted pursuant to a permit issued by the city or on city or
school owned property.
   F.   Mechanical Equipment. Properly maintained HVAC units, refrigeration
units, pool/hot tub motors and exhaust fans required by the building code.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
6-9-6: ENFORCEMENT AND REMEDIES:
A violation of any part of this chapter shall be considered a misdemeanor
offense. The penalty for a first offense shall be a fine of two hundred dollars
($200) plus any court costs. The penalty for a second or subsequent offense
which occurs within sixty (60) days of a previous violation of this chapter
shall be a fine of five hundred dollars ($500) plus any court costs. The
remedies set forth in this chapter are not exclusive and may be used in
addition to those set forth elsewhere in this code or by law. Nothing in this
chapter shall preclude the city from seeking to obtain voluntary compliance by
way of warning, notice, or informational materials.
(Ord. 6338, 12-11-2023)
TITLE 7
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
7-1-1: Adoption Of State Misdemeanor Statutes; Violations

7-1-1: ADOPTION OF STATE MISDEMEANOR STATUTES; VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Adoption: All misdemeanor offenses and any amendment thereof contained
in the Oklahoma Statutes, including, but not limited to, title 21, are hereby
adopted and included herein by reference and made a part hereof as if fully set
out herein.
   B.   Violations: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this code for any
person to commit an act or acts which constitute misdemeanors pursuant to the
Oklahoma Statutes, and any amendments thereof. The municipal court shall have
full authority to hear and sentence on all such violations of the law.
   C.   Conflicts: In the event of conflict between elements of the offenses
specifically set forth in the code and the state statutes adopted by reference,
prosecutions will be conducted under the state statutes and any amendments
thereof adopted by reference.
   D.   Penalty: In no event shall fines or incarceration exceed the
jurisdictional limits imposed by the Oklahoma legislature on the Ponca City
municipal court. (1980 Code § 22-180; amd. 2003 Code)

excepting the punishment, which shall not exceed the jurisdictional limits

7-1-3: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   Definitions; Duties Of Responders; Duties Of Alarm Users:
The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this section, shall have
the meanings as ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
      1.   Alarm Signal; Signals: "Alarm signal or signals" means the
activation of an alarm system that requests a response, by the police
department or the fire department, or by activating an audible alarm,
loudspeaker or bell.
      2.   Alarm System:
         a.   "Alarm system" means a burglary alarm system, robbery alarm
system, or automatic fire alarm system.
         b.   "Alarm system" does not include:
            (1)   An alarm installed on a vehicle, unless the vehicle is
permanently located at a site; or
            (2)   An alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises
that does not have a sounding device which can be heard on the exterior of the
alarm site.
      3.   Alarm System Contractor:
         a.   "Alarm system contractor" means:
            (1)   A person engaged in installing, maintaining, monitoring,
altering, or servicing alarm systems; or
            (2)   An agency that furnishes the services of a person engaged in
installing, maintaining, monitoring, altering, or servicing alarm systems.
         b.   "Alarm system contractor" does not include a person who only
sells or manufactures alarm devices, unless that person services, installs
monitors, or responds to alarm systems at protected premises.
      4.   Alarm System With Automatic Dialing System: Any device or
combination of devices that will automatically upon activation either
mechanically, electronically, or by any other means, initiate a telephonic,
recorded or programmed message to a preselected telephone number.
      5.   Alarm User:
         a.   "Alarm user" means a person in control of an alarm system within,
on, or surrounding any building, structure facility or site.
         b.   "Alarm user" includes the owner or lessee of an alarm system.
      6.   Defective Alarm System:
         a.   Presumption: A "defective alarm system" means any system
generating more than four (4) "false alarms", as defined, in any six (6) month
period, or any system, except a financial institution with an Underwriters
Laboratory approved audible alarm, activating an audible alarm, loud speaker or
bell that does not automatically reset and silence itself within thirty (30)
minutes of activation.
         b.   Notice Of Condition: A police officer or fire response officer
who answers a false alarm shall provide written notice to the alarm user of the
defective condition stating the number of false alarms activated during the
designated period and whether or not the alarm system is being placed on
defective status.
         c.   Actions By Alarm User: Upon notice from the appropriate police
department or fire department representative, an alarm user who has a defective
alarm system shall:
            (1)   Have the system inspected within thirty (30) days by an alarm
system contractor or alarm user, if qualified; and
            (2)   Within fifteen (15) days of the inspection file a written
report with the police department or fire department.
         d.   Report: The report shall contain:
            (1)   The results of the alarm system contractor's or alarm user's
inspection.
            (2)   The probable cause of the false alarms.
            (3)   Actions taken or recommendations for eliminating the false
alarms.
            (4)   Upon receipt of a report establishing that appropriate
measures have been taken to eliminate false alarms, the chief of police or his
designee, or the fire chief or his designee may remove the alarm system from
defective status.
            (5)   Nothing in this section shall prohibit enforcement of
violations concerning operation of a defective alarm system between the time
that a notice of condition is issued and an alarm system is removed from
defective status.
      7.   False Alarm:
         a.   "False alarm" means any request for immediate assistance by the
police department or fire department, regardless of cause, that is not in
response to an actual emergency situation or threatened suggested criminal
activity.
         b.   "False alarm" includes:
            (1)   Negligently or accidentally activated signals; and
            (2)   Signals that are the result of faulty, malfunctioning, or
improperly installed or maintained equipment; and
            (3)   Signals that are purposely activated to summon the police
department or the fire department in a nonemergency situation.
         c.   "False alarm" does not include:
            (1)   Signals activated by unusually severe weather conditions or
other causes beyond the control of the alarm user; or
            (2)   Signals activated during the initial sixty (60) day period
following new installation.
         d.   An alarm system that is activated a second time within a twelve
(12) hour period when the premises are unoccupied shall be deemed one false
alarm if:
            (1)   Access to the building is provided to the alarm system
contractor; and
            (2)   An alarm system contractor or an employee of an alarm system
contractor responds.
         e.   Failure to comply with subsection A7d of this section shall
result in each subsequent alarm being counted as a false alarm.
      8.   Police Department: "Police department" means the Ponca City police
department.
      9.   Fire Department: "Fire department" means Ponca City fire department.
   B.   Prohibited Acts: It shall be unlawful and an offense punishable under
the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court for:
      1.   Intentional Activation Of Alarm System: An alarm user to wilfully
and knowingly activate an alarm signal for a nonemergency situation.
      2.   Operating Defective Alarm System:
         a.   An alarm user to wilfully and knowingly continue to use a
defective alarm system after receiving a notice of such condition and that the
alarm system was placed on defective status. Without complying with user's
duties as specified in subsection A6c and A6d of this section.
         b.   Each false alarm activation, following being placed on defective
status, is a separate violation.
      3.   Operating Alarm System With Automatic Telephone Dialing System: An
alarm user, any person, company, or other entity to use or operate, attempt to
use or operate, or arrange, adjust, program or otherwise provide or install any
device or combination of devices that will automatically, upon activation
either mechanically, electronically, or by any other means, initiate a
telephonic, recorded or programmed message to the emergency number 911 or any
telephone number assigned to the police department or the fire department.
      4.   Making False Reports Of Crime, Injury, Fire Or Other Emergency: Any
person to intentionally and knowingly communicate a false fire alarm, false
crime report or false notice of injury, or activate an automatic apparatus
which transmits the same or in any manner to deceive or attempt to deceive the
fire department, the police department or a dispatcher for the same, or
employee thereof with reference to any fire alarm, false report of a crime or
an injury, or to knowingly cause the fire department, police department, or its
officers or employees to make a useless dispatch of fire, ambulance or police
personnel or equipment by reason of such information. (Ord. 5965, 1-11-2002)
7-1-4: GARAGE SALES; LIMITATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or allow to be conducted more
than one residential garage, yard, or rummage sale of used personal and
household goods, on property zoned as residential within six (6) months of any
other such sale at the same location. Any such sale shall not exceed three (3)
days in length. Any violation hereof shall be a public offense subject to the
general jurisdiction of the municipal court. (Ord. 5931, 5-22-2000)
7-1-5: DRILLING FOR OIL AND GAS; MINING FOR COAL:
   A.   Oil And Gas; Permit Required: The drilling and production of oil and
gas within the city limits is permitted subject to issuance of a permit
therefor by the board of commissioners which takes into account the reasonable
needs of the community adjacent to the drilling location.
   B.   Coal Mining Prohibited: The mining of coal within the limits of the
city is prohibited. (Ord. 5974, 5-28-2002)
7-1-6: BEGGING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to beg alms from any person, organization,
or agency except an organization or agency, public or private, whose purpose or
one of whose purposes is to aid persons in need. (1980 Code § 22-5)
7-1-7: PUBLIC MEETINGS IN STREETS PROHIBITED:
In the interests of public safety, and to aid in the control of traffic, public
meetings in the streets of the city are hereby prohibited, except as provided
by section
7-4-2 of this title. (1980 Code § 22-103; amd. 2003 Code)
7-1-8: LOITERING, OBSTRUCTING PASSAGE ON STREETS:
   A.   Violation Deemed Nuisance 1 : It shall be unlawful for any person or
persons to obstruct passage on a street or sidewalk or in front of any store or
place of business or upon any parking lot in such a manner as to be a nuisance
and to refuse or neglect to move on when directed by a police officer.
   B.   Definition: A "nuisance" is doing an act, or omitting to perform a
duty, which act or omission either:
      1.   First: Annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or
safety of others.
      2.   Second: Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct
or renders dangerous for passage on any street, sidewalk, highway or parking
lot.
      3.   Third: In any way renders other persons insecure in life or use of
property.
   C.   Penalty For Violation: Any person who shall violate any provision of
this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1980 Code § 22-104; amd. 2003 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 6, chapter 1 of this code for nuisances.
7-1-9: LOUD NOISE FROM OPERATION OF MECHANICAL DEVICES 1 :
   A.   Mechanical Devices; Loud Music: It shall be unlawful for any person to
disturb the peace and quietude of any part of the city by operating, having
operated or permitting to be operated any automobile, contrivance, machinery or
sound amplifying system in such a manner as to emit loud noise, loud sounds or
loud music.
   B.   Jake Brakes:
      1.   For the purpose of this section, use of a compression release type
engine brake or "jake brake" shall be defined as a device which when activated
retards one or more pistons on the engine of the motor vehicle in order to
assist the motor vehicle in braking, and in the process of doing so creates a
loud and offensive noise from the motor vehicle when inadequately or improperly
muffled.
      2.   It shall be unlawful, except to avert imminent danger, for any
person to use compression release type engine brakes, commonly known as "jake
brakes", unless the blow down from the compression release and the exhaust of
any internal combustion engine is discharged through an appropriate muffler
system before entering the ambient air. (Ord. 5920, 12-13-1999)

7-1-10: CONDUCT NEAR SCHOOLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any of the following conduct
or acts around any of the schools or school grounds or streets and alleys
adjacent to said schools in the city:
   A.   Loitering by any person not having lawful business in connection with
the school or employees thereof.
   B.   Any conduct that would disturb the orderly conduct of the school.
   C.   Annoy or molest any student or employee of the school.
   D.   Lewd or wanton conduct.
   E.   Move or park any vehicle in the vicinity of any school for the purpose
of annoying or molesting any student or employee of the school. (1980 Code §
22-112)
7-1-11: WEAPONS 1 :
   A.   Illegal Possession; Penalty; Confiscation: In addition to the penalty
otherwise provided for the illegal possession of a weapon, the judge of the
municipal court may order and adjudge any weapon or article found concealed on
any person in violation of 21 Oklahoma Statutes section 1272 as an instrument
used in violation of the public safety and in the furtherance of a nuisance,
and may order same to be destroyed by the chief of police in case said articles
have no particular value; but if same may have any particular value for a
lawful purpose, it may be ordered by said judge to be held for a period of six
(6) months by the chief of police, and after giving all persons claiming an
interest therein, if such persons are known to the chief of police, notice in
writing for a period of not less than five (5), nor more than fifteen (15)
days, such article may be sold after six (6) months from the date of the first
of such notices; and the proceeds therefor shall be turned over to the finance
director the same as a fine or forfeiture, and the chief of police shall make
due report to the city clerk of all articles sold, and the proceeds from such
sale. (1980 Code § 22-128; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Discharging Firearms, Air Guns: It is unlawful for any person to
discharge a firearm in the city except when doing so in the line of duty, when
doing so in defense of oneself, of another person or of property or on firing
ranges existing as of the date of the ordinance codified herein or when
otherwise authorized by this code or any law or ordinance. It is unlawful to
discharge an air rifle, BB gun, pellet gun or slingshot in the city. Any person
violating the provisions of this subsection shall be deemed guilty of an
offense subject to fine and/or within the jurisdictional limits of the
municipal court. (Ord. 6076, 3-24-2008)
