8-3-1: TRAFFIC COMMISSION 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
 
Notes
1 2. See section 3-1A-11 of this code.
8-3-2: CITY TRAFFIC ENGINEER:
   A.   Office Created: The office of city traffic engineer is hereby
established. The city traffic engineer shall be an engineer or a person
similarly qualified. The city traffic engineer shall exercise the powers and
duties as provided in this code and in the traffic ordinances of the city.
   B.   Duties: It shall be the general duty of the city traffic engineer to
determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control
devices, to conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents and to devise
remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions,
to plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of the city, and
to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to
improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties
imposed by this code. (1980 Code § 34-116)
8-3-3: DUTY OF POLICE:
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the street traffic
regulations of the city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street
traffic in the city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate
accidents and to cooperate with the city traffic engineer and other officers of
the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and
means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties specially
imposed upon said department by this code. (1980 Code § 34-113; amd. 2003 Code)
8-3-4: DIRECTION OF TRAFFIC:
   A.   Police: Officers of the police department or such officers as are
assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by
voice, hand, or signal in conformance with traffic laws; provided that, in the
event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard
pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions
may require, notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. (1980 Code §
34-114)
   B.   Firefighters: Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a
fire or other emergency, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic
thereat or in the immediate vicinity. (1980 Code § 34-115)
8-3-5: EMERGENCY AND EXPERIMENTAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   Regulations: The chief of police, by and with the approval of the city
traffic engineer, is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make
effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city and to make and
enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special
conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect
for more than ninety (90) days.
   B.   Traffic Control Devices: The city traffic engineer may test traffic
control devices under actual conditions of traffic. (1980 Code § 34-117)
8-3-6: RECORDS OF TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS:
The police department shall keep a record of all violations of the provisions
of this title and the traffic ordinances of the city or of the state vehicle
laws of which any person has been charged. Such record shall be so maintained
as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Said record shall
accumulate during at least a five (5) year period, and from that time on the
record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five (5) year
period. (1980 Code § 34-118; amd. 2003 Code)
8-3-7: ACCIDENT REPORTS AND STUDIES:
   A.   Investigations: It shall be the duty of the traffic division, assisted
by other police officers of the department, to investigate traffic accidents,
to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with
violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. (1980 Code § 34-
119)
   B.   Studies: Whenever the accidents at any particular location become
numerous, the police department shall cooperate with the city traffic engineer
in conducting studies of such accidents and determining remedial measures.
(1980 Code § 34-120)
   C.   Reports: The police department shall maintain a suitable system of
filing traffic accident reports. Accident reports or cards referring to them
shall be filed alphabetically by location. Such reports shall be available for
the use and information of the city traffic engineer. (1980 Code § 34-121)
8-3-8: DRIVERS FILES MAINTAINED:
   A.   Records: The police department shall maintain a suitable record of all
traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions, and complaints reported for
each driver, which shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the driver
concerned.
   B.   Studies: Said police department shall study the cases of all the
drivers charged with frequent or serious violations of the traffic laws or
involved in frequent traffic accidents or any serious accident, and shall
attempt to discover the reasons therefor, and shall take whatever steps are
lawful and reasonable to prevent the same or to have the licenses of such
persons suspended or revoked.
   C.   Time Period For Keeping: Such records shall accumulate during at least
a five (5) year period, and from that time on such records shall be maintained
complete for at least the most recent five (5) year period. (1980 Code § 34-
122)
8-3-9: ANNUAL TRAFFIC SAFETY REPORT:
The police department shall annually prepare a traffic report which shall be
filed with the city manager. Such report shall contain information on traffic
matters in the city as follows:
   A.   The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the
number of persons injured, and the other pertinent traffic accident data;
   B.   The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data
on the safety activities of the police;
   C.   The plans and recommendations of the department for future traffic
safety activities. (1980 Code § 34-123)
8-3-10: IDENTIFICATION OF FUNERAL PROCESSIONS 1 :
The police department shall designate a type of pennant or other identifying
insignia to be displayed upon, or other method to be employed to identify, the
vehicles in funeral processions. (1980 Code § 34-124)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 8-1-10 of this title.
CHAPTER 4
RULES OF THE ROAD
SECTION:
8-4-1: Turning Movements, Signals
8-4-2: Speed Regulations
8-4-3: Obstructing Street, Sidewalk
8-4-4: Negligent Collision
8-4-5: Driving On Sidewalk
8-4-6: Driving On Freshly Painted Markings
8-4-7: Use Of Alleys
8-4-8: Corner Cutting
8-4-9: Transporting Open Containers
8-4-10: Operating A Motor Vehicle While Texting Prohibited
8-4-1: TURNING MOVEMENTS, SIGNALS:
   A.   Turning Markers: The city traffic engineer is authorized to place
markers, buttons, or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the
course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such
course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as
prescribed by law or ordinance. (1980 Code § 34-277)
   B.   Restricted Turn Signs:
      1.   Authorized: The city traffic engineer is, with the recommendation of
the planning commission, hereby authorized to determine those intersections at
which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left, or U-turn, and shall
place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be
prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in
which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs or such signs may
be removed when such turns are permitted. (1980 Code § 34-278; amd. Ord. 6158,
6-11-2012)
      2.   Obedience: Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no
right or left or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the
directions of any such sign. (1980 Code § 34-279)
   C.   Limitations On Turning Around: The driver of any vehicle shall not turn
such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any roadway except
at an intersection and then only if such turn can be made in safety and without
interfering with other traffic; provided, however, that no such turn shall be
made within a business district nor at an intersection where a traffic control
signal is in operation. (1980 Code § 34-280)
8-4-2: SPEED REGULATIONS:
   A.   General Rule:
      1.   Any person driving a vehicle on a highway shall drive the same at a
careful and prudent speed not greater than nor less than is reasonable and
proper, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the highway and
any other condition then existing, and no person shall drive any vehicle upon a
highway at a speed greater than will permit him to bring it to a stop within
the assured clear distance ahead.
      2.   The driver of every vehicle shall, consistent with the requirements
of subsection A1 of this section, drive at an appropriate reduced speed when
approaching and crossing an intersection or railway grade crossing, when
approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when
driving upon any narrow or winding roadway, and when special hazard exists with
respect to pedestrians or other traffic, or by reason of weather or highway
conditions. (1980 Code § 34-257)
   B.   General Maximum Speed Limit: No vehicle, unless otherwise specifically
authorized by this chapter, shall be driven at a speed greater than twenty five
(25) miles per hour upon any street within the city, except as the board of
commissioners, as authorized by state law, declares and determines upon the
basis of engineering and traffic investigation that certain speed regulations
shall be applicable upon specified streets or in certain areas, in which event
it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of
any speed so declared when signs are in place giving notice thereof. (1980 Code
§ 34-258)
   C.   Maximum Speed In Central Traffic District: No vehicle, unless otherwise
specifically authorized by this title, shall be driven at a speed greater than
twenty five (25) miles per hour in the central traffic district of the city.
(1980 Code § 34-259)
   D.   Regulation Of Speed By Traffic Signal: The city traffic engineer is
authorized to regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the
movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at
variance from the speeds otherwise applicable within the district or at
intersections and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. (1980
Code § 34-261)
   E.   Speed Limits At Schools And School Crossings: Upon those streets
adjacent to schools or established school crossings, the city traffic engineer,
with the approval of the planning commission, is hereby authorized to
determine, on the basis of traffic and engineering investigations, those
sections of said streets where a speed limit lower than the general speed limit
provided for in subsection B of this section shall be applicable on certain
days and during certain hours, and to place appropriate signs giving notice
thereof. (1980 Code § 34-262; amd. Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
   F.   Speed Limits In Parks:
      1.   No vehicle, unless otherwise specifically authorized by this title,
shall be driven at a speed greater than twenty (20) miles per hour on the
roadways in any public park unless signs are erected giving notice of a
different speed as provided in subsection F2 of this section, in which event no
vehicle shall be driven in excess of the posted speed limit.
      2.   The park superintendent, with approval of the traffic engineer and
based upon traffic engineering studies, through administrative rules and the
posting of appropriate signs, may alter the speed limit on sections of said
roadways. (1980 Code § 34-263)
8-4-3: OBSTRUCTING STREET, SIDEWALK:
No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is
sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to
accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of
other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal
indication to proceed. (1980 Code § 34-186)
8-4-4: NEGLIGENT COLLISION:
   A.   Definition: "Negligence", as used herein, shall be defined as a failure
to use the same degree of care as a person of ordinary prudence would use under
the same or similar circumstances.
   B.   Prohibition: If any person driving or operating or in charge of any
vehicle shall through his negligence cause, suffer or permit such vehicle to
come into collision with any other vehicle of any nature whatever or with any
animal, person, street sign, street post, fire hydrant, mailbox, or any other
obstacle or object whatever, in or on any public street or any public place
whatever, in the city, such person shall be deemed guilty of the offense of
negligent collision. (1980 Code § 34-190)
8-4-5: DRIVING ON SIDEWALK:
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a
permanent or temporary driveway. (1980 Code § 34-193)
8-4-6: DRIVING ON FRESHLY PAINTED MARKINGS:
No person shall drive a vehicle on or across freshly painted street markings
when the same are marked by traffic cones or other devices to indicate that the
markings have been freshly painted, or disturb or remove said cones or other
devices when in use for this purpose. (1980 Code § 34-197)
8-4-7: USE OF ALLEYS:
No person shall drive a vehicle within an alley except for the purpose of
gaining secondary access to the property abutting said alley. Vehicular use of
alleys to shorten travel distance or to avoid using the streets for travel is
prohibited. (1980 Code § 34-198)
8-4-8: CORNER CUTTING:
   A.   No person shall drive a vehicle through any service drive or upon any
parking facility except with the intent of availing himself or herself of the
services offered on the premises served by the said service drive or parking
facility.
   B.   No person shall drive a vehicle through any service drive or across any
parking facility for the purpose of shortening their travel distance, avoiding
a traffic control device, avoiding using the streets for travel, or turning a
vehicle so as to proceed in opposite direction on the street from which it
entered said drive. (1980 Code § 34-199)
8-4-9: TRANSPORTING OPEN CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly transport in any vehicle upon
the streets or alleys of the city any alcoholic beverage, except in the
original container which shall not have been opened and the seal upon which
shall not have been broken and from which the original cap or cork shall not
have been removed, unless the opened container be in the rear trunk or rear
compartment, which shall include the spare tire compartment in a vehicle
commonly known as a station wagon and panel truck, or any outside compartment
which is not accessible to the driver or any other person in said vehicle while
it is in motion. (1980 Code § 34-200; amd. 2003 Code)
8-4-10: OPERATING A MOTOR VEHICLE WHILE TEXTING PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any
street or highway within this municipality while using a handheld electronic
communication device to manually compose, send or read an electronic text
message while the motor vehicle is in motion.
   B.   Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this section
shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00), or such other fine as the state may from time to time impose
on a comparable violation of state law.
   C.   The provisions of subsection A of this section shall not apply if the
person is using the cellular telephone or electronic communication device for
the sole purpose of communicating with any of the following regarding an
imminent emergency situation:
      1.   An emergency response operator;
      2.   A hospital, physician's office or health clinic;
      3.   A provider of ambulance services;
      4.   A provider of firefighting services; or
      5.   A law enforcement agency.
   D.   For the purpose of this section:
    CELLULAR TELEPHONE: An analog or digital wireless telephone authorized by
the federal communications commission to operate in the frequency bandwidth
reserved for cellular telephones.
   COMPOSE, SEND OR READ: With respect to a text message means the manual
entry, sending or retrieval of a text message to communicate with any person or
device.
   ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATION DEVICE: An electronic device that permits the user
to manually transmit a communication of written text by means other than
through an oral transfer or wire communication. This term does not include a
device that is physically or electronically integrated into a motor vehicle or
a voice operated global positioning or navigation system that is affixed to a
motor vehicle, or a hands free device that allows the user to write, send or
read a text message without the use of either hand except to activate,
deactivate or initiate a feature or function.
   TEXT MESSAGE: Includes a text based message, instant message, electronic
message, photo, video or electronic mail. (Ord. 6212, 10-12-2015, eff. 11-1-
2015)
CHAPTER 5
STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
SECTION:
8-5-1: Angle Parking
8-5-2: Parking Within Indicated Space
8-5-3: Obstructing Traffic
8-5-4: One-Way Streets Or Roadways
8-5-5: Hazardous Or Congested Places
8-5-6: Alleys
8-5-7: Street Rights Of Way
8-5-8: Parking For Certain Purposes Prohibited
8-5-9: Narrow Streets
8-5-10: Parking Restricted During Funerals
8-5-11: Parking In Excess Of Forty Eight Hours
8-5-12: Railroad Trains Blocking Streets
8-5-13: Handicapped Parking Spaces
8-5-14: Specific Street Restrictions, Prohibitions
8-5-15: Loading And Unloading
8-5-1: ANGLE PARKING:
   A.   Designation:
      1.   The city traffic engineer, with the recommendation of the planning
commission, shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted
and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be
indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within the city unless the
state highway commission has determined by resolution or order entered into its
minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without
interfering with the free movement of traffic. (1980 Code § 34-332; amd. Ord.
6158, 6-11-2012)
      2.   Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where
passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side
of the street. (1980 Code § 34-332)
   B.   Obedience:
      1.   On those streets which have been signed or marked by the city
traffic engineer for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle
other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such
signs or markings with the front of such vehicle directed toward the curb or
edge of the roadway.
      2.   No person shall park or stand a vehicle in angle parking spaces
designated by markings upon the pavement unless said vehicle is positioned
within the confines of an individually marked space. Said vehicle shall not be
of such length, or positioned in a manner, as to protrude into the street a
distance which would cause or require passing traffic to change lanes or drive
on the left side of the street. (1980 Code § 34-333)
8-5-2: PARKING WITHIN INDICATED SPACE:
In an area where parking spaces have been marked off on the surface of the
street, a driver parking a vehicle shall park it within a parking space as thus
marked off, and not on or over a line delimiting a space. (1980 Code § 34-334)
8-5-3: OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC:
No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such
conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the
roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. (1980 Code § 34-339; amd. 2003
Code)
8-5-4: ONE-WAY STREETS OR ROADWAYS:
   A.   One-Way Streets: The city traffic engineer is authorized to erect signs
upon the left hand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or
parking of vehicles, and when such signs are in place, no person shall stand or
park a vehicle upon such left hand side in violation of any such sign. (1980
Code § 34-336)
   B.   One-Way Roadways: In the event a highway includes two (2) or more
separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such
roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left hand side of
such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or
parking. The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine when standing or
parking may be permitted upon the left hand side of any such one-way roadway
and to erect signs giving notice thereof. (1980 Code § 34-337)
8-5-5: HAZARDOUS OR CONGESTED PLACES:
   A.   Determination: The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to
determine and designate, by proper signs, places not exceeding one hundred feet
(100') in length in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would
create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to
traffic.
   B.   Posting Of Signs: When official signs are erected at hazardous or
congested places, as authorized herein, no person shall stop, stand or park a
vehicle in any such designated place.
   C.   Tow Away Zones: The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to
determine and designate by proper signs any of the areas provided for in this
subsection as "tow away" zones. (1980 Code § 34-340)
8-5-6: ALLEYS:
   A.   Manner Of Parking: No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in
such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet
(10') of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic,
and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such
position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. (1980 Code
§ 34-341)
   B.   Business District: No person shall park a vehicle in an alley within a
business district except for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the
necessary and expeditious loading and unloading of merchandise or freight, and
then only for a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) minutes. (1980 Code §
34-356)
8-5-7: STREET RIGHTS OF WAY:
No person shall park a vehicle upon a sidewalk area, roadway median or other
portion of a street right of way within a business or residence district except
upon those roadway portions of said right of way maintained for vehicular use
where parking is permitted. (1980 Code § 34-357)
8-5-8: PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES PROHIBITED:
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of:
   A.   Displaying such vehicle for sale.
   B.   Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs
necessitated by an emergency. (1980 Code § 34-342)
8-5-9: NARROW STREETS:
   A.   Authority: The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to erect
signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does
not exceed twenty feet (20'), or upon one side of a street as indicated by such
signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty six feet (26').
   B.   Signs: When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow
streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any street in
violation of any such sign. (1980 Code § 34-343)
8-5-10: PARKING RESTRICTED DURING FUNERALS:
   A.   Authority: Funeral parlors and churches in the city are authorized to
restrict parking on streets adjacent to funeral parlors or churches by the
placement of funeral signs at least three (3) hours prior to any funeral.
   B.   Signs: No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any area where
said funeral signs are displayed. (1980 Code § 34-344)
8-5-11: PARKING IN EXCESS OF FORTY EIGHT HOURS:
No person, operator or owner is permitted to park or leave standing in any
public street, alley or other public place, any vehicle, wagon, automobile or
other character of private property, unattended and unmoved for a longer
continuous period of time than forty eight (48) hours. (1980 Code § 34-345)
8-5-12: RAILROAD TRAINS BLOCKING STREETS 1 :
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad
train to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a manner as to
prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time
longer than five (5) minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to
trains in motion other than those engaged in switching. (1980 Code § 34-346)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 143 of the city charter.
8-5-13: HANDICAPPED PARKING SPACES:
   A.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, "physically handicapped"
shall mean any person who has sustained a physical disability rendering it
difficult and burdensome to walk. (1980 Code § 34-348)
   B.   Determination Of Location: The city traffic engineer, with the
recommendation of the planning commission, shall determine locations upon
public property where parking spaces are to be reserved for the use of the
physically handicapped, and shall designate such spaces by erecting official
signs. (1980 Code § 34-348; amd. Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
   C.   Identification Of Spaces: The owner of any private parking facility may
designate parking spaces to be reserved for use of the physically handicapped
by identifying spaces with above grade signs as being reserved for physically
handicapped persons. Each sign shall be rectangular in shape having minimum
dimensions of twelve inches (12") in width and eighteen inches (18") in height,
erected so that the top of the sign is at least forty eight inches (48") above
the parking lot surface, and located to clearly distinguish each space being
reserved.
   D.   Prohibited Parking: The parking or standing of a vehicle in a parking
space which has been designated as being reserved for the handicapped, as
provided for in this section, on public or private property, shall be unlawful
unless the vehicle is being operated by, or under the direction of and for his
use, a physically handicapped person.
   E.   Insignia; Presumptions: A person who has secured an insignia issued by
the Oklahoma department of public safety pursuant to 47 Oklahoma Statutes
section 15-101 et seq., and has displayed such insignia on his vehicle, shall
be presumed to be utilizing such space in accordance with the terms of this
section. An individual who does not display said insignia on his vehicle shall
be presumed to be in violation of the provisions of this section. Such
presumption shall be rebuttable and may be overcome by the individual charged
or other parties submitting evidence to the contrary. (1980 Code § 34-348)
   F.   Penalty For Violation: Any person, firm or corporation violating the
provisions of this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1980 Code § 34-348; amd. 2003 Code)
   G.   Disabled Parking Violation Unit:
      1.   Creation: There is hereby created in and for the city a disabled
parking violations unit, composed of a number of volunteer civilians, accepted
by the chief of police.
      2.   Training And Equipment: Each member of the disabled parking
violations unit shall successfully complete not less than two (2) hours of
training in the elements and documentation of disabled parking violations, and
the proper means of enforcing applicable law and ordinances.
      3.   Procedures: The chief of police shall prepare and enforce police
policies and procedures which provide for the uniform reporting of violations,
the taking of photographs of violations, and the identification of each,
individual volunteer. Such procedure shall be followed by each member of the
unit in all efforts to enforce disabled parking laws and ordinances. The unit
shall confine its work to the enforcement of various parking ordinances of the
city, including, but not limited to, handicapped parking.
      4.   Photographs: All photographs, if taken, of apparent, disabled
parking violations shall be processed and maintained solely by the police
department, and all such photographs shall be available for inspection in any
proceeding to adjudicate the liability for a violation, but shall not be
available for any purpose other than as evidence of a disabled parking
violation. Such photographs and the affidavits or testimony based on the
photographs submitted by these volunteers within the unit shall be prima facie
evidence of the facts contained therein.
      5.   Notice Of Violation: A notice of violation (citation) shall be left
on the vehicle of each person alleged to be liable as an owner of a vehicle for
a violation of a disabled parking law or ordinance, and a copy of the citation
shall be sent to the municipal court clerk. Said citation shall reference the
law or ordinance allegedly violated, contain the name and address of the person
alleged to be liable as an owner of the vehicle, the license tag number of the
vehicle, the location where such alleged violation occurred, the date and time
of the alleged violation, and the identification of the volunteer who issued
the citation. The citation shall also contain such information as needed to
inform the accused of the manner and time to contest the violation alleged in
the notice, and advising that the failure to contest in the manner and time
provided shall be deemed an admission of liability, resulting in a default
judgment being entered.
If the accused fails to appear in court or fails to pay, a notice of violation
shall be sent by first class mail to each person alleged to be liable as an
owner of a vehicle for a violation of a disabled parking law or ordinance, and
a record of the notice shall be preserved in the case record. Said notice shall
reference the law or ordinance allegedly violated, contain the name and address
of the person alleged to be liable as an owner of the vehicle, the license tag
number of the vehicle, the location where such alleged violation occurred, the
date and time of the alleged violation, and the identification of the volunteer
who made the record. The notice shall also contain such information as needed
to inform the accused of the manner and time to contest the violation alleged
in the notice, and advising that the failure to contest in the manner and time
provided shall be deemed an admission of liability, resulting in a default
judgment being entered.
      6.   Compliance With Statute: The foregoing is intended to comply with 47
Oklahoma Statutes section 15-115, and all interpretations of this subsection G
shall be compatible with the terms and interpretations of that statute. (Ord.
6224, 6-13-2016)
8-5-14: SPECIFIC STREET RESTRICTIONS, PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Application Of Section: The provisions of this section prohibiting the
standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times, or at those times
herein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary
to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with
the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. (1980
Code § 34-366)
   B.   Regulations Not Exclusive: The provisions of this section imposing a
time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe
other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping,
standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times.
(1980 Code § 34-367)
   C.   Signs Required: Whenever by this section or any other ordinance of the
city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated
streets, it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to erect appropriate
signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless
said signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offenses. (1980
Code § 34-368)
   D.   Parking Prohibited On Certain Streets: When signs are erected giving
notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time upon
any of such streets. (1980 Code § 34-369)
   E.   Parking Restricted On Certain Streets: When signs are erected in each
block giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle
between the hours or on those days specified on such signs, except Sundays and
public holidays. (1980 Code § 34-370)
   F.   Parking Adjacent To School:
      1.   The city traffic engineer, with the recommendation of the planning
commission, is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon
either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such
parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous
situation. (1980 Code § 34-371; amd. Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
      2.   When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either
side of a street adjacent to any school property as authorized herein, no
person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. (1980 Code § 34-371)
8-5-15: LOADING AND UNLOADING:
   A.   Designation Of Curb Loading Zones: The city traffic engineer, with the
recommendation of the planning commission, is hereby authorized to determine
the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and
maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during
which the provisions of this section are applicable. (1980 Code § 34-380; amd.
Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
   B.   Standing In Passenger Curb Loading Zone: No person shall stop, stand,
or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a
passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to
such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed
three (3) minutes. (1980 Code § 34-382)
   C.   Standing In Freight Curb Loading Zone:
      1.   No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or
length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick up
and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone
during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no
case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty (30)
minutes.
      2.   The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place
marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of, and while actually
engaged in, loading or unloading passengers, when such stopping does not
interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which
is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. (1980 Code § 34-383)
   D.   Designation Of Public Carrier Stops And Stands: The city traffic
engineer, with the recommendation of the planning commission, is hereby
authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and
stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets
in such places and in such manner as he shall determine to be of the greatest
benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop, bus stand,
taxicab stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. (1980
Code § 34-385; amd. Ord. 6158, 6-11-2012)
   E.   Buses And Taxicabs Regulated:
      1.   The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any
street at any place other than a bus stand so designated as provided herein.
      2.   The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at
any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage
other than at a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as
provided herein, except in case of an emergency.
      3.   The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger
loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus when stopped to
load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position with the right
front wheel of such vehicle not farther than eighteen inches (18") from the
curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede
the movement of other vehicular traffic.
      4.   The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon
any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided
herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from
temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations
at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious
loading or unloading of passengers. (1980 Code § 34-386)
   F.   Restricted Use Of Bus And Taxicab Stands: No person shall stop, stand,
or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a
taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and
appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may
temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in
loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any
bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. (1980 Code § 34-
387)
   G.   Parking Of Trucks, Commercial Vehicles, RVs On City Streets:
      1.   No truck, trailer, commercial vehicle, bus, recreational vehicle or
other vehicle having more than two (2) axles and/or of a length of eighteen
feet (18') or greater shall park on any street or street right of way within
any residential area at any time, except for the immediate loading or unloading
of persons or materials, and only then when not in violation of any other
provision of this chapter.
      2.   No tractor trailer rigs (semitrailers) shall be parked or stored on
the street, street right of way, yard, or driveway within any residential area.
      3.   No tractors for semitrailers shall be parked or stored on the street
or street right of way within any residential area, except on driveways or
other hard surfaced areas. (1980 Code § 34-388)
CHAPTER 6
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
8-6-1: Crossing At Right Angles
8-6-2: Obedience To Railroad Signals
8-6-1: CROSSING AT RIGHT ANGLES:
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right
angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb except in a
crosswalk. (1980 Code § 34-479)
8-6-2: OBEDIENCE TO RAILROAD SIGNALS:
No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over, or under any crossing gate or
barrier at a railroad grade crossing while such gate or barrier is closed or is
being opened or closed. (1980 Code § 34-482)
CHAPTER 7
BICYCLES 1
SECTION:
8-7-1: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
8-7-2: Use Of Right Half Of Roadway
8-7-3: Riding Between Vehicles
8-7-4: Speed
8-7-5: Emerging From Alley Or Driveway
8-7-6: Parking
8-7-7: Riding On Sidewalks
8-7-8: Siren, Whistle Prohibited
8-7-9: Restricted On Grounds Of Marland Mansion
 
Notes
1 1. See section 13 of the city charter.
8-7-1: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official
traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left
or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the
direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle
to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the
regulations applicable to pedestrians.
   C.   Any person may walk bicycles and shall then be subject to all laws
applicable to pedestrians. (1980 Code § 34-448)
8-7-2: USE OF RIGHT HALF OF ROADWAY:
When an area along the right side of a street is designated by pavement
markings as parking spaces for motor vehicles, the operator of a bicycle may
proceed upon a due course as close to the center of the right most lane
available to vehicular traffic, or of the right hand portion of the remaining
portion of an unlaned street, as is practicable. (1980 Code § 34-453)
8-7-3: RIDING BETWEEN VEHICLES:
The operator of a bicycle shall not ride between vehicles standing or traveling
in a single direction within marked or unmarked travel lanes. (1980 Code § 34-
454)
8-7-4: SPEED:
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing. (1980 Code § 34-455)
8-7-5: EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY:
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall,
upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway,
yield the right of way to all pedestrians or bicycles approaching on said
sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right of way to
all vehicles and bicycles approaching on said roadway. (1980 Code § 34-456)
8-7-6: PARKING:
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or
against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic. No bicycle shall be parked within marked
stall lines denoting spaces for motor vehicles, nor between same where
vehicular stalls are separated by markings on the roadway. (1980 Code § 34-458)
8-7-7: RIDING ON SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Grand Avenue: Bicycles may be ridden upon any sidewalk within the city,
except no person shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk abutting Grand Avenue
within the central traffic district.
   B.   Yield To Pedestrians: Whenever a person is riding a bicycle upon the
sidewalk, such person shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian upon said
sidewalk and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any
pedestrian. (1980 Code § 34-459)
8-7-8: SIREN, WHISTLE PROHIBITED:
A bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle
any siren or whistle. (1980 Code § 34-461)
8-7-9: RESTRICTED ON GROUNDS OF MARLAND MANSION:
No bicycles, ridden, operated or otherwise, shall be permitted on the grounds
of the Marland mansion estate, except in designated driveway and parking areas.
Signage consistent with this section shall be posted at all entrances to the
Marland mansion estate property. (1980 Code § 34-462)
TITLE 9
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTIES
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Sidewalk Maintenance, Construction
9-1-2: Street Obstructions, Encroachments
9-1-3: Sweeping Trash Into Streets, Gutters
9-1-4: Protection Of Vehicle Load
9-1-5: Drainage Of Water Into Streets
9-1-6: Abandoned Driveways
9-1-1: SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE, CONSTRUCTION 1 :
   A.   Maintenance By Abutting Property Owner: The owner or other person in
charge of real property which adjoins a sidewalk or sidewalk area shall keep
the adjoining sidewalk or sidewalk area in good condition and safe for
pedestrian use; and it shall be unlawful for such owner or person in charge to
fail to do so. (1980 Code § 30-59)
   B.   Failure To Construct, Nuisance: Any place upon or over which there has
been regularly ordered a sidewalk to be constructed, and such order shall not
have been complied with within thirty (30) days thereafter, is hereby defined
and declared to be a public nuisance, and the owner or occupant of the
adjoining premises shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1980 Code § 30-60)
   C.   Damage Prohibited: Any person who shall, without obtaining necessary
permits, remove any portion of any sidewalk, or any support from any sidewalk
or crossing, or loosen or remove any plank, stringer or other support from any
culvert or bridge shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1980 Code § 30-61; amd.
2003 Code)
   D.   Gratings Closed: Any person who shall leave open any cellar door or
grating, or any other cover or door on any street, thoroughfare or sidewalk in
the city, or shall suffer any such door or grating belonging to the premises
occupied or owned by him to be in an insecure condition, whereby persons may be
in danger of falling into such cellar or other place, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1980 Code § 30-62)
   E.   Obstructions: Any person who shall suspend or erect any awning, sign,
sign base, or any other fixture or structure which extends over or upon any
sidewalk, without first obtaining the necessary permit, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1980 Code § 30-63; amd. 2003 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 114 of the city charter.
9-1-2: STREET OBSTRUCTIONS, ENCROACHMENTS 1 :
   A.   Goods, Wares, Merchandise: It shall be unlawful for any person to place
upon or permit to be placed upon the sidewalks, parkways, streets and alleys of
the city any goods, wares, articles of merchandise or any other obstruction,
and leave same thereon. (1980 Code § 30-75)
   B.   Pedestrians Or Vehicular Traffic: It shall be unlawful for any person
to use or obstruct the sidewalks of the city in any manner so as to interfere
unduly with pedestrian traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct the streets and
alleys of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with lawful traffic
and parking thereon. (1980 Code § 30-76)
   C.   Excavations In Streets: Any person in the city who shall make or cause
to be made any excavation in or adjoining a public place, or street, and shall
not in some substantial manner secure the same from persons or animals falling
therein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1980 Code § 30-77)
   D.   Vaults Unprotected: Any person who shall dig or cause to be dug, in any
highway, thoroughfare or sidewalk in the city, any vault, hole or other
excavation, and shall not arch or cover same over and secure the grating or
covering of the opening thereof in such a manner as to prevent persons,
animals, or vehicles from falling therein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1980 Code § 30-78)
 
Notes
1 1. See sections 146 and 148 of the city charter.
9-1-3: SWEEPING TRASH INTO STREETS, GUTTERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to put, sweep or cause to be put or swept
or otherwise placed or caused to be placed in any city street or its gutters,
any trash, paper, rubbish, refuse, or other matter from or off any sidewalk,
building or premises. (1980 Code § 30-1)
9-1-4: PROTECTION OF VEHICLE LOAD:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate trucks or other vehicles in such
a manner as to distribute, scatter or strew the load or any portion of the load
or contents thereof upon the streets of the city. (1980 Code § 30-2)
9-1-5: DRAINAGE OF WATER INTO STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of any place of business, or any
agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow storm water to flow or drain into,
upon, over or across any sidewalk, parking area, street, alley or other public
way without written approval of the city engineer. (1980 Code § 30-3; amd. 2003
Code)
9-1-6: ABANDONED DRIVEWAYS:
Whenever the curb line of any street has been removed or omitted for a driveway
entrance to private property, and physical changes have been made on said
property which prohibits the use of said driveway entrance for vehicular travel
to and from the property, or changes are made in the usage of the property or
improvements thereon which are incompatible with the use of said driveway for
vehicle access to the property, the curbing which has been omitted or removed
shall be installed or replaced and that portion of the public right of way
formerly used as a driveway entrance shall be reconstructed to conform with the
adjacent area of the public right of way by the abutting property owner. (1980
Code § 30-4)
CHAPTER 2
STREET IMPROVEMENTS AND SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 1
SECTION:
9-2-1: Definitions
9-2-2: Procedure Generally
9-2-3: Protests Against Street Improvements
9-2-4: Work Restricted
9-2-5: Insurance And Bond Requirements
9-2-6: Permits
9-2-7: Utility Cuts; Payment Of Costs
9-2-8: Abandonment Authorized For Certain Delays
9-2-9: Protection Of Public
9-2-10: Closure Of Streets Undergoing Improvement
9-2-11: Prohibited Acts; Removing Barricades
 
Notes
1 1. See section 145 of the city charter.
9-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
ALLEY: A public way less than twenty feet (20') in width between property
lines.
CONCRETE: As used in reference to existing improvements, shall include any
mixture of sand, or sand and rock, with Portland or natural cement as a binding
material, but as used in reference to new work shall mean concrete
proportioned, mixed, placed, and finished as hereinafter prescribed.
CURB LINE: The line of the face of the curb, i.e., the side toward the roadway
at a point one inch (1") above the surface of the pavement or gutter.
DRIVEWAY: A path for vehicular traffic entering or leaving specific premises.
It may or may not be improved and if improved, such improvement may or may not
extend from the roadway to the property line, but the purpose must be to serve
traffic crossing the property line; otherwise any surfacing for the use of
vehicular traffic, outside the existing roadway, shall be considered a pavement
widening, whether the roadway be improved or not, and shall be subject to the
regulations therefor, hereinafter prescribed.
GRADE: The predetermined elevation at which an improvement is to be
constructed.
GUTTER: A strip of roadway surfacing adjacent to the curb, separate from the
remainder of the roadway pavement and not more than three feet (3') wide.
PAVEMENT: Within the roadway, any surfacing whatever. In driveways, concrete or
other "hard" surfacing only.
PUBLIC WAY: Any land dedicated to the public as a way of public travel,
including the entire width thereof between property lines.
ROADWAY: In the case of an alley, the entire width between property lines. In
the case of a street, the space between the curbs or, if no curbs exist, the
space between the established curb lines.
SIDEWALK: A walk lengthwise of a street, located outside the roadway, and
intended to form a continuous public trafficway.
STREET: Any public way more than thirty three feet (33') in width between
property lines.
STREET INTERSECTION: The area at the junction of two (2) or more streets,
defined by constructing perpendiculars to the street centerlines from the
property corners.
WALK: An improved surface for pedestrian traffic, outside the roadway of a
street or alley. (1980 Code § 30-33; amd. 2003 Code)
9-2-2: PROCEDURE GENERALLY:
   A.   Compliance With Local And State Regulations: Except as herein provided,
the construction of the improvements, the time and manner and payment of the
assessments and the manner of payment of the contractor, and all other matters
and things relating to the collection of assessments and installments thereof,
and the certification and collection of delinquent assessments shall be as
provided in the City Charter, and as provided by the laws of the State of
Oklahoma in force at the time. (1980 Code § 30-34)
   B.   Compliance With Plans And Specifications: All streets, curbs and/or
gutters or sidewalks, or extensions and appurtenances thereto, and any other
improvement within the City, shall be constructed in accordance with plans and
specifications promulgated therefor by the City Engineer. (1980 Code § 30-48)
9-2-3: PROTESTS AGAINST STREET IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Protest Filed With City Clerk: Any person desiring to protest against
street improvements may file their written protests in the Office of the City
Clerk within ten (10) days after the last publication of the notice concerning
such improvements. (1980 Code § 30-35)
   B.   Manner Of Filing: Any protests filed against any street improvements
must be in writing and such protests shall be made separately as to each street
or public way. (1980 Code § 30-36)
   C.   Alteration: After such protest has been filed with the City Clerk
against a street improvement, the same shall be allowed to be altered by any
protestant, by the addition to or withdrawal of any protestant thereto up to
and including the last day of the protest period, provided that such addition
or withdrawal shall be by separate written document. (1980 Code § 30-37)
   D.   Insufficiency: If no sufficient protest against a street improvement be
filed, the Board of Commissioners shall by resolution declare such fact and
shall proceed thereafter as in cases where no notice is required. (1980 Code §
30-38)
9-2-4: WORK RESTRICTED:
   A.   City Authority: No pavement, pavement widening, gutter, or roadway curb
shall hereafter be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, nor shall any
grading or excavation be done within any roadway, except by the duly authorized
employees or agents of the City or of a duly organized special assessment
district, or by a street work contractor bonded as hereinafter provided, except
for excavation as covered by subsections B and C of this section.
   B.   Excavations: No existing pavement, walk, drive, curb or gutter within
any public way shall hereafter be cut or removed, nor shall any trench or
excavation be made in any public way, for the installation, removal, alteration
or repair of pipes, wires, conduits or other facilities or appurtenances
thereto, except by a plumbing, electrical, or street work contractor bonded as
hereinafter provided, or by the duly authorized employees or agents of the
City, a duly organized special assessment district, or a public utility concern
having a franchise for the use of the public ways. (1980 Code § 30-39)
   C.   Replacement: No pavement, walk, drive, curb, or gutter, removed as
described in the preceding subsection, shall be replaced except by a street
work contractor bonded as hereinafter provided, or by the duly authorized
employees or agents of the City, a duly organized special assessment district,
or a public utility concern having a franchise for the use of the public ways.
(1980 Code § 30-39; amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   Curb Removal: No curb shall be removed for a driveway except as above
authorized, or by the owner of the abutting property or the authorized agent
thereof.
   E.   Landscaping: Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit landscaping
and/or planting of trees, grass and shrubs in those portions of the public ways
not immediately required for purposes of public travel, either by employees of
the City or by the owners of abutting property; provided, that such work shall
not interfere with utilities that may be installed in the street or with public
travel. (1980 Code § 30-39)
9-2-5: INSURANCE AND BOND REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall construct, reconstruct, repair or remove any pavement, walk,
drive, curb or gutter within any public way or make any excavation therein
without having first complied with the following requirements:
   A.   Insurance: Having filed with the City Clerk a certificate of insurance
issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of
Oklahoma, in the minimum amounts as prescribed below:
 
Comprehensive liability, each individual $ 50,000.00
Property damage, per accident            25,000.00
Aggregate amount, each occurrence        100,000.00
 
All liability insurance policies shall name the City of Ponca City as an
additional insured and shall otherwise indemnify the City from any claim
arising out of any act, omission, or negligence on the part of a person
insured.
   B.   Bond For Publicly Negotiated Projects: Having deposited with the City
an approved performance bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
conditioned that the contractor and/or his surety will remove any work not
executed in accordance with the specifications hereinafter set forth, and
replace the same to the satisfaction of the City; provided that this provision
shall not apply to a public utility concern having a franchise for the use of
the public ways.
   C.   Bond For Right-Of-Way Work Not A Part Of A Publicly Negotiated Project:
Having deposited with the City an approved permit or license bond in the amount
of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned that the contractor and/or his
surety will remove any work not executed in accordance with the City's
ordinances, standards and regulations, and replace the same to the satisfaction
of the City. By way of explanation and not as a limitation, this provision is
intended to include driveway improvements located within the public rights-of-
way. Additionally, a permit shall be obtained as described in section
9-2-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 6231, 4-24-2017)
9-2-6: PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required; Fee: No person shall cut or remove any pavement, walk,
drive, curb or gutter, or construct or alter any walk, or driveway pavement or
curb, or make any excavation within any public way, without first securing from
the City Engineer a permit therefor, and paying to the City Clerk a permit fee,
together with any other fees hereinafter required for the particular work
involved, in such amount as established by resolution of the Board of
Commissioners from time to time. No permit shall be issued except to a person
authorized under this chapter to perform the work involved. Said permit shall
be in evidence on the job at all times until the work is completed.
   B.   Special Permit For City Work: When it shall become necessary for any of
the departments or employees of the City to tear up or open any part of the
pavement on any of the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public grounds, they
shall secure from the City Engineer a special permit to do so. Such permit
shall provide for no deposit or permit and inspection fee, but all other
portions of this section shall be effective and as fully complied with by City
employees as by other persons. (1980 Code § 30-41; amd. 2003 Code)
9-2-7: UTILITY CUTS; PAYMENT OF COSTS:
   A.   Permit Required: Whenever it shall be necessary to cut or remove any
pavement, walk, drive, curb and gutter or excavate in any roadway, the person
making such cut or excavation shall secure a permit therefor from the City
Engineer or his designee. A separate permit shall be issued for each cut made,
provided that more than one (1) cut may be covered by a single permit, if
located on a single connected installation of new pipe or conduit.
   B.   Replacement Fees: Replacement fees on utility cuts shall be separately
calculated for each permit, on the basis of actual cost.
   C.   Backfilling: All excavations shall be carefully backfilled by the
persons making the same, and the surface, whether or not paved, must be
restored with like kind of materials, and grade, as existing surface. Other
methods of backfilling shall be approved by the City Engineer. Only selected
materials shall be used in making the backfill. No broken concrete, rubble or
debris shall be used as backfill.
   D.   Compliance With City Regulations: In case refilling of any excavation
is not done in accordance with this chapter and the rules and regulations of
the City, and in a manner satisfactory to the City Engineer, then the City
Engineer shall have the right to cause to be taken out all the materials from
the excavation and have the same refilled in a proper manner at the expense of
the party or parties originally making the excavation. (1980 Code § 30-42; amd.
2003 Code)
   E.   Manner Of Payment: No assessment nor installment thereof to be made
pursuant to this section shall be paid other than in cash. (1980 Code § 30-44)
9-2-8: ABANDONMENT AUTHORIZED FOR CERTAIN DELAYS:
Whenever a contract has been entered into for the construction of street
improvement as provided by article VI of the City Charter and the completion of
the same has been delayed by litigation or act of God, the City may, with the
written consent of the contractor, appoint appraisers for the completed part of
the work, and cause assessments to be levied and improvement bonds to be issued
therefor in the manner provided by the statutes of Oklahoma in force at the
time, as modified by the City Charter and by ordinance passed pursuant thereto.
The uncompleted part of the improvement may be abandoned by the contractor by
serving written notice to that effect upon the City. (1980 Code § 30-43)
9-2-9: PROTECTION OF PUBLIC:
All obstructions to public travel shall be properly guarded and barricaded by
the contractor responsible for the same, and kept properly lighted between
sunset and sunrise. No materials or equipment shall be placed on any sidewalk
or roadway unless specifically authorized on the permit, except in that part of
the width of such sidewalk or roadway which must be blocked in any case by the
work under way, or that part of the width of the roadway which might normally
be occupied by standing vehicles. All operations shall be so handled as to
provide minimum hazard to the public and minimum obstruction to traffic. All
rubbish, equipment, and unused materials and supplies shall be removed by the
contractor before his work is opened to traffic. (1980 Code § 30-45)
9-2-10: CLOSURE OF STREETS UNDERGOING IMPROVEMENT:
When sidewalks, curbing, guttering, draining, paving or other street or alley
improvements are in course of construction on any street, alley or other public
place or highway in the City, the Board of Commissioners, or their designee,
shall have authority to close such street, alley or other place against traffic
or travel of every character, pedestrian included, for such time as such
commission or designee shall deem necessary for the proper protection of the
public safety and the security of the improvement. In such event traffic may be
entirely restricted or limited to definite classes. The portion of such street,
alley or other place to be closed shall be barricaded at the limits in such
manner as to indicate to the public that the same is closed, and a placard or
sign shall be erected at each limit stating that such street or alley or other
place is closed by order of the Board of Commissioners. The erecting of such
barricades and signs shall be deemed sufficient notice to the public and it
shall be no defense to a prosecution hereunder that any such barricade or sign
had been removed by some person without authority. (1980 Code § 30-46; amd.
2003 Code)
9-2-11: PROHIBITED ACTS; REMOVING BARRICADES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or destroy any barricade or sign
erected as provided in section
9-2-9 of this chapter, or to walk, drive animals or automobiles, or otherwise
travel upon any street, alley or other place, or portion thereof, closed as
provided in section
9-2-10 of this chapter, except as may be necessary in the proper construction
of the improvements thereon. (1980 Code § 30-47)
CHAPTER 3
PARKING LOTS
SECTION:
9-3-1: Application For Permit
9-3-2: Permit Fee
9-3-3: Bond Required
9-3-4: Insurance Required
9-3-5: Liability Of Owner Or Operator
9-3-6: Specifications
9-3-1: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person desiring to construct a parking lot shall submit to the building
official a plot plan showing the parking arrangement, methods of ingress and
egress, and other essential data as may be required by the building official
and make written application for a building permit. (1980 Code § 30-90; amd.
2003 Code)
9-3-2: PERMIT FEE:
Before commencing improvements upon any parking lot, the owner or operator
shall purchase from the building official a building permit, in such amount as
established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time,
which sum shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. (1980 Code § 30-
91; amd. 2003 Code)
9-3-3: BOND REQUIRED:
Any person who desires to engage in the business of surfacing or paving parking
lots within the city shall first execute and deliver to the city clerk a
performance bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). Such
bond shall run in the favor of the city and be conditioned upon the performance
of all installations of surfacing or paving made by them or under their
direction and shall be made in conformance with the minimum requirements of
this code. Any persons aggrieved may bring any action upon and with equal
rights as though such aggrieved persons had been named as the obligee in said
bond. (1980 Code § 30-92)
9-3-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
In addition to executing the required bond, every person desiring to carry on a
business as a parking lot contractor, before being permitted to file the bond
as above referred to, shall first file with the city clerk subject to the
approval of the board of commissioners, an owner's protective policy with the
city as named insured in the amounts of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) bodily injury each person, three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) bodily injury each accident and fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) property damage each accident. (1980 Code § 30-93)
9-3-5: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR OPERATOR:
The owner or operator of any such parking lot assumes responsibility for proper
drainage and proper grades for same, and the city shall not be responsible for
damages resulting from drainage or grades on or from such parking lot. (1980
Code § 30-94)
9-3-6: SPECIFICATIONS:
All parking lots and the portion of their driveways on private property shall
be covered with a crushed rock base having a double bituminous seal coat, using
either chips or sand, at twenty three (23) pounds per square yard for each coat
and a minimum of two-tenths (2/10) gallon of seal coat per square yard and
using an approved grade of asphaltic material, or equivalent specification.
(1980 Code § 30-95)
CHAPTER 4
STREET ADDRESS NUMBERS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Permit Required; Application
9-4-2: Investigation Of Applicant
9-4-3: Fee
9-4-4: Minimum Age Requirement
9-4-5: Painting Street Address Numbers On Curbs
9-4-6: Marking Standards
9-4-7: Penalty
9-4-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
A permit may be issued to persons desiring to paint street address numbers upon
the curbs of public streets of the city, and charging a fee for said service,
subject to the following limitations and requirements:
   A.   Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business
of painting street address numbers upon the curbs of public streets within the
corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit from the city
clerk.
   B.   Application: Applicants for the permit required by this chapter shall
file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing containing the
following information:
      1.   The full name, description, birth date and social security number of
each applicant.
      2.   His/her address both legal and local.
      3.   If employed by another, the name and address of applicant's
employer, together with a brief description of credentials showing the exact
relationship.
      4.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of
a felony, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed
therefor. (1980 Code § 30-131)
9-4-2: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
   A.   Conduct Of Investigation: Upon receipt of application for the permit as
set out in section
9-4-1 of this chapter, the city clerk shall refer a copy to the chief of
police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and
moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the
public and for the public welfare.
   B.   Disapproval: If, as a result of investigation, the applicant's
character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief
of police shall endorse on the application his disapproval and his reason for
the same, and return the application to the city clerk, and no permit shall be
issued.
   C.   Approval: If, as a result of investigation, the character and business
responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, he shall endorse
on the application his approval, and return the application to the city clerk,
who shall, upon payment of the required fee, issue the permit to the applicant.
(1980 Code § 30-132)
9-4-3: FEE:
   A.   Individual: Upon approval of the application of any individual to paint
street address numbers upon the curbs of public streets of Ponca City as
previously set out, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk such amount as
established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time for
the permit fee for one year, prior to receiving a permit from the city clerk.
   B.   Nonprofit Organizations: Nonprofit organizations, which have their
principal place of activity within the city, wishing to paint street address
numbers upon the curbs of the public streets within the city as a fund raising
project shall be exempt from paying the permit fee, but must comply with all
other provisions of this chapter. (1980 Code § 30-134; amd. 2003 Code)
9-4-4: MINIMUM AGE REQUIREMENT:
No permit shall be issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to any
persons under the age of eighteen (18) years. (1980 Code § 30-133)
9-4-5: PAINTING STREET ADDRESS NUMBERS ON CURBS:
   A.   Hours For Solicitation Of Business: No solicitations shall be conducted
within the city between the hours of one-half (1/2) hour before sunset and nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following morning. (1980 Code § 30-135)
   B.   Permission Of Owner Required: No markings provided for in this chapter
shall be installed without prior permission of the owner or occupant of the
property and his approval of the fee charged. (1980 Code § 30-136)
9-4-6: MARKING STANDARDS:
   A.   All markings shall consist of three inch (3") to four inch (4") black
numerals stenciled upon a painted white background.
   B.   All paints shall be waterproof when dry and recommended by the
manufacturer for outdoor application on concrete surfaces.
   C.   Markings shall be located on the vertical surface of the street curb
two feet (2') from the "house side" of the drive approach unless the resident
desires the markings to be placed upon the curb(s) of the drive approach. In
the absence of a drive approach, the markings shall be placed on the street
curb near the center of the property. (1980 Code § 30-137)
9-4-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to penalty
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Every act of solicitation without a permit shall constitute
a separate offense. (1980 Code § 30-138; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 5
LAKE PONCA REGULATIONS
SECTION:
