9-5-20: Penalties For Violation
9-5-1: PARK RANGER:
(Rep. by Ord. 6349, 11-11-2024)
9-5-2: ASSUMPTION OF RISK:
All persons, whether adult or minor, participating in water sports at Lake
Ponca shall do so at their own risk. (1980 Code § 18-5)
9-5-3: FEES FOR LOTS, DOCKS, SHELTERS:
   A.   Rental Fees For Lake Lots And Ski Docks: The annual fees for leasing of
Lake Lots and Ski Docks at Lake Ponca shall be determined by the Board of
Commissioners.
   B.   Rental Fees For Use Of Picnic Shelters:
      1.   Picnic Shelters are available for three different rental blocks:
         a.   8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m.; and
         b.   12:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.; and
         c.   5:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m.
      2.   Rates are established for picnic shelters located in Ponca City by
resolution of the Board of Commissioners.
   C.   Nontransferable: The established rates are not negotiable, transferable
and/or refundable. (Ord. 5955, 8-27-2001; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 6317, 11-14-
2022)
9-5-4: SHELTERS; PAVILIONS:
Any person residing in the Ponca City Utility Authority servicing area and
paying a Ponca City Utility Authority utility bill, may lease or purchase a
lease of a Ponca City Lake Lot. There are One Hundred Fourteen (114) total Lake
Lots available.
   A.   Building Design: Design of the building must comply with City of Ponca
City Standard Operations Policy No. 18.
   B.   Sleeping Quarters: Such buildings may be used as sleeping quarters,
provided:
      1.   Persons using the facility, other than the lessee, must possess on
their person, a consent signed by the lessee allowing them the use of the
facilities.
      2.   Overnight stays will be limited to seven (7) nights during any ten
(10) day period and shall be for recreational purposes only.
      3.   Persons staying overnight must be at least twenty-one (21) years of
age or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
   C.   Toilet Facilities: Lake Lots are permitted to have either an external
Port-O-Let or an internal Electric Incinerating Toilet.
   D.   Maintenance: The lessee has the sole responsibility of maintenance and
upkeep of land and any structure on leased land from the City. Should the
structure fall into disrepair or the lessee fail to abide by and perform each
and every condition of use imposed by the City of Ponca City Standard
Operations Policy No. 18 and the Lake Lot Lease or any part thereof, use of
Lake Lot shall be subject to termination. The person leasing or placing such
structure on a Lake Lot shall be entitled to no compensation therefor, being
construed to have abandoned the same. Any person who shall erect any type of
structure on a Lake Lot shall be held to have accepted the above provision as a
condition of receiving permission to erect the same. (1980 Code § 18-9; amd.
2003 Code; Ord. 6317, 11-14-2022)
9-5-5: SPECIAL PENALTIES IN CONNECTION WITH STRUCTURES:
Any person who shall erect any dock, boathouse, motor house, shelter or
pavilion on Lake Ponca, other than in a location approved by the city or not in
conformity with the structural requirements hereinabove prescribed, or without
the approval of the plans and specifications therefor by the city or who shall
permit such structure to go adrift or to become dilapidated or unsightly, or
who shall erect such a structure without having secured a license to operate a
boat upon the said lake or who, during the continuance of such structure on the
lake, shall permit such license to lapse, or shall use such structure for any
illegal purpose, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, including costs, for each offense. Each of the actions
enumerated above shall be deemed a separate offense. Each day that any
structure not conforming to the requirements hereof shall be upon such lake
shall constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 18-10; amd. 2003 Code)
9-5-6: BOATING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Rental Prohibited: Owners of private boats of all types shall not be
permitted to rent their boats for use on Lake Ponca or to collect fares or to
take donations for the use of the same. (1980 Code § 18-22)
   B.   Control Of Unsafe Boats: If a park ranger observes a boat or vessel
being used without sufficient approved lifesaving devices or in an overloaded
or other unsafe condition, and in his judgment such use creates a hazardous
condition, he shall direct the operator to take whatever immediate and
reasonable steps would be necessary for the safety of those aboard the vessel,
including directing the operator to return to mooring and to remain there until
the situation creating the hazard is corrected or ended. (1980 Code § 18-23;
amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Identification Of Restricted Areas: All restricted areas and safety
zones on Lake Ponca shall be suitably marked by buoys and other markers. (1980
Code § 18-24)
   D.   Transportation Of Alcoholic Beverages: It shall be unlawful for any
person to knowingly transport in any motor boat or vessel or while manipulating
any water skis, surfboard or similar device upon the navigable waters of Lake
Ponca any alcoholic beverage, except in the original container which shall not
have been opened and from which the original cap or seal shall not have been
removed. (1980 Code § 18-25; amd. 2003 Code)
   E.   Required Equipment And Devices:
      1.   Lighting: No motor propelled boat shall be allowed to operate on
Lake Ponca at night except boats having a white light to the rear and a green
light showing to starboard (right) and a red light showing to port (left).
Sailboats shall comply with U.S. coast guard rules for lighting. (1980 Code §
18-26)
      2.   Fire Extinguishers: All motorboats shall carry at least one U.S.
coast guard approved portable fire extinguisher which shall be readily
accessible and in good and serviceable condition. (1980 Code § 18-27)
      3.   Air Chambers In Metal Boats: All metal boats shall be equipped with
an air chamber or chambers of sufficient displacement to ensure buoyancy of the
craft and passengers in the event of capsizing, except fiberglass boats shall
comply with U.S. Coast Guard rules as to air chambers in effect at the time of
construction. (1980 Code § 18-28)
      4.   Exhaust: All motorboats must be equipped with exhaust which exists
below the water line when the boat is unoccupied and not under way, or through
transform exhaust on the boat. (1980 Code § 18-29)
      5.   Flotation Devices: No person shall operate any boat on Lake Ponca
unless there is at least one personal flotation device for each person in the
boat approved by the U.S. Coast Guard, which flotation device is designed to
keep a conscious person in a vertical or slightly backward position, and has at
least fifteen and five-tenths (15.5) pounds of buoyancy. (1980 Code § 18-30)
   F.   Unsightly, Unsafe, Abandoned Boats: If any person shall permit his boat
to fall into disrepair or become unsightly in appearance or unsafe for
operation, or abandoned, or fail to care for a boat for an unreasonable length
of time, or fail to provide a current license for his boat, the park ranger is
hereby empowered to remove the boat from the lake, or lakeshore as the case may
be. If any boat so removed is not claimed within thirty (30) days, the boat
will be confiscated and disposed of by the park ranger without compensation or
remuneration to the owner thereof, it being construed to have been abandoned.
(1980 Code § 18-31; amd. 2003 Code)
   G.   Length Of Motorboats Generally: (Rep. by Ord. 6249, 12-11-2017)
   H.   Persons Seated: No person shall ride on or in any motorboat being
operated on Lake Ponca except in a seat provided by the boat manufacturer for
passenger or operator of said boat. (1980 Code § 18-33)
9-5-7: BOAT OPERATORS; LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
    DAILY: Sunup to sundown to daylight of the following day of the date of
issue.
   DISABILITY: Same qualifications as required by the State of Oklahoma
disability lifetime fishing license.
   FAMILY: Resident family members sixteen (16) years of age or older living in
same household.
   NONRESIDENT: Any person without a Ponca City mailing address.
   RESIDENT: Any person with a Ponca City mailing address.
   SENIOR CITIZEN: Any person fifty five (55) years of age or older. (1980 Code
§ 18-42)
   B.   License Required: No person shall be allowed to have or operate any
boat upon Lake Ponca without first acquiring an annual or daily license
therefor and complying with the provisions of this section. (1980 Code § 18-41)
   C.   Minimum Age: No license required by the provisions of this section
shall be issued to any person under the age of sixteen (16) years. (1980 Code §
18-43)
   D.   Inspection Of Boats: All boats may be inspected for safety and
seaworthiness by the park ranger, prior to the granting of any license; and a
like inspection shall be made upon the granting of each annual license
thereafter. Each license shall state the number of persons the boat is licensed
to carry. The carrying of a number of persons in excess of that specified on
the license shall be deemed sufficient cause to revoke the license. No boat
shall be licensed or relicensed if, in the judgment of the park ranger, it is
unsafe for operation on Lake Ponca. (Ord. 6228, 2-13-2017)
   E.   Fees:
      1.   The permit fees for watercraft operated in Lake Ponca and for
watercraft dealers or demonstrators shall be in such amounts as established by
resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time.
      2.   Such fees are not negotiable, transferable or refundable. (1980 Code
§§ 18-45, 18-47; amd. 2003 Code)
      3.   No fee required by the provisions of this section shall be prorated.
(1980 Code § 18-48; amd. 2003 Code)
   F.   Issuance Of License: All boat licenses required by the provisions of
this section shall be issued by the park ranger or such other city employee as
may be designated by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 49; amd. 2003
Code)
   G.   License Nontransferable: No license issued under the provisions of this
section shall be transferable to any other person. (Ord. 6230, 3-13-2017)
   H.   Expiration Dates Of Licenses:
      1.   Any annual license issued under the provisions of this section shall
expire on December 31 following its date of issuance. (1980 Code § 18-51; amd.
2003 Code)
      2.   Daily: Any daily license issued under the provisions of this section
shall expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of the day of issuance thereof.
(1980 Code § 18-52)
   I.   Boat Operation: No person may operate a boat on Lake Ponca that is in
violation of the provisions of this chapter. Each operator or other licensee
under this chapter shall carry their license upon their person while on Lake
Ponca and produce it upon demand of any city employee authorized to require the
same. (Ord. 6228, 2-13-2017)
   J.   Tag Attached To Boat: The annual license of each boat shall be
designated by proper tag on the side of the boat, which must be plainly visible
for a distance of at least one hundred feet (100') from said boat. Such tag
shall be furnished with the license by the city. (1980 Code § 18-54)
   K.   Revocation Of License: Upon application by the city attorney, notice
thereof to the licensee, and hearing, the municipal judge may revoke or suspend
any license issued under the provisions of this section for licensee's
violation of any applicable provision of state law or this code. (1980 Code §
18-55; amd. 2003 Code)
9-5-8: BOAT OPERATION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Careful And Prudent Operation: Every operator of a boat shall at all
times operate the boat in a careful and prudent manner and at such rate of
speed as not to endanger the life, limb or property of any other person, and
shall obey all posted speed limits. (1980 Code § 18-63)
   B.   Operation Restricted: All persons are hereby prohibited from operating
any boat upon Lake Ponca at any time when, in the judgment of the park ranger,
the water is sufficiently rough to be dangerous. (1980 Code § 18-64; amd. 2003
Code)
   C.   Minors Restricted:
      1.   63 Oklahoma Statutes, section 4231 et seq. (except section 4235)
(the Kyle Williams boating safety education act), and associated definitions
and future amendments thereto are hereby adopted by reference and are made a
part of this subsection as if fully set out herein.
      2.   Provided that anywhere the age of twelve (12) years is mentioned in
said act, the age of fourteen (14) years shall be substituted in its stead.
      3.   No person under the age of fourteen (14) years may operate a motor
powered watercraft of any kind unless:
         a.   Accompanied by an adult eighteen (18) years of age or older
experienced in watercraft operations who is in/on the craft and who is in a
position to take immediate control of the craft in the event of danger; and
         b.   Has completed a boating safety education course and received a
boating education certificate; and
         c.   Is wearing a coast guard approved flotation device.
         d.   In such instances the adult shall be fully responsible for the
operation of the watercraft.
      4.   Any parent, legal guardian or person having actual responsibility
for a person under sixteen (16) years of age, or who is the owner of the vessel
operated by a person under sixteen (16) years of age, who knows, or should have
known that the person operating the vessel is not in compliance with the
boating safety certification required by the act shall be guilty of an offense
which shall be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) upon first offense. Any second or subsequent conviction shall be
punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      5.   Any minor's violation of the conditions of this section, as the
operator of the watercraft, shall be an offense punishable within the juvenile
and monetary jurisdictional limits of the court. (Ord. 6052, 4-23-2007, eff. 7-
1-2007)
   D.   Use Of Certain Kinds Of Boats Restricted:
      1.   Inflatable Vessels: Inflatable vessels that are approved and stamped
by the National Marine Manufacturers Association may only be operated on Lake
Ponca in the designated "no wake" areas.
      2.   Pontoon Boats: Motor propelled pontoon boats of not more than twenty
eight feet (28') in length may operate on Lake Ponca if licensed as required by
this chapter, but shall not operate at a speed such as to leave a visible wake
outside the designated ski area of West Lake Ponca and not to exceed the posted
speed limit in the designated ski area.
      3.   Paddleboats: Small paddleboats, propelled by foot driven propulsion,
such as may be approved by the park ranger, may be operated on Lake Ponca.
Paddleboats must be registered with the state and city and shall not operate in
the ski area at any time.
   E.   Fishing: Motor propelled boats shall be allowed on any neck or bay of
Lake Ponca only for the purpose of fishing and shall move only at such speed as
shall not create a visible wake. Tube fishing shall only be allowed in
designated "no wake" areas. (Ord. 6228, 2-13-2017)
   F.   Operation While Intoxicated:
      1.   Prohibited: No person shall operate any motorboat or vessel, or
manipulate any water skis, surfboard, or similar device while intoxicated or
under the influence of any substance included in the uniform controlled
dangerous substances act 1  of the state. (1980 Code § 18-70)
      2.   Evidence, Chemical Analysis: Upon the trial of any criminal action
or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any person
while operating any motorboat or vessel or manipulating any water skis,
surfboard or similar device while under the influence of alcoholic beverage,
evidence of the amount of alcohol in the person's blood as shown by a chemical
analysis of his blood or breath is admissible. For the purpose of this section:
         a.   Evidence that there was five-hundredths of one percent (0.05%) or
less by weight of alcohol in his blood is prima facie evidence that the person
was not under the influence of alcoholic beverage.
         b.   Evidence that there was more than five-hundredths of one percent
(0.05%) by weight of alcohol in the person's blood is relevant evidence of
operating any motorboat or vessel or manipulating any water skis, surfboard or
similar device while his ability to operate such motorboat or vessel or
manipulating any water skis, surfboard or similar device is impaired by the
consumption of alcoholic beverage; however, no person shall be convicted of the
offense of operating a motorboat or vessel or manipulating any water skis,
surfboard or similar device while his ability to operate such motorboat or
vessel or manipulating any water skis, surfboard or similar device while his
ability to operate such is impaired by consumption of alcoholic beverage solely
because there was more than five-hundredths of one percent (0.05%) by weight of
alcohol in the person's blood in the absence of additional evidence that such
person's ability to operate the above boats or other devices was affected by
said consumption of alcohol to the extent that the public health and safety was
threatened or that said person had violated a state statute or local ordinance
in the operation of a motorboat or vessel or manipulating any water skis,
surfboard or similar device.
         c.   Evidence that there was ten-hundredths of one percent (0.10%) or
more by weight of alcohol in his blood shall be admitted as prima facie
evidence that the person was under the influence of alcoholic beverage.
         d.   Percent by weight of alcohol in the blood shall be based upon
grams of alcohol per one hundred milliliters (100 ml) of blood.
         e.   To be admissible such evidence must first be qualified by
establishing that such specimen was obtained from the subject within not more
than two (2) hours of the arrest of the subject. (1980 Code § 18-71; amd. 2003
Code)
      3.   Refusal To Be Tested: If a conscious person under arrest refuses to
submit to a chemical test, none shall be given; but the park ranger, if he has
reasonable grounds to believe that the arrested person has been operating a
motorboat or vessel or manipulating water skis, surfboard or similar device
upon Lake Ponca and the person has refused to submit to a chemical test, shall
have the right to revoke the arrested individual's privilege of operating a
motorboat, sailboat, water skis, surfboard or any other similar device upon
Lake Ponca for a period of one year. (1980 Code § 18-72; amd. 2003 Code)
      4.   Appeal: Upon written request of the individual whose privilege to
operate a motorboat, sailboat, water skis or similar device upon Lake Ponca has
been denied by the park ranger, the board of commissioners shall grant the
person an opportunity to be heard within ten (10) days after receipt of written
request from said individual, but the request must be made within thirty (30)
days after denial of the privilege of operating a motorboat, sailboat, water
skis, or surfboard upon said lake by the park ranger. The scope of the hearing
shall cover the issue of whether the person had been operating one of the above
described devices upon Lake Ponca while under the influence of an alcoholic
beverage and whether the person was placed under arrest and whether he refused
to submit to the test or tests. The board of commissioners shall order either
that the denial of the privilege of operating one of the above mentioned
devices upon Lake Ponca be rescinded or sustained. (1980 Code § 18-73; amd.
2003 Code)
   G.   Reckless Operation:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a boat on Lake Ponca
in a reckless manner. Reckless operation of a boat includes operating the boat
in a manner which unnecessarily interferes with the free and proper use of the
navigable waters of Lake Ponca or unnecessarily endangers other boats therein,
or the life and liberty of any person.
      2.   Upon conviction of operating a motorboat or vessel, or manipulating
skis, surfboard, jet skis, sailboat or other watercraft upon Lake Ponca in a
manner not reasonable or proper, the municipal judge may revoke the convicted
individual(s) privilege of operating a motorboat, sailboat, water skis,
surfboard, jet skis, or other watercraft upon Lake Ponca for a period of one
year from date of conviction.
      3.   Upon written request of the individual whose privilege to operate a
watercraft upon Lake Ponca has been revoked, the board of commissioners shall
grant the person an opportunity to be heard within ten (10) days after receipt
of written notice from said individual, but the request must be made within
thirty (30) days after revocation of the privilege of operating such
watercraft. Upon hearing, the board of commissioners may sustain, overrule or
modify the revocation imposed by the municipal judge. (1980 Code § 18-74)
   H.   Exemption For Racing: Nothing contained in this section shall be
construed to prevent the operator of a boat lawfully competing in an event
which is authorized from attempting to attain high speeds on a marked racing
course. (1980 Code § 18-75)
   I.   Speed Generally: Jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices operating
inside of the area designated for their use may be operated at speeds creating
visible wake, but all motor propelled boats operating outside of the designated
ski area shall be operated at such speeds as not to create a visible wake,
except by special permit issued by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 18-
76)
   J.   Proximity To Other Boats: Motor propelled boats shall at all times keep
a safe distance from other boats. Motor propelled boats, while cruising at
speeds such as to create a visible wake, shall not come nearer than seventy
five feet (75') to any bank, dock or other structure on said lake. (1980 Code §
18-77)
   K.   Right Of Way:
      1.   Generally: Rowboats shall have the right of way at all times over
sailboats except during sanctioned competitive events. Sailboats shall have the
right of way at all times over motorboats. Police boats have the right of way
over all boats at all times. (1980 Code § 18-78)
      2.   Meeting, Overtaking:
         a.   When two (2) boats are approaching each other "head on" or nearly
so (so as to involve risk of collisions) each boat shall bear to the right and
pass the other boat on its left side.
         b.   When motor propelled boats approach each other obliquely, or at a
right angle, the boat approaching on the right side has the right of way.
         c.   One boat may overtake another on either side but shall grant
right of way to the overtaken boat. (1980 Code § 18-79)
   L.   Stopping Ability: No person shall operate any boat at a rate of speed
greater than will permit him, in the exercise of reasonable care, to bring the
boat to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. (1980 Code § 18-80)
   M.   Lookout: The operator of a boat on Lake Ponca shall keep a proper
lookout at all times while under way. (1980 Code § 18-81)
   N.   Jet Skis, Ski Bikes Or Similar Devices:
      1.   Designated Area: Jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices may be
operated in the East Lake of Lake Ponca at no wake, not to exceed fifteen (15)
miles per hour. (1980 Code § 18-82)
      2.   Regulations: All jet skis, ski bikes or similar devices must be
registered with the state of Oklahoma and licensed by the city. All operators
of such devices must wear United States coast guard life preservers at all
times, and operators of such equipment must conform to the water rules,
regulations and safety laws which apply to the operation of boats in Lake
Ponca. (1980 Code § 18-83)
 
Notes
1 1. 63 OS § 2-101 et seq.
9-5-9: WATERSKIING:
   A.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, the term "waterskiing"
shall mean the activity of being propelled along the water upon devices known
as skis and being at the same time towed by some type of boat and shall include
the use of surfboards, ski bikes, or any other device which may be used to
sustain any person upon the water while being towed by a motorboat. (1980 Code
§ 18-91)
   B.   Permit Requirements:
      1.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for the operation of any boat
to engage in the activity of waterskiing at Lake Ponca, if such boat does not
have a permit to participate in the activity of waterskiing.
      2.   Permit Fees:
         a.   The fees for waterskiing permits shall be in such amounts as
established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time.
         b.   Said permit fees are not negotiable, transferable or refundable.
      3.   Duration Of Permit:
         a.   Annual waterskiing permits shall be valid for one year, from
January 1 until December 31.
         b.   Daily waterskiing permits shall be valid from eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M. until sunset of the day for which issued.
      4.   Permit Nontransferable: No permit for waterskiing shall be
negotiable or transferable, and only the boat the permit is issued for shall be
entitled to use the same.
      5.   Revocation Of Permit: Upon application by the city attorney, notice
thereof to the permittee, and hearing, the municipal judge may revoke or
suspend any permit issued under the provisions of this section for permittee's
violation of any applicable provision of state law or this code.
   C.   Area Restricted: No person shall engage in waterskiing on Lake Ponca
except in the areas outlined by buoys for such activity by the park ranger.
(Ord. 6228, 2-13-2017)
   D.   Inexperienced Boat Operators: Persons inexperienced in boat operations
or persons under the age of fifteen (15) years shall not operate a boat which
is engaged in activity skiing upon Lake Ponca, unless accompanied by an adult
experienced in boat operations. (1980 Code § 18-94)
   E.   Proximity To Other Boats: At no time shall boats approach a boat
pulling skiers closer than fifty feet (50') to the boat or skiers. (1980 Code §
18-100)
   F.   Traffic Pattern: A counterclockwise pattern shall be maintained by all
boats in designated ski area on West Lake Ponca. (1980 Code § 18-101)
   G.   Maximum Number Of Skiers: No more than two (2) skiers shall be
permitted to be pulled by the same boat at any one time. (1980 Code § 18-102)
   H.   Swimming: (Rep. by Ord. 6122, 7-12-2010)
   I.   Personal Flotation Device: It shall be unlawful for any person to
manipulate water skis, surfboards or similar devices on Lake Ponca unless said
person being towed is wearing a coast guard approved flotation device. All
persons twelve (12) years of age or under shall wear a coast guard approved
flotation device while engaged in any water activity on Lake Ponca. (1980 Code
§ 18-105)
   J.   Speed: No boat shall be operated at a speed greater than thirty five
(35) miles per hour in the ski area of Lake Ponca without special permission
from the park ranger; boats shall be operated on East Lake at no wake not to
exceed fifteen (15) miles per hour. (1980 Code § 18-106; amd. 2003 Code)
   K.   Extra Passenger; Safety Precaution: No boat shall operate on Lake Ponca
while pulling one or more persons engaged in the activity of waterskiing if
said boat does not have another individual besides the operator of said boat
above twelve (12) years of age, or unless a rearview mirror has been installed
on such vessel in such manner as to permit the person operating said vessel to
face the direction of travel and be in a position to observe the progress of
the person or persons being towed. (1980 Code § 18-107)
9-5-10: FISHING:
   A.   Compliance With Local Regulations: It shall be unlawful for any person
to fish at Lake Ponca except in compliance with the provisions of this section.
(1980 Code § 18-119)
   B.   Licensing Requirements:
      1.   Required: Only those persons owning a current state fishing license
and a current city fishing license shall be permitted to fish in Lake Ponca.
(1980 Code § 18-136)
      2.   Eligibility: Any person legally entitled to fish in the state shall
be eligible for a city fishing license. (1980 Code § 18-137)
      3.   Annual License Fees:
         a.   The fees for fishing permits for Lake Ponca shall be in such
amounts as established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to
time.
         b.   Said permit fees are not negotiable, transferable or refundable.
(1980 Code § 18-138; amd. 2003 Code)
      4.   Waiver Of Fee: Any person entitled to fish in the state but exempt
by state law from purchasing a state fishing license may, upon application to
the park ranger, be issued a city fishing license without charge. (1980 Code §
18-140; amd. 2003 Code)
      5.   Possession, Display: Each person licensed to fish in Lake Ponca
shall carry his licenses upon his person while fishing and produce them upon
demand of any city employee authorized to require the same. (1980 Code § 18-
141)
   C.   Use Of Boats Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person to fish
from a boat unless such boat has been licensed to operate on the lake. (1980
Code § 18-120)
   D.   Safety Rules: Proper observance of rules for safety of all fishermen or
other persons legally upon Lake Ponca shall be strictly observed. (1980 Code §
18-121)
   E.   Restricted In Ski Areas: No fishing will be permitted in the ski area
as outlined by the park ranger after twelve o'clock (12:00) noon.
   F.   Size And Bag Limits:
      1.   Compliance With State Law: Size and bag limits shall be the same
size and bag limits as set forth by state laws and regulations with exceptions
noted in subsection F2, "Certain Fish, Specific Limits", of this section.
      2.   Certain Fish, Specific Limits: No largemouth bass or smallmouth bass
may be removed from Lake Ponca unless the length of each exceeds fourteen
inches (14"). Aggregate daily creel of largemouth, smallmouth and/or spotted
bass shall not exceed six (6) fish each day. Aggregate daily creel of white
bass and striped bass hybrids shall not exceed five (5) fish each and only two
(2) of the striped bass hybrids may be twenty inches (20") or longer. No
walleye or saugeye may be removed from Lake Ponca unless their length is a
minimum of eighteen inches (18") and a daily creel of six (6) fish.
   G.   Seines, Nets And Traps: It shall be unlawful for any person to use
seines, trawl nets or traps for fishing and/or catching game fish. Casting nets
and handheld dip nets may be used for taking nongame fish species only as bait
for personal use at Lake Ponca, not to exceed fifty (50) nongame fish,
including shad. Casting nets shall have a mesh size not to exceed three-eighths
inch (3/8") square. All persons utilizing these methods are required to have a
valid Lake Ponca fishing permit and a valid state of Oklahoma fishing license.
   H.   Lures, Baits Restricted: Only artificial lures and live bait, such as
worms, minnows or crawfish or fresh bait, such as fresh and unspoiled or
untainted shrimp, liver, beef, or other fresh meats which would be fit for
human consumption, may be used for fishing bait in Lake Ponca.
   I.   Trotlines Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to use throw
lines, trotlines, limb lines, jug lines or other similar devices commonly
referred to as trotline fishing in Lake Ponca.
   J.   Refuse: It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or otherwise
deposit bait, trash or other refuse into the lake.
   K.   Noodling Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to noodle in
Lake Ponca. (Ord. 6228, 2-13-2017)
9-5-11: CAMPING:
   A.   Use Of Campgrounds; Permission Required: The provisions of this section
are hereby established for all persons using or present at the city operated
camping facilities at Lake Ponca, and all camping, including the use of tents,
recreational camping vehicles and camping units, is limited to use in such
designated camping areas, except for camping by organized groups or individuals
at organized events with permission to camp elsewhere first being obtained from
the park ranger. (1980 Code § 18-153; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Fees:
      1.   The fees for rentals at Lake Ponca campgrounds shall be in such
amounts as established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to
time.
      2.   Individuals fifty five (55) years old and older will pay reduced
fees in such amounts as established by resolution of the board of commissioners
from time to time. (1980 Code § 18-154; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Maximum Period Of Time: No one person or group of persons shall be
allowed to camp within any camping area for more than two (2) weeks. (1980 Code
§ 18-155)
   D.   Misuse Of Facilities: It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy or
otherwise misuse any facility at a camping area. (1980 Code § 18-156)
   E.   Speed Limit: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle
at a rate of speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour in any camping area.
(1980 Code § 18-157)
   F.   Parking: It shall be unlawful for any person to park or remain standing
any vehicle except in areas specifically designated for such purposes. (1980
Code § 18-158)
   G.   Clearance Between Trailers: A distance of eight feet (8') shall be
maintained at all times between trailers and other camping or recreational
vehicles parked in camping areas. (1980 Code § 18-159)
   H.   Trash Disposal: Any and all trash generated by any person within a
camping area shall be placed in refuse containers provided therefor. (1980 Code
§ 18-160; amd. 2003 Code)
   I.   Fires Restricted: All fires set within camping areas shall be in
designated areas. (1980 Code § 18-161)
   J.   Dogs Or Cats: It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit a
dog or cat to be within any camping area unless such dog or cat is on a leash
at all times. (1980 Code § 18-162; amd. 2003 Code)
   K.   Noise Control: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a
motorcycle, motor bicycle, television or phonographic equipment after ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. within the camping facilities. (1980 Code § 18-163)
   L.   Disturbances: It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb other
persons in the camping areas by any loud or unusual noise, loud language or by
any other improper behavior. (1980 Code § 18-164)
9-5-12: NATURE CENTER AND WETLANDS PROTECTION AREA:
   A.   Reservation Of Nature Center: An area of approximately thirty (30)
acres located in the southeast corner of Lake Ponca Park, generally described
as southeast quarter of section 19, township 26 north, range 3 east shall be
reserved for a nature center. (1980 Code § 18-170)
   B.   Use Of Nature Center: The nature center shall be for the use and
benefit of the residents of Ponca City and shall be an outdoor laboratory for
the education of students of the Ponca City public schools. (1980 Code § 18-
171; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Wetlands: Within the nature center, an area generally located along the
northern and western boundary, comprising approximately one and seven-tenths
(1.7) acres, and delineated in exhibit A attached to ordinance 5763 on file in
the office of the city clerk, shall be deemed wetlands under the federal
definition of section 404, clean water act of January 1992. Such wetlands shall
be preserved and protected by the city in accordance with environmental
concerns. (1980 Code § 18-172; amd. 2003 Code)
9-5-13: SWIMMING IN LAKE PONCA PERMITTED; HOURS; VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Swimming in Lake Ponca is only permitted during daylight hours between
dawn and dusk in the following areas:
      1.   Any designated shoreside or beachside water area marked by a
floating buoy line that separates the designated swimming zone from the rest of
the lake, and is identified by signage allowing swimming; and
      2.   Permitted or city-owned ski docks allow swimming between the
proximate shoreline and lake facing edge of the dock;
   B.   Swimming in Lake Ponca is always prohibited and considered a violation
in the following areas:
      1.   The west fishing dock, east fishing dock, Hartford ramp, Windmill
Cove dock, and the deep-water-make-ready-dock are always closed to swimming.
      2.   A dive or jump into the lake from an elevation higher than two feet
(2') above the surface of the lake water or in an area in which swimming is not
permitted.
   C.   No water vessels of any kind shall be operated in or approach nearer
than fifty feet (50') to swimming areas designated by connected buoys. (Ord.
6122, 7-12-2010; amd. Ord. 6352, 4-14-2025)
9-5-14: PADDLEBOARDS:
Paddleboards shall be allowed on Lake Ponca under the same processes and for
the same fees as other vessels. Paddleboards may launch from Lake Ponca boat
ramps, public ski docks, private docks or any public shore area adjacent to a
no wake area; they shall be restricted to slow speed within no wake zones, and
operated during daylight hours only. Paddleboards must be equipped with a
whistle, and a coast guard approved personal flotation device must be worn by
operator. (Ord. 6217, 1-25-2016)
9-5-15: RESERVED:
(Ord. 6122, 7-12-2010)

9-5-20: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION:
Any violation of the provisions of this chapter, shall be an offense punishable
within the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court. (Ord. 6122, 7-12-2010)
CHAPTER 6
PARKS AND RECREATION
SECTION:
9-6-1: Operation Of Motor Vehicles
9-6-2: Glass Beverage Containers
9-6-3: Closing Hours For City Parks
9-6-1: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
All motorized vehicles are prohibited from operating in public parks and upon
public lands of the city except as follows:
   A.   Authorized service and maintenance equipment.
   B.   Motorized vehicles bearing current licenses for the state in which they
are registered may operate in those areas maintained for roadways and vehicular
parking areas.
   C.   Motorized vehicles not bearing current licenses for the state of
residence of the owner may operate in specific areas designated for their
operation by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 23-1)
9-6-2: GLASS BEVERAGE CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or to use glass
beverage containers in any of the city parks or in any area belonging to the
city in the vicinity of Lake Ponca. (1980 Code § 23-2)
9-6-3: CLOSING HOURS FOR CITY PARKS:
   A.   All city parks will be closed to the public at eleven o’clock (11:00
p.m.) and remained closed until six o’clock (6:00 a.m.) each day unless
otherwise designated.
   B.   Lake Ponca Park, duck ponds area, shall be closed to the public at ten
o’clock (10:00 p.m.) until seven o’clock (7:00 a.m.) each day.
   C.   The grounds of Lake Ponca shall be closed to the public at midnight
(12:00 a.m.) until five o’clock (5:00 a.m.) daily and shall exclude lake lots,
boat ramps, open water of Lake Ponca or shoreline used for fishing.
   D.   Public sidewalks in parks immediately adjacent to public streets and
paved trails in parks shall not be subject to these hours of use limitations.
   E.   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this code for any person to be
present in a city park or to use park facilities except during the posted hours
the park is open to the public.
   F.   Programs or events sponsored as approved by the city, or for which a
city permit has been issued, may be extended during any such program or event
and for a period of sixty (60) minutes prior or following the beginning or
conclusion of such program or event.
   G.   Signs stating park hours shall be posted prominently in each park.
   H.   A violation of any part of this chapter shall be considered a
misdemeanor offense.
      1.   The penalty for a first offense shall be a fine of up to two hundred
dollars ($200.00), plus any court costs.
      2.   The penalty for a second or subsequent offense of this chapter shall
be a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus any court costs.
      3.   The remedies set forth in this chapter are not exclusive and may be
used in addition to those set forth elsewhere in this code or by law. Nothing
in this chapter shall preclude the city from seeking to obtain voluntary
compliance by way of warning, notice or informational materials.
(Ord. 6350, 12-23-2024)
CHAPTER 7
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
9-7-1: Definitions
9-7-2: City Jurisdiction
9-7-3: Business Standards
9-7-4: Entry On Private Property
9-7-5: Injury Prohibited
9-7-6: Removal Of Dead Or Decayed Trees And Shrubs (Rep. by Ord. 6006, 8-23-
2004)
9-7-7: Overhead Electric Lines
9-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
CREW: One or more persons engaged in servicing trees at any one location,
residence, or business.
SHRUB: A woody plant with one or more stems or trunks at ground level that will
not reach a height of fifteen feet (15') at maturity.
TREE: A woody perennial plant that has an average trunk or stem diameter of
three inches (3") or greater at maturity and/or height of fifteen feet (15') or
more at maturity.
TREE SERVICE: Work performed on trees specifically excluding shrubbery and
including tree removals, tree trimming and cavity work, spraying for pests and
disease control, and fertilizing.
TREE SERVICEMAN: Any person servicing trees other than one working on his own
property. (Ord. 6039, 4-24-2006)
9-7-2: CITY JURISDICTION:
   A.   Park Department: The park department is hereby granted jurisdiction,
authority, control and supervision over all trees, plants and shrubs planted or
growing in or upon the public highways and public places in the city, and the
removal, maintenance and trimming thereof, except for those duties assigned to
citizens by title 6, chapter 2A of this code. (Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
   B.   Foremen Generally: It shall be the duty of the foreman of each crew to
properly supervise and direct the work of the crew of which he is in charge. He
shall be responsible for any violations or infractions of the provisions of
this chapter committed by himself or any member of his crew. (1980 Code § 35-5)
9-7-3: BUSINESS STANDARDS:
Every person engaging in the business or calling of the servicing of trees
within the city shall comply with all rules, regulations and specifications
promulgated therefor by the superintendent of parks of the city. (1980 Code §
35-6)
9-7-4: ENTRY ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed as authorizing park
department personnel to make entry onto private property beyond the city right
of way unless the permission of the property owner is first obtained. Such
permission shall be in writing. (1980 Code § 35-2)
9-7-5: INJURY PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure any tree or shrubbery on a street
or alley in the city; provided, that this shall not prohibit the lawful and
proper care and removal of such trees and shrubbery. (1980 Code § 35-3)
9-7-6: REMOVAL OF DEAD OR DECAYED TREES AND SHRUBS:
(Rep. by Ord. 6006, 8-23-2004)
9-7-7: OVERHEAD ELECTRIC LINES:
   A.   Public Nuisances: The planting or allowing of trees to grow within any
alleyway, street or utility easement in which overhead electric transmission or
distribution lines exist by the owner of said property, which said trees are of
a variety that may grow to within fifteen feet (15') of any electrical
transmission or distribution line, is hereby determined to be a public
nuisance.
   B.   Removal Or Trimming Of Trees Upon Notification: The owner of any
property upon which trees are planted or permitted to grow within an alleyway,
street or utility easement containing an overhead electric transmission or
distribution line which said trees are of a variety which may grow to within
fifteen feet (15') of an electrical transmission or distribution line shall,
when notified by the general manager of Ponca City energy or such person or
persons duly designated by him, remove said tree or trees or trim said tree or
trees more than fifteen feet (15') from an electrical transmission or
distribution line.
   C.   List Of Permitted Trees And Shrubs: The park superintendent of the city
shall maintain a list of trees and shrubs which may be planted in alleyways,
easements or street rights of way, and the property owner may obtain a list of
such trees and shrubs from the park superintendent and the planting of the
trees and shrubs so listed shall not constitute a public nuisance.
   D.   Authority To Trim Or Remove: Ponca City energy or its duly authorized
representatives, is authorized to trim any and all trees and shrubs within any
alleyway, street or utility easement containing overhead electrical
transmission or distribution lines when said trees or shrubs are within fifteen
feet (15') of any overhead electrical transmission or distribution lines; or if
said shrubs or trees are in said alleyway, street right of way or utility
easement containing overhead electrical transmission or distribution lines and
said trees or shrubs impose a continuing hazard to said electrical transmission
or distribution lines, which said hazard cannot be eliminated by trimming said
trees or shrubs, the general manager of Ponca City energy or persons under his
direction may cause such trees or shrubs to be removed.
   E.   Penalty For Failure To Remove Nuisance Tree Or Shrub: If the owner of
the property upon which said tree or shrub above described are located in any
street, alley or utility easement containing electrical transmission or
distribution lines shall not remove or trim any such tree or shrub within
thirty (30) days after notification by the general manager of Ponca City energy
such failure to remove such nuisance is declared to be a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction therefor, the person, firm or corporation failing to act shall be
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and each day that such failure to remove or trim said tree
or shrub shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 35-7;
amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 8
PUBLIC UTILITIES 1
SECTION:
9-8-1: Water Service Lines; Installation, Tapping Mains
9-8-2: Permit For Tapping Water Or Sewer Systems
9-8-3: Sewer Connection Restrictions
9-8-4: Annual Review Of Rate Schedules

9-8-6: Low And Moderate Income Developers; Hookup Required
9-8-7: Fluoridation Of Water Supply
9-8-8: Poles Restricted
9-8-9: Prohibited Deposits In Sewers
9-8-10: Tampering With, Damaging Electrical Equipment
9-8-11: Pollution Of Water Supply
9-8-12: Water And Sewer Line Extensions Outside City Limits
 
Notes
1 1. See sections 161 and 162 of the city charter.
9-8-1: WATER SERVICE LINES; INSTALLATION, TAPPING MAINS:
The following requirements shall be observed by all persons installing water
service lines and tapping water mains of the city:
   A.   Excavation Permit 1 : Before tapping any water main or laying a water
service, a permit to open the street must first be obtained from the city
engineer upon application to and the placing of deposit with the city engineer,
as required by this code.
   B.   Inspection: No persons other than those authorized by the environmental
services department shall tap the water mains of the city or lay the necessary
service lines to the water meters. Upon completion of the work of tapping the
main and laying of the service line, it shall be the duty of the person doing
the work to cause the same to be inspected by the water foreman, and approved
by him, before the lines are again covered or the street repaired.
   C.   Connections And Installation: On cast iron and ductile iron pipes, all
corporation cocks must be firmly screwed in place and must not tighten against
the shoulder of the cock. They shall be of such pattern as to allow connecting
up of the service line with as few fittings as possible. On PVC pipes,
connections shall be made with a saddle and corporation stop.
      1.   All three-fourths inch (3/4") and one inch (1") service lines from
the water main to meter must be of government type K extra heavy copper pipe,
continuous from main to the water meter, with a Mueller or equal ground key
curb stop placed back of the curb.
      2.   All one and one-fourth inch (11/4") or larger service lines must be
extra heavy copper pipe or class one hundred fifty (150) pounds cast iron pipe,
continuous from main to the water meter, with a ground key curb stop or a
suitable one hundred fifty (150) pounds brass or cast iron gate valve placed
back of the curb. No galvanized or black fittings, or pipe will be allowed
between the main and meter.
      3.   Where a series of taps in the water main are being made to feed a
large pipe or header to a large pipe, the number of copper goose necks must
equal the flow of the connecting pipe, and the proposed layout must first be
approved by the environmental services director. (1980 Code § 29-1; amd. 2003
Code)
 
Notes
1 2. See also section
  9-2-6 of this title.
9-8-2: PERMIT FOR TAPPING WATER OR SEWER SYSTEMS:
   A.   Required: It shall be an offense against the city for any person to
tap, open or connect with any water main, water pipe, sewer or sewer pipe
unless and until he shall have received a written permit from the environmental
services director to do so. (1980 Code § 29-10; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Liability Of City: The environmental services director is authorized to
issue the permit mentioned in subsection A of this section upon the condition
that the city shall be saved harmless from any damage suffered by any property
owner by reason of such water backing into any basement, sumps, blowoff tanks,
or things of like nature. (1980 Code § 29-11; amd. 2003 Code)
9-8-3: SEWER CONNECTION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Connections To Sewers At Risk: Any person receiving the written permit
mentioned in subsection 9-8-2A of this chapter shall take notice that the
sanitary sewer system of the city is constructed from the street level and up,
and that during times of flood or other emergencies when the capacity of the
sewer system is reached, sewage water is apt to back up to the extent of
overflowing the manholes; therefore, any person connecting with any sewer line
or who has heretofore connected any basement, sumps, blowoff tanks, and things
of like nature, and which are connected below the natural overflow of the
sewer, connect the same at his own risk. (1980 Code § 29-12)
   B.   Sewer Taps, Size Restricted: No sewer tap or connection of any type
shall be made or maintained on any sanitary sewer main or submain owned or
maintained by the city which is twelve inches (12") or more in diameter, except
at a manhole upon said main or submain. (1980 Code § 29-14)
9-8-4: ANNUAL REVIEW OF RATE SCHEDULES:
The board of commissioners shall, during the month of April of each year,
review in detail the rate schedules for water, electric, sewer and solid waste
services in the city and shall make such changes therein as may be necessary so
as to provide adequate funds for municipal services. (Ord. 5989, 9-8-2003, eff.
10-1-2003)
9-8-5: ZONING COMPLIANCE; TERMINATION OF UTILITY SERVICES:
   A.   Zoning Permitted Uses: No property within the city shall receive
utility services provided by the city unless that property's use or proposed
use is permitted by zoning ordinances which are or would be applicable to such
property.
   B.   Inconsistent Use; Hearing: At such time as the city planner determines
the proposed use of property is inconsistent with the present zoning
classification of the property or that the present use of the property is
inconsistent with its zoning, he shall so inform the board of commissioners by
scheduling a hearing before the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 29-16)
   C.   Terminate Utility Service: If at such hearing the board of
commissioners determines that the proposed or present use of the property is
not permitted by the property's zoning classification, they shall cause utility
services to be terminated. (1980 Code § 29-16; amd. 2003 Code)
   D.   Conduct Of Hearing; Issuance Of Notice: The hearing above referenced
shall be conducted expeditiously but with reasonable and actual notice to the
occupants of the property, opportunity to be heard and opportunity to confront
witnesses. Actual notice of this hearing may be provided pursuant to Oklahoma
Statutes or by personal delivery of notice of hearing to an occupant or
employee on the premises. (1980 Code § 29-16)
9-8-6: LOW AND MODERATE INCOME DEVELOPERS; HOOKUP REQUIRED:
All low and moderate income developers, landowners and commercial and
manufacturing businesses in the city that are within three hundred feet (300')
of the infrastructure financed in part by the Oklahoma department of commerce
(ODOC) CDBG-EDF located thereon, shall be required to hook up to city water,
sewer, electric, and utility services and shall do as follows: (1980 Code § 29-
17; amd. 2003 Code)
   A.   The phrases "low income" and "moderate income" shall be as defined by
the U.S. department of housing and urban development.
   B.   Each entity shall pay for their own utilities, yard service lines and
hookups to the city's utility systems.
   C.   Should an entity or person "household" that is hooking on to the
utility systems be determined by the city as an entity or person "household"
that is defined as a "low income" household using the U.S. department of
housing and urban development low and moderate income definitions, such hookup
shall be paid for by the city.
   D.   Each entity hooking up to the city's sewer, water, solid waste, and
electric services served by these infrastructure improvements shall provide
employment and beneficiary information on a quarterly basis for a period of at
least two (2) years after the infrastructure improvements project achieves
final closeout. (1980 Code § 29-17)
9-8-7: FLUORIDATION OF WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   Authorized: The water treatment plant superintendent is hereby
authorized to institute fluoridation of the water supply of the city, the
maximum content of fluorides to be not more than 1.2 parts per million. (1980
Code § 29-6; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Approval: The application of fluorides to the city water supply shall
only be started after the state health department has:
      1.   Received plans and specifications as required by law.
      2.   Approved the type of chemical feeding equipment to be installed and
used.
      3.   Approved the installation of equipment, plant layout, and methods of
handling the fluoride compounds to assure the safety of employees.
      4.   Approved the methods of analysis and control to be used in
determining the fluoride content of the water before and after the addition of
fluorides.
      5.   Appraised and approved the qualifications of the personnel who will
make the necessary analyses to control the application of fluorides. (1980 Code
§ 29-7)
   C.   Compliance: The control and testing of the water before and after
fluoridation and the method of determining the fluoride content of the water
and the test for purity of the fluoride chemical shall, in all respects, comply
with the rules and standards set up by the state department of health. (1980
Code § 29-8)
9-8-8: POLES RESTRICTED 1 :
There shall not be established in any alleyway, public easement or along any
street of the city more than one line or row of telephone poles or power poles.
Any franchise holder having a right to the use of said streets, alleyways or
public easements shall either attach to existing poles, or being unable to do
so, place all facilities underground in conformance with proper safety
procedures. (1980 Code § 29-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See sections 39, 42 and 144 of the city charter.
9-8-9: PROHIBITED DEPOSITS IN SEWERS 1 :
No person shall deposit or throw or cause to be deposited or thrown into any
sewer inlet, manhole, privy vault, or cesspool which has a sewer connection,
any animal or vegetable substance, or any hay, straw, ashes, cinders, sticks,
shavings, trash, soot, oyster shells or cans, broken ware, rags, pieces of iron
or other metal, old wearing apparel, or any article or thing whatever that is
liable to cause the sewer to choke up or otherwise obstruct the free flow of
water therein. (1980 Code § 29-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 9-8B-9 of this chapter.
9-8-10: TAMPERING WITH, DAMAGING ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner, without lawful authority,
to:
   A.   Interfere with, change, modify, move or obstruct any electrical wiring
being installed in or on any building, pole or fixture.
   B.   Retard, accelerate or prevent electric current passing through any
meter belonging to the city or any company engaged in the manufacture or sale
of electricity for light, power or other purposes.
   C.   Divert any electric current from any wiring belonging to any other
person or any company engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity for
light, power or other purposes. (1980 Code § 29-4)
9-8-11: POLLUTION OF WATER SUPPLY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit excrement or foul or decaying
matter in, or in any manner to corrupt, any spring or reservoir or other source
of water used for domestic purposes, or to place the carcass of a dead animal
or any refuse or filth upon any watershed draining into any lake or reservoir
of the city, or to aid or abet in any such act. (1980 Code § 29-5)
9-8-12: WATER AND SEWER LINE EXTENSIONS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS 1 :
   A.   Purpose: It is the purpose of this section to establish city policy
that, with the exception of rural water districts and existing water trusts,
Ponca City water and sewer services shall not be extended outside the city
limits. Such policy will ensure that Ponca City does not directly subsidize new
developments which do not meet city standards, will eliminate private lines
over which the city has no control and will aide in the enforcement of existing
city codes.
   B.   Statement Of Policy:
      1.   There is hereby established a policy that city water and sewer
services shall no longer be provided outside the city limits.
      2.   Said policy shall not affect the sale of quantities of treated water
to existing rural water districts or other existing water trusts nor shall it
affect those developments outside Ponca City presently receiving city water
and/or sewer services.
      3.   Developers who desire city services may petition the city for
annexation if said city services are desired. Developers shall then be
restricted to build according to existing city codes. (Policy, 6-1-1983)
 
Notes
1 2. See also section 9-8A-7 of this chapter.

   (May through September usage       $ 15.89
   periods)

   (October through April usage periods)
Energy Charge - Per kWh                  $ 0.067
 
      2.   Determination Of Maximum Demand: The customer’s maximum demand shall
be the maximum rate at which energy is used for any period of fifteen (15)
consecutive minutes of the month for which the bill is rendered and shown by
the demand meter. In the event a customer taking service under this rate has a
demand meter with an interval greater than fifteen (15) minutes, the City shall
have a reasonable time to change the metering device. In the event a demand
meter does not exist, the customer shall be responsible for all cost associated
with the installation of a demand metering device.
      3.   Determination Of Billing Demand: The billing demand upon which the
demand charge is based shall be the maximum demand as determined above
corrected for power factor, as set forth under the power factor clause;
provided that no billing demand shall be considered as less than sixty percent
(60%) of the highest summer season maximum demand corrected for power factor
previously determined during the twelve (12) months ending with the current
month.
      4.   Power Factor Clause: The consumer shall at all times take and use
power in such manner that the power factor shall be as nearly one hundred
percent (100%) as possible, but when the average power factor as determined by
continuous measurement of lagging reactive kilo-volt-ampere hours is less than
eighty-five percent (85%), the billing demand shall be determined by
multiplying the maximum demand, shown by the demand meter for the billing
period, by eighty-five (85) and dividing the product thus obtained by the
actual average power factor expressed in percent. The City may, at its option,
use for adjustment the power factor as determined by tests during periods of
normal operation of the customer’s equipment instead of the average power
factor.
      5.   Minimum Bill: The minimum bill shall be the customer charge plus a
minimum demand charge based on one hundred fifty (150) kW of demand.
   D.   Medium Power And Large Power Time Of Use: Those customers qualifying
for the Medium and Large Power classification may, at their option, be billed
at rates under this classification. Customers who request to be changed to the
Medium Power and Large Power Time of Use classification shall remain in this
classification for one (1) year before being permitted to change rates again.
      1.   Charges:
 
Customer Charge per bill per month $ 264.94
Demand Charge - Per kW per month:  $ 9.99
On-Peak Hours Billing Demand
Maximum Billing Demand             $ 4.91
Energy Charge - Per kWh            $0.059
 
      2.   Determination Of Maximum Demand: The customer’s maximum demand shall
be the maximum rate at which energy is used for any period of fifteen (15)
consecutive minutes of the month for which the bill is rendered and shown by
the demand meter. In the event a customer taking service under this rate has a
demand meter with an interval greater than fifteen (15) minutes, the City shall
have a reasonable time to change the metering device and the customer shall
bear all costs associated with the installation of a time of use metering
device.
      3.   Determination Of Billing Demand: The billing demand upon which the
demand charge is based shall be the maximum demand as determined above
corrected for power factor, as set forth under the power factor clause;
provided that no billing demand shall be considered as less than sixty percent
(60%) of the highest summer season maximum demand corrected for power factor
previously determined during the twelve (12) months ending with the current
month.
      4.   Determination Of On-Peak Hours Demand: The customer’s on-peak hours
demand shall be the maximum rate at which energy is used for any period of
fifteen (15) consecutive minutes as shown by the City’s demand meter during the
time period beginning one minute past two o’clock (2:01) p.m. through eight
o’clock (8:00) p.m. local time, except Saturdays, Sundays, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, and Labor Day, during the billing months of June through
September.
      5.   Determination Of On-Peak Hours Billing Demand: The monthly on-peak
hours billing demand shall be one hundred percent (100%) of the on-peak hours
demand as determined above, corrected for power factor established during the
most recent billing months of June through September.
      6.   Power Factor Clause: The consumer shall at all times take and use
power in such manner that the power factor shall be as nearly one hundred
percent (100%) as possible, but when the average power factor as determined by
continuous measurement of lagging reactive kilo-volt-ampere hours is less than
eighty five percent (85%), the billing demand shall be determined by
multiplying the maximum demand, shown by the demand meter for the billing
period, by eighty five (85) and dividing the product thus obtained by the
actual average power factor expressed in percent. The City may, at its option,
use for adjustment the power factor as determined by tests during periods of
normal operation of the customer’s equipment instead of the average power
factor.
      7.   Minimum Bill: The minimum bill shall be the customer charge plus a
minimum demand charge based on one hundred fifty (150) kW of demand. The City
may specify a larger minimum monthly bill, when necessary to justify the
investment required to provide service.
      8.   Term: The City, at its option, may require a written contract for a
year or longer subject to special minimum guarantees which may be necessary in
cases warranted by special circumstances or unusually large investments by the
City.

   G.   Security Lights: The monthly charges for security lights shall be as
listed below. The City shall determine the type and wattage to provide for any
new or replacement lights.
      1.   For a security light installed on an existing City-owned service
pole and connected to an existing City-owned line, the charge will be seven
dollars ninety-nine cents ($7.99) per month rental fee.
      2.   For a security light which was installed on a City-owned pole set
specifically for that light and served from an underground City electric
service, the charge will be nine dollars twenty-four cents ($9.24) per month
rental fee.
      3.   For a security light installed on a City-owned pole set specifically
for that light requiring a transformer to be installed to serve that light from
an overhead service, the charge will be ten dollars fifty cents ($10.50) per
month rental fee.
      4.   For a security light installed on a City-owned pole set specifically
for that light and fed from a transformer set to serve that light from an
underground service, the charge will be eleven dollars seventy-nine cents
($11.79) per month rental fee.
   5.   A fee of twenty one dollars eighty-seven cents ($21.87) will be charged
for the installation, connection, reinstallation, re-connection, or moving of
each light.
   H.   Classification Of Customers: It shall be the responsibility of the
customer to notify the City Utility Billing Office of any changes in rate
classification.
   I.   Production Cost Adjustment: The Ponca City electric rates, as
published, are based upon the average cost of production or purchase of
electricity of fifty nine and fifty hundredths (59.50) mills ($0.05950) per
kilowatt-hour. The monthly bills, as calculated under the published rate
schedules, shall be increased or decreased for each kilowatt-hour consumed by
an amount computed in accordance with the following formula:
         PCA = (A - B) x 1.090
         Where:   
         PCA =    The production cost adjustment factor (expressed in dollars
per kilowatt-hour) to be applied per kilowatt-hour consumed.
         A =   The cost per kilowatt-hour for fuel when generated by the City
generation plants, or the cost per kilowatt hour for electricity purchased, or
a combination of both, expressed in dollars.
         B =   The base per kilowatt hour (expressed in dollars) used for
upward or downward adjustment to be applied per kilowatt-hour consumed. Base
cost equals $0.05950 per kilowatt-hour.
   J.   Green Power Wind Rider:
      1.   Availability: The green power wind rider is available to all classes
of residential and general power customers and other classifications of
customers by special agreement.
      2.   Rate: The price for each one hundred (100) kilowatt hour block will
be one dollar ($1.00). The Green Power Wind Charge (GPWC) shall be one cent
($0.01) per kilowatt hour and shall be sold in blocks of one hundred (100)
kilowatt hours less corresponding exemptions for production cost adjustment.
Such charge shall be in addition to the applicable standard pricing for each
participant’s total monthly billing.
      3.   Minimum Bill: The monthly customer bill shall be the customer charge
plus the GPWC(s). (Ord. 6040, 5-22-2006; amd. Ord. 6188, 5-27-2014; Ord. 6291,
5-24-2021; Ord. 6327, 5-22-2023; Ord. 6359, 5-27-2025)

meter and meter box.

Meter                Charges

11/2 inch and 2 inch 2,100.00
2 inch compound      2,500.00
Over 2 inch          At estimated cost
 
The charges for three-fourths inch (3/4") and one inch (1") meters will include
up to fifty feet (50') of service line only. A fifteen dollar ($15.00) per foot
additional charge will apply in case more than fifty feet (50') of service line
needs to be installed. Similarly, for two inch (2") meters, a twenty dollar
($20.00) per foot additional charge will apply if more than fifty feet (50') of
service line needs to be installed.
Installation fee for a meter in excess of two inches (2") will be determined by
the Water Distribution Division based on field conditions and provided in
written quotation to the customer. (Ord. 6084, 5-27-2008)

9-8A-7: RURAL WATER PETITIONERS; DEPOSIT REQUIRED 1 :
From and after the effective date hereof, any petitioner for rural water shall
file along with his petition a deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00) payable to the
City with the City Clerk thereof for the purpose of defraying the estimated
expenses of processing the petition for said rural water. (1980 Code § 29-51.1)

9-8A-8: RESERVED:
(Ord. 6180, 8-12-2013)
9-8A-9: BILLING DUE DATE; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Billing Time; Discontinuance Of Service: All bills for utility services
furnished by the City shall be due and payable when rendered and shall be
considered delinquent twenty (20) days thereafter. A delinquent bill shall
become subject to the immediate discontinuance of service when the next bill is
rendered showing a previous balance due. (1980 Code § 29-53)
   B.   Penalty For Failure To Pay: In the event that any consumer of utility
services furnished by the City shall fail to pay his bill therefor when the
same is due, a penalty of five dollars ($5.00) shall be imposed for each time a
collector is dispatched to deliver a twenty four (24) hour cutoff notice. (1980
Code § 29-54)
   C.   Reconnection After Disconnection:
      1.   In the event that utility service is disconnected for nonpayment of
the bill, the customer thereof shall have the right to have the same
reconnected only upon the payment of the amount due and, in addition thereto, a
deposit in the amount required for new accounts. (1980 Code § 29-55)
9-8A-10: VOLUNTARY DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
Customers wishing to discontinue the use of any utility service will give
written notice thereof at the City Hall. Failure to do so shall render them
liable for the payment of all bills until such notice has been given. (1980
Code § 29-56)

9-8B-1: DECLARATION OF PUBLIC UTILITY:
The sanitary sewer system of the city is hereby declared to be a public
utility, and a proper source of revenue for the upkeep and maintenance of the
system and for other purposes. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-2: POLICY AND OBJECTIVES:
   A.   Objectives: This article sets forth uniform requirements for users of
the publicly owned treatment works for the city and enables the city to comply
with all applicable state and federal laws, including the clean water act (33
United States Code 1251 et seq.) and the general pretreatment regulations (40
code of federal regulations part 403). The objectives of this article are:
      1.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will interfere with its operation;
      2.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works,
inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with
the publicly owned treatment works;
      3.   To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be
affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the
general public;
      4.   To promote reuse and recycling of wastewater and sludge from the
publicly owned treatment works;
      5.   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the publicly owned treatment works;
and
      6.   To enable the city to comply with its Oklahoma pollutant discharge
elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and
any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is
subject.
   B.   Application Of Article: This article shall apply to all users of the
publicly owned treatment works. This article authorizes the issuance of
wastewater discharge permits; provides for monitoring, compliance, and
enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures; requires
user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable
distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. (Ord.
6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, certain terms and words are to be used and
interpreted as defined hereinafter:
ACT: The federal water pollution control act, also known as the clean water
act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq.
APPROVAL AUTHORITY: The Oklahoma department of environmental quality (ODEQ or
DEQ).
AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE OF THE USER: A. If the user is a corporation:
      1.   The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the
corporation in charge of a principal function, or any other person who performs
similar policy or decision making functions for the corporation; or
      2.   The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation
facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross
annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty five million dollars
($25,000,000.00) (in second quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign
documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with
corporate procedures.
   B.   If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: a general partner
or proprietor, respectively.
   C.   If the user is a federal, state or local government facility: a
director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation
and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their
designee.
   D.   The individuals described in subsections A through C of this definition
may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in
writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for
the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or
having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and
the written authorization is submitted to the city.
BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES: Best management practices or BMPs mean schedules of
activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other
management practices to implement the prohibitions listed in sections 2.1A and
B (40 CFR 403.5(a)(1) and (b)). BMPs include treatment requirements, operating
procedures, and practices to control plant site runoff, spillage or leaks,
sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND OR BOD5: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures
for five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C), usually expressed as a
concentration (e.g., mg/l).
BYPASS: The intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of an
industrial user's treatment facility.
CFR: The most recent publication of the code of federal regulations published
by the office of the federal register, national archives and records
administration.
CATEGORICAL INDUSTRIAL USER: An industrial user subject to a categorical
pretreatment standard or categorical standard.
CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD OR CATEGORICAL STANDARD: Any regulation
containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with
sections 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 USC section 1317) that apply to a
specific category of users and that appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N,
parts 405 - 471.
CITY MANAGER: The city manager appointed by the board of commissioners of the
city of Ponca City.
COMPOSITE SAMPLE: A combination of a series of aliquots taken on either a time
or flow proportional basis over a period of time.
CONTROL AUTHORITY: The city of Ponca City.
DAILY MAXIMUM LIMIT: The maximum allowable discharge limit of a pollutant
during a calendar day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in units of
mass, the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of the
day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in terms of a concentration, the
daily discharge is the arithmetic average measurement of the pollutant
concentration derived from all measurements taken that day.
DOMESTIC SEWAGE: Liquid wastes:
   A.   From preparation, cooking and handling of food; or
   B.   Containing human excrement and similar matter from the sanitary
conveniences of dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and
institutions; or
   C.   Collected by floor drains located in commercial establishments that
generate only floor washdown water that does not normally contact significant
amounts of any substance or wastes containing either toxic pollutants defined
under 40 CFR part 401.15, or oil and grease.
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency, or where appropriate, the regional water management division director,
or other duly authorized official of said agency.
GRAB SAMPLE: A sample which is taken from a waste stream without regard to the
flow in the waste stream and over a period of time not to exceed fifteen (15)
minutes.
INDIRECT DISCHARGE OR DISCHARGE: The introduction of pollutants into a POTW
from any nondomestic source.
INDUSTRIAL SEWAGE: Wastewater that is not "domestic sewage".
INDUSTRIAL USER OR USER: A source of "indirect discharge".
INFLOW: Water other than wastewater that enters a sewer system (including sewer
service connections) from sources such as, but not limited to, roof leaders,
cellar drains, yard drains, area drains, drains from springs and swampy areas,
manhole covers, cross connections between storm sewers and sanitary sewers,
catch basins, cooling towers, stream waters, surface runoff, street wash
waters, or drainage.
INSTANTANEOUS LIMIT: The maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be
discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or
composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the
duration of the sampling event.
INTERFERENCE: A discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or
discharges from other sources, both:
   A.   Inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations,
or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and
   B.   Therefore is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's
ODPES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a
violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance
with the following use statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued
thereunder (or more stringent state or local regulations); section 405 of the
clean water act, the solid waste disposal act (SWDA) (including title II, more
commonly referred to as the resource conservation and recovery act (RCRA), and
including state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan
prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the SWDA), the clean air act, the toxic
substances control act, and the marine protection, research and sanctuaries
act.
INTERIM LIMIT: A temporary limit established on a case by case basis by the
director for a pollutant for which a specific numerical limit has not been
established.
MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DISCHARGE LIMIT: The highest acceptable concentration of
pollutants or characteristics of a waste discharged to the POTW as established
by the most stringent requirements of this article, a permit or order issued
under the provision of this article, or national pretreatment standard.
MINOR USER: An "industrial user" who is not a "significant industrial user".
MONTHLY AVERAGE: The sum of all "daily discharges" measured during a calendar
