manner as to be representative of the maximum hourly discharge rate. It shall
also include the following:
         a.   Starting and ending time of the sampling period.
         b.   Hourly rate of flow observed during the sampling period.
         c.   Concentrations of BOD and TSS.
         d.   Total pounds of BOD and TSS discharged during the sampling
periods.
         e.   Concentrations of other pollutants listed on the user's current
industrial discharge permit.
      2.   All cost associated with collection, compositing, analyses and
reporting of these samples shall be borne by the user. The director can be
expected to collect grab samples one or more times per year from significant
industrial users. The city may or may not give prior notice of its intent to
collect a sample(s).
   B.   Sample Collection:
      1.   Except as indicated in subsection B2 of this section, the user must
collect wastewater samples using flow proportional composite collection
techniques. In the event flow proportional sampling is infeasible, the director
may authorize the use of time proportional sampling or a minimum of four (4)
grab samples where the user demonstrates that this will provide a
representative sample of the effluent being discharged. In addition, grab
samples may be required to show compliance with instantaneous discharge limits.
      2.   Samples for oil and grease, temperature, pH, cyanide, phenols,
sulfides, and volatile organic compounds must be obtained using grab collection
techniques.
   C.   Recordkeeping: Users subject to the reporting requirements of this
article shall retain, and make available for inspection and copying, all
records of information obtained pursuant to any monitoring activities required
by this article and any additional records of information obtained pursuant to
monitoring activities undertaken by the user independent of such requirements.
Records shall include the date, exact place, method, and time of sampling, and
the name of the person(s) taking the samples; the dates analyses were
performed; who performed the analyses; the analytical techniques or methods
used; and the results of such analyses. These records shall remain available
for a period of at least three (3) years. This period shall be automatically
extended for the duration of any litigation concerning the user or the city, or
where the user has been specifically notified of a longer retention period by
the director. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-31: USE OF STORM SEWER, NATURAL OUTLET:
Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers
as are specifically designated storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by
the director. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be
discharged, upon approval of the director, to a storm sewer or natural outlet.
(Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-32: STORMWATER PROHIBITED FROM SANITARY SEWER:
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface
water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or
unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer in the city. (Ord.
6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-33: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the municipal wastewater works. Any person
violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of
destruction or damage to public property. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-34: LIABILITY FOR LOSS, DAMAGE:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable
to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned to the city by reason of
such violation. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-35: RIGHT OF REVISION:
The city reserves the right to establish by ordinance more stringent
limitations or requirements on indirect discharges if deemed necessary to
comply with the objectives of section
9-8B-2 of this article. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-36: VALIDITY:
The user charge system shall take precedence over any terms or conditions of
agreements or contracts between the city and any of the users which are
inconsistent with applicable federal regulations regarding user charge systems.
(Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-37: PENALTIES:
   A.   Petition For Injunctive Relief: When the director or city manager finds
that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this
article, a permit issued by the director, or order issued under section
9-8B-5 of this article, or federal pretreatment standard or requirement; then
the director or city manager may petition the state district court of competent
jurisdiction through the city attorney for the issuance of a temporary or
permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific
performance of the permit issued by the director, an order issued under section
9-8B-5 of this article, federal pretreatment standard or requirement, or other
requirement imposed by this article on activities of the user. The director or
city manager may also seek such other action as is appropriate for legal and/or
equitable relief, including a requirement for the user to conduct environmental
remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against, or a
prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user.
   B.   Violation Of Article: Any person who shall violate any of the
provisions of this article and the sections thereunder shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per violation per day, or the jurisdictional limits of the
municipal court and costs; provided, that each day of such violation shall
constitute a separate offense. In the case of a monthly or other long term
average discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period
of the violation.
   C.   False Statements; Misrepresentation: Any person who shall make a false
statement or misrepresent the facts on any application, report, correspondence
or other information provided by the director shall, upon conviction thereof,
be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
violation per day, or the jurisdictional limits of the municipal court and
costs.
   D.   Fees In Addition To Fines: In addition to the fines provided herein,
the city may recover reasonable attorney fees, court costs, court reporter's
fees, and other expenses associated with the enforcement activities, including
sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred
by the city.
   E.   Remedial Action: Filing a suit for penalties under this section shall
not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a
user including emergency suspension or termination of sewer and/or water
service. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
9-8B-38: AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES TO VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Upset: An affirmative defense to violations of this article is an upset
as described below:
      1.   For the purposes of this section, "upset" means an exceptional
incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with
categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable
control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent
caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities,
inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventative maintenance, or careless
or improper operation.
      2.   An "upset" shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action
brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the
requirements of subsection A3 of this section are met.
      3.   A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset
shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or
other relevant evidence that:
         a.   An upset occurred and the user can identify the cause(s) of the
upset;
         b.   The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and
workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance
procedures; and
         c.   The user has submitted the following information to the director
or his duly authorized representative within twenty four (24) hours of becoming
aware of the upset, if this information is provided orally; a written
submission must be provided within five (5) days.
            (1)   A description of the indirect discharge and cause of
noncompliance;
            (2)   The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times
or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to
continue; and
            (3)   Steps being taken and/or planned to reduce, eliminate, and
prevent recurrence of the noncompliance.
      4.   In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the
occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof.
      5.   Users will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any
claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with
categorical pretreatment standards.
      6.   Users shall control production of all discharges to the extent
necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon
reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is
restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement
applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power
of the treatment facility is reduced, lost, or fails.
   B.   Reason Favoring Defense: A user shall have an affirmative defense to an
enforcement action brought against it for noncompliance with the general
prohibitions in subsections 9-8B-8A6, A8 and A17 of this article if it can
prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, alone
or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass- through
or interference, and that either:
      1.   A limit exists for each pollutant discharged in subsection 9-8B-9A
of this article, and the user was in compliance with each limit directly prior
to, and during, the pass-through or interference; or
      2.   No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change
substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when
the city was regularly in compliance with its OPDES permit, and in the case of
interference, was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal
requirements.
   C.   Bypass: Under the stipulations below, an affirmative defense in the
event of bypass is:
      1.   For the purposes of this section:
         a.   "Bypass" means the intentional diversion of waste streams from
any portion of a user's treatment facility.
         b.   "Severe property damage" means substantial physical damage to
property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become
inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can
reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. "Severe property
damage" does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production.
      2.   A user may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause
pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it also is
for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are
subject to the provisions of subsections C3, C4, C5 and C6 of this section.
      3.   If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall submit
prior notice to the director or his duly authorized representative, at least
ten (10) days before the date of the bypass.
      4.   A user shall submit oral notice to the director or his duly
authorized representative of an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable
pretreatment standards within twenty four (24) hours from the time it becomes
aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also be provided within five
(5) days of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The written
submission shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the
duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has
not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; and steps
taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass.
      5.   Bypass is prohibited, and the director and his duly authorized
representative may take an enforcement action against a user for a bypass,
unless:
         a.   Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury,
or severe property damage;
         b.   There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the
use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or
maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not
satisfied if adequate backup equipment should have been installed in the
exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred
during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance; and
         c.   The user submitted notices as required under subsections C3 and
C4 of this section.
      6.   The director or his duly authorized representative may approve an
anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the director or
his duly authorized representative determines that it will meet the conditions
listed in subsection C5 of this section. (Ord. 6197, 12-8-2014)
ARTICLE C. STORMWATER MANAGEMENT

9-8C-1: STATEMENT AND PURPOSE:
   A.   It is the purpose of this article to promote public health, safety and
welfare by providing for operating, constructing, equipping, maintaining,
acquiring and owning within the city a stormwater drainage system. The
establishment of a stormwater drainage system will:
      1.   Minimize flood and storm losses and inconveniences from uncontrolled
stormwater runoff in the city;
      2.   Assure that the movement of emergency vehicles is not prohibited nor
inhibited during storm or flood periods;
      3.   Preserve the city's watercourses, improve and preserve purity of
water, minimize water quality degradation, and otherwise facilitate urban water
resource management techniques, including both the reduction of pollution and
the enhancement of the urban environment;
      4.   Establish an overall plan and master plan for stormwater and flood
management and its implementation, including, without limitation, a coordinated
program of creating upstream ponding or temporary detention of stormwaters;
      5.   Establish a stormwater and flood management utility to coordinate,
design, construct, manage, operate, and maintain the stormwater and flood
management system;
      6.   Establish reasonable stormwater utility and flood management fees
based on the use of stormwater drainage system and flood drainage facilities.
(Ord. 5985, 6-30-2003)
9-8C-2: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   Unless otherwise provided in this article, for the purposes of this
article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given herein:
    ACCIDENTAL DISCHARGE: A discharge prohibited by this article into the
waters of the state or U.S. which occurs by chance and without planning or
consideration prior to occurrence.
   AREAS OF SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD: The areas identified by the federal emergency
management agency in a scientific and engineering report entitled, "The Flood
Insurance Study For Kay County, Oklahoma And Incorporated Areas" dated
September 25, 2009, with accompanying flood insurance rate map (FIRM) are
hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this article. The
flood hazard area shall be established by the city utilizing the base flood
elevation established from one of the following:
      1.   "The Flood Insurance Study For The City Of Ponca City", initially
adopted July 2, 1980, and revised on November 18, 1988, as amended or revised
with the accompanying flood insurance rate map (FIRM) and flood boundary and
floodway map (FBFM) and related supporting data and any revisions thereto
(effective until September 25, 2009, when superseded by subsection 2 of this
definition);
      2.   "The Flood Insurance Study For The City Of Ponca City", dated
September 25, 2009, as amended or revised with the accompanying flood insurance
rate map (FIRM) and related supporting data and any revisions thereto;
      3.   "Bois d' Arc Tributaries Stormwater Master Plan" dated July 2009
prepared by Meshek & Associates, Inc., and related supporting data (for areas
beyond the limits of detailed study in subsection 2 of this definition);
      4.   "Arkansas River Tributaries Stormwater Master Plan" dated July 2009
prepared by Meshek & Associates, Inc., and related supporting data (for areas
beyond the limit of detailed study in subsection 2 of this definition); and
      5.   If available, a report submitted by the applicant at their expense
prepared by a licensed professional engineer using acceptable engineering
hydrology and hydraulic methods to establish a base flood elevation and
subsequent flood hazard area.
The flood hazard area shall include the area above the base flood elevation to
the elevation of the design flood elevation.
   BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMP): Schedules of activities, prohibitions of
practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or
reduce the pollution of waters of the state or U.S. BMPs also include treatment
requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control facility site
runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw
materials storage.
   CFR: An acronym for "code of federal regulations".
   CWA OR THE ACT: Clean water act (formerly referred to as the federal water
pollution control act or federal water pollution control act amendments of
1972) P.L. 92-500, as amended Pub. L. 95-576, Pub. L. 96-483 and Pub. L. 97-
117, 33 USC 1251 et seq.
   CITY: The city of Ponca City, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation, and its
duly authorized officers, agents, and employees.
   COMMON BILLED: A billing for electric, water and/or sanitary sewer service
for a tract that is billed to the tract as one bill and not directly to the
individual units of that tract.
   CONTROL MEASURE: Any best management practice or other method used to
prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants to the waters of the state or
U.S.
   CORPS' DREDGE AND FILL PERMIT (404): A permit issued by the secretary of the
army under the authority of section 404 of the CWA. Said permit does not
include any permit which has not yet been the subject of final agency action,
such as a "draft permit" or a "proposed permit".
   DETENTION OR RETENTION FACILITIES: Facilities designed to hold stormwater
for a short period and then to release it to a watercourse or to hold
stormwater for a sufficient length of time for it to be consumed by
evaporation, infiltration into the soil or other natural means.
   DEVELOPED REAL ESTATE: Real property altered from its natural state by the
addition to or construction of an impervious surface such that the hydrology of
the property is affected.
   DEVELOPER: The person(s) who improves, subdivides land or alters real
property from its natural state by the addition to, or construction of, an
impervious surface such that the hydrology of the property is affected.
   DIRECTOR: The duly appointed director of the public works department of the
city of Ponca City and/or his designated representative.
   DISCHARGE: The discharge of a pollutant. Discharge includes the placement
into, failure to remove pollutants from, or failure to secure pollutants in a
manner to prevent it entering drainageways.
   DISCHARGE OF POLLUTANT: Any addition of any pollutant or combination of
pollutants to the waters of the U.S. from any point source, or any addition of
any pollutant or combination of pollutants to the waters of the contiguous zone
or the ocean from any point source other than a vessel or other floating craft
which is being used as a means of transportation.
This definition includes the addition of pollutants into waters of the U.S.
from: surface runoff which is collected or channeled by man; discharges through
pipes, sewers, or other conveyances owned by a state, municipality, or other
person which do not lead to a treatment works. The discharge of pollutants to
the drainageway does include exposure of pollutants to contact to rainfall or
snow (thereby allowing runoff), contact with stormwater runoff or snowmelt
waters, or failure to secure stockpiles or storage areas that could allow the
transport of pollutants from secured areas to areas where contact could occur
with runoff.
   DRAINAGE BASIN PLAN: The Ponca City stormwater master plan adopted by the
board of commissioners of the city of Ponca City.
   DRAINAGEWAY: A route or watercourse along which water moves or may move to
drain an area.
   EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNIT (ESU): Shall be established at one unit per eight
thousand (8,000) square feet of impervious surface or a portion thereof.
   EROSION: Wearing away of lands by running water and waves, abrasion, and
transportation.
   FLOATABLE: Any buoyant or semibuoyant, organic or inorganic, waterborne
waste material such as litter, paper, styrofoam, grass, leaf litter, cigarette
butts and other debris.
   HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES: For the purposes of this article, a hazardous
substance shall be as defined in 40 CFR part 116.
   ILLICIT CONNECTION: Any humanmade conveyance connecting an illicit discharge
to the drainage system of the city of Ponca City.
   ILLICIT DISCHARGE: Any discharge to a municipal separate storm sewer that is
not composed entirely of stormwater except discharges pursuant to an OPDES
permit (other than the OPDES permit for discharges from the municipal separate
storm sewer) and discharges resulting from firefighting activities.
   IMPERVIOUS SURFACE: Any surfaced area which prevents or retards the entry of
water into the soil, causing water to run off the surface in greater quantities
or at an increased rate of flow than was present under natural conditions.
Examples of an impervious surface include, but are not limited to, rooftops,
asphalt or concrete sidewalks, paving, driveways and parking lots, walkways,
patio areas, storage areas, and gravel, oiled macadam or other surfaces which
similarly affect the natural infiltration or runoff patterns of real property
from its natural state.
   INDIVIDUAL BILLED: Where billing for water and/or sanitary sewer services
for a tract is by separate billing to the individual units of that tract.
   INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITY: Any activity which is directly related to
manufacturing, processing or raw materials storage areas at an industrial
facility. The term includes, but is not limited to, industrial plant yards;
immediate access roads and rail lines used or traveled by carriers of raw
materials, manufactured products, waste material, or byproducts used or created
by the industrial facility; sites where material handling activities are
performed; refuse sites; sites used for the application or disposal of process
wastewaters; sites used for the storage and maintenance of material handling
equipment; sites used for residual treatment, storage or disposal; shipping and
receiving areas; manufacturing buildings; storage areas, including tank farms,
for raw materials, and intermediate and finished products.
   LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITY: Any land change which may result in soil erosion
from water and wind and the movement of sediment or pollutants into waters of
the state or U.S., into stormwater, or onto drainageways of the city,
including, but not limited to, clearing, grubbing, grading, dredging,
stockpiling in a manner subject to receiving precipitation or coming into
contact with runoff, excavating, transporting, mining, and filling of land.
   MEP: An acronym for "maximum extent practicable", the technology based
discharge standard for MS4s established by CWA section 402(p).
   MUNICIPAL SEPARATE STORM SEWER SYSTEM OR MS4: The system of conveyances
(including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs,
gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains) owned or regulated by the
city and designed or used for collecting or conveying stormwater, and which is
not used for collecting or conveying sewage.
   OPDES PERMIT: An acronym for the "Oklahoma pollutant discharge elimination
system". An OPDES permit is a permit to discharge issued by the Oklahoma
department of environmental quality for a point source, biosolids (sewage
sludge), and stormwater permitting standards for discharges to the waters of
the state of Oklahoma from those facilities within the jurisdiction of the
Oklahoma department of environmental quality as specified in 27A Oklahoma
Statutes section 1-3-101. Said permit does not include any permit which has not
yet been the subject of final agency action, such as a "draft permit" or a
"proposed permit".
   OKLAHOMA WATER QUALITY STANDARDS: Are developed by the Oklahoma water
resources board and are title 785 Oklahoma water resources board, chapter 45
Oklahoma water quality standards.
   OUTFALL (POINT SOURCE): Any discernible, confined and discrete conveyance,
including, but not limited to, any pipe, ditch, channel, tunnel, conduit,
landfill leachate collection system, vessel, or other floating craft from which
pollutants are or may be discharged.
   POLLUTANT: Any dredge spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, oil, grease,
sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical waste, chemical waste,
industrial waste, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or
discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, agriculture waste, industrial
waste, municipal waste and the characteristics of the wastewater including, but
not limited to, pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, and
odor.
   REPORTABLE QUANTITY: A spill or discharge to the drainageway of a hazardous
substance or substances subject to the requirements of 40 CFR part 117.
   RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY: Any property designed and used principally for
residential single-family, duplex or multi-family purposes and developed
according to and meeting the bulk and area requirements for residential single-
family, duplex or apartments zoned property as set forth in the city of Ponca
City zoning code at the time of development of such property.
   RESPONSIBLE PARTY: The party or parties that meet one or more of the
following descriptions:
      1.   The property owner;
      2.   The renter, lessee, or tenant exercising control over the site;
      3.   The developer;
      4.   A party or parties who have operational control over construction
plans and specifications, including the ability to make modifications to those
plans and specifications; or
      5.   A party or parties that have day to day operational control of those
activities at a project that are necessary to ensure compliance with this
article (e.g., they are authorized to direct workers at a site to carry out
activities required by this article).
   SWP3: An acronym for a stormwater pollution prevention plan which is to be
developed and implemented by an OPDES permit to discharge stormwater. The
purpose of the SWP3 is to protect the quality of stormwater discharged from a
site.
   SCOUR: The erosive action of running water in streams or channels in
excavating and carrying away material from the bed and banks.
   SEDIMENT: Material of soil and rock origin transported, carried, or
deposited by water.
   SPILL PREVENTION CONTROL AND COUNTERMEASURE PLAN OR SPCC PLAN: An acronym
for a spill prevention control and countermeasure plan which is required by EPA
or state requirements for certain transportation and storage activities for
petroleum or some other hazardous materials.
   SPILLS: Any release that has negatively or has the potential to negatively
impact the quality of water within, or discharges from the city's municipal
separate storm sewer system (MS4) or causes damaging or deleterious effects to
the city's MS4, including all structures or appurtenances, or creates any
violation of this article.
   STORMWATER: Defined in 40 CFR 122.26(b)(13) and means stormwater runoff,
snowmelt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage.
   STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM: Any facility, structure, improvement,
development, equipment, property or interest therein, or other structural or
nonstructural element made, constructed, used or acquired for the purpose of
collecting, containing, storing, conveying and controlling stormwater wherever
located including, but not limited to, storm sewers, conduits, sidewalks,
paving, drainage inlets, alleys, drainage easements, natural and manmade
channels, pipes, culverts and detention ponds whether public or private.
   STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: The overall strategy and framework for the
stormwater management activities of the city.
   STORMWATER RUNOFF: That portion of the rainfall that is drained into the
stormwater drainage system.
   STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE: The fee levied within the boundaries of
the city for the use of the city's stormwater drainage facilities.
   SUBDIVISION: Land that is separated into tracts, parcels or lots.
   TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOAD ALLOCATION OR TMDL: A document established and
adopted through the rule making procedures of the Oklahoma department of
environmental quality pursuant to section 303(d) of the CWA.
   TRACT: A lot, or parcel of land. Properties that are not abutting or
adjoining or are separated by any street, alley or other property shall be
considered separate tracts.
   UNDEVELOPED REAL ESTATE (UNDEVELOPED PROPERTY): Real estate unaltered by the
construction or addition of any impervious surface which would change the
hydrology of the property from its natural state.
   USER: The owner, renter or lessee of a tract of land that drains stormwater
to the stormwater drainage system. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-3: DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR:
   A.   The director shall exercise all lawful powers necessary and appropriate
to administer the city of Ponca City's stormwater management program. The
director shall have the authority to:
      1.   Develop and administer all phases of a comprehensive program of
stormwater management including planning, mapping, designing, establishing,
acquiring, constructing, developing, installing, administering, maintaining,
operating, improving, repairing, replacing and reconstructing the stormwater
drainage system of the city;
      2.   Administer the recordkeeping and support personnel necessary for the
efficient operation of the stormwater management program;
      3.   Administer the regulations contained in this article;
      4.   Perform studies and analyses required to establish or modify the
stormwater management program;
      5.   Provide for public information and awareness that will improve
management and reduce hazards to life and property;
      6.   Coordinate enforcement of regulations contained in this article with
other city departments; and
      7.   Seek the cooperation of counties and municipalities within the area
in minimizing the contribution of all storm drainage systems to flooding and,
in particular, cooperate with other affected political jurisdictions in
preparing and implementing master drainage plans. (Ord. 5985, 6-30-2003)
9-8C-4: STORMWATER DRAINAGE FUND:
   A.   A separate fund shall be maintained for the purpose of identifying and
controlling all revenues to stormwater drainage services. The costs of
administering, data collection, planning, maintaining, operating, and improving
drainage services and facilities shall be made from these revenues. (Ord. 5985,
6-30-2003)
9-8C-5: MASTER DRAINAGE PLAN:
   A.   The documents together titled the "Ponca City Stormwater Master Plan
2009", and any amendments thereto, are adopted as the city's master drainage
plan and made a part hereof as if fully set out herein. A full and complete
copy of the plan shall be maintained in the community development department or
any successor department charged with implementing and enforcing the terms of
the plan. Said plan shall be available for inspection by requesting parties.
   B.   The "Ponca City Stormwater Master Plan 2009" shall serve and otherwise
be referenced as the master drainage plan for the city. The plan is based on
engineering studies that indicate the location of all drainage facilities in
the city, including those facilities that currently exist and those determined
to be needed and that are intended to be constructed in the future. The plan
also includes floodplain mapping. (Ord. 6106, 9-28-2009)
9-8C-6: STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE:
There is hereby established a stormwater utility service charge for the City's
stormwater drainage system at rates hereinafter established; provided, however,
that the service charge shall not be imposed on the following types of
property:
   A.   City streets, rights-of-way, parks and City owned property;
   B.   State of Oklahoma highway rights-of-way;
   C.   Railroad rights-of-way;
   D.   Undeveloped land. (Ord. 5985, 6-30-2003)
9-8C-7: COLLECTION OF UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE:
   A.   The stormwater utility service charges herein established for the use
of the City's stormwater drainage system shall be billed to each user monthly,
along with a bill for electric, water or other utility services and such
penalties as are now or may hereafter be established for other utility service
bills. In the event any person's, firm's or corporation's utility account
becomes delinquent or he/she/it/they shall tender as payment for water service,
sewer service, collection of solid waste service and/or stormwater utility
service charge for the use of the City's systems an amount insufficient to pay
in full all the charges so billed, the payment shall be credited to the account
or accounts in accordance with accounting procedures used by the Customer
Service Department for utility bill payments. The City shall have the right and
privilege of discontinuing any and all utility service to any premises for
insufficient payment. Said services or any of them shall remain terminated
until all delinquent charges for utilities shall have been paid in full.
The provisions for collection provided herein shall be in addition to any
rights or remedies which the City may have under the laws of the State of
Oklahoma.
   B.   The invalidity of any provision, clause or portion of this section or
the invalidity of the application thereof to any person or circumstance shall
not affect the validity of the remainder of this section or the validity of its
application to other persons or circumstances. (Ord. 5985, 6-30-2003)
9-8C-8: STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE RATES:
   A.   The rates and charges for the stormwater management utility shall be as
follows:
      1.   Rate for each active residential account $4.75 per month.
      2.   Rate for each active commercial account $7.75 per month.
   B.   These rates shall be evaluated annually. (Ord. 5985, 6-30-2003; amd.
Ord. 6255, 5-14-2018; Ord. 6290, 5-24-2021; Ord. 6306, 5-23-2022; Ord. 6322, 5-
22-2023; Ord. 6346, 5-28-2024; Ord. 6358, 5-27-2025)
9-8C-9: LAND DISTURBING ACTIVITY REGULATED:
   A.   It shall be a violation of this article for any person to conduct or to
allow another to conduct any land disturbing activity without a permit issued
under this article. The term "land disturbing activity" shall not include:
      1.   Minor land disturbing activities such as home or community gardens,
individual landscaping on an individual lot or tract, repairs, maintenance
work, or other minor erosion control, provided that no more than one-half (1/2)
acre is disturbed;
      2.   Construction or repair of structures not requiring a building
permit, if less than one-half (1/2) acre will be disturbed;
      3.   Construction of individual utility service connections where less
than one-half (1/2) acre is disturbed;
      4.   Agricultural practices involving the establishment, cultivation, or
harvesting of products of the field or orchard, preparing and planting
pastureland, forestry land management practices, including harvesting, dairy
operations, livestock and poultry management practices, and the construction of
farm buildings which do not require a building permit;
      5.   Any project carried out under the direct supervision of the:
         a.   Natural resources conservation service of the U.S. department of
agriculture;
         b.   U.S. army corps of engineers of the U.S. army;
         c.   Oklahoma department of transportation;
      6.   Work undertaken by the bureau of Indian affairs of the U.S.
department of the interior;
      7.   Maintenance, repair, and operation of at grade or below grade
facilities that will not involve disturbance of more than one- half (1/2) acre
of land;
      8.   Construction activities regulated under an OPDES permit regulating
the discharge of stormwater from a construction site; and
      9.   Activities regulated under a 404 permit. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-10: LAND DISTURBANCE PERMIT, APPLICATION:
   A.   The terms and conditions required of a land disturbance permit shall
include an application prepared by the applicant and any other conditions
deemed necessary to implement the provisions contained in this article. If the
land disturbance activity proposed is in conjunction with a building
construction or demolition permit, then a separate land disturbance permit and
application shall not be required. The application for a land disturbance
permit shall include as a minimum the following items:
      1.   Name, address, telephone number and e-mail address of the applicant;
      2.   Name, address, telephone number and e-mail address for the preparer
of the stormwater pollution prevention plan or erosion/sediment control plan,
if different from the applicant;
      3.   Name, address, and telephone number and e-mail address for the
individual responsible for implementing and maintaining the erosion/sediment
control or stormwater pollution prevention control best management practices,
if different from the applicant;
      4.   Legal description and address of the site;
      5.   Estimated disturbed area;
      6.   A sketch identifying the location and extent of best management
practices to be employed on the site;
      7.   Details describing the best management practices;
      8.   A schedule indicating the estimated time of final completion
including final cover to prevent erosion from the developed site;
      9.   Signature of the applicant. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-11: CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES:
All construction activity, regardless of size or scale, shall be conducted
within the city in accordance with the provisions below.
   A.   Stripping of vegetation, regrading and other development activities
shall be conducted so as to minimize erosion. Clearing and grubbing must be
held to the minimum necessary for grading and equipment operation.
Preconstruction vegetative ground cover shall not be destroyed, removed or
disturbed more than twenty (20) calendar days prior to grading or earthmoving.
Construction must be sequenced to minimize the exposure time of cleared surface
area.
   B.   Property owners and/or developers shall be responsible, upon completion
of land disturbing activities, for leaving slopes so that they will not erode.
Such methods should include revegetation, sodding, mulching, or riprapping.
Regardless of the method used, the objective will be to leave the site erosion
free and maintenance free as practicable.
   C.   Whenever feasible, natural vegetation, including mature trees, shall be
retained, protected, and supplemented.
   D.   Permanent soil stabilization with perennial vegetation shall be applied
as soon as practicable after final grading is reached on any portion of the
site. Soil stabilization refers to measures which protect soil from the erosive
forces of wind, raindrop impact, and flowing water, and includes the growing of
grass, sod, application of straw, mulch, fabric mats, and the early application
of gravel base on areas to be paved.
   E.   A permanent vegetative cover shall be established on disturbed areas
not otherwise permanently stabilized.
   F.   To the extent necessary, sediment in runoff water must be trapped by
the use of debris basins, sediment basins, silt traps, silt fences, check dams
or similar measures until the disturbed area is stabilized.
   G.   Neighboring persons and property shall be protected from damage or loss
resulting from excessive stormwater runoff, soil erosion or deposition upon
property or public streets of water transported silt and debris.
   H.   Controlled construction entrance/exits shall be maintained in a
condition that will prevent tracking or flowing of sediment onto the public
right of way.
   I.   Erosion and sediment control measures must be in place and functional
before earthmoving operations begin, and must be constructed and maintained
throughout the construction period. Temporary measures may be removed at the
beginning of the workday, but must be replaced at the end of the workday.
   J.   Structural controls shall be designed and maintained as required to
prevent pollution. All surface water flowing toward the construction area
shall, to the extent practicable, be diverted by using berms, channels, or
sediment traps as necessary. Erosion and sediment control measures shall be
designed according to the size and slope of disturbed/drainage areas, to detain
runoff and trap sediment. Discharges from sediment basins and traps shall be
through a pipe or lined channel so that the discharge does not cause erosion.
Where considered practical by the city, discharges to the drainageway shall be
aligned to be as close as possible to the direction of flow in the drainageway.
Muddy water to be pumped from excavation and work areas shall be held in
settling basins or treated by filtration prior to its discharge into surface
waters where practicable. Waters shall be discharged through a pipe or lined
channel so that the discharge does not cause erosion and sedimentation. All
channels, outlets, storm sewer inlets, streets, creeks, and streams shall be
protected from the introduction of garbage, rubbish, yard waste, sediment, or
floatable materials.
   K.   All control measures shall be inspected, and repaired as necessary,
biweekly in dry periods and within twenty four (24) hours after any rainfall of
0.5 inches or more. During prolonged rainfall, daily inspections and repairing
shall be necessary. The permittee shall maintain record of such inspections and
repairs of:
      1.   Any land disturbing activity located in the watershed of any creek
or stream that is listed as impaired by the ODEQ shall be inspected, and
repaired as necessary, on a weekly basis in dry periods and within twenty four
(24) hours after any rainfall of 0.5 inches or more within a twenty four (24)
hour period. During prolonged rainfall, daily inspections and repairing shall
be necessary. The permittee shall maintain record of such inspections and
repairs.
   L.   A specific individual shall be designated to be responsible for erosion
and sediment controls on each site. A notice shall be posted on each site with
the OKR10 permit number (if applicable), contact name and telephone number,
project name and location of the SWP3 if not on site.
   M.   There shall be no distinctly visible floating scum, oil or other matter
contained in the stormwater discharge. The stormwater discharge shall not cause
an objectionable color contrast in the receiving water. The stormwater
discharge shall result in no materials in concentrations sufficient to be
hazardous or otherwise detrimental to humans, livestock, wildlife, plant life,
or fish and aquatic life in the receiving stream.
   N.   Concrete washout areas must be designated, utilized, and maintained to
minimize pollutant discharge.
   O.   When the land disturbing activity is finished and stable and perennial
vegetation has been established on all remaining exposed soil, the permittee
shall notify the city in writing of these facts and submit a notice of
termination (NOT) of the permit issued under this section. The city shall then
conduct a final inspection of the site and, when advisable, may require
additional measures to stabilize the soil and prevent erosion. If such
requirements are given by letter, the permittee shall continue to be covered by
this provision of this section, until a request for termination of the permit
has been accepted by the director.
   P.   No person shall place, spill or allow the flow of concrete or similar
construction materials on any public road, alley, highway or sidewalk, except
as may be required for the construction or the maintenance of the public road,
street, highway or sidewalk.
   Q.   Construction or demolition debris shall not be allowed to blow off the
site of origin.
   R.   Trash containers of sufficient size shall be located on each
construction site no later than the time the rough plumbing is ready for
inspection. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-12: POSTCONSTRUCTION BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES:
This section shall apply to properties for which an OPDES permit for stormwater
discharge from a construction site, or land disturbance permit has been issued.
Postconstruction best management practices are considered adequate when the
following conditions are met:
   A.   Compliance has been achieved of the final erosion control measures
described in the OPDES permit and a notice of termination has been submitted to
the Oklahoma department of environmental quality; and/or
   B.   Compliance has been achieved of the final erosion control measures
described in the land disturbance permit issued by the city of Ponca City; and
   C.   Permanent best management practices identified on development plans and
building plans approved by the city for subdividing, development, or building
construction have been inspected and approved by the city; and
   D.   The site has been finally stabilized (i.e., a uniform perennial
vegetative cover with a density of at least 70 percent of the native background
cover has been established for all unpaved areas and areas not covered by
permanent structures or where equivalent permanent stabilization measures such
as riprap or gabions have been used), and all stormwater discharges from
construction activities that are authorized by an OPDES permit or land
disturbance permit are eliminated and a notice of termination has been
submitted. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-13: ILLICIT DISCHARGES AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   The city shall take appropriate steps to detect and eliminate illicit
connections to the city stormwater system (MS4), including the adoption of a
program to screen illicit discharges and identify their source or sources.
   B.   The city shall take appropriate steps to detect and eliminate improper
discharges, including programs to screen for improper disposal and programs to
provide for public education, public information and other appropriate
activities to facilitate the proper management and disposal of used oil, toxic
materials, and hazardous household waste.
   C.   No person shall conduct, allow or permit the discharge of stormwater in
any manner in violation of this article or of any condition of a permit issued
pursuant to this article or a stormwater discharge permit issued by the state.
Such discharge is a violation of this article and shall be immediately
corrected or abated by any owner and by any operator.
   D.   No person shall conduct, allow or permit the direct or indirect
discharge of any material other than stormwater into the MS4, or waters of the
state or U.S. The following direct or indirect discharges are examples of
prohibited discharges:
      1.   Sewage dumping or dumping of sewage sludge;
      2.   Chlorinated swimming pool discharge;
      3.   Backwash wastewater from swimming pool filters;
      4.   Discharge of any polluted household wastewater, such as, but not
limited to, laundry wash water and dishwater, except to a sanitary sewer or
septic system;
      5.   Leaking sanitary sewers and connections;
      6.   Leaking water lines;
      7.   Commercial, industrial or nonexempt public vehicle wash or power
wash discharge, commercial, industrial or nonexempt cosmetic cleaning;
      8.   Garbage, rubbish, or sanitary waste disposal;
      9.   Dead animals or animal fecal waste;
      10.   Nonstormwater discharges, except pursuant to a permit issued by the
state or city, or otherwise allowed by this article;
      11.   Dredged or spoil material;
      12.   Solid waste and commercial or industrial process byproducts;
      13.   Chemical waste;
      14.   Wrecked or discarded vehicles, appliances or equipment;
      15.   Motor vehicle or stationary motor fluids; and
      16.   Construction and/or demolition debris. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-14: SPILLS AND ACCIDENTAL DISCHARGES:
   A.   Spills that have the potential to enter or have entered the city's MS4
shall be contained, and remediation activity shall be commenced, as soon as
possible. In case of vehicle accident, all spillage shall be properly contained
and cleaned and stored with accident vehicle. Any person identified as the
source of any spill into the city's MS4 shall be required to remediate, remove
and properly dispose of spilled materials. Remediation activities shall only be
considered complete when the cleanup is deemed satisfactory by the appropriate
city, state, or federal agency overseeing the spill. The required reporting or
notification for such spills shall be completed as specified under state and
federal law with copies provided to the city.
   B.   In the event a discharge occurs of any discharge or a hazardous
substance in amounts which could cause a threat to public drinking supplies, a
"significant spill", or any other discharge which could constitute a threat to
human health or the environment, the owner or operator of the facility shall
give notice to the director and the field office of the Oklahoma department of
environmental quality as soon as practicable, but in no event later than the
close of business on the day following the accidental discharge or the
discharger becomes aware of the circumstances. If an emergency response by
governmental agencies is needed, the owner or operator shall also call 911
immediately to report the discharge. A written report shall be provided within
five (5) days of the time the discharger becomes aware of the circumstances,
unless this requirement is waived by the director for good cause shown on a
case by case basis, containing the following particulars:
      1.   A reasonably precise description of the discharge;
      2.   The exact date and time of discharge; and
      3.   Steps being taken to eliminate and prevent recurrence of the
discharge.
   C.   The owner and operator shall take all reasonable steps to minimize any
adverse impact to the waters of the state or U.S., including such accelerated
or additional monitoring as necessary to determine the nature and impact of the
discharge. It shall not be a defense for the discharger in an enforcement
action that it would have been necessary to halt or reduce the business or
activity of the facility in order to maintain water quality and minimize any
adverse impact that the discharge may cause. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-15: GOOD HOUSEKEEPING:
   A.   With respect to the city's compliance with environmental laws, the
director and/or the director's authorized representatives may do the following:
      1.   Carry out all inspections, surveillance, enforcement, and monitoring
procedures necessary to determine compliance; administer the city's compliance
with its OPDES MS4 permit to discharge from the municipal separate storm sewer
system;
      2.   Inspect city properties for the presence of hazardous substances,
and develop and administer whatever remediation programs are required;
      3.   Audit city departments to determine whether the city is in
compliance with federal and state clean water act laws; whether the city has
obtained all permits required by federal and state environmental laws; and
whether the city is in compliance with the permits it has;
      4.   Audit use of herbicides, fertilizers, and pesticides at city
facilities to determine compliance with clean water act laws and to recommend
alternative solutions where practicable for the reduction of their use through
education and outreach programs;
      5.   Control the discharge of spills and the dumping or disposal of
materials other than stormwater (e.g., commercial waste, trash, motor vehicle
fluids, leaf litter, grass clippings, animal waste, etc.) into the MS4;
      6.   Monitor the city's compliance with all federal, state, and local
laws; including:
         a.   Administering the city's compliance with state and federal laws
relating to discharge from the wastewater treatment plant, landfill, Ponca City
energy, airport and city garage;
         b.   Monitor and coordinate with other city departments on the city's
response to releases of hazardous substances;
         c.   Monitor the use of city rights of way, property, and easements by
persons with use agreements for environmental monitoring;
         d.   Establish and supervise a program for the collection of hazardous
household waste;
         e.   Create, promote, and publicize educational programs for
environmental awareness; and
         f.   Provide quantitative data through field screening programs. (Ord.
6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-16: COMPLIANCE MONITORING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Stormwater Sampling Event Criteria: When the director requires that a
sample of a storm event be obtained, the following criteria must be met:
      1.   The depth of the rainfall must be greater than one-tenth inch (0.1")
or its equivalent;
      2.   The sample storm event must be preceded by at least seventy two (72)
hours of less than one-tenth inch (0.1") of rainfall; and
      3.   All point sources from the premises or industry required to sample
must be sampled, unless otherwise specified.
   B.   Sampling: When the director has reason to believe that any person or
industrial facility is violating this article, the person or industrial
facility may be required to obtain either a grab or composite sample and
analyze any discharge, stormwater, groundwater and/or sediment and provide a
copy of the analysis to the director for review.
   C.   Illicit Discharge Sampling: When the director has cause to believe that
any discharge is an illicit discharge, the director may obtain either a grab or
composite sample and analyze the discharge. If the director determines that the
discharge is an illicit discharge, then the director may fully recover all cost
of the sampling and analysis from the person or industrial facility. When the
discharge is likely to contain illicit discharges on a recurring basis, the
person or industrial facility may be required by the director to conduct
monitoring activities at its expense.
   D.   Chain Of Custody: Upon completion of sample collections and
documentation, a written record of the chain of custody must be completed. The
chain of custody record is an accurate step by step documentation of the
sampling path from origin through analysis. It must contain the following
information:
      1.   Name of the person(s) collecting the sample;
      2.   Sample ID numbers;
      3.   Date and time of sample collection;
      4.   Location of sample collection;
      5.   Name(s) and signature(s) of all persons handling the sample in the
field and in the laboratory;
      6.   Type of sampling equipment used;
      7.   Type of preservation; and
      8.   Certification of sample authenticity.
A copy of the chain of custody will remain with all sample analyses sent to the
city of Ponca City for review.
   E.   Substitution Of Substantially Identical Effluents: When a person or
industry is required to sample a storm event and that person or industry has
two (2) or more point sources with substantially identical effluents, the
person or industry may petition the director to allow the sampling of only one
point source and report that the data applies to the substantially identical
point source(s).
   F.   Monitoring Methods: Monitoring must be conducted according to test
procedures approved under 40 CFR part 136, unless other test procedures have
been specified by the director. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-17: WATERCOURSE PROTECTION:
Every person owning property through which a watercourse passes, or such
person's lessee, shall keep and maintain that part of the watercourse within
the property free of trash, debris, excessive vegetation and other obstacles
that would pollute, contaminate or significantly retard the flow of water
through the watercourse. In addition, the owner or lessee shall maintain
existing privately owned structures within or adjacent to a watercourse, so
that such structures will not become a hazard to the use, function or physical
integrity of the watercourse. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-18: ALLOWABLE STORMWATER DISCHARGES TO THE DRAINAGEWAY:
   A.   The discharges authorized below are to the drainageway only and not
authorized to discharge to the sanitary sewage collection system or to waters
of the state. It is allowable to discharge the following to the drainageways of
the city:
      1.   Raw drinking water supply and potable water from water line
flushing.
      2.   Diverted stream flows.
      3.   Rising groundwaters.
      4.   Residential building wash water without detergents.
      5.   Uncontaminated pumped groundwater (contaminated groundwater pumped
from a brownfield's site within the city is not an allowable discharge).
      6.   Uncontaminated groundwater infiltration.
      7.   Discharges from potable water sources.
      8.   Foundation drains.
      9.   Air conditioning condensate.
      10.   Irrigation water.
      11.   Springs.
      12.   Water from crawl space pumps.
      13.   Footing drains.
      14.   Lawn watering.
      15.   Individual residential car washing.
      16.   Dechlorinated swimming pool discharges.
      17.   Street and parking lot wash water, provided that no pollutants or
floatables are discharged into the city's storm sewer.
      18.   Fire hydrant flushings and water from flow testing fire hydrants
(excluding chlorinated water main disinfection waters).
      19.   Noncommercial or charity car washes.
      20.   Discharges from riparian areas or wetlands.
      21.   Discharges in compliance with an OPDES permit, which has been
issued and is in effect.
      22.   Dredging and filling operations in compliance with a 404 permit,
which has been issued and is in effect.
      23.   Discharges in compliance with the requirements of a land
disturbance permit.
      24.   Application of agricultural chemicals in a manner consistent with
labeling of the chemical product and at an amount not greater than ten percent
(10%) above agronomic rates.
      25.   Discharges or flows from emergency firefighting activities provided
procedures are in place for the incident commander, fire chief, or other on
scene firefighting official in charge to make an evaluation regarding potential
releases from the scene. Measures must be taken to reduce any such pollutant
releases to the maximum extent practicable subject to all appropriate actions
necessary to ensure public health and safety.
      26.   Discharges from property with adequate postconstruction best
management practices in place and properly operated for which an OPDES
stormwater discharge permit was issued during construction, or which a land
disturbance permit was issued. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-19: PROHIBITED STORMWATER DISCHARGES:
   A.   It shall be violation of this article to discharge or allow the
discharge of any of the following into the city's MS4:
      1.   All nonstormwater and stormwater to the MS4 that is not allowable as
determined by this article;
      2.   Stormwater from any activity required to obtain an "OPDES stormwater
discharge permit" that has not been authorized a current effective OPDES permit
or not in compliance with the requirements of the permit;
      3.   Dredge and filling activities required to obtain a "404 permit" that
has not been authorized by a current effective 404 permit or not in compliance
with a 404 permit;
      4.   Any spilled pollutants, unless it can be demonstrated that failure
to allow the discharge will result in a greater imminent peril or hazard to the
life, health, welfare, or safety of the public;
      5.   Any material that is disposed of or dumped in such a manner that
causes pollutants to be discharged;
      6.   The discharge of sewage, industrial wastes, or other wastes into a
well or a location where it is likely that the discharged substance will move
into a well, or the underground placement of fluids and other substance which
do or may affect the waters of the state or U.S.;
      7.   Water main disinfection water that has not been dechlorinated.
   B.   To place, store or locate any material in such a manner that causes
pollutants to be transported by wind, rain or other atmospheric conditions into
the city's MS4.
   C.   Any point source discharge into the city's MS4 that either singly or in
conjunction with other discharges causes the city to violate its OPDES
municipal stormwater discharge permit shall be prohibited.
   D.   To dispose of grass, dirt, leaves, sticks, limbs, trash, construction
or demolition debris, or other pollutants into the city's MS4.
   E.   Allow an animal to defecate (without the owner, keeper or harborer
removing the excreta deposited) on public or private property other than that
of the owner.
   F.   To deposit, drain or divert, whether directly or through an agent, into
or upon any public highway, street, sidewalk, alley, parking lot, paving,
drainage ditch, storm drain, sewer, gutter, creek, stream, river, lake, pond or
lagoon, any oil or oily liquid with petroleum content, grease, drilling mud,
rotary mud, sand, saltwater, sewer waste or industrial waste; or in any manner
permit by seepage, overflow or otherwise, any of such substances to escape from
any property owned, leased or controlled by such person nor shall any person
allow such substances to flow or be carried onto or upon any public highway,
street, sidewalk, alley, parking lot, paving, drainage ditch, storm drain,
sewer, gutter, creek, stream, river, lake, pond or lagoon within the city.
   G.   Concrete tailings.
   H.   Discharges required by the 2009 (or more recent code upon adoption)
international plumbing code are to be discharged to sanitary sewer instead of
the storm sewer.
   I.   Commencement of activities that result in or could result in a
discharge to the drainageway prior to establishing or implementing best
management practices. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-20: RECORDKEEPING BY THE RESPONSIBLE PARTY:
   A.   Records Maintenance, Retention: Every responsible party shall retain
and make available to the director or his designee for inspection and copying,
all records and information required to be retained under this article, or
order issued hereunder. The responsible party shall retain these records for a
period of no less than five (5) years after an initial request by the director.
This retention period shall be automatically extended for the duration of any
litigation concerning compliance with this article, or where the responsible
party has been specifically notified of a longer retention period by the
director.
   B.   Fraud And False Statements: Reports and other documents required to be
submitted or maintained under this article, or order issued hereunder, shall be
subject to the provisions of 18 USC section 1001, regarding fraud or false
statements and the provisions of section 309c(4) of the act, as amended,
governing false statements, representations, or certification.
   C.   Timely Manner: The requested documents shall be supplied to the city at
no charge and in a timely manner. In nonemergency situations, a reasonable
period of time for submitting said requested documents shall be not greater
than seven (7) consecutive calendar days. In emergency situations a reasonable
period shall be as soon as possible and not longer than twenty four (24) hours.
(Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-21: ACCESS FOR INSPECTION AND SAMPLING:
   A.   Representatives of the city or their duly authorized agent bearing
credentials and identification shall have the right to enter the premises of
any discharger to the drainageway to determine whether the discharger is
complying with all requirements of this article.
Dischargers shall allow ready access to all parts of the premises for the
purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination and copying, and the
performance of any additional duties.
   B.   Property owners and tenants shall provide access to their property to
allow person(s) performing inspections of the drainageways of the city of Ponca
City and areas of special flood hazard, or performing water quality sampling
and on site testing to representatives after presentation of credentials that
they are an authorized representative of the city.
   C.   The individuals authorized above are not subject to penalty provisions
involving trespassing and persons denying reasonable access in a timely manner
are subject to the appropriate penalties indicated in section
9-8C-23, "Penalties", of this article. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-22: RECOVERY OF COSTS:
   A.   Testing required by the permittee under an OPDES permit or 404 permit
are borne entirely by the permittee and not the city of Ponca City. However,
there may be additional costs and expenses incurred by the city for the reasons
stated below that the responsible party shall reimburse the city for:
      1.   Sampling and testing performed by the city of a discharge or
potential discharge to have a greater level of assurance that the discharge is
compliant with this article;
      2.   Sampling and testing if there is a reasonable expectation that
noncompliance with this article may be occurring;
      3.   Sampling and testing if the stormwater pollution prevention measures
have not been installed as described in a plan or operated as described in a
plan or as any other prudent discharger using that best management practice
considers prudent;
      4.   Sampling and testing if a violation has occurred or could occur with
an OPDES permit issued to the city of Ponca City needing the identification of
the source of the discharge causing the noncompliance (occurring or possible);
      5.   Sampling and testing if there is a difference between the
description of the activity from the plans or permit application and the
activities on the site;
      6.   Sampling and testing if there is an unknown or nonreported substance
that could discharge to the drainageway;
      7.   Sampling and testing required by an OPDES permit issued to the city
of Ponca City.
   B.   In addition to testing costs, there are also noncompliance events with
this article such as spills and accidental discharges and other emergency
response actions needed to be taken urgently to promote and protect health,
safety, and the environment in which immediate mitigating actions must be taken
by the city that the responsible party shall reimburse the city for such costs,
including:
      1.   Efforts to contain the potential pollutant;
      2.   Efforts to render the potential pollutant less dangerous or
hazardous;
      3.   Efforts to isolate the public from the hazard area;
      4.   Removing the pollutant or hazard;
      5.   Storage of the contaminated substances;
      6.   Cleanup of the contaminated area;
      7.   Ultimate disposal of the pollutant or contaminated substances.
The emergency response efforts listed above are not a normal service provided
by the city and not services the city will provide except in emergency
conditions and in addition to any penalties that may be pursued as provided
below. (Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
9-8C-23: PENALTIES:
   A.   Penalties Specified: The penalties shown below may be pursued
individually or in combination with any other penalty specified below:
      1.   Violation Of This Article: Any person who shall violate any of the
provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished up to
and including the maximum statutory limit of the municipal court. Each day of
violation shall constitute a separate offense. In the case of a monthly or
other long term limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of
violation.
      2.   Petition For Injunctive Relief: When the city finds that the
provisions of this article have been violated then the city may petition the
state district court of competent jurisdiction through the city attorney for
the issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which
restrains or compels the specific performance to achieve compliance with this
article. The city may also seek other action as is appropriate for legal and/or
equitable relief, including a requirement for the responsible person to conduct
environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar
against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the discharger.
      3.   False Statements Or Misrepresentation Of The Facts: Any person who
shall make a false statement or misrepresent the facts on any application,
report, correspondence, or other information provided to the city shall, upon
conviction, be punished up to and including the statutory limit of the
municipal court.
   B.   Fees In Addition To Fines: In addition to the fines provided herein,
the city may recover reasonable attorney fees, court costs, and court reporter
fees, other expenses associated with the enforcement activities, recovery of
costs under section
9-8C-22 of this article, and the cost of actual damages incurred by the city.
(Ord. 6159, 6-25-2012)
ARTICLE D. BROADBAND INTERNET SERVICES
SECTION:
9-8D-1: Undertaking And Scope
9-8D-2: Broadband Rates
9-8D-1: UNDERTAKING AND SCOPE:
The Ponca City Utility Authority shall undertake to provide broadband
connectivity to Ponca City and its environs. (Ord. 6027, 8-29-2005)
9-8D-2: BROADBAND RATES:
The following broadband internet service levels and rates are hereby
established:
   A.   Non-Commercial: The following rate schedule is applicable to any
customer requiring regular, ultra high speed access to the internet using
dynamic IP addresses, non-symmetrical bandwidth, where the service is used for
entertainment (or non-critical) purposes only, and/or where service outages
will be addressed during normal business hours. These rates are applicable
throughout the territory served by the Ponca City broadband:
      1.   Monthly Service Levels For Non-Commercial Customers Residing Inside
The City Limits: All non-commercial customers within the City limits shall pay
a set monthly fee for broadband internet service based upon service maximum
download bandwidths. This bandwidth is capped based on that service, except
during interruptions in service.
         a.   Gold Broadband: One hundred (100) Mbps download (fifty (50) Mbps
upload), sixty dollars ($60.00) per month.
         b.   Platinum Broadband: Three hundred (300) Mbps download (one
hundred fifty (150) Mbps upload), one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month.
         c.   Diamond Broadband: One thousand (1,000) Mbps download (five
hundred (500) Mbps upload), two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month.
      2.   Monthly Service Levels For Non-Commercial Customers Residing Outside
The City Limits: All non-commercial customers outside the city limits shall pay
a set monthly fee for broadband internet service based upon service maximum
download bandwidths. The bandwidth is capped based on that service, except
during interruptions in service.
         a.   Gold Broadband (Rural): One hundred (100) Mbps download (fifty
(50) Mbps upload), sixty-three dollars ($63.00) per month.
         b.   Platinum Broadband (Rural): Three hundred (300) Mbps download
(one hundred fifty (150) Mbps upload), one hundred five dollars ($105.00) per
month.
         c.   Diamond Broadband (Rural): One thousand (1000) Mbps download
(five hundred (500) Mbps upload), two hundred sixty-two dollars and fifty cents
($262.50) per month.
      3.   Activation Fees For Non-Commercial Customers: All non-commercial
customers shall pay anon-refundable two hundred dollars ($200.00) activation
fee at the time of signing up for service. This may either be paid in full or
over a period of twenty four (24) months for an additional forty dollar
($40.00) service fee. These periodic payments will be added to the non-
commercial customer's billing statements for a period of twenty four (24)
months at ten dollars ($10.00) per month. Activation fees must be paid in full
before an additional subsequent account can be activated by that individual.
      4.   Non-Commercial Classification: Non-commercial customers are those
customers who use their internet service for non-essential purposes,
entertainment in nature. Non-commercial internet access has no warranty, either
expressed or implied, as to fitness for any particular purpose and carries no
reimbursement for loss of use, including lost revenue. Non-commercial internet
access is restricted to the address of the customer obtaining service and
cannot be shared anywhere outside of that property. Customers requiring
essential services that allow them to conduct business (e.g. static IP
addresses, symmetrical upload/download speeds, multi-site access, and/or
immediate trouble resolution) must convert to commercial service where such
amenities are offered.
   B.   Commercial: The following rate schedule is applicable to any commercial
customer, including any building to which service is connected which is being
used primarily for business purposes. These rates are based upon pre-fiber
installation. Business rates are charged in "units of service". Commercial
Broadband service requires a two (2) year contract.
      1.   Rates For Each Unit Of Service: Each unit of service includes a
single public static IP address for business use, and includes speeds of one
hundred (100) Mbps guaranteed minimum symmetrical (upload and download)
bandwidth. This rate is two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month. Units of
service may be added, as needed, for an additional two hundred dollars
($200.00) per month.
      2.   Additional IP Addresses: Each additional public IP addresses is an
additional ten dollars ($10.00) per month, per IP address required to meet the
customer's need.
      3.   Amenities: Commercial service includes many amenities not included
in non-commercial service, which includes:
         a.   No activation fee;
         b.   Static IP address(es);
         c.   Ability to share the connection at multiple locations operated by
the business, as long the business installs their own local area network;
         d.   Service Level Agreement (SLA) that guarantees immediate repair
and/or replacement of any failed system components; and
         e.   Sharing of bandwidth between multiple devices within the
business.
(Ord. 6261, 10-22-2018, eff. 1-1-2019; amd. Ord 6274, 12-9-2019; Ord. 6280, 7-
13-2020; Ord. 6297, 6-14-2021; Ord. 6339, 4-8-2024)
CHAPTER 9
AIRPORT REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-9-1: Fuel Flowage Fee
9-9-1: FUEL FLOWAGE FEE:
   A.   Fee Imposed:
      1.   There is hereby imposed a fuel flowage fee, in such amount as
established by resolution of the board of commissioners from time to time, per
gallon on all aviation fuels dispensed on the Ponca City municipal airport.
      2.   Any individual or corporation dispensing aviation fuel on the Ponca
City municipal airport shall charge and collect such fee per gallon on all
aviation fuels dispensed in any aircraft or for use in any aircraft at said
Ponca City municipal airport and shall remit the same on or before the first
day of each month to the finance director. Said sum shall be due on the first
day of each month following the month in which the fuel was dispensed but shall
become delinquent on the fifteenth day of the following month in which the fuel
was dispensed.
   B.   Penalty: Any person, firm, or corporation who violates, neglects, or
refuses to comply with the provisions of this section or refuses to comply with
the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. Failure to pay each month as due shall
constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 4-1; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 10
ADVERTISING; HANDBILLS
SECTION:
9-10-1: Posting Generally
9-10-2: Destroying Lawful Posters
9-10-3: Marking On Streets, Sidewalks Prohibited
9-10-4: Sound Vehicles Restricted
9-10-5: Distribution Of Handbills
9-10-1: POSTING GENERALLY:
No person shall post any bills, signs, posters or advertisements on any
buildings, fences, poles or other property belonging to another without the
consent of the owner thereof. Such consent shall be secured in writing, and
such written consent shall be exhibited by the person having the same to any
police officer on demand. (1980 Code § 3-1)
9-10-2: DESTROYING LAWFUL POSTERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wrongfully and maliciously tear down,
deface or cover up any posted advertisement or bill of any person when the same
is lawfully posted and put up and during the time such sign or advertisement
shall be of value. (1980 Code § 3-4)
9-10-3: MARKING ON STREETS, SIDEWALKS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise, or attempt to advertise, by
marking or painting on any of the streets or sidewalks within the city. (1980
Code § 3-5)
9-10-4: SOUND VEHICLES RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise any goods, wares or
merchandise of any kind by the use of any amplifying equipment used by or
mounted on any vehicle without first having obtained a permit therefor from the
chief of police. (1980 Code § 3-6)
9-10-5: DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
    HANDBILL: Any printed or written matter, any sample, or any device, dodger,
circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise
reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature.
   NEWSPAPER: Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law,
any newspaper duly entered with the post office department of the United
States, in accordance with federal statutes or regulations, and any newspaper
filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and
in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine
regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to
the public, and shall mean and include any other copyrighted material.
   VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon
stationary rails or tracks. (1980 Code § 3-18)
   B.   Exemption For Mail And Newspaper: The provisions of this section shall
not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States postal service, nor
to newspapers, except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in
such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements
upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. (1980
Code § 3-19; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Inhabited Private Premises: No person shall throw, deposit or
